headline: LAWSON & JONES LTD reports earnings for Yr to dEc 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNITED ARTISTS COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A FLAT-SCREEN TELEVISION SET TO FIT IN YOUR BACK POCKET
abstract: Flat-screen, hand-held television sets - talked up in the television industry for years - are finally coming to market, and Japan's Sony Corporation and England's Sinclair Research are now trying to manufacture enough to distribute in the United States in time for Christmas. And the target date is apt: Either set will fit snugly in anyone's Christmas stocking.  Sony's set - christened the Watchman - weighs one pound three ounces, and is one and a quarter inches thick and less than eight inches long. It displays black and white images on a screen that measures two inches diagonally. The Sinclair unit, on the other hand, weighs less than a pound, measures only one inch thick and has a three-inch (diagonal) screen. Both sets will receive VHF and UHF channels.

headline: Tosco Bids Holders Bar Shale Pullout
abstract: In a letter mailed today, the Tosco Corporation asked its stockholders to rebuff an attempt to end its stake in the nation's most advanced shale-oil program.   Isadore M. Scott, chairman, and Morton M. Winston, president and chief executive, charged that Kenneth M. Good, a land developer who controls 8.8 percent of Tosco's shares, wants Tosco to sell its interest in a Colorado shale-oil plant and distribute the proceeds to stockholders ''in order to meet his continuing cash needs.''

headline: Triton Option Sold to Reliance
abstract: The American Financial Corporation, which is controlled by Carl H.  Lindner, a Cincinnati financier, said it had sold an option to buy a 22 percent interest in the Triton Group to the Reliance Group Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Reliance Group Holding Inc.   If the option is exercised, American Financial will receive about $7.5 million in cash.

headline: BROOKLYN REHABILITATION ENTERPRENEURS
abstract: Over cheesecake at Junior's, a Brooklyn restaurant, Daniel Greenbaum and Allen Handelman sealed their real estate partnership in January 1981. They agreed to seek out Brooklyn properties for rehabilitation and resale as cooperatives.   Mr. Greenbaum, now 27 years old, graduated from Boston University's law school two years ago and promptly became a commercial leasing broker in Manhattan. Mr. Handelman, who is 24, studied interior design at the Pratt Institute. His partner describes him as ''a carpenter at heart.''

headline: SANTA FE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for QTr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MORGAN, J P, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Police in West Berlin Arrest 2 Soviet Jews
abstract: Riot policemen stormed an apartment today and arrested a Soviet Jewish emigre and his wife after he had threatened to throw their six-month-old baby from a window unless his demands were met, the police said.

headline: EXXON'S WRITE-OFF ON COLONY
abstract: Stockholders of the Exxon Corporation were told yesterday that, as a result of Exxon's withdrawal early this month from the Colony Shale Oil Project in Colorado, the company expected to take an after-tax write-off of a maximum of $125 million, or about 15 cents a share.  But the company stressed that its involvement with Colony was not over.   ''We put it in mothballs,'' C.C. Garvin Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, said at Exxon's 100th anniversary annual meeting in New York. ''We'll continue to do the necessary research work. It was not a question of shutting it down and forgetting it.''

headline: Broker Merger In Canada Set
abstract: Richardson Securities of Canada said it had agreed to buy the equity interest of Greenshields Inc. and merge it into Richardson.

headline: HUGHES TOOL COMPANY ELECTS A NEW PRESIDENT
abstract: William A. Kistler, 55, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Hughes Tool Company, a leading maker of oil and gas drilling equipment. He succeeds James R. Lesch, 60, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Houston-based corporation.

headline: Pan Am Cuts Fares
abstract: Pan American World Airways today offered $99 one-way fares from several Northeast and Midwest points to Florida in response to fares announced last week by Air Florida.

headline: Salvadorans Home From Fort Bragg
abstract: About one-third of the Salvadoran soldiers sent for 14 weeks' training at Fort Bragg, N.C., returned here today, and military sources said they would be in the field within two weeks.   Declining to give an exact figure, a military spokesman said ''about 320'' troops arrived and another group of the 957 enlisted men sent to the United States was due by the weekend.

headline: KELLOGG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: National Medical Adds Two Units
abstract: National Medical Enterprises Inc., a Los Angeles-based hospital management company, said it had acquired two companies, Professional Pulmonary Services Inc., of Shenandoah, Iowa, and Oxygen Therapy Systems Inc., of New Orleans, for an undisclosed amount.   David J. Lothson, vice president of research at Kidder, Peabody & Company, estimated that the two transactions were valued at less than $10 million.

headline: ETHYL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MILTON ROY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: YIELD FALLS ON 10-YEAR U.S. NOTE
abstract: Despite the prospect of large budget deficits, the United States Treasury sold $4 billion of new 10-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 13.77 percent, down from 13.93 percent in Monday's preauction trading and well below the 14.68 percent yield for similar notes sold in February.   Although note and bond prices have increased and yields have fallen in a week of heavy Treasury financing, many dealers said the outlook for lower interest rates was not as one-sided as recent trading would indicate.   Among the uncertainties facing dealers and investors are the size of future Treasury borrowings, Federal Reserve monetary policy and the impact of the Falkland Islands dispute on large United States banks with loans to Argentina.   ''The market is probably split 50-50 between the bulls and the bears,'' said Edwin Kantor, a senior vice president at Drexel Burnham. ''There is steady underlying demand from investors who want to lock in these yields,'' he said, ''but they are cautious enough to keep some money in reserve so that they can follow the market whichever way it goes.''

headline: CANADA LIFTS KEY BANK RATE
abstract: The Bank of Canada today raised its benchmark bank rate by almost half a point in a further effort to shore up the country's badly deteriorating dollar.   The rate, which had fluctuated only slightly in recent months, was raised to 15.87 percent, the highest level since last November. from 15.43 percent last week. The rate is the one at which the central bank lends to private institutions and is the benchmark for all other interest rates.

headline: Norwich Eaton Adds To Lally Account
abstract: The Professional Products Group of Norwich Eaton Pharmaceuticals, a division of Morton Norwich, has consolidated the responsibility for the advertising of its prescription drugs into Lally, McFarland & Pantello, an agency that started in business two years ago with Norwich Eaton as its first client.   With the new business, the total billings from the company now at the agency are about $4.5 million.  The ethical drug products involved in the switch, previously served by Kallir, Philips, Ross, are Macrodantin, Vivonex-HN, Dantrium IV and Duvoid.

headline: Commodities; Proposed Options Criticized
abstract: NOW that stock-index futures have been successfully introduced, the commodity industry is preparing its next wave of new ''products'' - exchange-traded options on futures. Unlike the stock-index futures, which were widely backed by the industry, these options, as they are now proposed, are provoking quiet but fierce opposition from some leaders in the industry.   One of these opponents is George D.F. Lamborn, who supports the concept of exchange-traded options in general. Mr. Lamborn is a cochairman of Refco International Futures Inc., chairman of the clearing association of the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, and a member of other exchanges that plan to introduce exchange-traded commodity options in the next few months.   ''Despite the well-intentioned and costly efforts of exchanges and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the proposed options will not protect the public,'' he said ''Rather, what is inadvertently being designed is a carefully fashioned booby trap for investors, exchange floor traders, brokers and, indeed, the entire commodities industry.''

headline: SYSCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CENTRAL ILLINOIS PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Arab League Plans Parley
abstract: Arab foreign ministers will hold a special meeting here next Tuesday night to examine the situation in Lebanon and prepare a conference on the question, the Arab League said today. The Palestine Liberation Organization had agreed to take part but Lebanon had not yet said it would, sources in the organization said.

headline: Affairs of State In Motor City
abstract: The big talk lately in non-automotive-related Detroit advertising had to do with the future of the Michigan Department of Commerce account. First as the Michigan Tourist Council and then as the Michigan Travel Commission, the account had been served for 21 years by W.B. Doner there.

headline: SAVINGS UNIT HELP EXPECTED
abstract: A special group of Federal regulators is expected to approve on Tuesday a new short-term savings certificate intended to help thrift institutions and commercial banks in competing with money market mutual funds. But some of the intended beneficiaries of the savings certificate doubt that it will help them much.   Industry analysts said that a high-level committee established by Congress to do away with the ceilings on bank interest rates is likely to approve a short-term certificate with a minimum deposit somewhere between $10,000 and $25,000. The committee also would decide whether the interest rate would be tied to a short-term Treasury bill rate or whether institutions would be allowed to determine their own rates without restrictions.

headline: Company News; Schmidt Says Pabst Bid Fails
abstract: C. Schmidt & Sons Inc., the Philadelphia brewery that bid $168 million to acquire the Pabst Brewing Company, said that it had ''reluctantly reached the conclusion'' that there is ''no likelihood'' of the merger taking place.   Pabst said that it had no comment on Schmidt's statement ''at this time.''

headline: Technology; Standards For Pollutants
abstract: WITH Congress considering major changes in both the Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act, a number of business and environmental groups have been offering their views on the costs and benefits attributable to Federal environmental laws and regulations. Pollution control technology is bound to become a major issue in the debate.   In general, industry groups want to water down environmental laws and regulations. Many argue that at least some of the reductions in discharges that the regulations require are not worth the capital and operating costs. Others say that the time limits imposed by the existing laws are impossible to meet. And most of the industry groups say that there are a number of ways to achieve the desired overall improvements more economically; for instance, a company that would have to spend heavily to reduce discharges might locate a neighbor (already in compliance) that could achieve a comparable reduction at far less cost, and pay the neighbor to do it.

headline: India and China End Round of Border Talks
abstract: India and China ended four days of talks today, still sharply divided over a 20-year-old boundary dispute, a spokesman for the Indian Government said.

headline: MILITANTS TRY TO REACH SINAI BY BOAT
abstract: Jewish militants opposing Israel's withdrawal from Sinai tried to reach the area by boat today after the army closed it to unauthorized civilians and set up roadblocks.   Four of five boats that set out from the Tel Aviv marina were intercepted by the Israeli Navy, and one got through, a military spokesman said. It anchored off the beach at Yamit, on the Mediterranean, and its passengers went ashore in a rubber dinghy, the spokesman said.

headline: GASOLINE DECLINE SLOWS
abstract: Americans are using less gasoline, but recent figures indicate that the decline is slowing.  More than 102 billion gallons of gasoline were burned last year, a drop of 2.5 percent from 1980 levels, says the Lundberg Letter, a newsletter that tracks developments in oil and gasoline markets.

headline: Mesa Lines Up 1-Billion Credit
abstract: The Mesa Petroleum Company has signed a $1.05 billion credit agreement with nine banks to finance its tender offer for 12.1 million shares in the Cities Service Company, Mesa announced yesterday.

headline: DELOREAN DOUBTFUL ON BUDGET RENT-A-CAR ACCORD
abstract: John Z. DeLorean, president of the DeLorean Motor Company, said last night that it is unlikely the company will reach an agreement to lease some of its unsold 1981 inventory to the Budget Rent-a-Car Corporation of America, a deal that would have helped the ailing auto company stay in business.   ''So far we have been unable to put together a satisfactory arrangement,'' said Mr. DeLorean. He added that prospects for such an agreement appeared dim, but that the company had another financing arrangement that would help it pay its debts.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * World Book/Childcraft International to McCann-Erickson, Chicago. * The New York Stock Exchange Index to FCB/Corporate.

headline: DeLorean Acts to Free Its Inventory
abstract: The DeLorean Motor Company said yesterday that new financial arrangements had been completed to free its United States inventory of automobiles, frozen since March by its largest creditor, the Bank of America.   John Z. DeLorean, president of the company and its largest shareholder, said in a telephone interview that $13.7 million had been paid to the bank as of last Tuesday night.   Mr. DeLorean declined to name the source of the new funds, however, and would only say that ''a financial institution'' had put up the money. He said the bank had agreed to an arrangement whereby 600 cars would be released to pay the balance of the bank's loan to the motor company, which totaled some $17.8 million. Mr. DeLorean said he had dealer orders for the cars, the proceeds of which would go to the bank.

headline: American Bakeries Shift
abstract: Leonard Toboroff was named acting chief executive officer of American Bakeries Inc. yesterday to replace Neil S. Leist, who was injured in an auto accident during the weekend. Mr. Toboroff, a New York lawyer, is a director of the company.   Mr. Leist, 33 years old, took over the company in a proxy fight and was appointed chief executive in March.

headline: Court Orders Phone Study
abstract: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has reversed a ruling and ordered the Federal Communications Commission to reconsider a decision in 1980 that ordinary long-distance service and WATS are ''like'' services.   The new ruling has no bearing on telephone rates being charged now by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, sources at the company said, but it could alter the course of an investigation being conducted by the F.C.C. that could later result in a narrowing of the differences between regular long-distance service and WATS.

headline: GERMANS TRY TO REGAIN JAPAN'S TOOL ADVANTAGE
abstract: Last year Japan moved past West Germany to become the world's second-largest producer of machine tools behind the United States. It was another sign of slippage in a major German export industry often considered a barometer of the country's economic well-being.   Bonn officials insist that the Japanese surge was simply a result of a statistical distortion caused by the yen's sharp rise in value.  But much of it happened in West Germany's own backyard. Amid market shrinkage caused by the recession, Japan overtook Italy to become Germany's No.2 machine tool supplier. In 1977 Japan ranked sixth.

headline: DeLorean Plan To Save Plant
abstract: John Z. DeLorean said in an interview last week that he would meet with Sir Kenneth Cork on Thursday to present a plan supported by two West Coast investors aimed at eventually re-starting car production at the Government-owned plant in Northern Ireland.   Sir Kenneth is in charge of reorganizing the finances of the plant, which has been in receivership since last February.

headline: RUBIK'S RIVAL
abstract: dimensional puzzle.   Now the company faces a new kind of court challenge. A small chemical research and development company contends that the puzzle was invented by its chief scientist, Larry D. Nichols, and not by Erno Rubik, the now-famous Hungarian architect and teacher.

headline: GENERAL SHARE PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business Conditions; TRADE: A HIDDEN THORN
abstract: While some analysts attribute the ongoing recession to the continued slump in key industries like autos, housing and steel, the real reason may lie elsewhere.   Unlike any of its postwar predecessors, the current downturn has been sparked by a sharp drop in the merchandise trade balance.

headline: BANKS SET TO SIGN POLISH PACT
abstract: An agreement to reschedule $2.4 billion in debt that Poland failed to pay 500 Western banks last year will be signed in Frankfurt next Tuesday, an official of the Dresdner Bank of West Germany said today.   Hans Friderichs, chairman of the bank, said at Dresdner's annual news conference today that the banks had verified that Poland completed payment of $500 million of interest owed for 1981. The creditors had made payment of the overdue interest a condition for signing the agreement, which postpones for several years payment of most of the $2.4 billion in principal due last year.

headline: Argentine Submarine Was Once U.S. Vessel
abstract: The Santa Fe, the Argentine submarine attacked by British helicopters today, was commissioned by the United States as the Catfish in 1945 and was sold to Argentina in 1971, according to Jane's Fighting Ships, a standard reference book of the world's navies.   The submarine, one of four in the Argentine Navy, was built by the Electric Boat Company in Connecticut and was modified in the Navy's Guppy II program in 1950. With a range of 12,000 miles and a surface speed of 18 knots, the Santa Fe is powered by three diesel engines and equipped with 10 torpedo tubes.

headline: MOSCOW DECLARES STAND IS NEUTRAL
abstract: After appearing impartial during the early days of the Falkland crisis, the Soviet Union said today that the Argentine action was an outgrowth of Britain's resistance to decolonization.   However, two statements by the Foreign Ministry today set out a position that offered no backing to the Argentine seizure of the islands last week and avoided any explicit recognition of Argentina's claim to sovereignty.   In the first statement, read to foreign reporters over the telephone, the ministry said that the Soviet Union's ''position in the conflict is neutral'' and added that Moscow favored a ''peaceful resolution'' of the dispute.

headline: BRITISH WARSHIPS BEGIN BLOCKADE AROUND ISLANDS
abstract: Britain's air and sea blockade of the Falklands began today with ships of the British battle fleet reported in place around the islands in direct challenge to Argentina.   The fleet movements were reported by Western military sources here and in London. But the informants said that Argentina and Britain appeared to be waiting for each other to fire first to avoid being accused of starting a war.   Military sources here said British destroyers took positions between the Falklands and Argentina on Thursday, hours before the scheduled beginning of the blockade.

headline: SCHLUMBERGER UP 30.7% IN 1st PERIOD
abstract: Schlumberger Ltd. reported yesterday that strong gains by its oilfield services group caused net income in the first quarter of 1982 to soar 30.7 percent, while sales increased 13.1 percent.   Schlumberger, the world leader in well-logging services for the oil industry, said that net income in the latest three months increased to $354.4 million, or $1.21 a share, from $271.1 million, or 94 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Revenues advanced to $1.64 billion from $1.45 billion.

headline: BREZHNEV OFFERS PROGRAM TO INCREASE FOOD SUPPLY
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev today pledged a ''radical turn'' toward improved food supplies through a combination of powerful new regional structures and heavy infusions of money.   The Soviet leader introduced the program, first promised at the Communist Party Congress 15 months ago, at a special meeting of the party's Central Committee.   Although Mr. Brezhnev went to some lengths in his speech to defend the agricultural policies he has pursued in his 17 years in power, he underscored the urgency of the problem when he declared that a rapid improvement of food supplies ''is not only a top economic priority, but also an urgent sociopolitical task.''   He also referred to the situation created by American-led grain embargoes, saying his plan ''proceeds from the need to reduce import of foodstuffs from capitalist countries.''

headline: INDEX FUTURES IN NEW YORK
abstract: THE New York Futures Exchange faces a moment of truth Thursday when the moribund exchange plans to start trading in futures based on the New York Stock Exchange composite index of 1,532 stocks. But much more is riding on the new stock-index futures than the life of the small exchange.   Also at stake is the leadership of its parent, the New York Stock Exchange, in the fast-changing world of individual and institutional investments. The new venture could also determine whether the powerful Chicago markets that dominate the commodity industry will again steal a march on New York's financial community.

headline: BAR ARGENTINE ROLE; JUNTA BALKS AT TERMS; Mrs. Thatcher's statement, page A24.
abstract: More than 13,000 bedraggled Argentine troops in the Falkland Islands surrendered during the night, bringing the total to 15,000 in the fierce infantry campaign that lasted only three weeks, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today.   The capitulation came after heavily outnumbered British troops smashed to within rifleshot of the weary Argentine defenders of Stanley, their last major stronghold in the Falklands. At dawn today, the Union Jack fluttered once more over the capital, which was seized by Argentine forces on April 2.   The victory ended the fighting in the islands but not necessarily the state of undeclared war with Argentina.

headline: WELLS FARGO PLANS CUTS TO RAISE PROFIT
abstract: Wells Fargo & Company, the nation's 12th-largest banking organization, has decided to cut back on its overall activities and concentrate on California and other Western states, according to its chairman, Richard P. Cooley.   As part of this process, Wells Fargo plans to reduce its staff by at least 500 people this year, Mr. Cooley said in an interview Friday.   The purpose is to improve the bank's profitability, which Mr.  Cooley said is far more important than size.  In 1981, Wells Fargo earned 52 cents on each $100 of its average total assets, a key indicator of a bank's basic profitability. This made Wells the eighth most profitable among the nation's fifteen largest bank holding companies. In the first quarter of 1982, its rate of return on assets rose to 62 cents, ranking it sixth, but Mr.  Cooley said he would not be satisfied until the company earned a 70-cent return or more.

headline: MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The semiconductor industry is cautiously optimistic amid signs that it is emerging from a long slump. Orders are at a two-year high, excess capacity is shrinking and prices have firmed somewhat recently. But further improvement is tied to an upturn in the nation's economy. (Page D1.)

headline: RULES BENT FOR JAMAICA, HELPING U.S. INDUSTRY
abstract: President Reagan's expressed wish to transform Jamaica into an economic showplace of the Caribbean has prompted three Federal agencies to waive laws and bend rules, thereby providing more than $100 million to bolster the Jamaican operations of leading American aluminum companies.   The President has designated Jamaica, under Prime Minister Edward P.G. Seaga, as the centerpiece of his Caribbean Basin Initiative and as the testing ground for what he describes as the ''magic of the marketplace.'' It is an important theme in both Mr. Reagan's foreign and domestic policy.   The assistance to the aluminum companies, pushed through in the name of helping Jamaica and pleasing the President, underscores the close relationship between the Administration's foreign policy and American business. It also illustrates the extent to which the Federal bureaucracy responds to Presidential directives, especially when the President has publicly and repeatedly voiced enthusiasm for a project.

headline: Bangladesh Ousts 18 Officials And Recalls 15 Ambassadors
abstract: Martial law authorities have recalled 15 ambassadors, including envoys to the United States and the Soviet Union, and have dismissed 18 senior domestic officials, the state-controlled press said today.

headline: Pabst Stand on Bid
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company indicated that a sweetened takeover bid from C. Schmidt & Sons was not acceptable, but that it would not oppose an all-cash bid of the same value for its stock. Last month, Schmidt raised its bid for Pabst to $209 million, or $20.50 a share in cash plus a $5 subordinated debenture for each common share, from an earlier bid of $183 million, or $20.50 a share in cash. William F. Smith, president and chief executive of Pabst, said, ''We wouldn't oppose a clean-cut and all-cash tender offer for all shares at $25 a share if promptly made.''

headline: Heating Oil Futures Post Moderate Gain
abstract: After a day of extremely nervous trading, heating oil futures prices closed moderately higher yesterday. The nervous and confused activity was attributed to anticipation of the weekly statistics of the American Petroleum Institute, which are issued after the close each Wednesday.   The report proved bullish, showing distillate oil stocks to be the lowest since April 1979.  Meanwhile, the close of the New York Mercantile Exchange's heating oil futures market found the spot May contract, which expires this Friday, up 0.76 cent a gallon at 91 cents. The near June delivery rose 0.93 cent, to 89.35 cents, and the equally active July contract gained 0.57 cent, to 88.79 cents.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: A shareholder of McCormick & Company, the Maryland-based spice maker that said last week that its earnings from 1977 to 1980 had been exaggerated, filed a class action suit against McCormick, five of its officers and the company's auditor in United States District Court in New York.   The suit, filed by Edward H. Taubman, a Baltimore businessman who owns 200 shares of McCormick, is being brought against David B.  Michels, vice president; Hillsman V. Wilson, president; Richard I.  Pulse, controller; Donald W. Dick, vice president, and James J.  Harrison, vice president.

headline: Around the World; South African Police Seize Reporters' Notes
abstract: The police confiscated reporters' notebooks and documents about the South African National Intelligence Service from three Johannesburg newspapers, The Rand Daily Mail, a major English-language newspaper, reported today.   The paper said that on Friday police officers with search warrants took items from The Mail and two Sunday newspapers, Rapport and The Sunday Times, after a complaint from the head of the intelligence service.

headline: South African Gold
abstract: South African gold production totaled 1.72 million ounces last month, the Chamber of Mines reported today. This was up from 1.7 million ounces in February but down from 1.78 million ounces in March 1981.

headline: I.T.T. Fights Bell On Rate Request
abstract: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said it had asked the Federal Communications Commission to deny American Telephone and Telegraph Company's request to double charges for connecting non-Bell long-distance telephone service to local Bell operating companies.

headline: World Airways Debt Extension
abstract: Troubled World Airways received more time from its creditors to work out a debt restructuring plan.  The carrier, which is battling to avoid the fate of the bankrupt Braniff Corporation, obtained from its 16 creditors a two-week extension, to July 9, to restructure $17 million in debt and lease payments coming due through June 30, 1983, Brian Cooke, a World senior vice president, said.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Seating Co., Grand Rapids, Mich., has elected three officials of Fuqua Industries to its board of directors. They are J.B. Fuqua, Fuqua Industries' chairman; Lawrence P. Klamon, president, and Carl E. Sanders, a Fuqua Industries director.

headline: Iran Offers Anti-Israel Plan
abstract: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Vellayati of Iran today proposed forming an Islamic army to oust Israel from the Arab territories it has occupied since the 1967 Middle East War. He made the suggestion at a news conference at the end of a five-day visit to Pakistan.

headline: Lockhart & Pettus Plan New Branch in Atlanta
abstract: Keith E. Lockhart and Theodore P. Pettus will be opening a branch of their Lockhart & Pettus agency in Atlanta on June 1.

headline: PROSPECTS DIMMING FOR COAL PROJECTS
abstract: When exports of American coal soared three years ago, the huge coal loading facilities of Norfolk, Va., quickly clogged, and ships backed up for miles.   In North Carolina, as in other coastal areas, it did not take long for the leaders of local business to pinpoint coal shipping as a bright profit prospect. Eight projects were promptly started, which were to increase handling capacity to 74 million tons by mid-1985.  That is more than total United States exports just a few years ago.

headline: Denmark Will Open a Center In '83 for Victims of Torture
abstract: The Danish chapter of Amnesty International, the human-rights group, said today that Denmark will open the first international rehabilitation center for torture victims.   A spokesman for the group, Inge Kemp Genefke, said that the center will open in September 1983, with similar clinics opening later in Paris, Amsterdam and Toronto.   Denmark's center, to be staffed by about 50 medical professionals, including nurses, physicians, psychiatrists and physiotherapists, will treat about 300 patients a year, Dr. Genefke said.

headline: ARGENTINES REPORT BRITISH BREACHED STANLEY DEFENSES
abstract: British and Argentine troops were pitted in a major battle today for control of Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, the Argentine high command announced.   Military sources said heavy casualties were being incurred by both sides, and the independent news agency Noticias Argentinas quoted a military source this afternoon as having said that the British had ''succeeded in some penetration of the first Argentine line of defense'' about 10 miles west of the capital, which is the key Argentine stronghold on the islands called the Malvinas by Argentina.    (In London, Defense Secretary John Nott said that British troops had advanced more than five miles before dawn in what he described as ''a brilliant surprise night attack'' that had caught the Argentine defenders asleep. Page 26.)

headline: Index Setback For Dow Jones
abstract: Dow Jones & Company suffered another judicial setback today in its attempt to halt the Chicago Board of Trade from trading a stock index futures contract pegged to various Dow Jones stock market averages.   Citing the recent approval by the Commodity Futures Exchange Commission of the proposed futures contract, Judge James C. Murray of Cook County Circuit Court ruled today that the Chicago board would not infringe on the Dow Jones trademark or misappropriate any Dow Jones property rights by trading the futures contract.

headline: Around the World; Pact on Bases Expected Between U.S. and Spain
abstract: The United States and Spain are expected to sign an agreement early next week on the use of military bases in Spain, a Spanish Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

headline: Deutsch to Introduce Two Investment Funds
abstract: David Deutsch Associates will be the agency for the introduction of two new investment funds from the National Securities and Research Corporation. They are National Cash Reserves and National Government Reserves, which will primarily be distributed through investment brokers and dealers and managed by National Securities and Research.   If sales are good, advertising billings on each fund could go to $1 million.

headline: U.S. INSURANCE: CRITICS GROW
abstract: Whether you are the victim of a burglary in Brooklyn, a flood in Florida, an insurrection in Indonesia or a credit union collapse in California there is a good chance you will be looking to Washington for reimbursement.   Uncle Sam's insurance operations, even without counting Social Security or unemployment compensation, now cover more than $2,000 billion in risks, dwarfing the exposure of any private insurance company. As a group, the Federal insurance funds represent a vast grab bag of off-budget programs administered by more than a dozen agencies but coordinated by none. Many of the programs are virtually unheard of except by their constituents.   Recently, however, some of the Government insurance companies have become more visible, particularly in banking and pensions, where economic hard times have been piled on top of more basic problems. In fact, Representative Claude D. Pepper, Democrat of Florida, chairman of the House Committee on Aging, warned at a hearing today that one more bankruptcy filing like that of Braniff International could force the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, a Federal agency insuring pension plans, to go bankrupt itself.

headline: Raytheon Gains 8.5%
abstract: The Raytheon Company, the producer of military and civilian electronics and Beech aircraft, reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 8.5 percent, to $79.4 million, or 94 cents a share, from $73.2 million, or 88 cents, a year earlier. Raytheon said its sales in the quarter were $1.42 billion, up from $1.31 billion the previous year.

headline: ARGENTINES TELL OF SINKING FRIGATE
abstract: Argentina announced tonight that its planes attacked British forces making an amphibious landing on the Falkland Islands today, sinking a frigate and killing many of the British troops.   The military command said that the three British landing craft making the landing at Pleasant Bay, 16 miles southwest of Stanley, had been badly damaged. It said two of the landing craft had been beached and abandoned as fire and explosions broke out on board. It said the third landing craft had fires aboard and had withdrawn from the combat.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 2, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: U.S. Asks More Aides To Leave Buenos Aires
abstract: The United States is sharply reducing the number of officials and dependents at the American Embassy in Buenos Aires because of tensions with Argentina over the Falkland Islands conflict, a State Department spokesman said today.

headline: Ashkenazy Stake In Thrift Concern
abstract: Severyn Ashkenazy, a Los Angeles investor, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that he owned 9.9 percent of the capital stock of Financial Federation Inc., a holding company for 11 savings and loan associations with headquarters in Los Angeles.   In a filing with the commission, Mr. Ashkenazy said he held 420,000 of Financial Federation's capital shares and had entered into two option agreements for an additional 147,000 capital shares at an option price of $7 a share.

headline: AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOVIET IMPORTS OF GRAIN FROM ARGENTINA PUT OFF
abstract: The Soviet Union has postponed half of its June purchase of Argentine grain, according to shipping and grain officials here.   The move is expected to put additional economic and political pressures on the Argentine Government, which is short of foreign exchange needed to finance its military operations in the Falkland Islands.   The Soviet Union is Argentina's major trading partner, buying about three fourths of its 20 million-ton annual grain crop.  About 7 million tons of grain from this year's harvest with an estimated value of $800 million remain to be sold. The Soviet Union was expected to take about three fourths of that amount, mostly corn, sorghum and soy, in the next few months.

headline: Talking Business with Senator Richard G. Lugar; Federal Role In Rescues
abstract: It was not all that long ago, says Senator Richard G. Lugar, that the experts were predicting that neither New York City nor the Chrysler Corporation would ever see 1982 without slipping into bankruptcy.   Instead, the Indiana Republican says, New York City and Chrysler not only survived, but the give-and-take among natural adversaries facing fiscal disaster also opened the way to a new era of cooperation between management and unions. In that pattern, he says, Ford and General Motors have attained a contract with wage and benefit concessions undreamed of four or five years ago and given in exchange for work guarantees unheard of in the auto industry.  Senator Lugar was instrumental in fashioning emergency Federal aid for Chrysler and New York.

headline: MARINE'S NATIONAL OUTLOOK
abstract: Having emerged from a deeply troubled past, Marine Midland Banks Inc. is trying to make up for lost time by creating a nationwide federation of commonly owned, but autonomous banks.   Armed with capital from the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, which now has a 51 percent interest in the New York bank, Marine is aggressively seeking to buy banks around the United States. Hongkong and Shanghai, one of the most powerful banks in Asia, operates more than 400 offices in 40 countries and is especially strong in the Far East, the Middle East and India.   Because Federal law prohibits interstate banking, Marine's purchases cannot be consummated until the law changes, but the bank is confident that the change will come in the not-too-distant future. Until then, it is holding options to trade nonvoting preferred stock that it now owns in the out-of-state banks for common voting stock.  If the acquisitions do not go through, the preferred stock can be redeemed over a 20-year period.

headline: S.E.C. CALLS FOR NEW PARTIAL TENDER RULE
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed new rules to make it easier for small investors to take advantage of tender offers in takeover situations.   In a separate action, the commission agreed to send a letter to the Federal Reserve Board stating that it ''does not oppose'' the proposed acquisition by the BankAmerica Corporation of Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm. If the Fed approves the merger, it would mark the first time that an American bank has been allowed to acquire a brokerage house.

headline: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Crocker Arrives for Talks
abstract: Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, arrived here today for a meeting with South African officials to discuss South-West Africa. The talks will begin a new round of Western diplomacy aimed at achieving independence of the South African-controlled territory, also known as Namibia. The State Department spokesman, Dean Fischer, said in Washington that there would soon be a meeting of the five Western nations that have a United Nations mandate to seek a settlement.

headline: MORE HEUBLEIN STOCK BOUGHT
abstract: The General Cinema Corporation raised teh ante in its stock battle with Heublein Inc., announcing that it has acquired another 456,900 shares of the Farming, Conn., food and beverage company.   J. Atwood Ives, senior vice president at General Cinema, said that the company had filed notice with the Securities and Exchange Commission that recent stock purchases gave the company 12.8 percent of Heublein's 21.7 million shares.

headline: NATIONAL STATE BANK (ELIZABETH, NJ) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ASSAD SAYS HE WILL SEEK MORE ARMS IN SOVIET
abstract: President Hafez el-Assad of Syria says that, on his next visit to the Soviet Union, the source of Syria's arms, he will seek to achieve a strategic balance with Israel, according to a French Arabic-language magazine.   The magazine, Al Mostakbal of Paris, quoted Mr. Assad as having said that no date had been set for his trip to the Soviet Union, which has a treaty of friendship and cooperation with the Soviet Union.   ''The United States has no policy in the Middle East,'' the Syrian leader said. ''It only carries out Israel's policy in the region and this will eventually hurt American interests. The United States supplies Israel with the weapons it uses to occupy our land, while the Soviet Union supplies arms to help us defend ourselves.

headline: ARGENTINES PUT BLAME ON BRITISH FOR U.N. DELAY
abstract: Argentine officials said today that Britain was responsible for delaying negotiations on the Falkland Islands crisis but still expressed hope for a peaceful settlement.   Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez told reporters late Friday night that the return to London of Sir Anthony Parsons, Britain's representative in the United Nations' mediation talks over the Falklands, proved that ''the responsibility for the delay or the prolongation of the negotiations is certainly not Argentina's, but Britain's.''   Foreign Ministry officials, repeating that opinion today, also voiced hope that the Ambassador's recall was a positive step that might lead to an accord within the British Government for a negotiated settlement of the crisis.   Tonight as he left the Foreign Ministry after a day of meetings on the crisis, reporters asked Mr. Costa Mendez if he was optimistic.  ''That is a difficult assessment to make,'' he replied. ''I am confident in the negotiations.''

headline: BUDGET ACCORD PLAN SENDS DOW UP 8.75
abstract: Stock prices advanced sharply yesterday in heavy trading, spurred by the news of a tentative plan to settle the battle over the Federal budget deficit.   The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 8.75 points, to 863.20, with advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering stocks that declined by more than a 2-to-1 ratio.   Turnover on the Big Board, buoyed by expanded institutional participation, swelled to 67.5 million shares from 58.9 million shares Wednesday.

headline: Chalk, Nissen to Do Logan Ads for K Mart
abstract: K Mart has selected Chalk, Nissen, Hanft, to be the ad agency for the Jonathan Logan brand women's sportswear that the Kayser-Roth Corporation is going to manufacture under a licensing agreement with Jonathan Logan.

headline: Advertising; Computers And a Beer For Ally
abstract: ALLY & GARGANO, the creator of the award-winning Federal Express campaign and other memorable work, will be adding its combat skills to the booming battle of the microcomputers.   It will be participating in behalf of two new products from Commodore International in King of Prussia, Pa. And, according to Amil Gargano, the agency's president, the budget is going to be in the $20 million neighborhood.

headline: ISRAEL'S STATEMENT ON THE CEASE-FIRE
abstract: Following is the text of the Israeli Government statement today announcing a cease-fire in Lebanon, as translated from the Hebrew by United Press International:   JERUSALEM, June 11 (UPI) - Following is the text of the Israeli Government statement today announcing a cease-fire in Lebanon, as translated from the Hebrew by United Press International:   On Saturday, June 5, 1982, the Government decided to assign the Israel Defense Forces a mission to take all the Galilee settlements out of the firing range of the terrorists who are concentrated in their bases and headquarters in Lebanon.   In the five days of fighting the I.D.F. carried out the mission assigned it in its entirety, with heroism, with sacrifice and with great resourcefulness.   Happy is the nation whose warrior sons these are, the commanders of its army, its soldiers. The Government extends its respect to its holy and heroic sons, who gave their lives for peace in the Galilee and for all the citizens of Israel.

headline: EARLY ARMS TALKS PREDICTED BY HAIG
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said here today that Leonid I. Brezhnev's speech seemed to clear the way for early talks on strategic nuclear arms, but he rejected the Soviet leader's proposal for a freeze in deployment.   At a news conference at the end of the spring meeting of foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which had been devoted largely to arms control, Mr, Haig said a freeze would ''codify existing Soviet advantages.'   Mr. Brezhnev said at a convention of the Young Communist League in Moscow that President Reagan's proposals for cuts in strategic, or long-range, weapons were ''one-sided,'' but Mr. Reagan seemed to accept the idea of early talks voiced by Mr. Reagan on May 9 in a speech in Eureka, Ill. Haig Considers Speech Positive   ''To the extent they are willing to get into negotiations as early as possible, it is positive,'' Mr. Haig said of Mr. Brezhnev's speech.

headline: Mitterrand, on Tour, Defends Administration
abstract: LA-GAILLARD, France, May 4 (Reuters) - President Francois Mitterrand ended a rare provincial tour today that he has used to defend his administration's record after one year in office and to appeal for national unity.   For the last two days the President, accompanied by television crews, has walked the streets of Limoges, Brive and other towns, telling gatherings and local councils in this underdeveloped western region that his administration would stick to its program and that he would see out the seven-year term, which began after elections last May.

headline: 257 POLES ARE ARRESTED AT A SOLIDARITY CEREMONY
abstract: The Polish police said today that they arrested 257 people in the southwestern town of Wroclaw on Monday after a crowd of several thousand workers tried to lay a wreath at a plaque commemorating the founding of the local chapter of the banned Solidarity union.   That appeared to be the largest number of people arrested at one time in Poland since the demonstrations against martial law in Warsaw and several other cities on May 3.   According to reports reaching Warsaw today, when the workers reached the plaque at the Wroclaw bus terminal, they were met by a large force of riot policemen armed with tear gas and water cannon who told them to disperse. As the crowd started to break up, the police began checking identity papers and making arrests.

headline: CLORE STOCK TAKES OVER AT GULF
abstract: Alan E. Clore, the leader of a dissident stockholder group that won control of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Company, was appointed chairman yesterday at the first meeting of the company's new board of directors. He replaces Robert H. Allen, who was dismissed.   Gary A. Childress, the former president of a Pennsylvania resources and waste-management concern and a member of the dissident slate, was named chief executive officer. The office of president and chief operating officer will continue to be held by Frank G. Woodruff ''pending the outcome of a further review of the company's operations,'' a spokesman for the dissident group said last night.

headline: WHITE HOUSE PLAYING DOWN KIRKPATRICK REMARKS
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and other senior aides to President Reagan dismissed as inconsequential today the comment by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick Monday that the United States has behaved ''like a bunch of amateurs'' at the United Nations.   White House officials asserted that no consideration was being given to seeking Mrs. Kirkpatrick's resignation as delegate to the United Nations, although some acknowledged that her comment had left some of the people traveling with the President in Europe baffled and temporarily alarmed.   But the officials said Mrs. Kirkpatrick had reported to aides here today that her comment was not intended to refer specifically to the mix-up last weekend over a vote on a resolution about the Falkland Islands war.   Instead, these officials said, Mrs. Kirkpatrick was simply repeating an observation she has made on many occasions that the United States has not, for many years, conducted itself effectively at the United Nations. At the United Nations today, Mrs. Kirkpatrick said she was surprised at the attention received by her comments.

headline: GULF'S RESIDENT MERGER MASTER
abstract: MORE than 30 years ago, when he was a young management consultant in New York City, Harold H. Hammer helped a friend sell a small electrical business as a favor. Much to his astonishment, he found a check in the mail for $15,000 -more than his entire income that year - and promptly went into business buying and selling companies.   Mr. Hammer has since moved on to Pittsburgh and the Gulf Oil Corporation, where he enhanced his reputation as an accomplished deal maker. His most notable transaction took place only about a week ago, when together with Gulf's chairman, James E. Lee, he engineered the oil giant's $4.8 billion offer for the Cities Service Company, which was struggling to ward off an unfriendly takeover bid by the Mesa Petroleum Corporation.

headline: COWLES COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AMERACE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Diners Club Drive for Affluent
abstract: NOW that it has Citicorp to play its Daddy Warbucks, Diners Club can afford to raise its voice in the credit card marketplace, where the heavy emphasis these days is on making card holders of the affluent business travelers and their carefully cultivated expense accounts.   The 32-year-old operation, acquired last June by Citicorp (which already owned the Carte Blanche card) will be breaking a three-year advertising silence on Monday with a multimillion-dollar, multimedia campaign.   Pei-yuan Chia, senior vice president in charge of Citicorp's travel and entertainment cards, declined to be more specific on the budget than ''eight figures,'' which is pretty impressive in itself.

headline: Sabena Worker Pay Cut
abstract: Workers at Sabena Belgian World Airlines, the financially ailing national carrier, have accepted a series of austerity measures including wage cuts of up to 17 percent, the airline said today. The Belgian Government, Sabena's owner, has threatened to let the airline go bankrupt unless the company's payroll is cut by $20 million and at least $10 million is saved in other costs. Sabena, which has not been profitable since 1958, operates a fleet of 22 aircraft and has accumulated debts of almost $200 million.

headline: ROTELCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SPERRY PRESIDENT NAMED TO TOP POST
abstract: Gerald G. Probst has been named chief executive officer of the Sperry Corporation, succeeding J. Paul Lyet, and will also become chairman when Mr. Lyet retires from that post on June 1.   In announcing the appointment, Mr. Lyet described his successor as ''a key member'' of the office of the chairman, which was established in 1979. Mr. Probst, who has been president, chief operating officer and a member of the board of directors of Sperry since 1980, has had ''direct responsibility for the corporation's five operating divisions and the Sperry Research Center,'' Mr. Lyet added.

headline: Little 'White House' Battered
abstract: A Dutch antiwar group attacked a 60-by-20-foot replica of the White House with sledgehammers and spray paint today, but its designer said he would fix the creation he spent 20 years building. The designer, John Zweifel of Orlando, Fla., said: ''Nobody will ever destroy this thing because we'll build it up again. The world can change, but I don't have to change with it.''

headline: The U.N. Today; April 27, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Preparatory Commitee for the Sec- ond Special Session of the General As- sembly Devoted to Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: WRIGLEY REASSERTS ITSELF IN GUM MARKET
abstract: The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company is aggressively trying to re-establish itself as the nation's leading manufacturer of chewing gum.   The Chicago-based company, having turned back a challenge from its competitors' sugarless and bubble gum products, is now intent on becoming a force in the market for liquid-center gums.   Wrigley tried to do so once - and failed. The company introduced two liquid-filled chewing gum products several years ago, aimed at adults as a breath freshener, but they were withdrawn last year.

headline: Market Place; Bear Market In Forecasting
abstract: SECURITIES analysts, who follow the fortunes of publicly owned companies and predict their profit prospects, have taken refuge in a creed of economists: ''Forecast often.'' The strategy is designed to protect one's flanks in an error-prone business.   This has been a particularly tough year for estimating corporate earnings. The economy has deteriorated far more seriously than most analysts and economists foresaw at the start of 1982. Meanwhile, interest rates have remained at surprisingly high levels.

headline: Company News; 30% Merck Stake In Japan Concern
abstract: Merck & Company reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that on March 31 it acquired 30 percent of the capital stock of Torii & Company, a Japanese drug manufacturer, for about $8 million in cash.   Separately, Merck said that on March 11, it reached an agreement with Banyu Pharmaceutical Company Ltd. of Tokyo involving collaboration of the two companies in the Japanese pharamaceutical market.   Under this agreement, Merck said it paid about $18 million for 5 percent of Banyu's stock, and Banyu purchased on the open market around $2 million worth of Merck's common stock.

headline: ARGENTINE REGIME IS HOLDING 400 AFTER WIDESPREAD PROTESTS
abstract: The military Government said today that 400 people were being held for taking part in protests across the country against the regime's economic austerity program in violation of a ban on demonstrations.   In announcing the number of people still in custody, Deputy Interior Minister Bernardo Menendez gave no figure for the total arrested during demonstrations here and in other Argentine cities on Tuesday.

headline: LOW-KEY CEREMONIES SET FOR SINAI TRANSFER TODAY
abstract: The Government of President Hosni Mubarak today predicted a smooth final withdrawal of Israel's presence in Sinai Sunday as Egypt's black, white and red flag is raised at Rafa, in northern Sinai, and at Sharm el Sheik on the peninsula's southern tip.   Low-keyed ceremonies celebrating the return of the last third of Sinai under the terms of the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty are planned in various population centers. They are far more limited in scope than the huge national holiday that was often envisioned by President Anwar el-Sadat for the final transfer of the peninsula.   Besides the desert flag-raisings, there will be several military parades. Mr. Mubarak, who has professed a policy of austerity since coming to power after Mr. Sadat's assassination on Oct. 6, will place wreaths at Egypt's Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and at Mr. Sadat's grave adjacent to it.

headline: THE GOLD REPORT
abstract: Last week, the United States Gold Commission issued a report based on more than eight months of study that formally rejected a return to the gold standard. Following are excerpts from the section on domestic monetary arrangements, and comments by commission members.  WE considered a number of alternatives that would serve to reintroduce gold into our domestic monetary policy arrangements. The objective would be to improve monetary control through the discipline of gold for the purpose of reducing inflation. Linking changes in the growth rate of money or of some component of money, such as Federal Reserve notes, or of bank reserves, to the change in the gold stock is one approach which was considered for imposing the discipline of gold.   One way to reintroduce gold would be to require the Federal Reserve System to maintain a minimum ratio between the Government's gold stock and the Federal Reserve monetary base (i.e., Federal Reserve notes plus bank reserves) or some monetary aggregate. A variant would fix upper and lower limits to the ratio, so that the System would be required to take expansionary actions when the ratio was at its lower limit. The gold cover requirement might be valued at the price of $42.22, or adjusted gradually, or allowed to fluctuate with market prices.

headline: JITTERY BEIRUT, ISRAELI JETS OVERHEAD, IS TAKEN OVER BY RIVAL MILITIA
abstract: GROUPS By WILLIAM E. FARRELL   BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 9 - After seven years of violence and killings, this battered and shell-shocked city is again an eerie place of empty streets and crowded rooms, the fears being fed this time by a stream of rumors about approaching Israelis.   For more two hours, Israeli planes thundered overhead, apparently heading eastward for targets in the Bekaa Valley, where Syria had emplaced SAM-6 missiles. The high-flying planes drew futile bursts of antiaircraft fire from encampments along the Corniche abutting the sea.   Various militia groups engaged in random fire through the afternoon, and machine-gun bullets pocked and blistered buildings.

headline: NCC Plans to Sell Simplicity Stake
abstract: NCC Energy Ltd. is seeking to sell its 20 percent interest in the Simplicity Pattern Company, the large sewing patterns producer, which had suspended a planned merger with NCC Energy. That merger was halted in March in an effort by Simplicity to concentrate on making acquisitions in domestic and foreign oil and gas operations.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Albert Jay Rosenthal & Co., Chicago, has acquired Fran Wollack and Associates.   * Soskin/Thompson Associates, a direct marketing division of J.  Walter Thompson U.S.A., has opened Soskin/Thompson Associates (Canada) in Toronto.

headline: BACKING FOR ISRAEL CALLED DIMINISHED
abstract: The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Clement J. Zablocki, said today that Congressional support for Israel had ''somewhat diminished'' in the aftermath of Israel's attacks on Palestinian strongholds in Lebanon.   ''There's less support for Israel than historically in the past,'' Mr. Zablocki, a Wisconsin Democrat, said in an interview. ''Now they've gone after the Syrian missile sites and they've seem to gone beyond just going after the Palestinians.''   Mr. Zablocki's statement came as questions arose in Congress and within the Reagan Administration about Israel's use of American arms in the invasion of Lebanon. The United States has traditionally supplied arms to Israel on the agreement that the weaponry would be used only for defense.

headline: UNIVERSAL CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Yr to Nov 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PHOENIX STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Your Money; Tax Shelters: New Stature
abstract: TAX shelters have come a long way since the days when many of the deals seemed shady and structured to generate as much tax loss as possible. Today, the industry has grown huge, and the emphasis is on investment as much as write-off.   Robert A. Stanger, who publishes the Stanger Report on tax shelter investing in Fair Haven, N.J., estimates that sales last year, including public and private placements, reached $8 billion.   There are still shady deals around, but an emphasis on investment merit comes from the new tax law, which reduced tax brackets and cut the top Federal rate to 50 percent from 70 percent, curbing the appetite for large upfront deductions. It also gave the Internal Revenue Service more muscle by increasing penalties for underpayment of taxes and overvaluing assets for depreciation purposes.

headline: POPE BIDS I.L.O. BUILD SOCIAL SOLIDARITY
abstract: Pope John Paul II called here today for a ''new solidarity without frontiers'' based on the ''primacy of human work over the means of production.''   In an address to the International Labor Organization, a United Nations agency, the Polish-born Pope stressed that trade unions able to operate in ''full independence from the political authorities'' were essential for forming a ''society of solidarity.''   ''The working man must assume responsibility for defending the truth, the true dignity of his work,'' he said. ''He must not be prevented from exercising that responsibility, though also bearing in mind the good of the community.''

headline: UAL LOSS WIDENS IN QUARTER
abstract: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, reported that its loss for the first quarter widened to $129.3 million from $21.3 million in the same period of 1981.   The airline, the nation's largest domestic carrier, was responsible for the loss, registering a deficit of $129.7 million for the quarter, compared with $27.1 million a year earlier. UAL's Westin Hotels had net income of $2.3 million; the GAB business service division had a loss of $1.9 million.

headline: BRITAIN EXTENDS BLOCKADE, TELLING ARGENTINES TO STAY WITHIN 12 MILES OF MAINLAND
abstract: In an effort to protect its task force in the South Atlantic and to increase military pressure on Argentina, Britain announced tonight that it would treat as hostile any Argentine warship or plane found more than 12 miles from the mainland coast.   In effect, the declaration constituted a warning to Argentina to keep its planes at their bases and its ships in port or face attack.  It extends the territory covered by the air and sea blockade imposed in a 200-mile zone around the Falkland Islands on April 30, vastly increasing the area to be patrolled by the British fleet's ships and planes. The Argentine coastline extends for about 2,500 miles. Argentina Dismisses Move   Defense Minister Amadeo Frugoli said Argentina would respond to what he called growing aggression by Britain, and Argentine naval officers said the British fleet in the South Atlantic did not have the power to enforce the extension of the blockade around the Falklands. (Page 4.)

headline: The U.N. Today; May 14, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Special Session Devoted to Disar- mament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Open-Ended Working Group on Mi- grant Workers and Their Families - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOCIALIST ALLIANCE SWEPT INTO OFFICE IN MAURITIUS VOTE
abstract: The party that has ruled this Indian Ocean island democracy since independence 14 years ago was routed so completely in elections today that it was left with not a single seat in Parliament.   In a clean sweep, the opposition - the Mauritian Militant Movement and its smaller ally, the Mauritian Social Democratic Party - won election of all their candidates in the 60 constituencies. The only two members of the new Parliament not belonging to the victorious alliance are representatives of a local party on Rodrigues, an island dependency 250 miles to the east, where the victors ran no candidates.   The vote was a repudiation of the Labor Party and its leader, Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam, the 82-year-old Prime Minister, and brought to power a party that was pledged to limited nationalization under a program of ''Socialism with a Mauritian face.'' It has also promised to be nonaligned and to campaign in international forums such as the Organization of African Unity and the United Nations against the American military presence on the island of Diego Garcia, 1,250 miles away.

headline: A.M.C. Price Rise
abstract: The American Motors Corporation said it would increase the prices of optional equipment on its cars and Jeep utility vehicles an average $35, or three-tenths of 1 percent, and destination charges by $26.

headline: U.S. HARDENS CURBS ON SOVIET GAS LINE
abstract: President Reagan, in a major rebuff to West European allies, refused today to ease his ban on the sale of United States oil and gas equipment to the Soviet Union and instead extended the sanctions to foreign companies producing such equipment under American licenses.   A Presidential statement released by the White House this afternoon attributed the decision to Mr. Reagan's desire ''to advance reconciliation in Poland'' by continuing economic pressure on the Soviet Union and Poland.   Since the imposition of martial law, the statement read, ''little has changed concerning the situation in Poland; there has been no movement that would enable us to undertake positive reciprocal measures.''   The pipeline sanctions were first imposed last Dec. 30 solely on American companies in response to the imposition of martial law in Poland in mid-December. Their practical effect was to bar the General Electric Company, the Caterpillar Tractor Company and other major United States companies from selling equipment for the construction of a 3,700-mile pipeline from Siberia to West Germany that eventually might supply Germany, France, Italy and Spain with more than 30 percent of their natural gas.

headline: ABC-TV to Sell Spots For Commentary Ads
abstract: Last July ABC-TV began testing whether corporations, which in increasing numbers seem to want to run advocacy or issue advertising, would like to do it on late-night television.   In the months since then, there may have been a considerable number of inquiries but there were no takers.

headline: ARGENTINA AND CUBA SIGN TRADE PACT
abstract: Argentina's Foreign Minister signed a $100 million trade agreement with Cuba Thursday night to underline the new friendship that has sprung up as a result of the Falkland crisis.   But before leaving here today for Caracas, Venezuela, the Argentine official, Nicanor Costa Mendez, told reporters he had not discussed Cuba's offer of military aid to Argentina. ''We have excellent diplomatic and commercial relations,'' he said, ''but the military question is not of my competence.''

headline: Tosco Directors
abstract: The Tosco Corporation has announced that the five managementnominated candidates for the company's board received 60 percent of the 17.8 million votes cast at the oil refining concern's shareholders meeting on May 11. Tosco shareholders last week also approved a management-sponsored proposal for an employee incentive stock option plan. A proposal to double the number of Tosco's authorized common shares did not pass, however, the Los Angeles-based company said.

headline: BROKER GUILTY ON CONTEMPT CHARGE
abstract: Gary V. Lewellyn, the 33-year-old Iowa stockbroker who faces a welter of charges stemming from his secret purchase of enough shares to control Safeguard Scientific Inc., pleaded guilty to a new charge yesterday.   Appearing in a Federal court, Mr. Lewellyn admitted that, only two days after surrendering himself to Federal authorities last month to face the securities charges, he tried to sell 41,280 shares of Safeguard in direct violation of a court order freezing his assets.  His broker, however, kept him from collecting the $200,000 that the stock brought.   In addition to pleading guilty to contempt of court, Mr. Lewellyn consented yesterday to file for bankruptcy in Iowa within 10 days, and to ''disgorge'' up to $17.7 million, the amount the Securities and Exchange Commission said he gained from his trading in Safeguard. His securities firm, G.V. Lewellyn & Company of Des Moines, has already entered liquidation.

headline: Two Airlines Report Losses
abstract: Northwest Airlines reported a loss of $17.9 million in the first quarter yesterday, and Western Airlines said it had an operating loss of $6.4 million. Both carriers cited lower passenger revenue attributed to the recession and fare wars.

headline: OTHER BUSINESS; TEXACO'S NEW ENGINES IN U.P.S. BROWN TRUCKS...
abstract: Perhaps, finally, its time has come. After more than 30 years on the back burner in a Texaco research lab, the ''stratified charge'' engine is scheduled to hit the road by midyear in its first commercial application, under the hoods of 500 United Parcel Service delivery trucks.  Publicists bill the project as ''revolutionary,'' but its basic technology has been around since the 1940's, when Texaco engineers conceived their so-called ''controlled combustion system'' as an answer to pre-ignition and knock problems in gasoline engines.  U.P.S., the package delivery giant based in Greenwich, Conn., tripped into the venture three years ago while searching for a fuelsaving alternative to regular gasoline.

headline: ALGERIAN SUPPORTS BETTER TIES TO U.S.
abstract: A close aide to Algeria's President said this week that the Government was ready for a ''new phase'' of cooperation with the United States and wanted improved relations.   The aide, Col. Slimane Hoffmann, head of the foreign policy commission of the ruling National Liberation Front, emphasized in an interview that he was speaking ''on behalf of Algeria.''   ''What I am saying is the Algerian position,'' he said several times in the three-hour interview in his sparsely furnished office.  ''We are ready for cooperation,'' the colonel said, speaking in Arabic. ''We are ready for a balanced exchange, a relationship in which the rights of each party are respected and preserved.

headline: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VENEZUELA'S TERRITORIAL CLAIMS WORRY GUYANESE
abstract: The Government of Guyana has begun to worry - in part because of the Falkland Islands crisis - that Venezuela, its rich and more powerful neighbor, is about to press its claim to five-eighths of Guyana's territory.   A protocol that placed a 12-year moratorium on the Venezuelan-Guyanese dispute expires June 18. Venezuela has told Guyana that it does not want the protocol renewed.   Guyana's Ambassador to the United States, Cedric Hilburn Grant, said in an interview here that while there was still no hard evidence, there had been reports of Venezuelan military activity near the nations' shared border. There have also been Venezuelan efforts, he said, to weaken Guyana's already fragile economy through pressure on international lending institutions, foreign investors and developers.

headline: Ad Pages Up in May
abstract: The 113 magazines that are members of the Publishers Information Bureau showed a 2 percent gain in advertising pages in May over the same month last year with the total being 11,847, an increase of more than 287 pages. Advertising revenues were up 13 percent to $338.9 million, a gain of $39.5 million.

headline: West Bank Mayors Plan Disobedience Campaign
abstract: Occupied West Bank, May 6 (Reuters) - Palestinian mayors in the West Bank are planning a new campaign of refusing to cooperate with Israeli occupation authorities.   After weeks of anti-Israeli riots, the mayors say they have decided to halt municipal services in an attempt to persuade the occupying forces to reinstate four dismissed colleagues.

headline: Herfindahl Index a Gauge
abstract: The most dramatic change in the new merger guidelines is probably the adoption of the Herfindahl index, a mathematical standard for determining when an industry is so concentrated that mergers will be anticompetitive.   The Herfindahl index is more finely calibrated than the former standard, which differentiated only between industries in which the four largest companies had more than 75 percent of a market and those in which they did not. The Herfindahl index looks beyond the four largest companies to every company in an industry, calculating the sum of the squares of every company's market share.

headline: NO ICONOGRAPHY FOR CASTRO
abstract: There is something missing in Cuba. It is first sensed at Havana airport and on the long ride into town. It is the pictures of Fidel Castro that are not on the walls; the statues of him that are not in the squares.   In Communist or authoritarian countries around the world, visages of the leader stare down from everywhere. The cult of personality seems to fill the void of internal legitimacy. But not in Cuba.

headline: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 25
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HAIG ASSISTANT LEAVING
abstract: Robert D. Hormats, who has had a hand in the international economic decisions of the last four Administrations and is now Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs, will resign shortly to take a job in the private sector.   ''After 12 years in Government, it's time to move on to new challenges,'' he said, confirming reports that he had told Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. of plans to depart following the recently concluded Versailles economic summit.

headline: YUGOSLAV PARTY VOWS TO FOLLOW TITO'S COURSE
abstract: Yugoslavia's ruling Communists closed their 12th party congress today with a pledge to follow the basic independent policies of Marshal Tito but with a call for more action and greater responsibility at all levels.   Participants termed it the freest convention that the League of Communists has held, with open, heated debates and much selfcriticism.   For the first time, they said, the new president of the Central Comittee, Mitja Ribicic, was elected by secret vote. There was no competing candidate, but leading Communists called the election a significant step toward democratizing party procedures.

headline: 2 SENATORS DENY SOVIET ARMS LEAD
abstract: Two Democratic Senators who have often advocated a tough stance toward the Soviet Union said today that President Reagan was wrong when he contended that the Soviet Union possesses superiority in nuclear weapons.   Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington said, ''In the aggregate, we have the capability now of deterring the Soviets.'' He cited ''the qualitative advantages that we have, both in our bomber force and in our submarine force,'' as balancing Soviet advantages in heavy missiles.

headline: Security Pacific Up 7%
abstract: The Security Pacific Corporation, the parent of Security Pacific National ank, today reported first-quarter earnings before securities transactions of $52.6 million, up 7 percent from the $49.2 million posted a year ago. Per-share earnings were $1.77, unchanged from a year ago because of the recent issuance of convertible debentures. Net interest income for the quarter was $265.1 million, up 12 percent from a year ago.

headline: CENTERRE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: An Advanced Method To Track Consumers
abstract: At least six marketing research companies are currently availing themselves of the wondrous potential for tracking consumers' activities inherant in the Universal Product Code.   And those little line-filled squares of the code are showing up all over, extending from food and household products and on to magazines, automotive aftermarket products and liquor. Some 15,000 manufacturers are using the symbols.

headline: Cairo Asks Nonaligned Talks
abstract: Egypt called today for a meeting of the selfprofessed nonaligned nations to discuss the crisis in Lebanon and urged Washington to persuade Israel to end its siege of western Beirut. The Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Boutros Ghali, said he had taken up the issue of a nonaligned conference with Yugoslavia's Ambassador, Aleksandr Bozovic. He also said President Hosni Mubarak had asked President Reagan for decisive measures to lift the siege of Beirut.

headline: JEWISH GROUPS IN U.S. SUPPORTING THE INVASION
abstract: Israel's military campaign against Palestine Liberation Organization forces in Lebanon has received solid support from American Jewish officials, though there is also regret over the casualties incurred in the fighting.   Since the invasion began more than two weeks ago, senior officials from national Jewish organizations have kept in close touch with developments and have held a series of meetings. While support for Israel has been reaffirmed, the tone of many of the meetings has been more subdued and anguished than those during other Israeli military engagements.

headline: South Africa Angers Zulus
abstract: South Africa announced today that it would hand over a remote inhabited piece of the Zulus' coastal land to Swaziland in a move that would reduce South Africa's border with Marxist-led Mozambique. The action, which would also give the land-locked Swazi kingdom access to the sea, brought immediate and noisy protest from the country's five million Zulus.

headline: Company News; Ford to Omit Dividend Again
abstract: The Ford Motor Company's board of directors voted not to pay a second-quarter dividend on common stock - the second consecutive period in which stockholders will receive no bonus.   The announcement came as no surprise to industry analysts, who said that Ford decided earlier this year not to pay a dividend on its shares until it is back in the black.

headline: Lindner's Hart Stake
abstract: The American Financial Corporation, which is controlled by Carl H.  Lindner, the Cincinnati financier, has raised its stake in Hart, Schaffner & Marx to 9.9 percent, a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday. John M. Meinert, vice chairman of Hart, said Mr. Lindner had said the acquisition was for investment purposes and that he did not intend to buy more shares in the mens' wear manufacturer.

headline: BONN SEEKS SHIFT ON GAS CURB
abstract: West Germany said today that it had begun talks with the United States in an effort to get it to reverse its decision to widen restrictions on the use of American-developed equipment in a projected natural gas pipeline between Western Europe and the Soviet Union.   The Government spokesman, Klaus Bolling, said that West Germany was not ruling out the option of taking the matter before the International Court of Justice in The Hague.   Mr. Bolling characterized the Government's reaction to the Reagan Administration's announcement as one of ''concern'' and ''dismay.''
