And he described the decision as ''a contradiction to what was agreed on and discussed at the world economic summit meeting'' earlier this month.

headline: INVASION AFFECTED 600,000, U.S. SAYS
abstract: Reports reaching the State Department's Agency for International Development have estimated that as many as 600,000 people have been affected by the Israeli attack against Palestinian strongholds in Lebanon.   A situation report compiled by the agency said that 350,000 people had been affected in the south by the fighting, although exact numbers of people left homeless are unclear. A.I.D. officials said that many Lebanese are, if not homeless, in need of food, water and medical supplies.   Damage in Lebanon was listed as ''severe.'' In the Shouf mountain area southeast of Beirut, where there are many Palestinians, a partial estimate of the homeless was placed at 16,000.

headline: SHARP FIGHTING WITH GUERRILLAS REPORTED
abstract: The Israeli Army invaded southern Lebanon by land, sea and air Sunday in an attack aimed at destroying the main military bases of the Palestine Liberation Organization.   More than 250 Israeli tanks and armored personnel carriers, as well as thousands of infantrymen, rolled past the observation posts of the United Nations peacekeeping troops in southern Lebanon at 11 A.M. (5 A.M., New York time) and fanned out across the frontier, according to a United Nations spokesman in Beirut.   By late Sunday evening the Israelis had taken several P.L.O.  outposts in the craggy hills of southern Lebanon and were engaged in fierce firefights with the Palestinians for control of scores of other strongholds along the 33-mile front, stretching from the port city of Tyre to the foothills of Mount Hermon, the United Nations spokesman said. Main Targets Besieged   In the first day of the invasion the Israelis besieged all their main targets - Tyre, Beaufort Castle, Nabatiye and Kawkaba - but the Palestinians stood their ground and did not flee north. The number of casualties was not known.

headline: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 2, 1982; Companies
abstract: Pabst, itself a takeover target of two other brewers, is seeking 49 percent of Olympia Brewing for $35.56 million. The announcement startled the financial community. It also came as a surprise to Olympia, which said its board would probably discuss the offer today. Pabst is the fifth-largest brewer, and Olympia is No.8. (Page D1.)   Mesa Petroleum said Cities Service had rejected its $3.8 billion takeover bid. Cities Service, in an effort to cut off Mesa's financing, was reportedly ready to question Mesa's bankers to see whether they knew of its takeover plans. The bankers are thought to be Continental Illinois and the Bank of Montreal. (D1.)

headline: Olivetti Computer
abstract: Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, the Italian business machine manufacturer, said it had introduced a personal computer, called the M-20, with which it hopes to gain a major share of the rapidly growing computer market.

headline: REAGAN AD STAND GAINS
abstract: In a surprise reversal, the three major advertising associations told a House subcommittee today that they now supported the Reagan Administration's proposal to limit the Federal Trade Commission's authority to regulate deceptive advertising.   Just last month, in a Senate hearing on the issue, the same industry representatives declined to endorse the proposal, maintaining that 67 years of court decisions had adequately defined which types of advertising had the capacity to deceive consumers.  The industry was apparently concerned that a new definition might cause confusion while it was being interpreted by the courts.

headline: Market Place; Rosy Outlook At Matrix
abstract: THE Exxon Corporation ran into a problem about a year and a half ago with huge compressor pistons used in its North Sea oil and gas operations. They were breaking too often, bringing operations to a halt until the pistons could be replaced.   The problem was turned over to company engineers, who devised a computer program that could convert stress points in the pistons to color photographs, with different colors representing different stresses in pounds per square inch.   Soon Exxon's engineers found a way to change the configuration of the pistons and the materials used in them so that today the pistons are working satisfactorily.

headline: NEW U.S. MERGER RULES TO SCRUTINIZE MARKETS
abstract: The Reagan Administration, which some critics have called soft on corporate mergers, formally described for the first time today new guidelines it is developing to analyze proposed combinations under the antitrust laws.   In general, the new approach puts much greater emphasis than before on defining relevant markets and introduces specific numerical standards by which these can be determined. In addition, the Government will employ a more precise tool, known as the Herfindahl index, to assess the market concentration that would result from a given merger.   Today's preview of the Justice Department's long-awaited revision of its merger guidelines was provided by Attorney General William French Smith in an address before antitrust specialists of the American Bar Association at the Shoreham Hotel.

headline: 2 U.S. Reporters in Uganda Freed After 2 Days' Detention
abstract: Two American journalists detained by the Ugandan Army for two days were handed over to the United States consul in Kampala today.

headline: MRS. KIRKPATRICK SEES REAGAN OVER HER QUARREL WITH HAIG
abstract: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, who is admittedly at odds with the Administration's pro-British policy over the Falkland Islands, met for 40 minutes today with President Reagan to discuss her point of view, White House officials said.   The unusual holiday session at the White House was at Mrs.  Kirkpatrick's request, the officials said. In response to questions, one official said that as far as he knew Mrs. Kirkpatrick had not resigned or been asked to do so.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allied Corp., Morristown, N.J., has named Daniel P. Burnham vice president and controller. * AVX Corp. has appointed Robert B. Welsh vice president-finance.   * Black & Decker Manufacturing Co., Towson, Md., has elected Stephen F. Page treasurer.

headline: BEGIN TELLS LEADING U.S. JEWS OF INVASION'S GOALS
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel told officials of American Jewish organizations yesterday that the Israeli Army would remain in Lebanon as long as the Palestine Liberation Organization posed a threat to the security of his country.   ''We don't covet one inch of the territory of Lebanon,'' Mr. Begin said. ''We want our soldiers to go home and see their loved ones. But as long as rockets are falling on our people, the Israeli Army will be in Lebanon.''

headline: U.S. Gypsum
abstract: The United States Gypsum Company began a temporary freeze on salaries last month and recommended that no bonus or incentive payments be made this year, Graham J. Morgan, chairman, told the annual meeting here. He said that bonus or incentive payments would be made after earnings equaled or exceeded the $2.40 annual dividend paid to holders of common shares.

headline: U.S. ENVOY MEETS LEBANESE LEADERS TO DISCUSS TRUCES
abstract: Philip C. Habib, the American special envoy, held a series of meetings with Lebanese officials today, reportedly aimed at heading off a collapse of Israeli-Palestinian and Israeli-Syrian cease-fires.   Lebanese Government sources made it clear today that Mr. Habib was not trying to negotiate an overall end to the crisis. But there was no direct information available from the talks, which were held in the Israeli-controlled village of Baabda outside Beirut.   Mr. Habib, who met there today with President Elias Sarkis; Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan; the leftist Moslem militia chief, Walid Jumblat, and the Christian militia commander, Bashir Gemayel, was said to be trying to impress on Lebanon's still-divided politicians the urgency of creating a united stand on how to deal with the Israeli withdrawal terms and the Syrian and Palestinian presence here.

headline: CONAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HAIG'S SPEECH ON AMERICAN NUCLEAR STRATEGY AND THE ROLE OF ARMS CONTROL
abstract: Following is the text of a speech delivered at the International Club by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. before Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies and made public by the State Department:   It is a melancholy fact of the modern age that man has conceived a means capable of his own destruction. For 37 years mankind has had to live with the terrible burden of nuclear weapons. From the dawn of the nuclear age, these weapons have been the source of grave concern to our peoples and the focus of continuous public debate. Every successive President of the United States has shared these concerns.  Every administration has had to engage itself in this debate.   It is right that each succeeding generation should question anew the manner in which its leaders exercise such awesome responsibilities. It is right that each new administration should have to confront the aweful dilemmas posed by the possession of nuclear weapons. It is right that our nuclear strategy should be exposed to continuous examination.   In debating these issues, we should not allow the complexity of the problems and the gravity of the stakes to blind us to the common ground upon which we all stand. No one has ever advocated nuclear war. No responsible voice has ever sought to minimize its horrors.

headline: 2d-Ranking Austrian Official Starts on Official Trip to U.S.
abstract: Vice Chancellor Fred Sinowatz of Austria left here today for an official visit to the United States during which he will meet Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., a spokesman at his office said today.   The spokesman declined to give details of subjects expected to be discussed in the talks but said they would cover ''questions of interest to both sides.''   Asked if Mr. Sinowatz would also discuss the visit to Austria last March by the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and a possible meeting between Chancellor Bruno Kreisky and President Reagan, the spokesman said, ''I am sure these subjects will also be brought up in the talks, but they are not the specific purpose of the visit.''

headline: Ulster Nail-Bomb Wounds 2
abstract: Two civilians were wounded early today by a guerrilla nail-bomb probably aimed at security forces, the police reported. No group took responsibility for the bomb, which exploded in a garbage can, but police sources blamed the Irish Republican Army.

headline: BRITISH COLUMBIA FOREST PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LONG STRIKE IS CALLED KEY McCARDELL ERROR
abstract: At the International Harvester Company's annual meeting several weeks ago, Archie R. McCardell told a questioner that being called a failure by stockholders and union members did not bother him.   ''My own children, who also own Harvester stock, call me a failure, too,'' quipped the company's chairman, adding, ''This is a very difficult period.''   On Sunday afternoon, Harvester's board of directors added its voice to the chorus of those who said Mr. McCardell was not up to the job of completing the company's turnaround. Asking him to step aside, the directors turned to Louis W. Menk, the former chairman of Burlington Northern Inc., to guide Harvester through the turbulent months ahead.

headline: Rolls-Royce Begins New Ad Campaign
abstract: To help potential customers make the decision to part with the $111,000 to $162,000 needed to get behind the wheel of one of its products, Britain's Rolls-Royce Ltd. began a new ad campaign last Friday that is the biggest it has ever unleashed in this colony.  Warren Pfaff Inc. is the agency.

headline: Italy Suing Sindona
abstract: Italy is seeking to recover $6 million that it contends was diverted by Michele Sindona from two of his now-bankrupt Milan banks. Mr. Sindona is serving a 25-year sentence after having been convicted on charges relating to the 1974 failure of the Franklin National Bank in New York.   The suit, filed last Thursday in United States District Court in Manhattan, named as defendents the Porcelain Company, a Manhattan company formerly called the Interlakes Realty Corporation, and three of its director-officers: Daniel A. Porco, of Manhattan, a longtime Sindona associate; William E. Colesar of Cape Coral, Fla., and Mary Bosiack of Valencia, Pa.

headline: Palestinians' Shelling Of Galilee Is Sporadic
abstract: The Palestinian guerrilla bombardment of Galilee let up today as Israeli armor advanced toward the gun positions in southern Lebanon. No casualties were reported.

headline: Fireman's Fund
abstract: The Fireman's Fund Insurance Companies, a subsidiary of the American Express Company, said it had reached agreement with the Sime Darby Group of Malaysia calling for the companies to acquire equity interests in each other's insurance operations and to exchange technical and marketing resources in five South-east Asian nations and Hong Kong. Sime Darby is the largest publicly owned nonbank corporation in the five Asian nations and Fireman's Fund is the 10th-largest property-liability insurer in the United States.  Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: Bars to Trade Are Opposed
abstract: Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser of Australia proposed today that the major industrial countries agree to a ''standstill'' on protectionist measures threatening further erosion of world trade and then to a reduction of existing barriers in the next five years.   Mr. Fraser, who held a news conference shortly after meeting with President Reagan, expressed concern about the international economic scene and declared that exceptional measures needed to be taken at the economic summit conference in Versailles next month.

headline: DEMOCRATS SAY REAGAN PLAN ON ARMS MOVES TOO SLOWLY
abstract: Democrats warned today that the reduction in long-range nuclear missiles and warheads proposed by President Reagan could take years to negotiate, and they called for adoption of the second strategic arms limitation treaty in the interim.   ''In order to make progress we have to get to practical specifics - something we can get on with now,'' former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie said at a news conference at his town house in suburban Bethesda, Md.   Mr. Muskie, a former Democratic Senator from Maine, said the Reagan Administration apparently ''sees this initiative as taking years to result in nuclear stabilization, and years we can not afford.''

headline: Santa Fe Coal
abstract: Santa Fe Industries said that it would invest $140 million in the development of a coal mine, the Lee Ranch Mine, in the San Juan Basin of New Mexico. The Tucson Electric Power Company has agreed to buy 15 million tons of coal from the mine to fuel its Springerville, Ariz., plant during the period 1984-91. The mine will be operated by the SF Coal Company, a unit of Santa Fe Industries.

headline: KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Falkland Islands; History
abstract: The Falklands, a group of bleak, windswept islands 250 miles off South America's southeast coast, have been a source of contention between Britain and Argentina for 150 years. They were long strategically important as the nearest refuge for ships from the dangerous passage around Cape Horn. Their territorial waters are now considered a likely source of oil and gas.   Britain's claim to the Falklands, one of its last colonial possessions, is based on their probable discovery in 1592 by John Davis. The islands have also been claimed and occupied at various times by Spain, France and Argentina. The Argentine claim stems mainly from rights inherited from Spain, which recorded a discovery in 1520 by members of Ferdinand Magellan's round-the-world expedition. The islands were named in 1690 for Viscount Falkland, treasurer of the British Navy. In 1832, a colony of Argentines seized several United States sealing ships, which led to a United States punitive expedition that forced many colonists out. In 1832-33, a British expedition removed the last Argentines and founded a permanent colony of settlers. Many of their descendants still live there and have repeatedly affirmed their intention to remain British.

headline: I.B.M. Advance
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had developed a computer-aided design system that can cut the cost of designing computer logic chips by as much as 90 percent. I.B.M. said the system is capable of providing high performance and high density using an automated, instead of a custom, design. It said the system can automatically design chips with over 7,000 circuits.

headline: SOVIET LEADERS' CLINIC REMAINS UNDER CLOSE GUARD
abstract: Policemen continued today to mount watch around the clinic used by members of the Soviet leadership amid indications that Leonid I. Brezhnev may have been admitted there on his return from a trip to Central Asia 10 days ago.   Apart from publishing Mr. Brezhnev's signature under official messages of greeting to foreign statesmen, the Soviet press has been silent on his activities.   An unofficial Soviet source with contacts in the party has told foreign reporters that Mr. Brezhnev, who is 75 years old, was taken to the clinic from the airport on his return from Tashkent on March 25. The source said he had been told that the Soviet leader was carried from the plane on a stretcher.

headline: PATENTS; Recovery of Solvents In Industrial Painting
abstract: A means of recovering valuable organic solvents used in industrial painting has been invented by Richard K. Rathmell, a professional engineer in Ramsey, N.J. He was granted patent 4,326,343 for the method and equipment this week.

headline: Enders Asserts d'Aubuisson Will Be Allowed to Visit U.S.
abstract: A State Department official said today that Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist banned from the United States for two years, would be allowed to come to this country to meet with policy makers.   The official, Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, made the remarks in an interview with the National Public Radio to be broadcast this weekend on the ''Communique'' program.

headline: SATURDAY, JUNE 5, 1982; The Summit
abstract: The economic summit meeting formally opened in Versailles, France, with the heads of the seven leading industrial nations at odds over how to ease the world recession. (Page 1.) A plan to defuse the Europeans' worry over volatile currency rates and high interest rates may emerge. (30.) An array of electronics devices at Versailles underlined President Mitterrand's stress on technology. (31.)   An accord easing friction between the U.S. and Japan over airline services was reached by President Reagan and Prime Minister Suzuki of Japan. Under the pact, United Airlines will enter the Japanese market, while Japan Air Lines will fly to Chicago. (30.)

headline: E-SYSTEM PROTESTS FOREIGN ARMS DEAL
abstract: A leading defense contractor, E-Systems Inc., has enlisted the support of several Congressmen in a campaign to stop companies of Western Europe, Canada, Egypt and Israel from selling weapons and equipment to the United States armed forces under special diplomatic agreements.   So far E-Systems has gained backing by members of Congress from Indiana, Florida and Texas, including the House majority leader, Representative James C. Wright of Texas. But the company has stirred strong resistance from the State Department and Defense Department, which fear foreign policy repercussions.   The immediate target, according to documents filed with the General Accounting Office, is an Israeli electronics concern, Tadiran, which underbid E-Systems on a $38.9 million contract for Army radios. E-Systems, with headquarters in Dallas, sold $275 million worth of electronics and other equipment to the Defense Department last year.

headline: NOWSCO WELL SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TINY COPIER MAKER TAKING A BIG STEP IN DEAL WITH CHINA
abstract: In the copier industry, dominated by giants, Otto A. Clark and his company, the Clark Copy International Corporation, are minuscule: Clark Copy has only 23 employees and 300 stockholders. Total sales last year barely exceeded $1 million, and it spent only $1.2 million on research and development.   But this nondescript, five-year-old company, which makes paper copiers and cassette tape-copying machines in a cramped factory outside of Chicago, has beaten the world leaders in the paper copier business - Xerox, Olympia, Minolta, Sharp - to a lucrative 20-year contract with China.   ''I never even heard of the company before this,'' said Eugene G.  Glazer, a stock analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''Now they're the talk of the town. This contract may not put them on the Fortune 500 list, but it's an awful lot of business.'' Indeed, the deal with China could bring Clark Copy $65 million in sales during the contract's life.

headline: Comment; CRYING WOLF OVER WORD PROCESSORS
abstract: O the Business Editor: Professor Bergmann has struck out with her article. She used erroneous information, and inadequate research methods to, naturally, arrive at a mistaken conclusion.

headline: Coke Era Ends In Johnstown
abstract: The last of the old coke ovens that produced fuel for huge steelmaking blast furnaces in this industrial city are cold, never to be used again.   ''We have been making coke in Johnstown for around 87 years,'' Jack Meredith, an administrator at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's plant here, said today.

headline: ISRAEL SAYS SYRIAN BUILDUP NEAR BEIRUT HAS COLLAPSED
abstract: The Israeli military spokesman declared tonight that ''the entire Syrian military buildup'' in the Lebanese mountains east of Beirut had collapsed at the end of the fourth day of heavy fighting along the Beirut-Damascus highway.   Israeli combat planes flew missions through the day, attacking what the spokesman described as Palestinian and Syrian ammunition dumps and command posts.   Shortly after this announcement was made, the Israeli state radio said that as of 8 P.M. Israeli forces had begun observing a new cease-fire in Lebanon and that Israel's agreement to do so had been communicated to Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy, currently in Beirut.   The military spokesman said that the Beirut-Damascus highway was in Israeli hands from the Beirut suburb of Baabda to the town of Bhamdun, an east-west stretch of about 10 miles.

headline: TRIAD SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Other Business; AN M.B.A. AU VIN, THE LATEST FROM THE CHICAGO SCHOOL
abstract: CHICAGO It's not enough to speak authoritatively about macroeconomics or cost-benefit analysis, to dress for success and use the right fork, according to the University of Chicago. Not if you think that bellying up to the bar for a beer is appropriate at a business lunch.   But if you do, help is on the way: Oenology has come to business school. Fine-tuning its efforts to turn out polished graduates of its master of business administration program, the university's Graduate School of Business is now teaching the art of selecting wines when dining out with clients.

headline: Two Soviet Naval Ships Start Repairs in a Greek Shipyard
abstract: Repairs have started on two Soviet naval supply vessels at a shipyard here under an agreement signed this year.   The shipyard said Soviet Union would pay $2.5 million for the repair and servicing of the two vessels.  An announcement also said that the vessels would be in the noncombatant category and carry no armaments when entering Greek waters.

headline: 20 MEN LOST AS FRIGATE IS SUNK
abstract: British reinforcements poured ashore on East Falkland Island today as the beachhead established on Friday was widened to 10 square miles, Government officials reported tonight.But a British missile frigate hit in the landing attack sank in Falkland Sound with the presumed loss of 20 lives.   John Nott, the Defense Minister, said that the 3,250-ton frigate Ardent had gone down after being hit by bombs and rockets during intensive air raids by the Argentine Air Force. The four-year-old ship was the second lost by the British task force in the South Atlantic; the destroyer Sheffield was fatally damaged by an Exocet missile on May 4.   British sources said that 5,000 marines and paratroopers had moved into the beachhead around San Carlos Bay on the northwestern coast of East Falkland - far more than it had been thought possible to land in 36 hours.

headline: Gulf Starts Offer For Cities Service
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation formally began its $5 billion takeover bid for the Cities Service Company by starting a tender offer of $63 a share for 51 percent of Cities Service's common stock.   The offer had been announced last week following a struggle between Cities Service and the Mesa Petroleum Company to gain control of one another.

headline: Funds' Merger Set
abstract: Directors of Scudder Duo-Vest Inc. and Scudder Special Fund have approved a proposed merger of the two funds. The merger will be taxfree for the shareholders of both funds. Shareholders of Scudder Duo-Vest, a dual-purpose fund offering both capital and income-share stock, met yesterday to approve the change of the fund's name to Scudder Capital Growth Fund which will be the new fund's name if the merger is approved by stockholders of both funds at meetings in September.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: For all the fierceness of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's words, for all the reiteration of lofty principle, Britain has considerably scaled down in the last month its terms for settlement of the deepening crisis in the Falkland Islands.   No change has been publicly acknowledged. The Government has behaved as if the positions it outlined after the islands were captured April 2 remain intact. But change there has been, and not only in the confidential surroundings of the negotiating room; much of the softening of British policy can be traced in public statements.

headline: PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: URGES END TO FALKLAND WAR
abstract: Pope John Paul II arrived in this proud but war weary nation today praying for peace in the Falkland Islands and asking that the British and Argentine Governments pursue it.   Shivering in the face of gusting winds and a steadily increasing drizzle, the Pope refused to head for cover as he read his speech in Spanish on the tarmac of Ezeiza International Airport.   ''Allow me, from this very moment,'' he said, in a theme he would repeat throughout the day, ''to invoke the peace of Christ on all victims of both sides left by the war conflict between Argentina and Great Britain.''   ''Let me demand from the governments and the international community,'' he added, ''suitable measures to avoid greater damage, to heal the wounds of war and to favor the reestablishment of the terms of a just and durable peace and for the gradual appeasement of the spirits.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Beverly Enterprises, Pasadena, Calif., has appointed J. Calvin Kaylor president of its newly created division, Heritage Health Care, in Washington, D.C.   * Chemical Bank has named Howard W. Dates 3d, Stephen J. Conlin, Raymond J. Coady, Gautam Chakravartty and F. Jak Amato vice presidents.   * Computer Products Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has appointed J.  Earl Templeton executive vice president and chief operating officer.

headline: Arms Negotiator Sees No Change in Position
abstract: Edward L. Rowny, head of the United States delegation to the strategic arms talks that are to open here on Tuesday, said today that the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. should have no impact on the negotiations.   Mr. Rowny, a retired Army lieutenant general, said on his arrival here from Washington that he had received ''final approval to my instructions'' at a lunch with President Reagan and Mr. Haig on Friday.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Israel's main risk in the invasion of southern Lebanon is not resistance by the Palestine Liberation Organization, but the possibility that the operation will provoke a strong military response from Syria.   Israeli intelligence experts agree that Syria is the Arab country best prepared militarily and psychologically for war.  British analysts believe that Syrian will react immediately if the Israeli tanks that are now thrust into Lebanon should veer toward the Bekkaa Valley. Since the end of the 1973 Arab-Israeli war, the Syrian high command has considered that valley the sector most dangerous in the event of war with Israel. Its possession would enable an Israeli force to bypass the main Syrian defenses and push north into central Syria.

headline: NEW INVESTMENT IN FOTOMAT
abstract: The Konishiroku Photo Industry Company, a leading Japanese manufacturer of photographic products and the makers of Konica cameras, said yesterday that it would invest $13.5 million in the Fotomat Corporation in exchange for an increase in its stake in the large photofinishing retail chain to 20 percent from 8 percent.   The agreement would give Fotomat needed capital and help it prepare for the boom in disk camera sales that is expected this year, analysts said. In return, Konishiroku, Fotomat's prime supplier of color paper and film, would gain the right to place two directors on Fotomat's board.

headline: CITY OF SHEFFIELD MOURNS SAILORS LOST ON DESTROYER
abstract: Under lazy spring skies the people of Sheffield gathered today for a memorial service to the 24 sailors lost last week off the Falklands.   Provost Frank Curtis said the gathering of 1,000 people was the largest he could remember at Sheffield Cathedral. The crowd overflowed the Cathedral and several hundred residents listened to the service over loudspeakers on the grassy forecourt.   ''When we heard she'd been damaged beyond repair, there was an incredulous shock reaction,'' Mr.  Curtis told the group, as he stood in the stone pulpit bathed in the glare of television lights.  ''Something of us had been destroyed.''

headline: GHOTBZADEH ADMITS ROLE IN PLOT
abstract: Iran's former Foreign Minister, Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, confessed on Iranian television to receiving money in connection with a reported assassination attempt against Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Teheran radio said today.   ''I am shamed before the nation. Free me or execute me,'' Mr.  Ghotbzadeh was quoted as saying by an exile source.  Mr. Ghotbzadeh, whose face became familiar to millions of Americans as a spokesman for the Teheran Government during the hostage crisis, reportedly admitted in the interview that he had received money from an aide to a religious leader, who was stripped of his titles in connection with the plot. However, the religious leader, Ayatollah Kazem Shariatmadari, 82 years old, has not been officially charged in the plot, according to a revolutionary guard spokesman.

headline: LONDON REPORTS NEW CLASH AT SEA
abstract: The Defense Ministry reported today that missilefiring British helicopters sank an Argentine patrol vessel and damaged another ship early this morning in a clash off the Falkland Islands.   The attack came 10 hours after a British submarine torpedoed the Argentine cruiser General Belgrano. British military sources said tonight they believed that the cruiser had sunk. In Buenos Aires, an Argentine communique confirmed that the ship, which carried a crew of 1,042 men, had been lost.

headline: INVENTORY AND THE ECONOMY
abstract: Typically, when a recession ends, businesses are caught with empty shelves and scramble to raise raw material inventories and production. This provides momentum to the entire economy.   ''Usually, early in a recovery, demand for inventories suddenly grows rapidly, and purchasing agents can't raise inventories as fast as they wish,'' said Albert T. Sommers, chief economist at the Conference Board, a business research organization. ''In the first six months of the recovery, the economy usually moves from substantial liquidation of inventories to substantial accumulation, and that's a great kick to the business cycle.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: President Reagan's proposal for cuts in the strategic nuclear arsenals of the Soviet Union and the United States seems as if it ought to meet the common objective of reducing fears on both sides. But it is generally agreed that it is going to be very hard to translate the proposal into an agreement.   Any proposal to curb nuclear arms would run into formidable problems at this stage. The starting point is the fact that Soviet and American strengths and weaknesses are almost mirror images of each other. Thus, the United States would try to curtail Soviet advantages in land-based missiles, and the Soviet Union would seek to thwart American leads in submarines that fire ballistic missiles, the submarine-launched missiles themselves, long-range bombers and cruise missiles.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 9, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: 42 SOUTH KOREAN CHRISTIANS ASK RECALL OF 2 TOP U.S. AIDES
abstract: South Korean Christian leaders urged the Reagan Administration today to recall the two top American officials here, because of ''increasing anti-American feeling.''   The request by 42 prominent Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders came six days before Vice President Bush is due here on a visit.The statement also called on President Chun Doo Hwan to restore democratic rule, free political prisoners, halt torture of people suspected of anti-Government activity and reinstate thousands of labor leaders, students and journalists ousted under sweeping ''purification'' campaigns.

headline: Market Place; Health Science Fund's Promise
abstract: PUTNAM HEALTH SCIENCES TRUST appears to have proved that an exciting idea plus a strong marketing effort can overcome shareholder apathy in a bear market. The Putnam Management Company's newest investment vehicle - a mutual fund that will invest exclusively in health science equities - has just sold a quarter of a billion dollars worth of shares.   Putnam, based in Boston, closed the books on the offering last week. Investors must pay for their $15 shares by Friday. It remains to be seen whether the new fund can put the $265 million or so to work in a somewhat limited field. So far, the fund has made no investments.

headline: Nicaragua Condemns U.S. Veto at the U.N.
abstract: Nicaragua said today that Friday night's veto by the United States of a United Nations Security Council resolution against the use of force in Central America confirmed its fears of American ''military aggression'' in the region.   ''Nicaragua shares the alarm of the people of Central America that the United States has used a veto to block a resolution that only confirmed the Magna Carta of the United Nations,'' a Government statement said.

headline: G.T.E.'S CELLULAR PACT WITH A.T.&T.
abstract: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation today disclosed details of its agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to provide cellular radio telephone service to 29 of the nation's 30 largest cities.   Cellular radio is a new technology expected to revolutionize the mobile telephone business by making radio calls from cars and pocket phones almost as common as calling from home.   Earlier this month, the Federal Communications Commission accepted applications to provide cellular radio service in the nation's 30 largest cities. A.T.& T. and G.T.E. subsequently announced a partnership agreement under which they divided up 29 of the 30 markets and brought in smaller telephone companies as minority partners.

headline: Construction Contracts Up
abstract: Contracts for new construction in March rose 8 percent, to $13 billion, from the level of the previous month, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said yesterday. But it added that the numbers did not reflect an upturn in the building industry.

headline: Around the World; U.S. and 6 Other Nations Block Vietnam Food Aid
abstract: The United States, along with Argentina, Canada, West Germany, Japan, Thailand and Britain, have blocked a $5.3 million food-aid program for Vietnam at the executive council meeting of the United Nations World Food Program, the agency's officials reported today.   Nguyen Anm Vu, the Vietnamese delegate, accused the United States of using technical ''pretexts to hide its political hostility'' toward Vietnam and to prevent the agency from extending food aid to his country.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM MAGAZINE ARTICLE ON ARMS POLICY
abstract: Following are excerpts from an article in the spring issue of Foreign Affairs, the journal of the Council on Foreign Relations Inc,, written by McGeorge Bundy, George F. Kennan, Robert S. McNamara and Gerard Smith:   For 33 years now, the Atlantic alliance has relied on the asserted readiness of the United States to use nuclear weapons if necessary to repel aggression from the East. Initially, indeed, it was widely thought (notably by such great and different men as Winston Churchill and Niels Bohr) that the basic military balance in Europe was between American atomic bombs and the massive conventional forces of the Soviet Union. But the first Soviet explosion, in August 1949, ended the American monopoly only one month after the Senate approved the North Atlantic Treaty, and in 1950 Communist aggression in Korea produced new allied attention to the defense of Europe.

headline: IN VIETNAM, AN EX-AIDE SPEAKS OUT
abstract: Dr. Quong Quynh Hoa, who says she is Vietnam's only Communist-era Cabinet Minister to resign, runs a research center at Ho Chi Minh City's Pediatric Hospital 2.   She says Vietnam is worse off now medically and nutritionally than it was two years ago, when rice harvests were poorer than last year's.   The reasons for such difficulties, she says, have at least as much to do with mismanagement, rigid doctrine, disastrous planning and Communist hostility to bourgeois technicians, administrators, farmers and others as they have to do with decades of destructive war.   Politically and economically, she said in an interview earlier this month, Vietnam is ''feudal'' - ''a gerontocracy'' and ''a failure.'' Dr. Hoa offers such outspoken criticism from a better vantage point than most Vietnamese. A high-ranking Communist Party member from 1959 to 1979, she was Health Minister in South Vietnam's Provisional Revolutionary Government from 1969 to 1976.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE   CLABIR CORPORATION-Henry D. Clarke Jr., chairman, sold 34,400 shares leaving him directly with 804,817 shares.

headline: Petro-Lewis
abstract: The Petro-Lewis Corporation said its proven oil and gas reserves were estimated to be 74.4 million equivalent barrels of oil, split evenly between gas and oil, representing a 44 percent increase from a year ago. The acquisition of producing oil and gas properties, as well as successful drilling efforts, accounted for the increase, said Jerome A. Lewis, chairman and chief executive of Petro-Lewis.

headline: KUWAIT'S BUSTLING STOCK SOUK
abstract: It's called Souk al-Manakh, but it has very little in common with the old Arab markets, the souks of Cairo and Damascus, where jewelers and antique dealers are wedged in between spice and cloth merchants in men sit pensively in cafes looking out into space.    Here everything is frantic and feverish and new. The building, barely completed, is an ultramodern structure with air-conditioning, escalators and ramps leading to the parking areas on each of the five floors. What is traded here is money - large quantities of money.

headline: Dataproducts President Will Also Become Chief
abstract: Charles A. Dickinson, the 58-year-old president of the Dataproducts Corporation, a major manufacturer of computer printers, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer.  He succeeds Graham Tyson, 59, who will continue as chairman of the company, which has headquarters in Woodland Hills, Calif.

headline: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japan to Alter Trade Rules
abstract: Japan will soon disclose another program to liberalize import restrictions to fend off growing United States and European criticism of Japan's restricted markets, a top Government spokesman said today.   The Chief Cabinet Secretary, Kiichi Miyazawa, said that the second round of revised regulations is to be completed during a special economic affairs Cabinet meeting scheduled for May 7.

headline: DOW SOARS IN HEAVY TRADING
abstract: Stock prices soared yesterday as big institutional investors poured cash into the market, encouraged by forecasts that the market would continue to rally. Trading volume of 71.8 million shares was the seventh-heaviest turnover in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.   ''I think you're seeing a buying panic by institutions,'' said William G. Garrison, president of Garrison, Keogh & Company, an investment advisory firm.   The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 9.04 points, to 862.16, reaching a 12-week high. It climbed 9.70 on Thursday for a two-day gain of 18.74 points, which was also the gain for the week. The Dow has advanced in each of the last six weeks, the first time since the autumn of 1972 that the market has risen in so many consecutive weeks.

headline: CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: China Says the Strain in Ties With U.S. Won't Affect Japan
abstract: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China assured Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki today that China's solid economic and political ties with Japan will be unaffected by any backsliding of relations with the United States.   Officials said that in the two-hour meeting with Mr. Suzuki, Mr.  Zhao said there had been no improvement in strained China-United States relations.

headline: KOCH'S FUND RAISER GETS EARLY SUPPORT
abstract: When New York State Comptroller Ned Regan dropped out of the governor's race a few weeks ago, he gave as one reason his inability to compete for campaign funds against Mayor Koch. Now the Mayor's fund raising drive is moving into full swing, and it appears that some of the city's wealthiest and most powerful businessmen are indeed jumping on the Koch bandwagon.   The Mayor's key man on Wall Street is Kenneth Lipper, 40, a partner at Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm. After only two weeks on the job as Mr. Koch's campaign finance chairman, Mr. Lipper has persuaded an impressive list of New York City executives to join the team.

headline: Warner-Lambert to Acquire IMED at Cost of $465 Million
abstract: The Warner-Lambert Company, a major pharmaceutical concern, said yesterday that it would acquire all the shares of the IMED Corporation, a San Diego-based maker of medical electronic equipment, for $465 million, or $163 a share.   The move is a major part of Warner-Lambert's plan under Ward S.  Hagan, chairman, to enter the rapidly expanding business of hightechnology health care, a strategy that most of the major drug companies have been aggressively pursuing in the last few years, while divesting some consumer products.   The price, about 23 times IMED's expected earnings of $20 million for 1982, startled industry analysts, who said that the purchase would have a negative effect on Warner-Lambert's earnings for the next three years, force it to borrow anywhere from $100 million to $250 million, and dilute its share price.

headline: Solar Cell Development
abstract: Sumitomo Electric Industries said it had developed with the Kansai Electric Power Company of Japan a new solar cell using a gallium arsenite semiconductor device. The company said it needed more time before it begins commercial production as gallium arsenite is still costly, but said the new cell could attain a much higher heat-electricity conversion efficiency than cells using other devices such as silicon. Sumitomo said it would be suitable for highly concentrated photovoltaic systems including a power source for satellites, as its resistance to high temperature and radiation is strong.

headline: Abitibi, Union End Talks
abstract: Contract talks have broken down between Abitibi-Price Inc., the world's largest newsprint producer, and the paperworkers' union, opening the way for a strike next month at eastern Canada paper mills, the union said today.   James Buchanan, president of the Canadian Paperworkers' Union, said the talks were called off late yesterday because ''the company was moving a little slow.''

headline: CHASE SELLS DRYSDALE'S BONDS
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday began the laborious job of liquidating $4.5 billion in bonds at Drysdale Government Securities to convert the mountain of paper to cash in the wake of Chase's surprise decision to pay off Drysdale's debts to Wall Street dealers.    The total - interest payments already due and to come due over the coming year - is expected to reach $270 million. The approximately $160 million that came due last Monday has already been paid by Chase to 30 or so dealers in Government securities.   The payments represent the interest on Treasury bills and notes that Drysdale had temporarily purchased from the other dealers with the understanding that it would pass on to these dealers the interest paid periodically on the securities by the Government. Besides the $160 million that came due Monday, an additional $110 million in interest will come due later this year.

headline: OUSTED ARGENTINE LEADER IS A VICTIM OF SYSTEM THAT RAISED HIM TO POWER
abstract: Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri was the victim of Argentina's defeat on the Falkland Islands by British, a defeat he brought on by ordering the islands seized 11 weeks ago.   But the military system through which General Galtieri rose to rule Argentina remains, and that system will largely determine the country's direction.   ''The cohesion of the armed forces is definite,'' said Col.  Bernardo Menendez, Deputy Minister of the Interior.  The military is often described here as a political party, one made more powerful by guns. It has either directly ruled the nation or manipulated it through controlled elections for 34 of the last 52 years.

headline: Two Men Are Shot to Death In Separate Attacks in Ulster
abstract: A Protestant and a Roman Catholic were shot to death in separate attacks in Northern Ireland today, the police said.

headline: CAMBEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Britain Denies Afghan Charge On the Smuggling of Treasure
abstract: The Foreign Ministry said today that charges of treasure smuggling against a prominent British archeologist imprisoned in Afghanistan were ''absolute nonsense.''

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: THE J. Walter Thompson Company, which suspended and then dismissed the head of its TV spot buying earlier this year after the disclosure of $30 million of computer accounting irregularities, has lost the Lever Brothers assignment as its agency of record for all spot buying.   The United States subsidiary of Unilever, on Friday, notified its two other major agencies, Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, and Ogilvy & Mather, that they would divide the assignment, while Lever would continue to buy network television in-house.   The story that came out of the huge JWT Group holding company, beginning with the suspension of Marie Luisi in February, was that no Thompson client had been improperly billed.

headline: Other Business; GOSPEL MUSIC ON THE ASCENT
abstract: The marquee four doors away offers a live nude revue for a quarter. A man on the street outside peddles ''loose joints.'' But in the sanctity of the Christian Publications Book Store near Times Square, gospel records are the hot items. About 1,000 are sold each month, the store manager, Gary Gin, says.   As recently as 1977, gospel record sales had been so minuscule that they had been included in the ''all others'' category of national record sales, accounting for only 3 percent of the record and tape market along with less popular music, according to Warner Communications. But by 1980 they accounted for roughly 5 percent of the $3.6 billion market, according to Warner's most recent survey.

headline: Israeli Police Question Maimed Arab Mayor
abstract: Bassam al-Shaka, the deposed mayor of Nablus in the occupied West Bank, was detained for questioning by the Israeli police in Nablus today after his Israeli bodyguards complained that he had cursed them and spat at them in the town's central square.   He was released after an hour and a half, according to a source in the military government.

headline: Talks Start in Geneva On Afghan Settlement
abstract: The Foreign Ministers of Pakistan and the Soviet-backed Afghanistan regime met here separately today with Under Secretary General Diego Cordoves of the United Nations for the start of talks on settling the conflict in Afghanistan.

headline: Higher Cable Commissions
abstract: It is the observation of John Slaven, ad director of Volkswagen, that most interest in cable television is coming from the client rather than the agency side. Nicely, he exempts his own agency, Doyle Dane Bernbach.

headline: RATES ON U.S. ISSUES DECLINE
abstract: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday for all maturities of Government securities as the Federal Reserve continued its aggressive policy of injecting liquidity into the money market.  Although the tax-exempt and corporate bond markets were slow to respond to the stimulus, prices of better-grade issues managed to finish moderately higher for the day.   The market's initial recovery reflected a return of confidence following the shock caused by the default of Drysdale Government Securtiies. However, dealers said the rebound became pronounced after the Federal Reserve entered the market just before noon to, in effect, drive down the key overnight lending rate through four-day repurchase agreements.

headline: Israelis Are Censoring Accounts of Invasion
abstract: All dispatches filed by correspondents from Israel on the Israeli invasion of southern Lebanon are subject to censorship by the military authorities. Last Sunday, the Israelis extended military censorship to accounts issued by the United Nations on the fighting.

headline: ARABS EASE U.N. ATTACK ON ISRAEL
abstract: Arab nations, under pressure from other third-world countries, today abandoned their plan to expel Israel from the General Assembly.   Instead, the Arab group is circulating a document, due to be approved on Wednesday, that condemns Israel for what the document calls the mistreatment of Palestinian Arabs and condemns Israel's supporters, notably the United States.   This text marks a substantial softening of the Arab group's original draft, which asserted that Israel ''has persistently violated'' the United Nations Charter and called on the Assembly ''to review Israel's status'' at the next session in September.

headline: THATCHER ANSWER TO THE POPE
abstract: Following is the text of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's reply to Pope John Paul II on his appeal for a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands, as made public by 10 Downing Street:   LONDON, May 24 (AP) - Following is the text of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's reply to Pope John Paul II on his appeal for a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands, as made public by 10 Downing Street:   We share the anguish which you express at the loss of life in the tragic conflict over the Falkland Islands. I deeply respect the reasons which led you to send your message and should like to reply in the same spirit of frankness and candor.   The conflict was not of our making. It was the Argentine forces who invaded the islands and broke the peace. We have striven for seven weeks to secure a negotiated settlement but Argentina has shown no disposition to match our endeavors in good faith. A cease-fire has to be accompanied by withdrawal of Argentine troops. To do otherwise would leave the aggressor in occupation and in possession of the rewards of military adventure.

headline: American Lost in Thai Gulf
abstract: An American oil company worker and a Canadian pilot were among 12 people missing when a helicopter crashed en route to a natural gas production rig in the Gulf of Siam, a provincial police officer said today. He did not identify the men.

headline: SHELL CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A.M.C.'S HOPES FOR A NEW CAR
abstract: Inside turn-of-the-century buildings that once produced mattresses and bicycles, the American Motors Corporation is preparing for what is probably its last effort to remain a volume manufacturer of passenger cars.   A.M.C. is set to begin production of the Alliance, a front-wheeldrive subcompact model, next month, with public introduction scheduled for early in September. The company said it hopes to sell 100,000 Alliances in 1983.   The badges on the backs of some pilot production cars tell of their ancestry. On the right is the familiar A.M.C. logo; on the left is the Renault emblem. The Alliance, in fact, is an Americanized version of the French company's R-9 model, which was introduced in Europe last year. It is about the size of a Ford Escort, but is classified as a five-passenger, rather than a four-passenger, car.

headline: Doyle Dane and F.C.&B.  Conclude Merger Talks
abstract: The driving desire for hugeness brought Foote, Cone & Belding and Doyle Dane Bernbach together for quiet exploratory talks on the subject of merger. But they ended Friday with an announcement that the ''discussions have be amicably terminated.''

headline: GROUP ATTACKS ENERGY PLAN
abstract: In a major criticism of the federal energy program, Canada's oil and gas industry warned today that the official goal of energy self-sufficiency by 1990 would not be attained within the framework of present policy.   The Canadian Petroleum Association, the umbrella trade group for the major domestic and foreign companies operating in Canada, said the policy had reduced the industry's cash flow by 30 percent, ''in turn, drastically limiting the ability of oil companies to finance the activities which, over the long term, would make the nation selfsufficient and secure.''   The association delivered its attack today in full-page newspaper advertisements, before a committee of the House of Commons and finally at a news conference. The parliamentary committee is considering a bill to create a system of exploration incentives that would favor Canadian-controlled companies.

headline: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Moscow Backs the West On Nuclear Talks Plan
abstract: In a surprise last-minute reversal, the Soviet bloc today joined the West and nonaligned nations in backing a proposal to have a special working group try to break an impasse on talks on a nuclear test ban, Western diplomats said.   Louis G. Fields Jr., the United States representative at the talks, called the Soviet move significant for the future of arms control.

headline: Holiday Closings
abstract: On Monday, all United States stock and commodities markets and most businesses will be closed for Memorial Day. In addition, some markets in Britain and on the Continent will be closed in observance of the Whitsun holiday.

headline: Investing; SOME SOLID COMPANIES FOR A SAFETY NET
abstract: "BUSINESS balance sheets and corporate liquidity are more fragile than at any other time in the postwar period,'' warns Allen Sinai of Data Resources Inc., and who could argue?   The headlong borrowing of past years, when companies counted on paying off debts with inflation-cheapened dollars, laid the groundwork for the present precarious situation. Recession and unrelenting interest rates have brought matters to a head. More companies went bankrupt the week before last than in any other week in half a century.

headline: LOW SOVIET CROP IN FORECAST
abstract: The Agriculture Department today sharply reduced its earlier estimate of this year's Soviet grain crop, forecasting that the Russians would harvest only 185 million metric tons because of poor growing conditions this spring in the major crop areas.   If the revised forecast is accurate, it would be the fourth consecutive year of disappointing harvests for the Soviet Union, which has become the world's leading importer of grains. Last month, the forecast was for 200 million tons.

headline: INVESTOR GROUP IS SUED BY SOUTHEAST BANKING
abstract: The Southeast Banking Corporation filed a suit yesterday charging that a group of local investors tried to manipulate its stock. The group already has obtained a 9.59 percent interest in Southeast, Florida's largest banking organization.   In the suit, filed in Miami's Federal District Court, Southeast charged that the group had violated Federal securities laws by making false and misleading statements and by omitting certain material information in a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Lane Bryant Bid
abstract: Limited Stores Inc. said it had received and accepted for payment more than 90 percent of the outstanding shares of Lane Bryant Inc. in response to its tender offer for all shares at $29 each. The offer expired yesterday.

headline: HAIG REPORTED SHORT OF GOAL AS HE LEAVES BUENOS AIRES
abstract: Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had left Buenos Aires with some movement from the Argentine side, but not enough progress to assure an early resolution of the dispute between Argentina and Britain over the Falkland Islands.   But as Mr. Haig's Air Force plane was heading north, an air of mystery developed concerning its ultimate destination. Upon leaving Buenos Aires this afternoon, Mr. Haig said he had finished ''this stage of our work,'' that he was making the results available to Britain and ''I am returning to Washington to report to the President.''   Later in the day, however, State Department officials said that it was possible that Mr. Haig might not fly directly to Washington, but might go to London if he received additional signs of flexibility from the Argentines while he is still in the air, or if the British Government asked him to come.

headline: Britoil Stock Sale
abstract: The sale to the public of 51 percent of the stock of Britoil will take place before the end of the year if market conditions permit, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Geoffrey Howe, said today.

headline: Times Co.  Net Up 56% In Quarter
abstract: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its firstquarter net income rose 56 percent, to a quarterly record of $18.96 million, or $1.51 a share, from $12.1 million, or 98 cents a share, in the first quarter last year.   The earnings included a $4.2 million gain from last year's sale of the company's Australian magazine interests. An additional gain of about the same amount will be realized in the current quarter when the final payment for the purchase is received in May.

headline: U.S. Oil Imports to Rise
abstract: The Energy Department forecast United States net oil imports would increase from 3.7 million barrels a day in the first half of 1982 to 5.4 million barrels a day in the second half. It forecast a 3 percent drop in petroleum consumption in 1982 compared with 1981.

headline: Quebec Takeovers
abstract: The government of Quebec is exploring the possible purchase of 40 percent of Gulf Canada Ltd.'s assets in the province, Premier Rene Levesque said. Mr. Levesque said the province is also involved in similar talks with Ultramar Canada Inc. and B.P. Canada Ltd. Finance Minister Jacques Parizeau said talks are at an early stage and could last several years.

headline: Salomon Reports 6% Columbia Stake
abstract: Salomon Brothers Inc., the large investment banking firm, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it held 6 percent of the common stock of Columbia Pictures Industries.   Salomon Brothers, which was acquired by the Phibro Corporation last September, said it held the equivalent of 507,900 common shares of Columbia, comprising 421,150 common shares and $3.5 million principal amount of debentures convertible into 87,750 common shares.   The stock and debentures were purchased for $31.7 million by Salomon Brothers and were acquired for arbitrage purposes in the proposed merger of Columbia into the Coca-Cola Company, according to the filing.

headline: HITACHI APPROACH REPORTED
abstract: The president of a small firm of computer designers said today that executives of Hitachi Ltd. had asked him last August to obtain several volumes of confidential workbooks for computers being introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation.   Maxwell O. Paley, president and chief executive of Palyn Associates Inc., said he had refused.  ''I said: 'That's illegal. We're not going to do it,' '' he stated in an interview from his office in San Jose, Calif.  Hitachi officials in Tokyo earlier this week said it was Palyn Associates who first put Hitachi representives in touch with Glenmar Associates, an undercover operation run by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The Hitachi officials said that Palyn Associates had been a trusted consulting concern for seven years.

headline: HINDUS SEEK TO REVISE ROLE IN INDIA'S HISTORY
abstract: A former Government official is campaigning for acceptance of his belief that the Taj Mahal and other Indian tombs and shrines credited to Moslem emperors were actually built by Hindu rulers.   As founder and president of the Institute for Rewriting Indian History, the former official, P.N. Oak, is the author of 15 books asserting that the Mogul and other Moslem rulers merely desecrated and occupied architectural masterpieces that were designed by Hindus.    Historians here and abroad reject his thesis, but his writings reflect a discomfort in this predominantly Hindu nation that so much of its documented history concerns the periods of Moslem and British rule.

headline: Guilford Mills Set To Sell Its Assets
abstract: Guilford Mills Inc., a fabric company based in Greensboro, N.C., said that it had agreed in principle to sell its assets to some of its senior executives and two other investors, including Harold S.  Geneen, a former chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, for $23 a share in cash.   Other buyers include the company's chairman, Charles A. Hayes; its vice chairman, Maurice Fishman, and its president, George Greenberg, who together own about 42 percent of Guilford's common shares.

headline: QUEBEC TRIES TO OVERRIDE PART OF CONSTITUTION
abstract: Quebec, which has always proclaimed the right to be different, moved this week to prevent the application of large sections of Canada's new Constitution to the province.   Three weeks after Queen Elizabeth II proclaimed the Constitution in Ottawa, Premier Rene Levesque's government introduced a bill in the National Assembly that uses one section of the basic law to nullify others that deal with rights and freedoms. And with the bill's expected passage before summer, Quebecers will not live under the same bill of rights as other Canadians.   Mr. Levesque thus sought to make good his vow to reject a Constitution that he feels infringes on the powers of the Quebec Assembly and to make its application in the largely French-speaking province as difficult and complicated as possible. Alone among the 10 provinces, Quebec refused to sign an agreement reached last November between Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and the nine premiers of English-speaking Canada that finally led to the country's constitutional independence from Britain.

headline: SORG PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GYPSY LEADER SAYS PERSECUTION IS CONTINUING
abstract: For the last several years, an English-born man popularly known as the ''king of the gypsies'' has organized campaigns on behalf of his people from a home in the slum quarters of this northern Greek city.   ''We want an end to persecution,'' said 42-year-old Grattan Puxon, who for 11 years has been the elected secretary general of the World Romany Congress, an organization of gypsies, or Roma, as they prefer to be called.   The congress, which is based in Belgrade, says it speaks for all 10 million gypsies around the world. Four million live in Eastern Europe and 2 million in the West.

headline: U.S.-Thai War Games Set
abstract: Warplanes, 28 naval vessels and more than 8,000 Thai and American military personnel will begin military exercises in the Gulf of Siam next month, officials announced today. The two-week exercise, called ''Cobra Gold 82,'' is designed to ''enhance the spirit of cooperation and readiness of the naval forces of both countries,'' the United States Embassy said. The war games, which will include naval operations and amphibious landings on the Thai coast, are scheduled for June 2-14, although some smaller-scale activities will start at the end of this month.

headline: SOVIET AGAIN ASSAILS ISRAELIS BUT SHOWS CAUTION ON CRISIS
abstract: Pravda condemned Israel again today for its invasion of Lebanon but a commentary in the Soviet Communist Party newspaper offered no indication that the Kremlin was preparing to abandon the cautious diplomatic stand it has observed since the fighting began.   The Pravda article reiterated Soviet charges that Israel's objectives in the invasion were to destroy the Palestinian Liberation Organization, to establish a pliant government in Lebanon and to weaken Syria so that it, too, would fall in line with what Pravda called the ''second stage'' of the Camp David agreement signed in 1978 by Israel, Egypt and the United States.   The Soviet paper said that the Camp David idea was ''to beat the Arabs, one by one,'' beginning with Egypt. The aim now is to add the P.L.O., Lebanon and Syria to the list, it added, thus making it possible for Israel to impose its conditions for autonomy on Palestinians living on the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip and to make the Israeli occupation of those areas permanent.

headline: PLANS TO LIFT TAXES DIVIDE BUSINESS
abstract: Robert E. Lighthizer, chief counsel of the Senate Finance Committee, says that the pattern of business tax lobbying this year is best portrayed by Senator Russell B. Long's ditty: ''Don't tax you, don't tax me, tax that fellow behind the tree.''   ''They're objecting to everything,'' Mr. Lighthizer says of the business lobbyists. ''Their general rule is: Look and see if you're going to be paying more; if you are, you're against it.''   In 1981, at a time of tax cutting, the business community was largely united. It supported tax measures that relaxed depreciation write-offs. The unity came even though depreciation is worth relatively little to some industries, such as services and trade, that are labor intensive.

headline: Real Estate; Research Venture at Polytechnic
abstract: IN Philadelphia, the city and a group of colleges and universities have built the University City Science Center, a 16-acre complex bound by the University of Pennsylvania and Drexel University. The center consists of nine buildings designed to house scientific research activity.   In Cambridge, Mass., the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a private developer and the city began a similar development project 20 years ago called Technology Square, a 14-acre complex with a million square feet of office and research buildings.   Neither project was an overnight success. They were years in the making, but now they are fully leased and are considered highly successful. Many major cities, including New York, would like to duplicate those achievements.

headline: Small Business Bill Advances
abstract: A bill to give small businesses a bigger share of the $40 billion that the Federal Government spends on research and development each year won House approval today.   The legislation would require major Federal agencies to set aside a portion of their research and development funds for work by small businesses.

headline: AMERICAN GENERAL BID BY NLT
abstract: In what analysts called a defensive riposte, the NLT Corporation of Nashville, an insurance company, yesterday announced a tender offer worth more than $600 million to raise its stake in the American General Corporation to 50.2 percent from the present 2.2 percent.   Houston-based American General, also a major insurance company, had offered $1 billion in stock for NLT on April 16.  At NLT's headquarters, Walter M. Robinson Jr., its chairman, president and chief executive officer, said: ''We have been hearing that some people regard this as a trading gambit. It is not a trading gambit. We feel we'll be successful.''

headline: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MRS. THATCHER CONSULTS URGENTLY WITH COLLEAGUES
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher consulted with colleagues by telephone tonight as anxiety mounted here over the continuing deadlock in peace negotiations in Buenos Aires.   The Prime Minister's urgent calls, placed from her office at 10 Downing Street, marked the second time in the last 24 hours she had canvassed the opinion of Government members on the Falklands crisis.  Last night she met for two hours with the members of the crisis cabinet - Francis Pym, the Foreign Secretary, John Nott, the Defense Minister, and William Whitelaw, the Home Secretary, who also acts as the Deputy Prime Minister.   For the last three days, Mrs. Thatcher has been awaiting word from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on the outcome of his talks with the Argentine junta. Late tonight, she was still waiting.

headline: Rights Group Says Morocco Tortures Political Prisoners
abstract: Moroccan authorities are holding political prisoners incommunicado for months, even years, and torturing many of them, the human-rights group Amnesty International said today.   In a report on a mission to Morocco in February 1981, the Londonbased organization said the Moroccan authorities had failed to account for hundreds of prisoners, some of whom, it said, had died in deplorable conditions.

headline: INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dole Backs Simpler Taxation, Lower Rates and Wider Base
abstract: Senator Bob Dole, speaking as chairman of the tax-writing Finance Committee, declared his support today for a ''step-by-step'' evolution of the Federal income tax in the direction of lower rates, simpler rules and a broader taxable-income base.   ''This is the time for advocates of a simpler and fairer tax system - and I consider myself one of them - to come forward and take the first steps that are needed,'' the Kansas Republican said in a prepared statement he read to the committee.   He reaffirmed an earlier promise that the committee would hold hearings this year on proposals for a ''flat,'' or single-rate, income tax. 'Dramatic Demonstration'   Indicating that he thought tax simplification combined with rate reduction could be politically rewarding, Senator Dole referred to the statement of support for such tax revision adopted by the Democratic conference in Philadelphia. ''Over the weekend, we saw a dramatic demonstration of the growing support for a lower-rate, much simpler income tax,'' he said.

headline: QUEEN IS IN CANADA TO PROCLAIM NEW CHARTER
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II arrived in her Canadian dominion today to preside over the transition of constitutional power from London to Ottawa.   The British sovereign, who flew here as Queen of Canada aboard a Canadian Air Force jet, will proclaim the Constitution Act Saturday at a ceremony on Parliament Hill. That will end the British North America Act of 1867, this country's constitution up to now.

headline: UNEASY MOOD EMERGING IN EGYPT OVER THE RELATIONSHIP WITH ISRAEL
abstract: The announcement today of at least a partial cease-fire in Lebanon has done little to ease the pains of Egypt's leaders and people, who in the last week have been almost as humiliated in their peace with Israel as they had been in war.   In general, there is a widespread and somber feeling here that by moving its forces into Lebanon, Israel was contemptuously taking the peace offered by Egypt for granted and thus exposing this country's impotence and isolation. At the same time, editorials in the press here, the terse statements of the nation's leaders and the inert placidity of street life seemed to reaffirm that Egypt has very little leverage over Israel.   The official condemnation of the Israeli onslaught has been impassioned and clear. Yet there has been no serious attempt on the part of any public official to urge a retreat from the process of normalizing relations with Israel that was set in motion by the Camp David accords.

headline: DETROIT: A SIGN OF THE TIMES
abstract: DETROIT The billboards along this city's busiest expressways flipped an extra digit on March 26, showing that Detroit had built one million cars so far this year. It was, however, no time for rejoicing. Last year, the million mark was hit exactly one month earlier, and that wasn't exactly a banner production rate either.

headline: GULF AND WESTERN TO SELL CIGAR UNIT
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell its Consolidated Cigar Company subsidiary to MacAndrews & Forbes Group, a Philadelphia-based chocolate producer, for more than $100 million in cash and notes.   Gulf and Western said that the sale of Consolidated, the leading cigar manufacturer in the United States, was in keeping with its previously stated policy of restructuring and streamlining its operations and reallocating assets.

headline: Oxoco Acquisition
abstract: Oxoco Inc., an oil and gas exploration company based in Houston, said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the privately held Hawthorn Oil and Gas Company for about $32 million.

headline: CHINESE PROVINCE HAS SEVERE FLOOD
abstract: China's populous southeastern province of Guangdong has begun recovering from severe floods that marooned 450,000 people and left at least 430 dead.   The floods, said to be the worst in Guangdong in 30 years, came after torrential rains early May 12. They affected over a million people in northern and western Guangdong and raised fears that Canton might be threatened.

headline: 'GENERALS FOR PEACE' PUSH CASE AT U.N.
abstract: In Cyprus, on his last post, Brig.  Michael Harbottle first discovered that swords are best beaten into ploughshares.   He was commanding the United Nations peacekeepers on the island in 1967 when Gen. George Grivas, leader of the Greek nationalist guerrillas, threatened to clean out suspected Turkish Cypriot fighters in a village.   ''I told Grivas he'd have to fight us first,'' Brigadier Harbottle recalled the other day. ''Grivas withdrew without a shot fired, one of many problems we dealt with without using any force.''

headline: GULF'S PURSUIT OF CITIES SERVICE
abstract: For weeks, the Gulf Oil Corporation had been flirting with the Cities Service Company. But the betrothal, which could lead to one of the biggest corporate acquisitions on record, was negotiated during 36 high-pressure hours that included marathon meetings at several Park Avenue addresses and last-minute telephone calls between the chairmen of the two companies.   In an unusual move for a merger of this size, Gulf did not use the services of an investment banker.  In a joint announcement Thursday, Gulf said that it planned to buy 51 percent of Cities Service stock for $63 a share in cash in a $5.1 billion deal that would create the nation's seventh-largest industrial corporation. Gulf said that it would buy the remainder of Cities Service stock with fixed-income securities valued at ''no less than $63'' a share.

headline: Italy Holds Terror Suspect
abstract: A part-time teacher believed sympathetic to West German terrorist causes was arrested carrying a bomb in a suitcase with a false bottom at Rome's Leonardo da Vinci Airport, authorities said today. Police sources said the woman, who flew in from Bucharest Friday, declared herself a ''political prisoner'' and refused to answer questions. She was identified as Christa Margot Frohlich, 40 years old, a resident of Hanover, West Germany.

headline: PYRAMID OIL CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Heinz Net Off 5.4% in Period
abstract: The H.J. Heinz Company said today that net income in its fiscal fourth quarter fell 5.4 percent from a year earlier, but earnings for the full year rose 19.9 percent.   Heinz, which makes and packages food products, said it earned $48.5 million, or $1.03 a share, in the quarter ended April 28.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Co. has named Ronald K. Glover executive vice president of marketing for consumer financial services.   * Avis Inc., Garden City, L.I., has elected Harry Savage vice president of the vehicle rental and leasing company.

headline: REICHHOLD CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PATENTS; Stereoscopic System For Group Viewing
abstract: A stereoscopic picture system patented this week by George F.  Hausherr of Lynbrook, L.I., offers a wide variety of equipment to provide three-dimensional views for one or many persons.

headline: DRIVE-INS, LIKE CHEAP GAS, FADE INTO YESTERYEAR
abstract: They were once the hit of suburbia, in the days when the girls in pedal pushers and the boys in blue jeans packed into '57 Chevies to watch Annette Funicello and Frankie Avalon cavort in ''Beach Blanket Bingo'' or ''Bikini Beach.'' But for many drive-in movie theaters these days, the allure - and the profits - of old are wearing out,   Born in 1934, when Richard Hollingshead aimed a 16-millimeter projector at the back wall of his machine-parts shop in Camden, N.J., drive-ins soon became Hollywood's answer to the threat posed by television. Their oversized screens proliferated through the 1950's and flourished in the 1960's, when Americans in love with their cars drove them just about any place four wheels would go.   By the 1970's, however, drive-ins had begun to go the way of cheap gasoline and big cars. And last year, according to the National Association of Theater Owners, only 3,354 drive-in screens still operated in the United States - down 11 percent from a decade before and more than 17 percent from the 1958 peak of 4,063. In fact, the drop is probably greater, because a growing number of drive-in theaters are operating multi-screen facilities.

headline: AIR FORCE BUSES CARRIED SOME TO CHEER PRESIDENT
