abstract: The Air Force provided 6 to 12 buses to take Congressional aides to and from the Friday evening welcoming ceremonies for President Reagan at Andrews Air Force Base, a Defense Department spokesman said today.   Lieut. Col. Dick Rapp said the buses had been provided ''at the request of leaders of Congress.'' But he said he did not know who the leaders were who had made the request. A spokesman for Representative Robert H. Michel, the House Republican leader, said Mr. Michel had nothing to do with the request and did not know who had made it.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: George P. Shultz, President Reagan's nominee for Secretary of State, will face an unusually large number of international crises as well as continuing institutional tensions between the White House and the State Department.   President Reagan wants to take a firmer line on restricting Western trade with the Soviet Union, which implies dealing more firmly on the issue with Western Europe and Japan.   There are also signs that the President intends to take a stronger position with Israel over further military moves in Lebanon. He is, in addition, expected to urge Britain to settle the Falkland Islands sovereignty dispute with Argentina.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: German Jobless Drop
abstract: West German unemployment dropped by 123,900, to 1,811,400, or 7.6 percent of the work force, in March, the federal Labor Office said today. The equivalent February figures were 1,935,300 unemployed, a rate of 8.1 percent.  The rate in March 1981 was 5.2 percent.

headline: U.S. VISITORS WARN SALVADOR RIGHTISTS ON CENTRIST ROLE
abstract: A high-level Congressional delegation has delivered a strong message to El Salvador's warring political leaders that they must form a broad-based, moderate government committed to economic and social justice if the country is to continue receiving aid from the United States, according to members of the delegation.   The eight-member delegation, headed by Representative James C.  Wright Jr., Democrat of Texas, the House majority leader, arrived at a time when El Salvador's politicians were locked in intense negotiations about the country's social, economic and political future.   ''We were here to deliver a message,'' said a member of the delegation who asked not to be identified.  That message, he explained, is that the Christian Democrats must occupy key positions in the new government. And that government, he added, must continue the economic and social changes begun by the Christian Democrats over the last two years.

headline: ABC Adds New Slots; For Commentary Ads
abstract: Not only will the ABC-TV Network sell time for advocacy advertising in the late night area of programming, from midnight to 1 A.M., as it has offered during its test period, but also from 6 A.M. to 7 A.M. each weekday.

headline: I.B.M. INTRODUCES 3 LARGE COMPUTERS
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced three large computers, which analysts said would fill a gap in the company's product line and intensify the pressure on its competitors.   The new computers, called the 3083 Model Groups E, B and J, will range in price from about $1 million to $3 million and will be capable of executing several million instructions each second.   The new models are the smallest members of I.B.M.'s 3081 series of computers, its largest machines, but they are larger than the processors in the company's next largest family of computers, the 4300 series.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bankers Trust Co. has appointed W. Douglas Cadogan, Brian J.  Farmer, Richard N. Geib, Neil Harding, Thomas W. Hardy and Steven A.  Kol-tai vice presidents.   * Brooks Brothers has named Guido Cozzolino vice presidentmanufacturing.   * Continental Telecom Inc., Atlanta, formerly called Continental Telephone Corporation, has elected Malcolm Holmes executive vice president-finance, and Donald W. Weber executive vice presidenttelephone.

headline: Total Petroleum
abstract: Total Petroleum Ltd. said talks were taking place for the possible sale of all or part of its Canadian operations, which have interests in oil and natural gas properties in Ontario, Saskatchewan and offshore Labrador. The talks may result in an increase in the Canadian ownership of those operations, Total said.

headline: NATO Blames East For Arms Buildup
abstract: NATO said today that the West had been compelled to strengthen its forces because of a continued military buildup by the Warsaw Pact in Eastern Europe.   The Ambassador from Luxembourg, Edouard Molitor, speaking on behalf of the Western alliance, rejected Soviet accusations that NATO moves were incompatible with the objectives of East-West talks here on reducing armed forces in Europe. ----   MOSCOW, June 17 (UPI) - The Soviet press agency Tass, commenting on the NATO meeting in Bonn last week, said today that the conference clearly ''absorbed the ideas of the American belligerent politicans and the U.S. military-industrial complex.''

headline: Asbestos Ltd.  Insurance
abstract: The Asbestos Corporation Ltd. said Friday in its annual report that it had enough damage insurance to cover a substantial portion of any damages that might be assessed it under several pending United States lawsuits.

headline: Brock Backs Trade Plan
abstract: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, today backed an Australian proposal for a ''standstill'' on protectionist measures by major industrial countries and a reduction of existing trade barriers over the next five years.   ''We have got to make the trading system work or it will blow up in our face,'' the chief trade negotiator told a meeting of the National Press Club.

headline: Around the World; Salvador Relief Chief Is Feared Kidnapped
abstract: The director of El Salvador's Green Cross relief agency was reported missing and feared kidnapped in a raid by unidentified gunmen on his home Friday. The Green Cross has been accused by rightists of aiding leftist rebels.

headline: Polaroid Enters 35-Millimeter Field
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation, which has experienced a steady earnings decline in recent quarters, displayed several new products at its annual meeting today, marking the company's long-awaited entry into the 35-millimeter camera market.   The Cambridge, Mass., company demonstrated several prototype color and black-and-white 35-millimeter transparency films used to make slides.

headline: American Filtrona
abstract: The American Filtrona Corporation said it had agreed to buy 51 percent of the Dolinger Corporation from certain sharehodlers at $36 a share and that it would begin a tender offer next week to acquire the remaining shares at the same price.

headline: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MITEL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Feb 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Chrysler Plans Price Increases
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would increase the manufacturer's suggested retail price on select car models, with the base price for the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon Miser four-door hatchback rising by $200, to $5,699, effective June 14.

headline: SANCTIONS' FULL RENEWAL NOT EXPECTED BY BRITISH
abstract: British officials conceded today that they were unlikely to win full renewal of the sanctions against Argentina from Common Market allies when the question is taken up by the 10 foreign ministers in Brussels on Monday.   Instead, the British officials said that ''we would be encouraged by some form of support'' for the action taken by Britain in the Falkland Islands, even though it ''may not be in the same manner.''   The sanctions imposed five weeks ago were extended for one week in Luxembourg last Monday by eight of the members of the European Economic Community. The two other countries, Italy and Ireland, refused to renew the measures but promised not to import Argentine goods during the one-week extension.

headline: Saxon Inventories
abstract: Saxon Industries, a paper-products and photocopier maker operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, said its auditor had uncovered an ''apparent overstatement'' in the inventory of its business products group of ''at least $24 million.'' The auditor, Fox & Company of New York, is still investigating, but Saxon expects that inventories will be reduced and prior operating performance hurt, said Saxon's chief executive officer, William J. Scharffenberger.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Borg-Warner Acceptance Corporation, a unit of the Borg-Warner Corporation, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of up to $200 million aggregate principal amount of its senior unsecured debt securities, to be issued on a delayed or continuous basis.   * Campbell Taggart Inc. said it was negotiating to buy about 974,000 shares of its common stock from a single stockholder to be held by the company as treasury stock.   * Citicorp announced that an average rate of 13.864 percent was set at yesterday's weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, up from 13.819 last week.

headline: PINK SLIPS TOUGH ON EVERYONE
abstract: It is every employee's nightmare. The boss beckons him to his office and, with averted eyes, tells him that he is being ''dismissed'' or ''let go'' or ''separated.'' Things just have not worked out.

headline: A.&P. Shift Leaves Key Spot Still Open
abstract: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company shook up its management yesterday, but it has still not yielded an answer to the big question: Who will take the spot left open by the resignation last year of David Morrow as president?   Michael Rourke, spokesman for A.& P., said that even though the assignment shuffling did not provide any clues about who would get the No.2 job, it should ''make way for profitable operations.''

headline: A RICH NEW MINE RUNS INTO THE DIAMOND SLUMP
abstract: The potential for disappointment seemed minimal when the geologists and mining engineers from De Beers Consolidated Mines, the South African diamond concern, ran feasibility studies on a flat, arid savannah here that was sparsely covered with thorn bushes and cattle.   That was about five years and $315 million ago, when the international diamond cartel that De Beers manages could not acquire enough gemstones to meet the demand made on its London-based Central Selling Organization.   Now the pendulum has swung, with the result that De Beers, which markets 85 percent of the world's diamonds, has cut its supposedly sacrosanct dividend for the first time in more than a generation and the cartel has all but suspended purchases of the more expensive stones. Diamond Market in Slump   The diamond trade has been in a slump since the spring of 1980 when many investors began taking advantage of high interest rates and consumers started buying fewer, and smaller, diamonds.

headline: 17 Die in India Bomb Blast
abstract: A bomb exploded in a crowded bazaar tonight in the northwestern city of Gauhati, killing 17 people and wounding 28, the United News of India said.

headline: CANADIANS BICKER OVER NEW EMBASSY IN U.S.
abstract: Canada is going to build a new embassy in Washington, but the project has become enmeshed in acrimony.  The choice of Arthur Erickson of Vancouver as the architect of what is officially described as ''the Canadian Government's prime architectural showpiece abroad'' has created an uproar in architectural and political circles. The reason is that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau ignored the recommendations of a special panel that spent months examining some 300 applications.

headline: Long Island University Names Business Dean
abstract: A banker has been chosen as dean of the School of Business Administration at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University.  The school announced yesterday that John H. Vogel, chairman of the National Bank of North America, will take over Sept. 1.  Mr. Vogel, 65, retires today after a 48-year finance and banking career. He will remain a director at the National Bank of North America. His successor at the bank, which has assets of $6.4 billion and 157 branches in New York City and its suburbs, has not yet been announced.

headline: Quebec Calling a Halt To English Stop Sign
abstract: The English order ''Stop'' will be removed from stop signs at road junctions in Quebec, leaving only the French word ''Arret,'' the Government has decided.

headline: Senate Panel Overrides a Ban On Food Assistance to China
abstract: The Senate Agriculture Committee on Wednesday rejected the Reagan Administration's request for legislation declaring China a ''friendly nation'' as far as American food aid is concerned.   Instead, the committee adopted language to accompany a foreign assistance bill that in effect overrides a 1966 prohibition against aid to China under the Food for Peace program.

headline: MONDAY, MAY 17, 1982; International
abstract: OPEC convenes in Ecuador this week for its semiannual price-setting meeting amid strong signs that the world oil oversupply is ending.  The mood of crisis surrounding the group at its last meeting appears to have dissipated. (Page D1.)

headline: Stroh Brewery Mortgages Unit
abstract: The Stroh Brewery Company helped pay for its $494.7 million acquisition of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company by mortgaging its Detroit brewing facilities, according to a national mortgage insurer.

headline: COALITION IN BONN PUT UNDER STRAIN
abstract: The Social Democratic Party acknowledged the deep psychological effect today of its defeat in the Hamburg state elections Sunday and said that the results created strong new pressures on the federal coalition in Bonn.   Willy Brandt, the party chairman, said the losses suffered in Hamburg by both the Social Democrats and their coalition partners, the Free Democrats were ''a serious setback'' that made the business of governing together ''very much more difficult.''   The results meant that for the first time since World War II, the opposition Christian Democrats had outpolled the Social Democratic Party in Hamburg, a bastion to which Mr. Brandt's party had always laid claim.   It signified as well a reversal in traditional roles between the Christian Democrats and Social Democrats. The opposition party has become the leading vote-getter in every major city -Hamburg, West Berlin, Frankfurt, Stuttgart and Munich - all places where the Social Democrats, who describe themselves as representing working people, were once dominant.

headline: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS OPPOSED AID
abstract: Led by United States Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, finance ministers from 10 major industrial countries today rebuffed demands from less developed countries for a vast infusion of aid.   Mr. Regan told reporters after the meeting of the so-called Group of 10 that the members had agreed on the need to reduce budget deficits, continue with tight-money policies and keep a tight rein on lending by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.   The ministers' meeting took place during the two-day session of the interim committee that guides the I.M.F.'s lending policies.  The Group of 24, which lobbies for the third world on economic matters, urged Tuesday that the rich countries increase aid substantially and work to lower interest rates and raise government spending to help the world recover more quickly from recession.

headline: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Haig to Visit Aegean Nations
abstract: The State Department announced today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. would travel to Turkey and Greece May 12-16 ''for meetings with governmental leaders to discuss subjects of mutual interest.''

headline: PATENTS; Military Surveillance Methods Are Disclosed
abstract: Several methods of surveillance were disclosed in patents granted to the Navy this week.  One is for the automatic observation from aircraft of man-made objects on the ground.

headline: AMERICAN METALS SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHIEF AT UNR INDUSTRIES ADDS CHAIRMAN'S POST
abstract: David S. Leavitt, 56, has been elected chairman of financially troubled UNR Industries, a Chicago holding company with interests in industrial, commercial, transportation and consumer products. Mr.  Leavitt, who has been chief executive, president and chief operating officer, succeeds Edwin E. Hokin, 66, who retired but who will remain as a director and chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Hokin also will serve as a consultant.   Sam Silverstein, UNR vice president and president of the Midwest Corporation, a UNR subsidiary, was elected president and chief operating officer. Mr. Silverstein, who resides in Charleston, W.Va., is moving to Chicago.   UNR is in the midst of a financial crisis brought on by mounting losses, costly litigation and dismal markets for its steel products, its main business. Earlier this month Mr. Leavitt suggested to stockholders at the annual meeting that the company faced liquidation. ''But we're not presently facing that possibility,'' he said.

headline: Economic Affairs; WHAT'S ALL THE MERGING ABOUT?
abstract: DURING the last year, the wave of mergers of large corporations r eached a new crest. More than $45 billion of assets were acquired int he process of completing the hundred largest mergers, an amount moret han twice the average of the previous three years of such mergers.  T he two largest were the $8 billion purchase of Conoco Inc. by Du P ont, and the $6 billion purchase of the Marathon Oil Company by U nited States Steel. There were seven mergers in which more than $1 b illion of assets were acquired and there were 69 mergers in which m ore than $100 million were purchased.  The 100 largest mergers, according to my listing, averaged $520 million paid for the acquired assets.  Why all this buying of companies, in an economy marked by capital stringency and in the midst of a recession? Is there some pattern in these activities that allows us to infer the economic effects of increased merger activity?

headline: MALAY COALITION WINNING BY LANDSLIDE VOTE
abstract: The National Front of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad was headed for a landslide victory today after most of the ballots had been counted from Thursday's general election.   By late this afternoon the ruling coalition of 11 ethnic Malay, Chinese, Indian and tribal parties - inheritor of the alliance that has governed since independence in 1957 - had captured 110 of the Parliament's 154 seats and seemed ready to achieve an even larger majority than the 130 seats it held in the last Parliament.   The largely Chinese Democratic Action Party dropped from the 16 seats it won in the 1978 election to just 6 seats. Several of the party's strongholds along the industrialized west coast of the peninsula fell to challengers from the Malaysian Chinese Association, a member of the coalition and a party that some Malaysians thought was losing touch with the country's Chinese.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Allis-Chalmers Corp. said it had been awarded an $85 million contract for the modernization of the turbines at the Aswan High Dam in Egypt.   * American Maize Products Co. said its Jno. H. Swisher & Son subsidiary will close its cigar manufacturing plant in Cullman, Ala., effective July 31.   * American Standard Inc.'s Wabco Westinghouse International Co. has been awarded a $40 million signaling contract by the Secretaria de Comunicationes y Transportes of Mexico.

headline: Harvester to Sell Trucks to Pakistan
abstract: The International Harvester Company announced that it would sell 240 medium-duty trucks and parts to the Government of Pakistan for $8 million.

headline: U.S. STEEL WIDENING IMPORT PLEA
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation announced today that it would file a fresh batch of unfair trade complaints against foreign steelmakers on Friday, widening the industry's cluster of petitions to include every major category of steel imports.   The company also said that, because of the major decline in steel demand, it would decide within the next 30 to 60 days whether to shut down its huge integrated steel mill at Fairfield, Ala., near Birmingham. The plant has a capacity to turn out 3.1 million tons of sheet, strip, galvanized, structural and other steel products used mainly by the depressed auto, appliance and construction industries.   The Fairfield works has a full complement of 7,000 workers, and about half of them have already been furloughed. The plant is now operating at about one-third of capacity. It represents 8 percent of U.S. Steel's capacity to produce steel and 2 percent of the capacity of all domestic steelmakers.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Aid Auto Stores Inc., based in New York, said it had agreed to sell its Florida business to Discount Auto Parts Inc., a privately held Florida corporation, for about $1 million.   * Artco Industries Inc. said it had reached an agreement in principle to sell the assets of its school furniture division and has announced a plan of liquidation of the rest of its assets.

headline: STATE NATIONAL BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DISPUTES OVER THE HAYES AND ABERNATHY GOSPEL
abstract: To the Business Editor: At last Professors Hayes and Abernathy seem to get management to listen to simple wisdom that has long been clear to millions of their lower-level staff - the use of short-term profitability, separately for each operating division, as a performance criterion is short-sighted foolishness.   An important root cause of this problem, not emphasized in your article, is the large-corporation practice of shifting young executives around for short stints at the head of different groups.

headline: Zimbabwe Premier's Airliner Is Forced to Land in France
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, his wife, four Government ministers and 161 other passengers slid down emergency chutes from an airliner Saturday night after a bomb scare forced it to land in Paris, officials said today.   Orly Airport sources said the pilot landed after he thought he heard an explosion on board.  The police searched the Air Zimbabwe Boeing 707 at the airport but nothing was found, the sources said.

headline: 11 Americans Killed In Crete Plane Crash
abstract: All 11 people aboard a United States Navy plane were killed when it crashed into a mountain range on this Greek island, the police said here today.   A spokesman for the United States Embassy in Athens said rescue teams reached the site of the accident today and found no survivors.

headline: GIBSON, C R, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VOLUME GROWS
abstract: The stock market continued to advance yesterday in accelerated trading with some of the stocks that responded to specific news developments registering the largest price moves.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout most of the session, closed up 2.66 points, to 846.08.  Since March 8, when the blue-chip barometer closed at 795.47, its lowest level in almost two years, the Dow has advanced about 55 points despite a weakening economy and high interest rates.

headline: Heileman Pabst Talks
abstract: Russell Cleary, chairman of the G.  Heileman Brewing Company, said today that the company had discussed acquiring the Pabst Brewing Company with a New Orleans company, but he denied that Heileman and the Coy International Corporation had reached any agreement. He added that he was not pursuing a deal with Coy but that Heileman was awaiting results from a proposal by Irwin Jacobs, a Minneapolis businessmen, under which Mr. Jacobs's group would acquire Pabst and then sell some Pabst operations to Heileman.

headline: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S.-Japan Charters
abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it would establish a system to allocate charter flights by United States airlines between the United States and Japan. American and Japanese airlines are each allowed 300 one-way charter flights a year between the United States and Japan under a new bilateral agreement expected to be signed soon.

headline: TEXAS-NEW MEXICO POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S.-SOVIET ARMS TALKS GO BACK TO 60's
abstract: While the origins of nuclear arms talks go back to the early 1960's, the United States and the Soviet Union have been negotiating on limiting such weapons since 1969.   The results have been a treaty to limit defensive nuclear systems, signed in 1972 and ratified by the Senate; an interim agreement on limiting some long-range offensive nuclear weapons, signed at the same time and endorsed by both houses of Congress, and an unratified treaty on offensive nuclear arms completed in 1979.   Last Nov. 30 the two countries began talks in Geneva on intermediate-range nuclear weapons. These talks are now in recess.  President Reagan has proposed what he calls the ''zero option.'' Under this the United States would cancel plans to deploy 572 new medium-range weapons in Western Europe - 464 cruise missiles and 108 Pershing 2's -in exchange for an agreement by the Soviet Union to dismantle 600 SS-20, SS-4 and SS-5 missiles already stationed in the European part of its territory.

headline: Britons Set Up Everest Camp
abstract: A British expedition has established its base camp at 21,000 feet in an attempt to climb the unscaled east side of Mount Everest, the world's highest peak, according to a report received here today.The six-man team set up the camp April 4, the report said.

headline: Alcoa and Nippon Form Company
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America and the Nippon Electric Company of Japan said that they had formed a corporation, the Alcoa-NEC Communications Corporation, to make and market television receiver systems.   Alcoa did not specify the value of the joint venture, which will be 51 percent owned by Alcoa and 49 percent by N.E.C., but Richard R. Schalk, a spokesman for Alcoa, said it was ''in the many millions of dollars.''

headline: I.B.M. Plans 2 New Systems
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would offer a less expensive version of its Displaywriter system and a new Datamaster system with substantially more storage and a new printer.   The Datamaster, a data processor aimed at small businesses, has not sold as well as I.B.M. had expected, analysts said.

headline: HOUSE DELEGATION TO VISIT SALVADOR
abstract: The Reagan Administration has asked a Congressional delegation to go to Central America to assess the postelection situation in El Salvador and to discuss the Caribbean basin development plan with nations in the region.   The delegation, headed by Representative Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, the House Majority Leader, will leave Wednesday morning for a 10-day trip to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Panama, Nicaragua and Jamaica.   ''We got a request from the State Department to put together a bipartisan group representing the Congressional leadership,'' Mr.  Wright said in an interview tonight. ''We are going to talk to them as a fact-finding mission on facts and trends. Things are changing so much - we want to get a grasp and feel of what is happening, particularly in El Salvador in the wake of the elections.''

headline: Zimbabwe's Capital To Be Renamed Harare
abstract: Zimbabwe, celebrating its second anniversary of independence, announced today that in honor of the occasion, the name of Zimbabwe's capital would be changed from Salisbury to Harare, after a 19th-century tribal chief. Officials said they expected the change to be ratified by the Salisbury City Council next month.   This city of 800,000 was named after Lord Salisbury, who was British Prime Minister when white settlers founded a British colony here in 1896.

headline: Fujitsu Awarded MCI Cable Order
abstract: Fujitsu Ltd., a major Japanese computer manufacturer, said it had received an order for a fiber optic communications system from the MCI Telecommunications Corporation.

headline: TAKING CONTROL AT BURLINGTON
abstract: Like many of the new generation of chief executives, Richard M. Bressler starred first as a financial specialist and then took the reins as a division head and a corporate planner before reaching the top.   That training, in three companies, is now being put to the test.  Nearly two years ago, Mr. Bressler moved from a high-level oil industry job to head Burlington Northern Inc., a 29-state railroad that for years had been plagued by an awkward management structure that resulted in lagging profits and a failure to take advantage of the company's natural resources.   By introducing new financial goals, filling some key positions with outsiders and focusing more on natural resources, Mr. Bressler has eased some problems and moved Burlington onto a markedly different track.   Following a billion-dollar spending program undertaken by his predecessors to cash in on the Western coal-hauling boom, the 51-year-old chairman and chief executive officer dropped 660 miles of idle rural track, along with outmoded depots and maintenance yards.

headline: NEW PRESIDENT NAMED AT VAIL ASSOCIATES
abstract: For the past 10 years, Harry H. Frampton 3d has worked to turn 5,500 acres of raw Virginia land into Brandermill, a lakeside residential community with 2,300 suburban homes.   Now, as the newly appointed president of Vail Associates Inc., Mr.  Frampton hopes to turn the chilly base of Colorado's Beaver Creek Mountain into a thriving resort, while holding down costs at the Vail and Beaver Creek ski areas.   ''The extreme growth of the ski industry in the last 10 years is not likely to be as great in the next 10,'' Mr. Frampton said in an interview. ''The industry has been able to raise prices and raise prices - and the consumer just accepted it. Now we need a real focus on marketing and improving productivity.''

headline: U.S. OFFICIALS HOPEFUL ON NAMIBIA TALKS
abstract: Reagan Administration officials believe that the delicate and complex negotiations to bring the South Africancontrolled territory of South-West Africa to independence as the new state of Namibia could reach a successful conclusion by the end of the year.   Within recent days, State Department officials have told reporters the Administration was hopeful that international diplomacy had made headway in working out a settlement between South Africa, which has governed the territory since 1920, and the South-West Africa People's Organization, which has led the guerrilla struggle for an independent nation.   Negotiations on the issue move to a new phase this week as Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, meets with African foreign ministers at the United Nations. ''The differences are narrowing,'' one ranking State Department official said. ''Things are in an active phase.''

headline: MILLIONS IN 'FICTITIOUS' ORDERS ENMESH DAYCO IN COURT FIGHT
abstract: The company was big and so was the opportunity. In 1979, the Dayco Corporation had record sales of $740 million, stood among the largest 400 industrial companies and was offered a chance to break into a vast new market: the Soviet Union.   With Dayco's domestic sales down because of a slump in the automotive industry, and profits sliding, the company welcomed the $117 million worth of Soviet orders for belts and hoses that were placed by a New York sales agent.   Dayco cranked up its plants and, in an unusual move, prepaid $13 million in commissions to its sales agent. But the Soviet deal turned sour. Early this year, Dayco announced that most of the orders had turned out to be ''entirely fictitious,'' took an after-tax write-off of $11.7 million and recorded a loss for its fiscal year ended last Oct. 31.

headline: WEIMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Prague Rail Crash Kills One
abstract: One passenger was killed and 42 were injured when a passenger train ran into the last car of an empty train waiting between two stations in Prague today, the official C.T.K.  press agency said.

headline: LEBANON'S COUNCIL REPORTS NO PROGRESS IN FIRST MEETING
abstract: An emergency council representing Lebanon's major disparate factions met for the first time tonight to discuss ways of ending the Israeli siege around Beirut. The meeting made no progress.   (Israel shelled coastal areas of west Beirut and the southern outskirts of the city early Monday, according to a Reuters report, which quoted the Palestinian press agency Wafa. The agency said the shelling, by land and sea, continued for more than one hour.)

headline: Tax as a Remedy
abstract: To the Business Editor: Professor William Nordhaus has taken us around the barn in his discussion of the projected budget deficits - ''Cross Purposes on the Economy'' (May 16). In so doing, he collected a lot of smelly stuff we have been fed for years and insisted it is still good for us.

headline: Pope Invites Church Leaders To Rome for Mass for Peace
abstract: Pope John Paul II issued an ''urgent and personal request'' to primates of Argentina and Britain to join him at the Vatican at a mass for peace in the Falkland Islands, Roman Catholic officials said today.   Basil Cardinal Hume, Roman Catholic primate of England and Wales, issued a statement saying he would fly to Rome on Thursday to take part in the Friday prayers.

headline: SHORT-TERM RATES RISE SHARPLY
abstract: The credit markets were in turmoil yesterday, as heavy borrowing by large commercial banks helped to push short-term interest rates up sharply while investors and speculators shunned the note and bond market, where prices fell to their lowest levels in four months.   The sharp increase in borrowing costs at commercial banks yesterday heightened speculation in the money markets that some banks might soon raise the prime rate charged on loans to businesses from the 16 1/2 percent level that has prevailed since Feb. 23.   The rising interest rates continued to depress the stock market.  The Dow Jones industrial average dropped by 5.42 points yesterday, to 791.48, its lowest level in 26 months. (Page D8.)

headline: EXCERPTS FROM MRS. THATCHER'S TALK
abstract: Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's speech in the House of Commons today, as recorded by The New York Times: Special to the New York Times   LONDON, April 14 - Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's speech in the House of Commons today, as recorded by The New York Times:   On his first visit we made clear to Mr. Haig that withdrawal of the invaders' troops must come first, that the sovereignty of the islands is not affected by the act of invasion, and that when it comes to future negotiations what matters most is what the Falkland Islanders themselves wish.   On his second visit on Easter Monday and yesterday, Mr. Haig put forward certain ideas as a basis for discussion, ideas concerning the withdrawal of troops and its supervision and an interim period during which negotiations on the future of the islands would be conducted. Our talks were long and detailed, as the House would expect. Some things we could not consider because they flouted our basic principles; others we had to examine carefully and suggest alternatives.

headline: RPM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: APRIL SALES AT RETAIL GREW 1.4%
abstract: Retail sales, virtually stagnant since last spring, rose 1.4 percent in April with gains for cars, furniture and other durable goods, the Commerce Department reported today.   Apart from a February increase of 2.7 percent, a figure that most analysts said was overstated, the April sales increase was the largest in any month since January 1981.   Economists inside and outside the Government said they were encouraged by the report, but they stopped short of declaring that a national economic recovery had begun.

headline: REGAN'S INNER CIRCLE
abstract: WASHINGTON There are those who are close to Donald T. Regan, the Treasury Secretary. But, insiders at Treasury say, there is no one official that the Secretary regularly turns to for advice.   One of the influential people in the crucial September and November tax fights of 1981 was Paul Craig Roberts, the Assistant Secretary for Economic Affairs and an ardent supply-sider who saw the enemy in David A. Stockman and his chief economist, Lawrence Kudlow. But Mr.  Roberts has left to take a professorship at Georgetown University.

headline: Advertising; Graduates Advised on Job Hunt
abstract: IT'S cap and gown time and college graduates, convinced by parents, professors and peers that they are wonderful writers, will be descending on New York to make their services available to the advertising agency business.   For them, some advice: Go someplace else.  Try a smaller apple, a far-out-of-town agency, or the advertising department of a department store or the promotion sections of local radio stations or newspapers. But somewhere else.

headline: An Israeli General Says There Must Be Talks
abstract: Gen. Benjamin Ben-Eliezer of Israel said today that his country's army would not leave Lebanon until there was an ''agreement guaranteeing the security of Israel from the P.L.O.''   ''This will involve negotiations with Lebanon,'' he said, ''and Syria will be welcome as well.'' General Ben-Eliezer spoke at a news conference on the first day of a nationwide tour to explain the Israeli reasons for invading Lebanon.

headline: Diversified Background Aids UAL's Chairman
abstract: Richard J. Ferris, president and chief executive officer of UAL Inc. and chairman and chief executive of United Airlines. its main subsidiary, yesterday was elected to the additional post of chairman of the holding company. The 45-year-old Mr. Ferris succeeds Edward E. Carlson, 71, who is relinquishing his chairman's post but will remain as chairman of the executive committee and a director.   The change of command, expected for some time in both UAL and the airline industry, places a man at the helm of the diversified UAL who has trained for and held top responsibilities in hotels and food services. UAL, seeking diversification as a hedge against the uncertainties of the airline industry, has diversified into hotels with the Westin chain.

headline: Gold and Silver Futures Show Substantial Drop
abstract: Precious metals futures prices crumbled yesterday in the largest one-day decline since late last September. Although the market had expected gold and silver prices to decline for both fundamental and technical reasons, many brokers and traders said they were surprised by the size of the losses.   Based on closing futures prices on New York's Commodity Exchange, the spot April gold contracts plunged $18.80 an ounce, to $341, while the active near June delivery lost $19.50, to $346.50.  Meanwhile, spot April silver futures plunged 43.5 cents an ounce, to $7.145, with the active near May contracts down 44 cents, to $7.18.

headline: Questor Is Moving
abstract: The Questor Corporation will move its headquarters from Toledo to Tampa, Fla., this summer, James Milligan, president and chief executive officer, told the 50 employees at the company's headquarters building. The company, which makes Spalding sporting goods, Evenflo, Lullabye and Kantwet baby products, and Leslie-Locke building products, said the move would be ''consistent with its new growth strategy and permit greater accessibility to the company's principal continuing businesses.''

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE POPE'S REMARKS AT COVENTRY AND LIVERPOOL
abstract: Following are excerpts from the texts of Pope John Paul II's remarks today at an outdoor mass near Coventry and at Speke Airport near Liverpool: Coventry   We are close to the city of Coventry, a city devastated by war but rebuilt in hope. The ruins of the old cathedral and the building of the new are recognized throughout the world as a symbol of Christian reconcilation and peace. We pray at this mass, ''Send forth your spirit, O Lord, and renew the face of the earth.'' In this prayer we call upon God to enable us to bring about that reconciliation and peace not simply in symbol, but in reality too.

headline: Real Estate; Commercial Co-Op in Brooklyn
abstract: TWO years ago when word got around Brooklyn Heights that the medical office building at 142 Joralemon Street would be converted into a cooperative with its commercial space to be sold, not rented, many in the real estate community there thought the idea laughable, the new owners say.   ''For one thing, the notion of a commercial co-op was a relatively new idea,'' said Stephen M. Raphael, one of the principal partners in Medical Arts Funding Associates, the project's development company.  ''I think some thought we were taking an unnecessary risk. After all, as a commercial rental the building was stable and doing well and the location in the heart of the Heights meant that its future as a desirable spot was solid. They would have been able to understand it if we had decided on a residential conversion. There are plenty of precedents for that.''

headline: Copper Group Loses on Penny
abstract: The copper industry lost another round today in its effort to keep the Treasury Department from drastically reducing the amount of copper in a penny.

headline: YUGOSLAV PUTS THE ECONOMY ATOP HER LIST
abstract: Milka Planinc, the first female Prime Minister of Yugoslavia, is a businesslike politician whose overriding concern is the ailing state of the nation's economy.   Continued high inflation, sluggish production, unemployment and Yugoslavia's foreign debt are among the eonomic questions at the top of the agenda of the 12th congress of the Communist Party, being held here this weekend.   ''We've got to solve our economic problems soon because we cannot live on short-term credit,'' the Prime Minister said during her first meeting with the chiefs of diplomatic missions last week.   Mrs. Planinc (the name is pronounced plah-NEENTZ), a longtime party member who was elected Prime Minister on May 16, was virtually unknown in Belgrade's diplomatic circles. Diplomats who met her recently were generally impressed.

headline: Conoco Card Fee
abstract: Conoco Inc., the oil subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical company, said that it would begin charging its distributors a 2 1/2 percent processing fee on all Conoco credit card invoices, beginning June 15.

headline: WEINBERGER SAYS SOVIET WEAPONS ARE AIDED BY WESTERN TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said yesterday that the United States and other Western countries had been selling the Soviet Union the technological ''rope to hang us'' but that the Reagan Administration was putting a stop to this.   Speaking to the Foreign Policy Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan, Mr. Weinberger said: ''It is essential, while we improve our own defense, that we close down Soviet access to the technology they want for their military buildup. Selling them our valuable technology upon which we have historically based much of our security is short-sightedness raised to the level of a crime.''

headline: PRESIDENT LEAVING MISSOURI PACIFIC
abstract: Thomas H. O'Leary, president of the Missouri Pacific Corporation of St. Louis, said yesterday that he would resign July 31 to become a vice chairman and a director of Burlington Northern Inc.   Mr. O'Leary, 48 years old, a former Citibank loan officer, has been with the railroad holding company for 17 years and president for the last eight.   The Missouri Pacific is an object of acquisition by the Union Pacific Corporation. Mr. O'Leary said that a favorable Government ruling was expected in October and that the merger would probably be completed in 1983.

headline: Around the World; Soviet Dissident Gets 10-Year Sentence
abstract: A Moscow court today sentenced Ivan S. Kovalyov, 27 years old, a member of the Moscow Helsinki Watch Committee, to five years in labor camp followed by five in internal exile for producing and distributing anti-Soviet material.   Mr. Kovalyov thus joins his wife, Tatyana Osipova, and his father, Sergei A. Kovalyov, in the long roster of dissidents serving terms of imprisonment and exile.

headline: Around the World; Britons Say El Salvador Held Fair Elections
abstract: Britain's two official observers at the March 28 elections in El Salvador said today that the elections were fairly conducted.

headline: TURKISH TEA GROWERS BEWAIL TIGHT QUALITY RULES
abstract: They're not burning tea leaves or throwing them into the sea here anymore. In fact, they are not sure they can produce enough this year to meet the demands of this tea-consuming nation of 45 million people.   After efforts by the military Government to clean up the tea industry, quality improved significantly, but production and income of the tea growers have dropped. Turkish tea drinkers have long complained that the State Tea Monopoly has been buying everything green, including grass and weeds, and dumping excess leaves into the Mediterranean.

headline: Funds Obtained By Saxon Oil
abstract: The Saxon Oil Company, based in Dallas, said yesterday that its chairman and founder, Bill D. Saxon, would sell his 80 percent interest in the company and that the buyers would extend $65 million of credit to it.   Saxon Oil said the additional money, made necessary by falling oil prices and its accelerated drilling program in the Anadarko Basin in Oklahoma, would allow all of the company's commitments to be met through the end of 1982.

headline: BRITONS GIVEN ONLY 2 OFFICIAL REPORTS DURING DAY
abstract: For Britons, the first news of the long-awaited landings in the Falkland Islands came just after noon today. In his now-familiar, emotionless tone, the Defense Ministry spokesman, Ian McDonald, said at the regular noon press briefing that raids and attacks by British troops had taken place.   That news, coming while Argentina was still asleep, was the only report this country was to have for much of the day. Then at 8:30 P.M. the almost-as-familiar face of Defense Secretary John Nott appeared before television cameras with a fuller account of the day's events.

headline: Insurer to Acquire William Penn Life
abstract: The Continental Corporation, a large insurance company based in New York, announced that one of its units would acquire the William Penn Life Insurance Company of New York for more than $20 million. William Penn is a subsidiary of the Massachusetts Indemnity and Life Insurance Company, which in turn is a unit of Penncorp Financial Inc.    Continental's Life and Health division is purchasing William Penn because it ''complements our existing book of life and health business and reflects our policy of growth in the life insurance field through selective acquisitions,'' Richard A. Liddy, senior vice president of the division, said.

headline: GENOCIDE
abstract: The Turkish Government categorically denied today that any threat had been made to Jews here in retaliation for Armenian participation in a scheduled international conference in Tel Aviv on genocide.   The Israeli charge d'affaires in Ankara, Calon Liel, also said there had been no pressure on the 20,000 Jews in Turkey ''to the best of our knowledge.''   Mr. Liel, who since April has had ''mutual exchanges of information'' with Turkish officials on the genocide conference, informed the Foreign Ministry today that all Israeli official and semiofficial institutions had withdrawn from the conference and that other participants had been urged to do the same. He expressed the hope that the organizers would decide to cancel the conference, scheduled to open June 17, if it turned into a small private seminar without official backing.

headline: Conoco Considers Sale of Reserves
abstract: Conoco Inc., a subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, announced that it was considering selling some oil and gas reserves of Continental Oil Ltd., an oil and gas partnership with interests in Oklahoma and Texas.

headline: Advertising; 'Nonstop News Machine'
abstract: THE Satellite News Channel, a joint effort of Westinghouse's Group W and the American Broadcasting Companies, begins its 24-hour-a-day service on Monday, challenging the lock that Ted Turner's Cable News Network has on the cable TV news market. There will, of course, be advertising to help with the introduction.   Slater Hanft Martin, which is in charge of the drum beating, has come up with the concept of ''The Nonstop News Machine,'' in order to get across the idea that, unlike CNN, with its frequent news features, SNC, like Group W radio news, is hard news only and recirculated every 18 minutes.

headline: Petro-Lewis Offer
abstract: The Petro-Lewis Corporation said subscriptions to the public partnership formed in June in its oil income program were a record $86.9 million, up sharply from $15 million in the June 1981 partnership. The company said the June partnerships brought the total for the fourth fiscal quarter ending June 30 to $155.4 million, surpassing the previous quarterly high of $128.7 million raised in the three months ended Sept. 30, 1980.

headline: LONG-TERM BOND PRICES FALL
abstract: Long-term bond prices were stable early yesterday, but turned lower in the afternoon when dealers said that a significant amount of Treasury issues were sold.   The selling pressure was confined to the long-term market, however, and prices of Treasury bills and note issues due in three years or less actually increased slightly during the day. For example, the rate on three-month Treasury bills fell about five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 12.05 percent, while 13 3/4 percent Treasury notes due in two years were offered at 99 3/4 to yield 13.86 percent, unchanged on the day.   The bellwether issue for the bond market - the 14 percent Treasury bonds due in 2011 - were offered early in the day at 103 1/8, but fell to as low as 102 6/32 before closing at an offered price of 102 5/8 to yield 13.62 percent, down about 1/8 point on the day.

headline: FOUR NUCLEAR SUBS WILL SPEARHEAD BRITISH FLOTILLA
abstract: The spearhead of the British blockade of the Falkland Islands, which is to begin on Monday, will be formed by four of the Royal Navy's nuclear-powered submarines, military sources confirmed today.   One of the four, the Superb, was dispatched from Gibraltar early last week, according to the sources, and has already arrived off the South Atlantic archipelago. The other three - the Sceptre, the Spartan and the Splendid - are officially reported ''out on patrol'' and believed to be within two days' sailing time of the islands.

headline: CANADIANS WARMLY WELCOME FRENCH PREMIER
abstract: The French Prime Minister arrived here today for a six-day official visit that is expected to widen France's interest in Canada beyond Quebec.   Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who has long sought to end France's almost exclusive preoccupation with its former Frenchspeaking colony, was all smiles as he greeted the French official, Pierre Mauroy, and his party at the Ottawa Airport. They then began a series of talks and receptions designed to increase the rather low level of trade and economic and technical cooperation between their countries.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Firestone May Seek Hertz
abstract: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company confirmed reports that it was discussing the possibility of acquiring the Hertz Corporation, the car and truck rental unit of the RCA Corporation, for an undisclosed price.   RCA said earlier this year that Hertz was for sale.

headline: HAIG AND GROMYKO MEET FOR 5 HOURS
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. opened a new round of high-level Soviet-American talks with Foreign Minister Andrei A.  Gromyko yesterday that was expected to include discussion of a possible meeting later in the year between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev.   After their initial five-hour meeting at the United States Mission to the United Nations, Mr. Haig told reporters that he and Mr.  Gromyko would meet again today at the Soviet Mission.   The main topics that were discussed yesterday, Mr. Haig said, were the broad principles underlying Soviet-American relations and the Administration's approach to arms control issues, as enunciated in President Reagan's recent speeches. Mr. Haig said that pressing regional issues such as the Lebanon crisis would be discussed at today's session beginning at 9:30 A.M.   Several hours before his meeting with Mr. Gromyko, Mr. Haig had breakfast with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel to discuss the intensive diplomatic efforts now going on to produce a lasting cease-fire in Lebanon. According to American officials, Mr. Haig again urged that Israel show military restraint and live up to its pledge not to capture Beirut.

headline: HOW TO GET GOOD PAY IN BRITAIN
abstract: LONDON THE scenario would astonish some: The American head of a flourishing British multinational company predicts its biggest source of profits this year will be Britain, where its productivity has risen substantially, while its most stubborn obstacle will be the United States, where demand is being strangled by the current recession.   The company is the BOC Group, formerly the British Oxygen Corporation, and its managing director and chief executive is 48-year-old Richard Vincent Giordano.   ''There's nothing so special about us,'' insisted Mr. Giordano, a Harvard College and Columbia Law School graduate. Perhaps, but despite a sagging British economy and $30.6 million in payments to laid-off workers last year, BOC's after-tax profits jumped 27 percent, to $166.3 million, in 1981 on sales of $2.7 billion. The price of BOC stock more than doubled, to $2.81, since the former Wall Street lawyer took over in late 1979, and further brisk growth is predicted. Indeed, profits jumped 34 percent in the first quarter of this year, to $39.4 million.

headline: STANDARD OF INDIANA GAINS 24.7%
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the nation's-fifth largest oil concern, said yesterday that its net income for the first quarter rose by 24.7 percent while the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), ranked No.14, said its profit for the quarter fell by nearly 13 percent. The two were the first of the big oil companies to report results for the period.   Officials at Indiana Standard said the increase resulted largely from higher earnings in domestic refining and marketing tied to lower crude oil costs. Sohio also reported increased earnings in its refining and marketing arms but said the gains did not compensate for losses from the company's chemicals, coal, metals mining and industrial products subsidiaries.

headline: IRANIAN PROGRESS IN GULF WAR RAISES NEW FEARS IN AREA
abstract: Iran's sudden major breakthrough in the long-stalemated war with Iraq is having repercussions throughout the divided and volatile Middle East.   As details of a crushing defeat of entrenched Iraqi forces in the Dizful area emerged here, the fears of the more conservative Arab nations were underscored by an unscheduled, emergency trip to Baghdad today by the Defense Minister of Saudi Arabia, Prince Sultan.   Saudi Arabia, Jordan and the small, oil-rich nations along the Gulf have openly worried that an Iranian victory over President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in the 18-month-old war would make them vulnerable to the kind of Islamic fundamentalist revolution advocated by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Hostilities Could Spread   A key question over the coming days will be whether these countries would be willing to commit troops to shore up President Hussein as they see his position crumbling.

headline: TRADE ETHICS IN SILICON VALLEY
abstract: Although the arrest of Japanese businessmen by the Federal Bureau of Investigation this week set off a furor, the acquisition of trade secrets by legal and illegal means has always been part of doing business in Silicon Valley, the center of the American electronics industry.   In the pressure cooker atmosphere of this area, where product life cycles are rarely more than two years, success or failure can turn on the difference of a few weeks in product introduction dates.   Add to that a clannish atmosphere in which most executives have at one time worked with one another, a lack of public scrutiny until recent years and an endlessly migrating middle management and technical staff, and all the ingredients are in place for industrial intelligence, and at times espionage.   What seems to distinguish the Japa-   Mitsubishi pulled back from its denial that it had conspired to steal information from I.B.M. Page D3. nese case, according to Silicon Valley executives, is the size of the payments, involving hundreds of thousands of dollars, for International Business Machines computer secrets, bought via Glenmar Associates, an F.B.I. front that acted as a consulting firm. Also unusual were the participation of Federal law enforcement authorities and the fact that it took place in the ''systems'' business rather than in computer parts, such as semiconductors.

headline: PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC COO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 104 New Products Brought Out in March
abstract: The 104 new product introductions in March that were tracked by the newsletter Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News were a slight increase compared with the 102 recorded in the same month last year but a drop from the 114 in 1980. For the year so far there have been 277 introductions, compared with 265 last year, but a drop from 278 in 1980.

headline: BRITAIN REPORTS TROOPS SEIZE KEY HARBOR ON SOUTH GEORGIA AFTER FIRING ON ARGENTINE SUB
abstract: Argentina said early today that British forces had "apparent initial success" in their assault on the remote South Atlantic island of South Georgia.   Britain said it had captured South Georgia's principal port of Grytviken. Argentina's military junta said in a communique this morning that its forces "fell back from their initial positions and continue fighting in interior zones with an unbreakable spirit of combat."   The statement followed a series of communiques that appeared to be preparing the Argentine public for the news that the first battle of the Falkland Islands crisis had been lost.   As President Leopoldo Galtieri met with other military chiefs, the last statement issued Sunday night said the commander of Argentine marines at Leith Harbor, the other Argentine-defended position on South Georgia, "in his last message, communicated that he has destroyed his codes and would do the same with his radio before confronting the final combat."

headline: U.N. Envoy Heads for Teheran For Talks on Afghan Problem
abstract: Diego Cordoves, a special United Nations envoy, left Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, for Teheran today on the last leg of a tour to discuss the chances of a negotiated solution to the Afghan problem, the Kabul radio said.

headline: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COMINCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SCHMIDT'S PARTY IS DEALT A SEVERE DEFEAT IN HAMBURG STATE ELECTION
abstract: The opposition Christian Democratic Party administered a stunning defeat to the Social Democratic Party tonight, outpolling it for the first time in elections for the Hamburg State parliament that may affect the future of the federal coalition Government in Bonn.   The loss came in the most traditional of Social Democratic strongholds. Hamburg is not only the home of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who campaigned hard over the last month there, but also of Defense Minister Hans Apel and the party's whip in the federal Parliament, Herbert Wehner.   The outcome was described on the state television network as a ''political earthquake.'' Not only was the vote a direct blow to the authority of the Chancellor, but it weakened the relationship between the Social Democrats and the Free Democrats, the junior partners in the Bonn coalition. The Free Democrats failed to win the 5 percent of the total vote that is necessary to enter the state parliament and appeared to be losing much of their weight as the decisive element in determining the distribution of power between the Christian Democrats and Social Democrats on the national level.

headline: FLEET WITHIN WEEK OF THE FALKLANDS
abstract: The vanguard of the British battle fleet is less than a week's sailing time from the Falkland Islands, military sources indicated today.   The sources said that the last warships of the task force left the rendezvous point off Ascension Island, in midocean between Africa and South America, sometime early Thursday.   Other elements of the main British flotilla, which consists of about 25 ships, were reported to have left the area as early as last Monday or Tuesday, headed toward the South Atlantic.   It appears that the fleet is making about 18 or 19 knots, which means it will take the ships about seven or eight days to complete the voyage from Ascension to the South Atlantic, where nuclearpowered submarines of the Royal Navy are enforcing a blockade in a 200-mile zone around the Falklands.

headline: 2 Food Chains List Earnings
abstract: Two supermarket chains yesterday reported net earnings for their most recent quarters. Pantry Pride Inc. said its third-quarter profits tumbled 36.5 percent from the same quarter last year, while Stop and Shop Companies said it rebounded from a first-quarter loss in 1981.

headline: NEW BID TO RAISE DEBT CEIILING IS DUE
abstract: ''Dear Mr. Chairman,'' the letters will begin. Signed by Donald T. Regan, the Secretary of the Treasury, they will tell the chairmen of the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee that Congress - for the third time in 16 months - must again raise the ceiling on the national debt or the Government will be unable to pay its bills.   And so will occur a new round in a dialogue between the Treasury and Congress that goes back to 1946, when Congress imposed a ''permanent'' ceiling on the Government's debt of $275 billion. The ceiling now is $1,079.8 billion and the debt, which varies from day to day, exceeds $1,000 billion, or $1 trillion.

headline: PAULEY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Moscow Denounces Schmidt On U.S. 'Policy of Strength'
abstract: The Soviet Union criticized Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today for his allegiance to an American ''policy of strength.''   The Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda said Mr. Schmidt had raised the ''bogy of the Soviet menace'' as a political defense against ''increasingly large numbers of people in West Germany who see that the real threat to peace in Europe stems from the militaristic course of the United States and NATO, with which Bonn is in clear solidarity.''

headline: Money Fund Assets Slide
abstract: Assets of the nation's 185 money market funds fell $1.06 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $192.29 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   In reporting the figures, an institute spokesman said that some funds had reported large withdrawals by investors apparently to pay income taxes before the April 15 deadline.

headline: French Steel Expansion
abstract: The French Cabinet adopted a plan today to modernize the French steel industry.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Until last week, morale had never been better at the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's third-largest bank holding company. Bank-stock analysts as well as the company's executives had been ebullient about   Chase's strong and apparently well-balanced earnings over the last two years.  But that image was badly marred when the bank announced it would take an after-tax write-off of $135 million as the result of its dealings with the Drysdale Government Securities Corporation.   The loss is equivalent to a third of Chase's earnings in 1981 and threatens to produce an overall loss for the company in the current quarter. Analysts estimated the pretax charge at $270 million.

headline: For $2.7 Million, CBS Gets Cuisine Magazine
abstract: That which was supposed to happen, happened. CBS Inc. has acquired Cuisine Magazine - for $2.7 million.

headline: TAXING THE RICH: HUNTS VS. I.R.S.
abstract: Documents filed in the United States Tax Court for cases involving Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Texas billionaire, provide a rare public glimpse into the finances of one of America's most fiercely private and wealthy families.   The recently filed documents, the result of efforts by the Internal Revenue Service to recover more than $4 million in back taxes from Mr. Hunt for the years 1974 to 1977, show wild swings in his taxable income. In the years 1972 and 1973, Mr. Hunt had more than $100 million in personal taxable income, but in 1975, 1976 and 1977 he declared losses and paid virtually no Federal income taxes.   The Tax Court cases also provide insight into a number of Mr.  Hunt's sources of income as well as devices for avoiding taxes, including these examples:   - Mr. Hunt, in 1974, was a 5 percent investor in the partnership that owned the New York Yankees. The partnership claimed a loss of $4.4 million that year, based mostly on depreciation of $7.4 million in player contract costs, but the I.R.S., for unspecified reasons, is disallowing $2.8 million of the loss.

headline: Market Place; The Recession And Guardian
abstract: WHEN a company's primary markets are depressed, Wall Street may not notice if it is doing well at the expense of competitors. That, at least, is the approach Shearson/ American Express takes in viewing Guardian Industries. Among other products, Guardian offers glass for new cars and private homes - two of the hardest-hit markets in the recession.   Scott Merlis, a Shearson senior analyst, released a report at 10 A.M. yesterday suggesting that Guardian had picked its markets more carefully than some of its competitors. While acknowledging that Guardian sells glass for new cars, he noted that most of its sales in the automotive field were replacement glass, a healthier market.

headline: FOREMOST APPOINTS CHEMICAL UNIT HEAD
abstract: Barry B. Blocker, 44 years old, has been named president of the chemical group of Foremost-McKesson Inc., based in San Francisco. He succeeds George Ditz Jr., 65, who is retiring as head of the unit, a major chemical distributor and recycler of solvents.

headline: Wickes Petitions
abstract: The Wickes Companies said it had filed additional petitions for relief under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws for its Howard Brothers Discount Stores unit, two of Howard's wholly owned subsidiaries and two credit units. Wickes, a major retailer, sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 last Saturday. The company, which has $2 billion in debts, said that it had filed for the additional relief in Howard's case because of ''precipitous actions by a few trade creditors, in particular a levying and seizing of goods.''

headline: Price Cases Settled
abstract: The Energy Department said it had reached separate proposed consent orders with the Getty Oil Company and the Williams Exploration Company.

headline: ARGENTINE COMMAND SAYS TROOPS ARE STILL FIGHTING TO EXPEL BRITISH
abstract: Argentina said today that its forces on the Falkland Islands were still fighting British troops who have established a beachhead near Port San Carlos.   A military spokesman said the Argentines were trying to push the British back. But an air force spokesman said Argentine planes, although active on Friday, had not returned to the battle.   The spokesman said British ships had withdrawn from Falkland Sound between the archipelago's two main islands.  The military command said later that Harrier jets had attacked Argentine positions near Darwin, the Falklands' second largest settlement, 15 miles south of the San Carlos landing zone. One of the jets was shot down by antiaircraft fire, the Argentine command said in a communique.

headline: A STRIPPED-DOWN QE2 TO SET SAIL FOR WAR TODAY
abstract: A bustling horde of technicians, suppliers, workmen, sailors and soldiers swarmed over the Queen Elizabeth 2 today as the giant ship prepared to sail for the South Atlantic.   The liner pulsed with activity in a struggle to complete its transformation from a floating resort to troop carrier and load the last of thousands of tons of supplies and weapons.   Starting at dawn Wednesday, just over 3,000 troops will begin boarding and if all goes according to plan the 963-foot ship will be nosed out of its home port at about 4 P.M., bound for Ascension Island and then probably the Falkland Islands.   The soldiers are from the Five Brigade, made up of Welsh Guards, Scots Guards, Gurkhas and support forces, and are intended to form the garrison on the Falklands should they be retaken, according to military men aboard the ship. In addition to the troops, about 700 members of the normal Cunard crew of 1,000 are sailing, including 23 women.

headline: Your Money; Tax-Exempt Money Funds
abstract: BY now, the enormous development of money market funds since they first came into wide-scale public acceptance during the last decade has become familiar to investors and noninvestors alike. But relatively few are aware of what has recently become the most rapidly growing portion of this industry: tax-free money market funds that invest in short-term debt of state and local governments.   The tax-exempt funds, which are of increasing benefit to investors as their tax bracket rises to the maximum Federal income tax rate of 50 percent, are by no means a new invention. But in the last year or so, the assets of these funds - which have all the advantages and the disadvantages of money market funds in general - have proliferated.

headline: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS SEEK BACKING TO FORCE WITHDRAWAL OF SYRIANS
abstract: Lebanon's Christian militia forces have opened a new international campaign aimed at forcing the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon and the disarming of Palestinian guerrillas.   A conference of more than 100 prominent delegates from 15 countries, the European Parliament and other organizations gave support to the Lebanese Christians in their efforts against ''the twofold occupation,'' meaning the Palestinian and the Syrian military presence.   Although the conference, which ended today, did not receive any public endorsement from foreign governments, there were messages of support from prominent individuals such as Senator Edward M.  Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, Representative Jack F. Kemp, Republican of Erie County, N.Y., former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France and the Gaullist leader Jacques Chirac.

headline: Study Says Paraguay Regresses on Rights
abstract: A new report by the International League for Human Rights asserts that there has been a deterioration of human rights in Paraguay over the last two years.   After 28 years of military rule under Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, the Paraguayan Government ''continues to invoke martial law as the justification for arbitrary actions such as preventive arrests, detention without charge and unreasonable delay before trial,'' the report by the private organization said.   The latest League report was a follow-up on one two years ago that also criticized human rights violations in Paraguay.

headline: CITIES SERVICE RAISES BID
abstract: The Cities Service Company reported yesterday that its $17-a-share offer for 51 percent of the Mesa Petroleum Company had brought in some 30 million shares, about 41 percent, by the Thursday deadline for assuring payment.   Late in the day Cities Service increased its offer for the 51 percent -37 million shares - to $21 a share, apparently to encourage shareholders who have submitted their shares not to take them back between now and June 21, when their right to do so expires.   The $4 increase had been anticipated, partly because Cities Service had proposed the sweetener to Mesa executives if they endorsed the bid. With Mesa's shares selling well above $17, the $21 bid had to be made, in any case, for Cities Service to protect the shares already tendered.

headline: ISRAEL FORGING TRADE LINKS WITH SOUTH LEBANON
abstract: The Israeli Government, which wants to ease the passage of goods into southern Lebanon, plans to open three new banking and customs centers here along the Israeli-Lebanese border, and it is thinking of reviving an abandoned rail link with Lebanon.   The Government's effort to forge economic links with occupied Lebanon comes despite continuing tension in the area. The latest reported fighting involved a clash between an Israeli patrol and a Syrian unit Friday in which five Syrian soldiers were killed and three Israelis wounded near Lake Karoun, 18 miles north of this windswept town in the extreme north of the Galilee. And Syrian Army trucks were seen repositioning sealed artillery pieces Saturday near the Israeli-Syrian cease-fire lines not far from the villa of Jib Janine, six miles northeast of the lake.

headline: MRS. THATCHER ASSERTS ARGENTINA HOLDS 'KEY TO PEACE'
abstract: With the dispute over the Falkland Islands about to enter its most dangerous phase, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher asserted today that ''the key to peace is in the hands of the Argentine Government.''   In an emergency debate in the House of Commons, the fourth since Argentina occupied the islands on April 2, Mrs. Thatcher affirmed the view that ''gentle persuasion is not going to make the Argentine Government give up what it has seized by force.''   She rejected, for the moment at least, demands from the opposition that she turn to the United Nations or to the International Court of Justice in a last-ditch attempt to avoid war.   About an hour after the debate ended, a rejoinder came from Argentina with the announcement that it planned to treat as hostile British ships and planes that approached the mainland, the Falklands or South Georgia. The Foreign Office said it had no immediate comment, but the announcement appeared to constitute an indirect rejection of diplomatic overtures.

headline: CITIBANK ENDS DEPOSIT SURVEY
abstract: An effort by Citibank to improve its weekly money supply forecast by surveying deposits at about 20 banks across the country has been abandoned, bank officials acknowledged yesterday. They said the plan left it vulnerable to allegations that it would make improper use of the material.   According to officials at Citibank and the Federal Reserve Board, there have been no such allegations. However, the collection of deposit data from other banks raised the possibility that the bank could be accused of improperly using insider information, bankers said. And this was enough to cause Citibank's chairman, Walter B.  Wriston, to order the cancellation of the survey, they added.

headline: BRITISH TROOPS REPORTED BATTLING ARGENTINES 15 MILES FROM STANLEY
abstract: Paratroops and Royal Marines have battled to within 15 miles of Stanley, the main Argentine stronghold on the Falkland Islands, the Defense Ministry indicated tonight.   The ministry said British troops were fighting Argentine forces in the hills west of Stanley. Brian Hanrahan of the BBC reported fighting in the area of Mount Kent, a steep 1,535-foot hill dominating both of the rough tracks leading to the capital. Reports of Second Landing   It appeared from reports from correspondents on the Falklands that a combat group taking the northern route across East Falkland Island had linked up, probably early today, with another approaching Stanley along another route to the south.

headline: MORE ON RUSTLING AND MERRILL'S THUNDERING HERD
abstract: When last we looked, Merrill Lynch, the nation's largest securities firm, was celebrating some success in the steps it took to curb rustling from the Thundering Herd. Its officers expressed jubilation last month when an arbitration panel at New York Stock Exchange ordered a competitor, Drexel Burnham Lambert, to pay damages of $250,000 to Merrill Lynch as compensation for improper recruiting practices. In the case against Drexel Burnham, Merrill Lynch accused four of its defecting executives of copying records and luring away clients.

headline: Levi Strauss Appoints President for Hat Unit
abstract: When Mike Gibbons was manager of a Levi Strauss jeans distribution center in Florence, Ky., a local newspaper interviewed him and said that he wore many hats.   ''That remark was my total exposure to hats,'' Mr. Gibbons said yesterday.  But that will all change now. Levi Strauss & Company has just appointed him president of its Resistol Hat Company.  Resistol, with headquarters in Garland, Tex., makes western hats and the more traditional fedora-style hats under the Dobbs and Churchill brand names. Mr. Gibbons, 43 years old, replaces John Milano, 54, who resigned after nine years, but will continue as a consultant to the company.

headline: Humphrey Browning Gets Records Account
abstract: The record industry, faced with the dual problem of home recording and commercial piracy, has retained the services of Humphrey Browning MacDougall, the Boston advertising agency, to research the problem and, if an advertising solution can be found, to develop such advertising.

headline: Earnings; CHEMICAL BANK UP BY 15.4%
abstract: The Chemical New York Corporation reported yesterday that its net operating earnings rose 15.4 percent in the first quarter, to $62.2 million, from $53.9 million in the similar period a year earlier.  Chemical, the nation's seventh-largest bank holding company, was the first of the majors to report first-quarter earnings.   On a per-share basis, net operating earnings, before securities transactions, rose 8.3 percent in the first quarter, to $2.43, from $2.24 in the comparable period of 1981. Alan H. Fishman, executive vice president, attributed the lower percentage gain to the conversion to common stock of convertible bonds and preferred stock.

headline: STATEMENTS ON THE TRUCE
abstract: Following is the text of the Israeli Foreign Ministry's announcement Saturday night of the cease-fire between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. It is followed by the P.L.O. statement of acceptance, issued in Beirut and translated from the Arabic by The Associated Press:   Israeli Announcement   On June 11 the Israel Defense Forces were instructed to cease fire as of noon.

headline: Kaufman Forecast
abstract: Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, reiterated yesterday earlier forecasts of a sluggish, brief economic recovery that could be short-circuited by volatile interest-rate movements. In his Investment Strategy Report, Mr. Kaufman repeated earlier forecasts that long-term rates were especially vulnerable to increases later in the year.

headline: SAXON INDUSTRIES FILES CHAPTER 11
abstract: Saxon Industries, a paper products and photocopier manufacturer, filed for financial reorganization yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, a Saxon official said.
