The Manhattan-based corporation, which listed assets of $503 million and liabilities of $461 million, said that its largest creditors were Chemical Bank, which was owed $21.5 million; First Interstate Bank of California, owed $20.7 million, and First National Bank of St. Paul, owed $10.7 million.

headline: Quentron's Position
abstract: Quentron Inc. said today that it opposed any takeover by Andrew Evans, chairman of Evans, Llewellyn Securities Inc. Mr. Evans, in proxy solicitations, has called the Quentron management unqualified.

headline: HOUSE FOREIGN AFFAIRS PANEL SEEKS NUCLEAR FREEZE
abstract: The House Foreign Affairs Committee, in a rebuff to President Reagan, approved a resolution today that called for a freeze in American and Soviet nuclear arsenals.   The vote was 26 to 9, with Democrats generally supporting the measure and Republicans badly divided.  In endorsing the nonbinding resolution, which calls for a freeze and then reductions in atomic arms, the committee defied the Administration, which has opposed a moratorium, and rejected White House protests that the resolution would undermine American negotiating strength six days before the opening of talks with the Soviet Union in Geneva on reducing strategic nuclear weapons.   While some committee members pleaded for nonpartisan action, all but 2 of the panel's 21 Democrats voted in favor of the freeze proposal; 9 of the 16 Republicans voted against it.

headline: UTILITIES LEAD OFFERINGS
abstract: Electric utilities are the largest group of companies that definitely plan to sell debt issues this week. If conditions are favorable, they may be joined by many industrial corporations.   Analysts at Salomon Brothers estimated that $600 million of corporate issues were scheduled for sale domestically this week, while 12 United States name issues totaling $1 billion were scheduled in the Eurodollar bond market.

headline: Weather in Falklands: No Major Storms Seen
abstract: The weather is clear over the Falkland Islands, with no major storms within 50 to 100 miles, the National Weather Service reported today.   A satellite photo of the area at 11 A.M. Eastern daylight time showed that a storm over the islands Sunday night had moved off to the southeast, Dennis Heller, a meteorologist, said.   There were some scattered clouds along the Argentine coast, Mr.  Heller said, but in general no major storm for more than 1,000 miles heading toward the islands.

headline: Chapter 11 Petition Considered by AM
abstract: AM International Inc., responding to published reports, acknowledged yesterday that it was actively considering filing for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.   Marion G. Durk, a spokesman for the financially troubled company, also said that recapitalization was another option for the company but that no decision had yet been made.

headline: VOLUNTEER CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAPAN'S HITACHI ADMITS PAYMENT FOR I.B.M. DATA
abstract: Hitachi Ltd., a leading Japanese computer manufacturer, said today that it had authorized the payment of $540,000 for confidential computer information belonging to the International Business Machines Corporation.   Hitachi said it was still studying the legality of the payment, which was made to a consulting firm that apparently was a decoy used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Buying information from research firms is common within the computer industry, and the key questions seemed to be whether Hitachi knew that it was paying for stolen information and whether it was coerced by Federal agents.   ''It seems that Hitachi stepped into the trap,'' said Yasushi Sayama, a spokesman for Hitachi in Tokyo.  The startling admission came in an

headline: Abu Dhabi Oil Price Cut
abstract: The Abu Dhabi National Oil Company has cut the official Government selling price of its crude oil by 94 cents a barrel, Japanese oil industry sources said today. The sources said Abu Dhabi National's Japanese customers had received notice that the reductions would be retroactive to shipments from March 20.

headline: DAUGHTER OF PLAYBOY
abstract: Like father, like daughter. Christie Hefner (right) became president last week of Playboy Enterprises.

headline: DRYSDALE SECURITIES OUT OF BUSINESS
abstract: The Drysdale Securities Corporation, a 92-year-old stock and bond trading firm, announced yesterday that it was liquidating its business.   The company's brief statement offered no reason for the liquidation. But it appeared to be linked to the troubles that developed after its offspring, Drysdale Government Securities, shook the markets by defaulting last month on $160 million in interest payments due on Treasury securities it had borrowed from other firms.    Although Drysdale Securities had tried to separate itself from Drysdale Government Securities, which it had spun off as a separate operation in January, a cash squeeze developed at the parent company. Banks reportedly tightened up on credit, and others placed restrictions on business done with the firm.

headline: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to Jan 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ASEA'S NEW CHIEF PLANS PUSH IN U.S.
abstract: The robots are coming, and the industrial giants are scrambling to get a piece of the market now dominated by Unimation and Cincinnati Milacron. United Technologies, General Motors, Westinghouse, General Electric, I.B.M. and Bendix all are in the business or have plans to get in.

headline: ISRAELIS BURY A SETTLEMENT IN SINAI SAND
abstract: By nightfall the town of Yamit had been ground into the desert and covered over with its sand.  All but about 20 of those who had made a desperate stand against the return to Egypt of the last sector of Sinai under Israeli control were carried, shouting at soldiers, into buses that took them across what will again become an international boundary next week. The rest have promised to leave Sunday.

headline: Dow Off 5.8 in Broad Selling
abstract: A broad stock market retreat accelerated yesterday as investors apparently remained skeptical about the prospects for a sustained rebound from the recession.   A rumor early in the session that the pension fund of the International Harvester Company intended to sell $300 million worth of stock as part of a major portfolio restructuring was also cited as a reason for the downturn. After the close, Harvester confirmed that its pension fund had sold between $200 million and $300 million of equity securities to ''a major investment banker'' and bought fixedincome securities.

headline: MANY GASOLINE REFINERS BEGIN ALLOCATING SUPPLY
abstract: Major oil companies have started restricting gasoline sales to jobbers and service stations because of rapid depletion of stocks over the last six weeks, according to several industry analysts.  Most analysts stress, however, that no shortages at service stations are expected to result from the restrictions,   Although the allocations generally are keyed to, and often exceed, jobbers' average monthly gasoline purchases during the first three months of 1982, the industry has been rife with reports of spot shortages at the wholesale level.   Daniel Lundberg, an industry analyst, said that ''in no way can this result in supply distress'' at service stations, ''except in very spotty incidents of high volume operators who have been getting unlimited product at a very good price.''

headline: PRIME COMPUTER SUES ON SALES LIST
abstract: Prime Computer Inc. has filed suit against a privately owned competitor, the EMC Corporation, charging it with penetrating Prime's computer bank containing a confidential sales list of 2,600 Prime customers.   Richard J. Egan, president of EMC, replied that the charges were ''absolutely untrue'' and that EMC ''did not steal their list.''

headline: British Car Sales Up
abstract: British car sales for March rose 8.4 percent from the 1981 level, to 175,000 units, and increased 42 percent from February 1982, figures from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders show.

headline: FORMER AFRICAN COLONIES RETAIN STRONG FRENCH TIES
abstract: When Graham Greene toured a part of West Africa in the 1930's, his journey took him across the border between Liberia and what was then the French colony of Guinea. As Mr. Greene recounts the story, the Liberians did not call their neighbor ''Guinea,'' but ''France,'' so pervasive was French colonial influence.   The anecdote, told in Mr. Greene's ''Journey Without Maps,'' is illuminating, for it sums up an aspect of European colonial rule in Africa that still has a strong impact more than two decades after foreign rule gave way to independence.   Where the British, personified in the aloof district officer, clad in starched knee-shorts and pith helmet, kept a reserved distance between the rulers and the ruled, the French sought to implant their notions of culture and civilization to a much deeper level, imposing a style of rule that was intended to stamp a sense of ''French-hood'' on territories and people far distant from Paris. Intermarriage Encouraged   Such was the French desire to fuse colonies and metropolitan France that, in 1902, a French scholar, known only as Dr. Barot, drew up the ground rules for marriage between colonial officers and African women in a book called ''A Practical Guide for Europeans in West Africa.''

headline: RAYCHEM CARVES A PROSPEROUS NICHE
abstract: Sometimes, a new technology can pleasantly surprise even those with high hopes for it. Paul M. Cook was convinced by his work for the Atomic Energy Commission almost 30 years ago that radiation chemistry -in particular, bombarding plastics with radiation - could produce unusual and useful materials.    Nevertheless, he shakes his head in happy amazement as he recalls the quiet niche-by-niche rise into the Fortune 500 of the Raychem Corporation, the company he founded in 1957 to pursue that conviction.   ''It's been a much more encompassing technology than I thought it was going to be,'' Mr. Cook, who is Raychem's president, said in an interview.   The first valuable thing Raychem learned to do by radiating plastic was to make it heat-shrinkable. Today, an almost incomprehensible variety of pipes, cables and wires are sealed, spliced or insulated by plastic materials that are shrunk to fit during installation using a blow torch or other heating devices.

headline: CHARGES OF CORRUPTION WORRY SRI LANKA PARTY
abstract: Although national elections are still more than a year away, the ruling United National Party appears deeply concerned over opposition charges that corruption is rampant in the country.   The party has called on its leader, President J.R. Jayewardene, to conduct wide inquiries, if needed, into the actions of Cabinet ministers and other public officials, Members of Parliament and chairmen and board members of state institutions.   In an election campaign more than five years ago, the party promised to wipe out the corruption that it charged had developed because of the centralized economic policies of the Government of Sirimavo Bandaranaike, then the Prime Minister. The Jayewardene party charged that the Bandaranaike Government's highly restrictive import policy and other practices had paved the way for politicians and officials to profit.

headline: Nabisco Brands Assigns Former MCA Accounts
abstract: The brands that Nabisco Brands decided last month to remove from MCA Advertising after a one-year stay were reassigned yesterday to Benton & Bowles and McCann-Erickson, already on the company's agency roster.   Benton & Bowles, whose current assignments include Planters Peanuts, got a long list of Fleischmann's and Blue Bonnet margarines.

headline: HADDAD LOOKS TO SIDON AS A NEW HEADQUARTERS
abstract: MERJ 'UYUN, Lebanon, June 19 -Maj. Saad Haddad, the Lebanese Christian militia leader who controls an enclave on Israel's northern border, says he plans to move his headquarters to Sidon, the port city that was occupied by the Israelis in their invasion.   Major Haddad, speaking with reporters this week, also said that many communities in southern Lebanon had asked to become part of his territory, which he calls Free Lebanon.   Leaning against his jeep as he talked with journalists, he said that his militia had played ''not too much'' of a role in the Israeli invasion. But he indicated that he felt he had the resources to control a far larger area than he now does; his enclave before the invasion had a population of perhaps 120,000.

headline: REAGAN AT WESTMINSTER: RED CARPET ALL THE WAY
abstract: After the 500 Members of Parliament had taken their seats in the Palace of Westminster this morning - and just before President Reagan arrived to address them - Lottie Pearson, a charlady there, got out her vacuum cleaner and ran it one more time over the red carpet that leads up to the grand marble staircase.   ''We want the whole affair to be nice for him,'' Mrs. Pearson explained. And nice it certainly was, intricately planned and exquisitely executed, right from the first trumpet fanfare.   President Reagan spoke in the Royal Gallery of the Parliament, a splendid, richly decorated, 110-foot chamber adjacent to the House of Lords, and it was the kind of glittering, ceremonial occasion that the British stage with great flair.

headline: 15 Die in South-West Africa
abstract: West Africa, May 26 (UPI) - A head-on collision between a truck and an army vehicle killed 15 tribesmen on Tuesday, an army spokesman said today. The tribesmen were in the truck on their way from an army base to Nkurenkuro.

headline: BREZHNEV AT RALLY, SCOTCHING 4 WEEKS OF MYSTERY AND RUMOR
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev appeared at a nationally televised Kremlin rally today, ending a four-week absence from public view during which Moscow was swept by unconfirmed reports that he had been hospitalized.   The 75-year-old leader appeared considerably thinner but otherwise much as he had before as he took his place on the stage of the Moscow Palace of Congresses at celebrations marking the 112th anniversary of Lenin's birth.   Mr. Brezhnev did not speak, but he listened to an hourlong address by his Politburo colleague Yuri V. Andropov, chairman of the Committee for State Security, the K.G.B., and then took a seat for a program of songs and dances.

headline: Print Entries Do Poorly In Art Director Awards
abstract: Only 18 gold medals were given out last Friday at the 61st annual awards of the Art Directors Club at the Waldorf-Astoria, and only 10 of them were for media advertising. Last year, 29 golds were awarded.

headline: LEASE LAW IS DEFENDED BY LONG
abstract: Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana, the ranking Democrat on the Republican-controlled Finance Committee, lined up with the Administration today in defense of the 1981 law that loosened the rules governing the use of leasing agreements to sell tax benefits.   Senator Long's fervent statement of support as the committee began discussing how to raise revenue, and an attack on the law by Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, were seen as signs that a hard battle over leasing is ahead. Senator Bentsen is Senator Long's friend and usually his ally.

headline: ARGENTINES SEE JUMP IN INFLATION
abstract: Short-term emergency measures adopted since the outbreak of the Falkland crisis more than a month ago have injected a bit of stability into Argentina's recession-struck and hyper-inflationary economy.   But the consensus in Argentina's business community is that the financial strains and dislocations that the conflict in the South Atlantic have caused - combined with a wave of spending by the military - have guaranteed that inflation will soar in the months ahead, and that a free-market, belt-tightening experiment under Economics Minister Roberto Alemann is just about over.   Well-placed bankers, economists and business executives say that a protracted war with Britain could force Argentina into declaring a moratorium on payments of its foreign debt. Economist and Publisher   Thus far, Mr. Alemann, a respected economist and publisher, has insisted in public and in the policies he has directed that Argentina will honor payments on its approximately $34 billion in foreign debt - to the point of establishing an escrow account for the British share of the debt. ''Some people say he's even going too far in showing that we are going to meet our obligations,'' one Argentine banker said.

headline: High Court Rejects a Gas-Pricing Appeal
abstract: The Supreme Court today refused to halt Federal regulation of prices for natural gas that never leaves the producing state.   The court turned away, without comment, arguments by Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and an Oklahoma-based oil company that such Federal regulation is invalid when applied to natural gas that never enters interstate commerce.   At stake are natural gas costs to consumers.  At issue is a 1978 law passed by Congress, the National Gas Policy Act.

headline: DISPUTES OVER THE HAYES AND ABERNATHY GOSPEL
abstract: To the Business Editor: While I enjoyed reading ''Management Gospel Gone Wrong'' (May 30), which attempted to deal with the subtle reasons for Japan's current industrial productivity, unfortunately it doesn't tell us anything that is not obvious. If this is the essence of revolutionary spirit at the Harvard Business School, then we really are in trouble.   There are no simple keys that unlock the Japanese mystery. Any portrayal of that philosophy will defeat the current opportunity to correct our dilemma. Discounted cash flow, lower labor costs, automation, etc., are industrial characteristics of Japanese social structure and value systems that are several hundred years old. We cannot transplant these characteristics of Japanese industry into American soil and assume they will survive.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CASTRO OFFERS TO GIVE HIS ALL
abstract: Over the last two decades, Fidel Castro has conceived myriad ways of keeping alive Cuba's revolutionaty spirit. Last year, he caught Cubans by surprise with his campaign against obesity. Now he has asked them to donate their - presumably slimmed down - bodies for medical use after death.   ''Let's see if the millions of citizens of this country agree,'' the Cuban leader told a Communist Youth Congress in April, ''and in this way we'll deprive the worms of some of their food.''

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The British victories at Goose Green and Darwin, where British paratroops were reportedly outnumbered 2 to 1, appear to vindicate the NATO doctrine that aggressive, well-officered infantry constantly on the move can defeat a larger enemy force tied to fixed defenses.   British military sources believe that similar tactics, supported by naval gunfire and Harrier jets, should enable the paratroops and marine commandos to engage the Argentine garrison at Stanley on something like even terms. These sources are confident that the superior training and morale of the British professionals will be decisive.   The unknown ingredient in the tactical situation is how and where the British Fifth Brigade will be used. The brigade, made up of two Guards battalions and one Gurkha battalion, has now been transferred from the Queen Elizabeth 2 to assault ships and represents Rear Adm.  John F. Woodward's floating reserve.

headline: WEIDENBAUM REJECTS ESTIMATES OF LOWER DEFICIT
abstract: Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, today dismissed as mistaken the forecasts that the Federal budget deficit this year may be $30 billion or more below the $100.5 billion projected by the Reagan Administration.   An estimate that the deficit might be as low as $65 billion was published earlier this month by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research organization. The thread of that argument was repeated Monday by a senior Republican Representative, Clarence J.  Brown, in an open letter to President Reagan. Mr. Brown is one of four contenders for the Repubican gubernatorial nomination in Ohio.

headline: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FRENCH GENERATOR PACT
abstract: Alsthom-Atlantique S.A. said today that Electricite de France had placed two firm orders and four options on eight sets of 1,300-megawatt turbo generators. The company did not state the value of the order but said that the generators used French technology only.

headline: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Woolworth Unit Plans
abstract: F.W. Woolworth & Company Ltd., the British subsidiary of the United States retail chain, is considering the sale of up to 25 stores and an office building, the chairman, Geoffrey Rodgers, said in the annual report released here today.   A spokesman said the 25 stores might fetch about $160 million.

headline: PAULIN, H, & CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; June 22, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Other Business; EASTER TREATS FOR CHOCOLATE MAKERS
abstract: From dime-store marshmallow chicks to pricey chocolate cottontails, Easter goodies are selling well this year.  At Macy's Herald Square store, hundreds of pounds of solid chocolate bunnies and foil-wrapped rabbits, selling at $4.95 a pound, were sold out by midweek at the candy department. Sales clerks also reported a brisk business in imported Easter delicacies -Perugina's $10 to $25 chocolate eggs and $12 ceramic Limoges eggs.

headline: Your Money; Plan Now For 1982 Taxes
abstract: THIS may be the time to be struggling with last year's taxes, but it's also the time to look ahead. What should taxpayers be thinking about now to make things easier next year?   ''There's a feeling that you should clear the decks now and forget about taxes until next year,'' said David Berenson of Ernst & Whinney, the public accounting firm. ''But that's the biggest mistake you can make in tax planning. You should look at taxes with foresight, not hindsight.''

headline: Harvester Statement
abstract: The International Harvester Company, which on Thursday reported a $198.3 million loss for the second quarter, reiterated today that there was ''no truth to the rumors'' that it would file a bankruptcy petition.   On Thursday, the rumors sparked a sell-off of Harvester shares, which fell $1.375, to $3.25, on heavy volume.

headline: DENNY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELI JETS BOMB GUERRILLA TARGETS IN REPRISAL STRIKE
abstract: Waves of Israeli jets struck at Palestinian guerrilla camps here and in southern Lebanon today in what the Israeli command described as retaliation for the shooting of the Israeli Ambassador to Britain.   For two hours, Israeli planes bombed crowded Palestinian guerrilla camps in Beirut's southern suburbs. Then Israeli jets attacked southern guerrilla strongholds in the terraced hillsides around Nabatiye, Arab Selim and Wadi al-Akhadar, about 10 miles north of the Israeli border.   Lebanese Government security sources said at least 45 people were killed and more than 150 wounded in the Israeli strikes here and in southern Lebanon.

headline: HRT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Penchina Agency On Next Plateau
abstract: Stephen Penchina opened his own agency under his own name a year ago with a bunch of lawyers as clients. Having survived that experience he has stepped up to the next plateau and now he is chairman and creative director of Penchina, Selkowitz, at a new location, 575 Madison Avenue, instead of 870 Fifth Avenue, and has a couple of new clients.

headline: EXPERTS FEAR THAT UNPREDICTABLE CHAIN OF EVENTS COULD BRING NUCLEAR WAR
abstract: Time and again, the people who are engaged in the grim exercise of speculating how nuclear war might begin allude to the summer of 1914, when the nations of Europe slipped into a world war after a relatively minor incident.   That incident, the shooting of the Archduke Francis Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary in the Bosnian city of Sarajevo, set in motion a series of events that the world's most powerful leaders could not stop, and it has suddenly emerged at the heart of the discussion over the possibility of nuclear war in this age. Military planners, Government officials and foreign policy scholars stress that they do not believe a nuclear war is likely, but many add that they fear that one could grow out of the countless unpredictable events that occur each year.   ''You can think of a hundred ways in which nuclear war might start, and it could still start in a thoroughly unpredictable way,'' said Jerome B. Wiesner, a former Presidential science adviser and an architect of America's air defense system. Debate Becoming Public   Until recently such discussion was confined to planners in the Pentagon and the State Department and to a handful of experts in universities and policy institutes. But as the movement for a freeze on nuclear arms has gathered momentum, speculation about the events that might set off a nuclear war has been increasingly conducted publicly.

headline: Ad Pages Down 1.4%
abstract: For the first time this year, ad pages of member magazines in the Publishers Information Bureau dipped in March over the comparable month last year. The figure was 11,434, a 1.4 percent drop, according to the P.I.B., a sister organization of the Magazine Publishers Association. Revenues looked better, up 5 percent, to $320 million.

headline: ARGENTINA SAYS 2 BRITISH WARSHIPS HAVE VIOLATED ITS ZONE OF DEFENSE
abstract: Argentine officials said tonight that two British warships violated the Argentine defense zone today by moving to within 50 miles of the sparsely inhabited Falkland Islands dependency of South Georgia.   The Argentine press agency Telam quoted one Government official as saying a British attack on South Georgia, which is situated 800 miles east of the Falklands, was ''imminent.''   The officials, terming the ship's movements a violation of the Rio Treaty, said the Government had filed a protest with the Organization of American States. The treaty, known formally as the Inter-American Treaty of Reciprocal Assistance, states that an armed attack against any nation that signed the accord constitutes an attack against all.

headline: Shultz to See Reagan At Camp David Today
abstract: George P. Shultz, President Reagan's choice to replace Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State, is scheduled to arrive at Dulles Airport outside Washington at 11 A.M. Saturday via Concorde jet, the White House said tonight.   Mr. Shultz is then to go by helicopter to Camp David in the Maryland mountains for a 12:30 P.M. working lunch with the President. Mr. Shultz has been in London on a business trip.

headline: SCHLITZ ASKS COURT TO BLOCK STROH BID
abstract: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company asked a Federal judge today to block a $315 million takeover bid by the Stroh Brewery Company.

headline: TANDEM COMPUTERS: NO RECESSION HERE
abstract: going manner and country drawl, has always seemed the hayseed who came to the Silicon Valley from Texas and outsmarted the local talent. Mr. Treybig's company, Tandem Computers Inc., was founded six years ago and is selling its machines now at an annual rate of $300 million, a performance that outpaces even Tandem's famous computer-manufacturing neighbors.   Tandem found its niche with a computer that it branded the Nonstop. It is designed to run for years without stopping. It does so by employing two processors for redundancy and with a built-in battery to provide backup in power failures. Such machines are critical in industries needing to protect vital records or assure continuous service and Tandem has sold to a wide range of customers, including banks, stock exchanges, hospitals, service bureaus, communications firms, publishers and the Federal Government. As these customers grew, so did Tandem.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: JAMAICA'S PREMIER PRAISED BY REAGAN
abstract: President Reagan began a working vacation in the Caribbean today by hailing Jamaica as proof that democracy and economic development go hand-in-hand and attacking Cuba, 90 miles to the north, for supporting ''a philosophy alien to this hemisphere.''   Mr. Reagan praised Jamaica on every appearance during the day. At the end of a working dinner with Jamaican leaders at 10:45 P.M., the President, who seemed tired, added attacks on Cuba for pursuing ''a road to serfdom'' and promoting ''the turmoil in El Salvador.''   He praised the record of Prime Minister Edward P.G. Seaga, just after the Jamaican leader had hailed Mr. Reagan's Caribbean basin economic plan and thanked him for American aid and investment.

headline: Around the World; Former Premier Hua Hospitalized in Peking
abstract: Hua Guofeng, the former Chinese Prime Minister and Communist Party Chairman who was demoted to sixth deputy chairman last year, has been hospitalized here and is recuperating from an unspecified illness, the official New China News Agency said tonight.   Mr. Hua, Mao Zedong's chosen successor, was Prime Minister from 1976, after Mao's death, until 1980.  The former party chief, now 61 years old, makes occasional public appearances but is believed to have little power.

headline: A line of type was dropped from a caption last week accompanying the article on the electronic stock market. The caption should have read as follows: ''If the firm is itself a market maker, it may fill the order from stock it owns or match the buy order with a sell order. This is known as 'internalization.' ''
abstract: Also, in a chart on page 19 listing the 30 stocks to be traded in the new system, the quotes for the Barnett Banks of Florida were incorrect. The company's 12-month, high-low range was 29 1/2 to 18 3/4, and its May 13 closing price was 20 5/8.

headline: PATENTS; Device Promotes Relaxing Brain Waves
abstract: A device to promote brain wave patterns associated with relaxed and meditative states of mind has been patented for the Omnitronics Research Corporation, Akron, Ohio. John D. Williamson, an electronics engineer, is the inventor named in this week's patent 4,335,710.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 23, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee of the Special Session - 9 A.M.   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M.

headline: INDIANAPOLIS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Syntex Unit's San Jose Plant
abstract: The Syntex Corporation, a diversified pharmaceuticals and agribusiness concern based in Panama, said its Syntex (U.S.A.) unit would build a $500 million pharmaceutical plant in South San Jose, a city of 670,000 at the south end of San Francisco Bay.   Construction would start by late 1983 or early 1984, Francis Koch, vice president of Syntex (U.S.A.), said.

headline: VOLVO DIVERSIFYING AWAY FROM AUTOS
abstract: A.B. Volvo, Scandinavia's biggest company, is approaching auto manufacturing as if, over the long term, the company realizes that almost everything else it does has greater potential than making cars.   In 1971, about 75 percent of Volvo's revenue involved autos. Now it is about 25 percent. Oil trading, a Volvo activity since Beijerinvest, a Scandinavian trading company, became part of the Volvo group last year, accounted for greater sales in 1981 than cars did, just as the group's food-processing companies - basically beer and soft drinks - represented greater volume than the bus division.

headline: Ogden to Acquire Allied Maintenance
abstract: The Ogden Corporation and the Allied Maintenance Corporation announced a definitive agreement for Ogden to acquire Allied in a transaction valued at about $116 million. Under the agreement, Allied stockholders would receive 1.75 shares of Odgen common stock for each Allied share.

headline: Polaroid to Skip Wage Increase
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation, which earlier this year dismissed 1,000 employees in a move to cut costs, said that it would not pay a midyear cost-of-living increase to most of the remaining employees.   Company officials said that all but 200 of the company's 12,000 domestic employees would be affected by the suspension in raises, which was made necessary by the ''severe decline in the world economy'' that has lessened demand for Polaroid's photographic products.   ''We're not freezing salaries or anything like that - we'll still grant merit increases,'' said Samual A. Yanes, director of public relations. Mr. Yanes said Polaroid granted a general 5 percent pay increase earlier this year and that the savings from yesterday's decision would be ''negligible.''

headline: RED CROSS GROUP SEEKS SAFE ZONE IN STANLEY
abstract: The International Committee of the Red Cross, disclosing that it had sent a team into the Falkland capital of Stanley last Thursday, urgently appealed today for the establishment of a neutral zone there for the protection of the civilian population.   The British Government promptly accepted the appeal, in a statement that also acknowledged the possibility that the first two civilian deaths in the war had occurred this weekend.   But with the British expected to assault the Argentine defenders' positions in Stanley at any time, the Red Cross had received no official answer from the Argentine Government. However, the independent news agency Noticias Argentinas reported, without citing any source, that the junta in Buenos Aires had also decided to accept the safety-zone proposal.

headline: REGAL-BELOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELI DIPLOMAT SHOT AND KILLED IN PARIS
abstract: An Israeli diplomat was fatally shot by a young woman today in the lobby of his Paris apartment. No group took responsibility, but Israel said the slaying was the work of the Palestine Liberation Organization.   The P.L.O. office in Paris said it would have no immediate comment.  Authorities said it was the first time an Israeli diplomat had been assassinated in Paris.  The 43-year-old diplomat, Yacov Barsimantov, second secretary in charge of political affairs, died of head wounds about two hours after the shooting, the police and Israeli officials said. His wife and 8-year-old daughter were with him at the time of the attack, according to French and Israeli officials.

headline: CANADA HAPPY WITH FRANCE'S BALANCING ACT
abstract: Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy has returned to Paris, leaving Quebec with a promise that France will never abandon it and will remain at its side ''whatever the ways it may choose to affirm its identity.''   On Tuesday Mr. Mauroy ended a six-day visit to Canada during which he performed a difficult balancing act between opposing Governments - that of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau in Ottawa, intent on keeping Quebec part of Canada, and that of Premier Rene Levesque of Quebec, equally intent on achieving independence.   While refusing to be drawn into the quarrel, Mr. Mauroy managed to please both sides by insisting on his desire for ''normal'' and ''friendly'' relations with the federal Government, and for the continuation of ''privileged'' relations with French-speaking Quebec, a ''branch'' of a common family tree.   Mr. Mauroy asserted that compatability between the two relations was very possible and he left behind more good feelings between France and Canada than at any time in the last 15 years of often strained ties.

headline: Union Oil Sees Future for Shale
abstract: The Exxon Corporation's scuttling of the Colony Oil Shale Project does not mean the death of oil shale development altogether, says Fred L. Hartley, chairman and president of the Union Oil Company of California.   Indeed, work at Union Oil's planned oil shale facility will continue unabated, he said yesterday.

headline: JAPANESE EXECUTIVES CHARGED IN I.B.M. THEFT CASE
abstract: Eighteen Japanese businessmen, many of them senior officials at two major Japanese computer companies, were charged today with conspiring to steal confidential computer information from the International Business Machines Corporation and transport it to Japan.   The Justice Department said the conspiracy involved separate efforts by employees of Hitachi Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation to obtain I.B.M. information needed in the development of computers and related equipment. As part of the charge, the Japanese were accused of paying a total of $648,000 to an undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to steal computer secrets from I.B.M.   Six of the Japanese were arrested today by the F.B.I. in California and warrants were issued Monday for the others, all of whom reside in Japan, according to William H. Webster, the director of the F.B.I.   The case is part of a larger emphasis by the bureau in recent years on protecting technology, considered one of the country's most valuable assets, from industrial espionage as well as foreign intelligence agents. The attempt to steal I.B.M. technology, although it involves foreign businessmen, is not a counterintelligence case, F.B.I. officials said, but a commercial theft case.

headline: ISRAEL SAYS SYRIA BROKE CEASE-FIRE
abstract: Israel said today that Syrian and Palestinian forces attacked Israeli troops in Lebanon south of the Beirut-Damascus highway this morning, resulting in heavy fighting.   An Israeli military spokesman said that Israeli forces, which on Tuesday evening accepted a cease-fire requested by the United States, replied to today's attacks with air strikes and artillery barrages and that heavy fighting continued at Beirut and eastward along the highway. He added that the Israelis were ''silencing the sources'' of Syrian and Palestinian fire.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Absolute Coatings Inc. has appointed Donald J. Miner vice president, sales.   * American General Corp., Houston, has named Andrew Delaney vice chairman.   * Bally Manufacturing Corp. has elected Donald B. Romans executive vice president amd chief financial officer.

headline: BRAZIL OPPOSITION OPTIMISTIC ON VOTE
abstract: A Government maneuver to guarantee victory for its party in scheduled nationwide elections appears to have failed, and opposition leaders have recovered their belief that they will end up with significant gains.   The vote, set for Nov. 15, will be the first fully free balloting in Brazil in the last 16 years. It represents a key step in the political liberalization program being conduced by the country's military rulers. Under the program, called ''abertura,'' the Portuguese word for opening, political prisoners have been freed, most censorship has been lifted, an amnesty has been declared for thousands of Brazilians who were exiled or who lost their political rights, and a variety of political parties have emerged.

headline: NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LABORITE LEADERS MOVE TO OUST LEFT-WING FACTION
abstract: The Labor Party leadership, seeking to reverse a long political slide, moved today to rid itself of a ''conspiratorial'' left-wing faction that was partly responsible for defections to the new Social Democratic Party.   Labor's ruling National Executive Committee voted 16 to 10 to set up a register of approved organizations operating within the movement, and then also decided that one of them, known as the Militant Tendency, did not fit the criteria.   The committee softened the intended expulsion by setting a threemonth limit for the leftist group to ''list its aims, officers, employees, membership and accounts'' and otherwise follow the party's requirements for political organizations affiliated with the Labor movement.

headline: Brunswick Files Suit Over Patents
abstract: The Brunswick Corporation, a diversified manufacturer of technical and recreational products, said it had filed a patent infringement suit against the Suzuki Motor Company of Japan in Federal District Court in Milwaukee.

headline: U.S. ENVOY GETS MIXED REVIEWS IN MOROCCO
abstract: When Richard M. Nixon arrived for a recent visit, the United States Ambassador gave a dinner in his honor, with the 23-year-old son of the late Shah of Iran seated next to him.   The Iranian, Riza Pahlevi, who now lives in Rabat and who has proclaimed himself his father's successor, has become a regular at the Ambassador's residence, a relationship that is much discussed here. Even more the talk of Rabat, however, is the exuberant style with which the 44-year-old Ambassador, Joseph V. Reed Jr., conducts diplomacy.   In the eight months since Mr. Reed, a former vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank, arrived here, he has delighted King Hassan II, whom he has seen 40 times, with pledges of increased American assistance. He has irritated some influential Moroccans who wonder whether the Reagan Administration will be able to deliver the help.  He has also annoyed some other envoys who regard his style as grating.

headline: Head of Steel Group
abstract: The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, David Roderick, was elected chairman of the American Iron and Steel Institute yesterday, succeeding William De Lancey, the chairman and chief executive of the Republic Steel Corporation, who had served two one-year terms as head of the industry trade group.

headline: Around the World; U.S. Official Finds No Repression in Haiti
abstract: The third-ranking official of the Justice Department says he is convinced that there is ''no political repression'' in Haiti.   Associate Attorney General Rudolph W. Giuliani, testifying Thursday at a hearing of a class-action lawsuit seeking the release of 2,100 refugees in Government detention camps, said that repression in Haiti ''simply does not exist now'' and that refugees had nothing to fear from the Government of Jean-Claude Duvalier.

headline: BLACK-RUN BUSINESSES RANKED
abstract: Energy-related companies dominated the top of the list of the 100 leading black-owned businesses in 1981, while construction, hightechnology and services that cater to black consumers showed the strongest growth, an annual survey by Black Enterprise magazine shows.   According to the survey, which was published in the June issue and based on revenues, Motown Industries, the entertainment company, remained in the No.1 position, where it has been since the survey started 10 years ago. The magazine estimated Motown's 1981 revenues at $91.7 million.

headline: NICARAGUA IS GIVEN NEW U.S. PROPOSAL TO MEND RELATIONS
abstract: A State Department official said today that the United States had offered Nicaragua a new plan that would mend relations in return for an end to that country's support for insurgents in El Salvador.   In essence, the eight-point plan provides for the resumption of American economic aid to the Central American nation, a pledge of nonintervention in Nicaraguan affairs and pressure against Nicaraguan exiles in the United States plotting to intervene in Nicaragua.   In return, Nicaragua would have to end aid to guerrillas in El Salvador and agree to limits on heavy arms and foreign military advisers in Central America. The arms question has been the stalling point in past attempts to start negotiations.

headline: Market Place; PERT's Fight With Tenant
abstract: SHAREHOLDERS of Produce Exchange Realty Trust are holding fast, waiting to see how much rent their prize tenant is going to pay. The outcome will determine the value of their infrequently traded shares.    PERT, as the trust is known, owns the land and building at 2 Broadway in Manhattan. The 1.3-million-square-foot building is fully occupied. But for the moment, anyway, PERT is having trouble collecting the rent. Even so, its shares were firm, at $20 bid Monday on the over-the-counter market. That was the most recent trade.

headline: GULF GOAL: DOMESTIC RESERVES
abstract: Few American oil companies have been more severely hurt by their reliance on foreign sources of supply than the Gulf Oil Corporation.  And even fewer have matched Gulf's determination to buy another oil producer with large domestic reserves.   In April, Harold H. Hammer, Gulf's executive vice president and chief administrative officer, said in an interview that the company was considering acquisitions of small, medium-size and even large oil companies. ''The best buys are the biggest ones,'' he added.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN INQUEST HALTED BY DISPUTE
abstract: An inquest into the death of a white trade unionist in the custody of the security police was halted today on its first day by objections from a lawyer for the police to the presentation in open court of an affidavit the dead man signed on the last day of his life.   Dr. Neil Aggett, a young physician who worked for a predominantly black trade union, was said by the police to have committed suicide by hanging in the early hours of Feb. 5. About 14 hours earlier, the magistrate conducting the inquest was told, he signed a statement in which he declared that he had been assaulted by the security police and subjected to electric shocks during interrogation sessions.   Pieter J. Schabort, a lawyer retained by the police to protect their interests in the course of the Aggett inquest, argued tenaciously for an hour and a half today that the dead man's affidavit was inadmissible because the question of whether he was assaulted before his death had little or no bearing on the central question of how he died.

headline: 3 CAMBODIANS SIGN ACCORD ON EXILE REGIME
abstract: A new Cambodian government in exile was signed into existence today by three men, once bitter enemies, who now see Vietnam as their common foe.   Prince Norodom Sihanouk, former Prime Minister Son Sann and Khieu Samphan, a still shadowy figure from the years of Pol Pot's Communist rule, now constitute the ruling ''inner cabinet'' of what has been named the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea.   The three leaders promised to intensify their military opposition to the presence in Cambodia of up to 200,000 Vietnamese soldiers.They also announced that they would meet again very soon, ''inside Cambodia,'' to work out the details of their delicately balanced resistance.

headline: CRIME'S LINGERING ALLURE
abstract: AMID hard times, crime is doing handsomely. The television networks p lan a bumper crop of crime dramas for the fall. Major b ookpublishing houses are reissuing squads of classic detective n ovels from decades past. Bookstores specializing in crime stories s ay business is better than ever.   In the current economic decline, the appeal of drama and fiction about crime and detection has widely proven slump-proof and, in certain areas, actually countercyclical.   The people who write, produce, or sell these crime-related works of the imagination say there's no great mystery why the recession should spare, and indeed favor sectors of the crime-story industry while it has bludgeoned the steel business, smothered housing starts, and starved Detroit.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: SATURDAY, MAY 1, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The index of leading economic indicators fell 0.5 percent in March, its 11th consecutive monthly decline, the Commerce Department reported. The report was taken as another signal that the recession is continuing, though perhaps at a slower pace. (Page 33.) Orders for new factory goods rose 0.2 percent in March, the second monthly increase in a row. (42.)   President Reagan discussed budget strategy with G.O.P.  Congressional leaders in the aftermath of the failure of bipartisan negotiations. There were predictions that Congress will find it extremely difficult to adopt a budget this year. (1.)

headline: P.L.O.'S MAIN LEBANON BASES FALL TO FAST-MOVING ISRAELIS
abstract: Israeli troops have now captured nearly all the major Palestinian strongholds in southern Lebanon and have also heavily damaged the guerrillas' headquarters complex, in a crowded Palestinian quarter at the southern edge of Beirut.   The major remaining Palestinian base, in the coastal town of Damur, about 10 miles south of Beirut, is under steady naval and air bombardment.   The town, mostly in ruins since the 1975-76 Lebanese civil war, and a mountain ridge rising sharply to the east are mostly held by guerrillas from what is called the rejectionist wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization, including the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command.

headline: TRIAL GIVES PEEK AT SOUTH AFRICA INTELLIGENCE WEB
abstract: The testimony of Col. Mike Hoare, the mercenary leader who is now standing trial on a charge of hijacking arising from his attempt to oust the Government of the Seychelles in November, has focused attention on the influential role played by Military Intelligence, a branch of the South African armed forces.   It is a subject normally of conjecture and rumor that South African newspapers cannot discuss directly as a result of stringent legislation giving the Defense Ministry a virtual veto on anything that is said about its activities.   But in testifying that his attempted coup had active backing from the Government here, Colonel Hoare appeared to confirm the widespread belief that Military Intelligence has gained a position of primacy in the South African security establishment since P.W.  Botha, who served as Defense Minister for 13 years, became Prime Minister in 1978.   In the mercenary leader's account, his contacts with the Government were initially with the National Intelligence Service, a civilian agency analogous to the Central Intelligence Agency. This unit was regarded as being in a dominant position under Mr. Botha's predecessor as Prime Minister, John Vorster, when it was known as the Bureau of State Security. But it was subsequently renamed and apparently downgraded by Mr. Botha.

headline: CBS-A.T.& T. Videotex To Study Ad Potential
abstract: The 200 homes in Ridgewood, N.J., that will take part this fall in an experiment of videotex service by CBS and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will also be getting advertising from 13 of the country's better-known advertising agencies.   CBS will supply all of the computer data that the householders will receive through their Bell-supplied two-way terminals and the agencies will be testing the medium for its advertising potential.   ''You almost have to get into the water to get a feel for the thing,'' said George Simko, senior vice president of Benton & Bowles, one of the agencies.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Publications to acquire American Automatic Merchandiser magazine from the co-founders/publishers, Mike Michaels and Ben Ginsberg.

headline: Knight Royalty
abstract: The Knight Royalty Corporation said today that it had a working capital deficiency of about $1.1 million on March 31, which it hoped to correct by offering unspecified oil and gas properties for sale at $7.5 million. The company reported a loss of $397,294 on revenue of $1,187,586 for the nine-month period ending March 31.

headline: People
abstract: * Edward M. Lebar and Marc S. Bromberg appointed senior vice presidents at Young & Rubicam USA.

headline: STANDARD OIL CO (INDIANA) reports earnings for Qtr to March31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEW WARS SHOW POWER OF MILITARY BASICS
abstract: The fighting in Lebanon, in the South Atlantic and between Iran and Iraq has tended to focus public attention on advanced missiles and weapons, on glamorous military hardware. But the combat also seems to underline the importance of such basic military factors as training, tactics, motivation and the skillful use of standard weapons.   The United States armed services have not yet seen the ''afteraction reports'' of the Israeli and British forces that won victories in Lebanon and in the Falkland Islands, and they cannot yet make refined conclusions.   And while Gen. David C. Jones, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said, ''It is premature to draw any sweeping conclusions,'' it is not necessarily premature to draw some limited ones. Established Ideas Reinforced   Even in the technological field, some military analysts say, the recent events tend to reinforce established military thinking rather than to suggest revolutionary changes.

headline: CHASE LOWERS DRYSDALE WRITE-OFF
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it would take a $117 million after-tax write-off in its second fiscal quarter as a result of its dealings with Drysdale Government Securities, an improvement over the $135 million write-off the bank said it anticipated last month.   The bank said it arrived at the $117 million figure only after it finished liquidating Drysdale, a small Government securities firm that stunned Wall Street on May 17 when it failed to make $160 million in interest payments due on borrowed securities.   Chase officials said the bank was able to narrow the anticipated write-off after reassessing the tax impact of covering Drysdale Government's debts.

headline: 2 Sentenced in Belgrade
abstract: Two ethnic Albanians were sentenced to jail for spreading hostile propaganda against Yugoslavia, the newspaper Politika Ekspres reported here today. The paper said the men, who are brothers, had distributed an illegal newspaper that ''crudely attacked our system and country'' and had circulated leaflets, written slogans on walls and taped propaganda broadcasts. One man got four years and the other, five.

headline: AMERICAN PIPE SUPPLIES UNNEEDED, SOVIET SAYS
abstract: If President Reagan's decision to extend the ban on American technology for the Siberian gas pipeline has hurt or frightened the Russians, they have been characteristically careful not to show it.   The official Tass press agency briefly denounced the action as ''an attempt to turn ordinary trade between states into a weapon of political blackmail and pressure.'' But for the most part, commentaries have been limited to quotes from Western business and government leaders venting anger over the United States decision.

headline: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Magazines for Industry May Be Up for Sale
abstract: There was a report abroad yesterday that Harcourt Brace Jovanovich is negotiating to buy Don Gussow's Magazines for Industry, with the exception of Glass Industry magazine, which a book publisher is looking to acquire.

headline: Kate Greenaway
abstract: Kate Greenaway Industries, a New York manufacturer of girls' dresses, said it had filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 7 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: TEXAS FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FUGITIVE BROKER SURRENDERS
abstract: Gary V. Lewellyn, a fugitive stockbroker charged with embezzlement and stock manipulation, surrendered here today, ending a three-week hunt by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.   Federal officials had been looking for the 33-year-old Mr. Lewellyn since his disappearance on March 31, when he drove his blue Jeep Wagoneer to the Des Moines airport and hopped on a flight to Chicago. There he withdrew $500,000 in $100 bills from the Continental Illinois Bank and went into hiding.   Mr. Lewellyn waived a preliminary hearing and was released by United States Magistrate James Hodges on a $500,000 unsecured bond, which meant no cash had to be posted. United States Attorney James Reynolds had asked that bond be set at $5 million so ''there would be some sting to it.'' The court proceedings lasted 12 minutes and later Mr. Lewellyn traveled to his home in Des Moines.

headline: NEW-HOME SALES RATE FALLS 15.3%
abstract: Sales of new single-family houses plunged 15.3 percent in April from March, to the lowest level since the Government began keeping such figures 19 years ago, two Federal agencies said today.   Robert Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist, said that with interest rates on mortgate loans still high, ''prospects for an upturn in the immediate future are virtually nil.''   The April sales pace - 315,000 houses at a seasonally adjusted annual rate -was well below the previous low of 335,000 last October, the Commerce Department and the Department of Housing and Urban Development reported. Only an estimated 30,000 new homes were sold in April. April's sales rate was 30.9 percent below that of December, apparently indicating that the recession in the important construction industry was continuing.

headline: Rising Truck Output
abstract: Truck production by the nation's major auto makers will reach an estimated 588,000 vehicles this quarter, up 16.7 percent from 504,000 in the same period a year ago, according to an industry trade journal.

headline: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Court Blocks Bank Merger
abstract: A Federal District Court in Hartford has blocked the Hartford National Corporation's $57 million acquisition of the Connecticut National Bank of Bridgeport, saying that Hartford National's proxy statements were ''materially false and misleading.''   The court ruled in favor of E. Clayton Gengras, a financier who owns about 6.2 percent of Hartford National's stock, who sued to block the merger, which would create the largest bank in the state.  Mr. Gengras accused Hartford National of issuing a misleading proxy statement, especially in respect to the financial history of the bank, which experienced large losses in 1976.   Hartford National said it plans to appeal the ruling.  Mr. Gengras, who is Hartford National's largest stockholder, has opposed the merger on the grounds that the price is too high.

headline: JUNTA IS USING SLICK ADS TO BOLSTER WAR MORALE
abstract: Not far from where Argentina's military leaders are plotting the country's war strategy for the Falklands, another group is plotting its advertising strategy.   The advertisements, which appear in newspapers here as well as on all four Buenos Aires television stations, have been used not only to rally the public behind the war effort but in recent days to head off some of the discomfort over the Government's conduct of the war.   With all but a handful of journalists barred from the battle zone and information sifted through tight censorship, it is sometimes easier to get a sense of the Government's thinking from its 30-second television spots than from its official communiques.   The advertisements are slick, well-produced affairs. They are often filled with patriotic images and always set to a rousing, infectious theme song, performed at marching cadence by a chorus of men and women accompanied by piano and heraldic trumpets.

headline: Aramco Production
abstract: The giant Arabian American Oil Company said today its crude oil production in Saudi Arabia last year was unchanged from 1980, at 9.6 million barrels a day.

headline: Advertising; Magazine Ad Survey Findings
abstract: IN the battle between broadcast and print advertising media, every weapon is important. That's why the movers and shakers in magazineland were upset. A $1 million piece of research by Alfred Politz shows magazines to have a number of special and very positive qualities as carriers of advertising that agencies have not been using in the media evaluation process - probably because the last Politz project was 16 years ago.

headline: Trial for Ghotbzadeh Is Expected Soon
abstract: Former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, accused of plotting to overthrow Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic Government, will be put on trial soon, according to the Iranian Prosecutor General.   In an interview published in the newspaper Ettelaat today, the Prosecutor General, Hojatolislam Mousavi-Tabrizi, said that the interrogation of those involved in the plot was almost complete and that the trial would begin within a month.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Time and options are running out for the British task force at the Falkland Islands.  Time because the troops at sea are unlikely to retain their fighting edge much longer after more than three weeks tossing in the tumultuous South Atlantic and with the weather worsening daily.   Options are running out, because, despite the bravado of announcing a 12-mile limit for Argentine men-of-war and aircraft, Adm. Sir John Woodward has only 14 ships and 17 Harrier fighters to enforce a close blockade of a coast that runs for over 2,500 miles from Buenos Aires in the north to Ushuaia in the south.

headline: Advertising; Recovery Is in Sight At Esquire
abstract: FOR Esquire magazine, next year will bring not only a 12 percent ad rate increase but also a 50th anniversary, and the young entrepreneurs who are now running it are trying think up a proper way to celebrate, the 50 years, that is.   ''Our goal is to make it the single most important event in publishing that year,'' said Alan Greenberg, the 31-year-old package goods marketing man who is the magazine's advertising director.   Actually, the very fact that the fabled but long-troubled publication is still around might be an important enough event in itself.   Magazine people cannot point to many successful turnarounds.  Cosmopolitan is the classic. John Mack Carter, editor of Good Houskeeping and long a student of the medium, said that you could probably add The New Yorker, Sports Afield and True Story. But he was hard put to think of another.

headline: Iranian Oil Price Down
abstract: Iran is selling oil on a spot basis for under $28 a barrel, well below the $34 benchmark price of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, West German oil industry sources said today. They added that the National Iranian Oil Company had begun a major marketing drive, increasing sales during April to around two million barrels a day, though some of this appeared to be from stocks.

headline: Morocco's King in U.S.  To Discuss Arms Aid
abstract: King Hassan II of Morocco, whose North African nation is fighting a guerrilla war in Western Sahara, arrived here today seeking American arms and support.   Morocco bought $30 million worth of American military goods in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, and the Reagan Administration has proposed increasing that to $100 million next year.

headline: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 UP 20.6%
abstract: The Big Three auto manufacturers reported today that sale rose a substantial 20.6 percent in early May, renewing hopes for a successful spring selling season.   The General Motors Corporation reported sales were up 30.6 percent, the sharpest increase of the five major domestic manufacturers, while the Ford Motor Company's sales increased 5.1 percent from the comparable 1981 period. Sales by the Chrysler Corporation were up 2.5 percent. There were eight selling days in the period both this year and last.

headline: El Paso Gas Interest
abstract: The El Paso Company said today that it had a 48.44 percent interest in a gas well in Okahoma's Anardarko Basin. The well was tested successfully by the Inexco Oil Company, the well's operator, El Paso said. The 1-22 Fourtner, situated in Custer County, Okla., tested gas from 22 feet of the lower morrow sandstone at 15,260 feet at 3.4 million cubic feet daily, flowing through a 3/16 inch choke, the company said.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * American Electric Power Co. said it would seek regulatory approval for a public offering of up to seven million shares.   * Dan River Inc. announced it had agreed to issue up to 450,000 shares of its common stock to Salomon Brothers Inc., in exchange for up to $7.5 million of the company's long-term debt securities to be tendered by Salomon.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 20, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets on question of Palestinians at 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STRIKES SWEEP ITALY AFTER WAGE PACT IS ENDED
abstract: Protest strikes were held throughout Italy today after a decision Tuesday by the principal employers' organization to revoke an accord that for seven years has raised wages automatically as the cost of living mounted.   Strike calls issued by the three major trade-union federations, which are linked, respectively, to the Communist, Christian Democratic and Socialist Parties, were widely followed, particularly in the industrial north. The strikes ranged from 15-minute stoppages in most public services to four-hour walkouts in the private enterprises that are members of the Confindustria, the employers' confederation.

headline: Newspaper Ad Bureau Has New President
abstract: Jack Kauffman, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau since 1966, will turn over his office next Tuesday to Craig C. Standen, 39, a packaged goods marketing pro who has been executive vice president of the bureau since joining two years ago.

headline: BROWN & SHARPE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Southwest Leasing
abstract: The Southwest Leasing Corporation, a Los Angeles-based car and truck rental company with annual revenues of about $70 million, said yesterday that it had begun discussions regarding a possible merger.  The company refused to disclose further details.

headline: SEVENTH AVENUE'S SHARPEST EYE
abstract: EVERYTHING in the office is oversized, from the giant pretzel p ropped against one wall to the four-foot kitchen whisk leaning a gainst the sofa and, not least, to the man behind the desk. Measuredb y either his physical girth or his influence on the marketplace of f ashion, there is nothing small about Bernard Ozer. On Seventh Avenueh e is known as the man with the keenest eye for trends - and the g reatest gift for spreading them all across America. Mr. Ozer's view o f himself is terser, if no less grand. ''I'm an entity,'' he said.   Among the manufacturers and purveyors of clothing, Bernie Ozer, 51, is perhaps unrivaled as a fashion forecaster and hard-headed merchant who is heeded by practically everybody. His importance exceeds his official duties, which themselves are substantial: He makes buying recommendations for junior and better-priced women's apparel to 28 of the biggest department store companies in the United States - including Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, in New York; Strawbridge & Clothier, Philadelphia; Filene's, Boston; Rich's, Atlanta; Dayton's, Minneapolis, and Carson Pirie Scott & Company, Chicago - which together have a total of 353 branches.

headline: U.N. Gets Antinuclear Plea
abstract: A petition calling for abolition of nuclear weapons signed by 500,000 people, most of them Japanese, was delivered to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cullar today by a group of Roman Catholic bishops from Japan.

headline: Diners Club Will Use SSC&B Outside U.S.
abstract: Diners Club International, which has its domestic advertising done by Doyle Dane Bernbach, has decided on using SSC&B:Lintas for the rest of the known world.

headline: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that a broad decline in demand for aluminum resulted in a loss of $24.9 million for the first quarter of 1982, contrasted with earnings of $68.1 million, or $1.60 a share, in the similar quarter a year earlier. Revenues dropped 12.1 percent, to $733.8 million, from $834.4 million.   Cornell C. Maier, chairman of the Oakland, Calif., company, said in a statement: ''Aluminum prices continue to be weak and are now below the level prevailing at the beginning of the year. Thus we anticipate continuing losses in aluminum despite slightly higher volume expected in the second quarter.''

headline: BRITAIN SAID TO ORDER TROOPS TO BEGIN ATTACK WHEN READY
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has ordered British commanders in the Falkland Islands to begin their final assault on the Argentine garrison at Stanley as soon as they are ready, Government officials said today.   Paratroopers and Royal Marines are already skirmishing with the Argentines on the outskirts of Stanley, which is the islands' main settlement. British artillery is shelling the settlement from the Two Sisters ridge to the west, and reporters peering through binoculars from the summit said they could see the Argentine defenders eating their lunch.   Mrs. Thatcher said Wednesday that Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri, the Argentine President, could stave off further bloodshed by agreeing to withdraw his troops on an agreed timetable. A member of the British war cabinet added today that her remarks, in television interviews, were intended as a genuine offer to Argentina but that she was not prepared to delay military action while awaiting an answer.

headline: Iranian Security Forces Raid Leftist Hideouts
abstract: Iranian security forces killed or arrested more than 50 members of the leftist People's Mujahedeen in raids on their hideouts in Teheran today, the Teheran radio said.   The radio, monitored here, described the raids as a heavy blow to the Mujahedeen, a group of Islamic socialists.

headline: 2 DEFECTIONS THREATEN BEGIN COALITION
abstract: Two members of Parliament defected from Prime Minister Menachem Begin's shaky coalition today, leaving uncertain the Government's ability to muster a majority for a no-confidence vote Wednesday.   The two members, Yitzhak Peretz and Amnon Linn, switched from Mr.  Begin's Likud bloc to the opposition Labor alignment, led by Shimon Peres.   The change left the fate of the Government in the hands of two small parties that are not members of the governing coalition but that have sometimes supported Mr. Begin in the past.   One of them, a right-wing faction called Tehiya, with three of the Parliament's 120 seats, opposed the recent return of Sinai to Egypt and was reported tonight to be leaning against the Government.  The other, the Telem Party formed by Moshe Dayan, has two seats and intends to decide its position Wednesday morning.

headline: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pope Bids Israel Show Magnanimity in Beirut
abstract: Pope John Paul appealed to Israel today to show magnanimity in Lebanon, saying that he feared for those besieged in southern Beirut and now facing a decisive battle.

headline: KEY U.S. DIPLOMATS DERIDED BY TOON
abstract: Malcolm Toon, a former Ambassador to Moscow, said today that the Reagan Administration was using United States diplomatic posts ''as a dumping ground'' for defeated politicians and Republican financial backers.   Mr. Toon, who held three other ambassadorial posts in a 30-year Foreign Service career, said in an interview in the Foreign Service Journal that some of the most important United States embassies were being put in the hands of unqualified amateurs.   ''We do not have to accept the poor sort of talent we have seen over the last year,'' Mr. Toon said.  ''We have an actor in Mexico City, a political post, the most sensitive spot in the hemisphere,'' Mr. Toon said, in a reference to John Gavin, a Spanish-speaking film actor and longtime friend of President Reagan.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co. said it had signed a definitive agreement for its proposed acquisition of Geosource Inc.   * Argo Petroleum Corp. said that a holder had acquired nearly 5 percent of its common stock outstanding and that the company was holding discussions with the holder's representatives about his intentions.   * Benchcraft Holdings Inc., a newly formed company owned by the partners of the Jordan Company and the senior management of Benchcraft Inc., has acquired the assets and business of Benchcraft Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: U.S. INSISTING SALVADOR PURSUE LAND PROGRAM
abstract: The Reagan Administration warned El Salvador today that the United States was insisting on further progress in its land redistribution program and on the curbing of ''abuses'' by Salvadoran security forces.   One day after the Senate Foreign Relations Committee cut $100 million in proposed military aid to El Salvador because of concern over a suspension in the land redistribution program, the Administration said it had been assured by Salvadoran authorities that the delay was for ''agricultural efficiency'' and that the rights of potential beneficiaries would be protected.   ''We are watching the practical effects of this change very carefully, to see that progress will continue,'' Deputy Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel Jr. said in a policy speech on Central America. ''Salvadorans should know that we will support no less.''

headline: FALKLAND ADVANCE ASSURES VICTORY, BRITAIN DECLARES
abstract: Britain's Defense Secretary, John Nott, said tonight that his country's success in ousting Argentine troops from the Falkland Islands had been assured by fighting this weekend.   But he disclosed that the 5,400-ton light cruiser Glamorgan, carrying a crew of 471, had been hit by Argentine gunfire during the assault Friday night on enemy positions west of Stanley, the main Argentine garrison on the islands. Nine British sailors were killed and 17 injured, Mr. Nott added, but the ship remained fit for battle. Buenos Aires had claimed to have sunk a British frigate.

headline: Maytag Planning Jenn-Air Purchase
abstract: The Maytag Company, a manufacturer of home laundry equipment and dishwashers, said it had agreed to acquire the Jenn-Air Corporation and its subsidiary, Jenn Industries, from the Carrier Corporation for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.

headline: UNITED STATES LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SALVADOR'S PRESIDENT WILL LET LAND BILL STAND
abstract: El Salvador's President, Alvaro Alfredo Magana, said today that he had decided not to veto legislation that suspends the rights of peasants to buy the small plots of land they work as tenant farmers or sharecroppers.   Instead, Mr. Maga@n@a said, he intends to ask the assembly to enact legislation that would clarify the rights of tenants to buy their land.

headline: ISRAELI JETS STRIKE AT SYRIAN MISSILES
abstract: Israeli warplanes destroyed Syrian SAM-6 missiles today as they were being installed in east Lebanon's Bekaa Valley, the Israeli military command said.   Military sources had earlier reported that everything on the ground was quiet after Friday's intensive bombardment of Beirut and Syrian positions east of Beirut. A cease-fire with Syrian and Palestinian forces declared Friday was supposed to be in force at the time the attack was mounted.   The Soviet-supplied ground-to-air missiles were apparently being set up to replace a rocket network knocked out by the Israelis earlier in the Lebanon invasion.

headline: HARVESTER: THE CRISIS GROWS
abstract: For more than two years now, International Harvester has gone from crisis to crisis, publicly playing down the seriousness of each setback and predicting that recovery was only a few months away.   From the pace of recent activity, however, there appears to be a growing sense of urgency at the troubled company.  After an impasse of several months, the manufacturer of trucks and farm equipment began bargaining with the United Automobile Workers this week, looking for concessions of $100 million annually.  Telegrams were delivered to suppliers recently asking them to freeze prices for the rest of the year. Top executives spent last weekend asking officials in Ohio and Indiana for state assistance to help keep two truck factories open.   The sick economy has killed Harvester's hopes of profits this year, and losses are mounting rapidly as cash is dwindling. The organization is adjusting to yet another management change (the last was in September) after the abrupt resignation in March of the former president, Warren Hayford. The outlook is so bleak that many analysts and lenders believe that Harvester may fail.

headline: Donnelley's Cable Move
abstract: R.R. Donnelley & Sons, the nation's largest contract printer, announced today that it had agreed to purchase the Rockford Loves Park Cablevision Companies for an undisclosed sum.

headline: DOW ADVANCES 5.33
abstract: Stock prices moved higher for the second straight session yesterday as institutional investors continued to step up their trading activity. Energy-related and technology issues ranked among the market's best groups. Drug, defense and brokerage stocks also advanced.

headline: NARRAGANSETT CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Seychelles Defendant Unexpectedly Set Free
abstract: A South African-born woman charged with treason in connection with a bungled coup in the Seychelles last November was unexpectedly set free today in the courtroom where she and six white men were on trial for their lives.   Earlier, Chief Justice Earle Seaton overruled a defense submission that the seven accused could not be tried for treason, the only capital offense under Seychelles law.

headline: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Earnings; KODAK PROFIT SLIDES 27.2%; BUSCH, PEPSICO GAIN
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's leading producer of photographic equipment, reported yesterday that depressed economic conditions worldwide, the strengthening of the United States dollar and start-up costs for new products combined to depress net income in the first quarter of 1982 by 27.2 percent on a 2.6 percent decline in sales.   The company, based in Rochester, said earnings fell to $181.3 million, or $1.12 a share, from $249.1 million, or $1.54 a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Sales slipped to $2.25 billion from $2.31 billion.   ''Lackluster economic conditions in many areas of the world restrained shipments of Kodak products during the first quarter,'' said Walter A. Fallon, Kodak's chairman and chief executive, and Colby H. Chandler, president, in a joint statement.

headline: Tokyo Says a Japanese Boat Has Been Seized in Yellow Sea
abstract: A Japanese fishing boat with a 12-member crew was reported to have been captured by what appeared to be a North Korean vessel in the Yellow Sea, the Japanese Maritime Safety Agency said today.   An agency spokesman identified the Japanese boat as the 114-ton No. 85 Kyofuku Maru but was unable to say why the vessel had been seized.

headline: SYRIAN AIDE ASSERTS TROOPS IN LEBANON WILL BATTLE ON
abstract: Syria's Information Minister declared today that Syrian troops would keep fighting in Lebanon ''for our Palestinian and Lebanese brothers and for our basic national security.''   Ahmed Iskander Ahmed asserted that the Israelis had moved more than 85,000 troops into Lebanon and that their objective was to conquer Beirut and to gain control of the vital highway eastward from Beirut to the Syrian border and Damascus.   ''We cannot let them occupy the capital of an independent country,'' Mr. Iskander declared.
