''Israelis have imposed this savage war on us and we have no choice but to fight for our Palestinian and Lebanese brothers and for our basic national security, which is threatened by the Israeli invasion,'' Mr. Iskander said.

headline: CLAIMS 16 PLANES, REPORTS OF 5 OF ITS SHIPS HIT; Statements by Britain, page 6.
abstract: British troops attacked the Falkland Islands today and established ''a firm bridgehead'' in the fighting with Argentine troops, Defense Secretary John Nott announced tonight.   Mr. Nott reported that five British ships were damaged, two of them seriously, and that one Harrier jet was missing at the end of the first day of fighting.   (The Defense Ministry said Saturday morning that 16 Argentine planes and four helicopters were shot down in the fighting, The Associated Press reported. The first report claimed 17 planes and two helicopters. The ministry also said British casualties were 3 dead, 2 missing and 27 wounded, the agency said, but 21 Britons were presumed dead after a helicopter crashed into the sea before the attack.)

headline: BEGIN ASKS SETTLEMENTS VOW
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he would press for a parliamentary resolution barring future Israeli governments from concluding peace treaties that require the dismantlement of Israeli settlements.   In an interview on the army radio station, Mr. Begin said the Israeli settlers in occupied territories needed assurances that the trauma of the Yamit area, where a town and 13 rural-settlements were dismantled in order to return the Sinai to Egypt in accordance with the Camp David peace treaty, would not recur.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The acute shortage of air cover for the fleet, which has been a calculated risk from the start of the British intervention in the Falkland Islands, may have drastically reduced the tactical options open to the task force.   The successful attack on the destroyer Sheffield by an Exocet missile fired by a Super Etendard fighter-bomber, informed British military sources said, was likely to force the movement of the two carriers, the Hermes and the Invincible, and their protecting screen well east of the islands, out of range of further Argentine attack.   This would reduce the capacity of the fleet's Sea Harriers to cover a British landing on the islands.  The Harriers, British naval sources suggested, would now be used exclusively to patrol the air space beyond the fleet to avert another attack by Argentine planes flying from bases on the mainland.

headline: REPORTS OF SOVIET AID ARE DENIED
abstract: A spokesman for the Argentine military was quoted by an Argentine news service today as denying that Soviet technicians had been working to help the Argentine military upgrade its radar system in the southern part of the country.   There was no official statement by the military command on the reports of Soviet help, which were carried in The New York Times and The Los Angeles Times today.

headline: EXECUTIVES PESSIMISTIC, UNCERTAIN
abstract: The top executives of the nation's major corporations, who gathered here over the weekend for the semiannual meeting of the Business Council, were generally pessimistic about the economy and uncertain about what the future holds.   The executives, many of whom were the chief cheerleaders for the Reagan economic program a year ago, have been chastised by the deepening recession. But despite the weak   High interest rates and a depressed economy helped to cause some of the worst earnings declines in years for major corporations in the first quarter. Page D10. performance of the economy in the first year and a half of the Reagan Administration, many of the business executives said that they still supported the President's policies over all.

headline: Balaguer Withdraws From Dominican Race
abstract: Former President Joaquin Balaguer, who lost his office in the 1978 election after three consecutive terms, announced today that he would not seek another term as President of the Dominican Republic.

headline: TIMEPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Clausen Cites Bank's Aims
abstract: The president of the World Bank, A.W. Clausen, said today that the bank planned to strengthen its role as a catalyst for international investment.   In remarks before the International Monetary Conference in Vancouver, British Columbia, and made available here, Mr. Clausen outlined major areas that the bank intended to pursue in assisting the developing countries.

headline: GOING UNDERGROUND IN SILICON VALLEY
abstract: JOHN HENRY 'ONE EYED JACK' JACKSON, 44 years old, is waiting for his trial to begin, where he will face charges of grand larceny, conspiracy, and the buying, receiving and possession of stolen and altered property. The courtroom setting is familiar to Mr. Jackson, who is currently out on bail. He has been convicted four times on lesser counts, involving passing bad checks, forgery and burglary.   But this trial is different. In pretrial hearings over the last year, One-Eyed Jack has not been listening to the district attorney's office describe him as a small-time criminal, but rather as a kingpin in the electronics underground. Mr. Jackson has pleaded not guilty to all the charges.   The case against Mr. Jackson alleges that he both led a crime ring that stole 10,000 memory chips from the Intel Corporation, Silicon Valley's giant semiconductor manufacturer, and remarketed as many as 100,000 other similar devices, most of them stolen. The chips he is accused of stealing are Intel's 32K Eprom's, a highly specialized computer chip, worth $100 apiece at the time. But more important to the prosecutor's office and Federal investigators is the range of their application in electronic equipment - from harmless video arcade games to guidance systems aboard fighter aircraft.

headline: GENERAL DYNAMICS NET OFF BY 8.1% IN QUARTER
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation, one of the nation's largest defense contractors, reported yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter, ended March 28, dropped 8.1 percent from the year before, while sales slipped eight-tenths of 1 percent.   The St. Louis-based company said net income in the three months fell to $28.3 million, or 51 cents a share, from $30.8 million, or 56 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales edged down to $1.23 billion from $1.24 billion.

headline: Gasoline Stocks Up
abstract: Gasoline inventories, which had been falling in recent months, rose 2.2 million barrels last week as refiners increased production, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday. In the week ended last Friday, stocks rose to 215.2 million barrels from 213.0 million barrels in the previous week, but were below the level a year ago of 252.8 million barrels and below the Department of Energy's recommended range for this time of year.

headline: INDIA AND CHINA RESUME BORDER TALKS
abstract: India and China resumed official talks here today on the protracted border dispute that has soured relations between the two Asian nations for more than 20 years.   An Indian spokesman said that a solution of the dispute was ''central to our relations'' and that progress on the issue would ''have an impact on other spheres of the relationship.''   The spokesman, Mani Shankar Aiyer, refused to say if there was any progress at today's opening round of the talks.  The Indian-Chinese discussions marked the start of a flurry of diplomatic activity by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government.  Indian officials are in Afghanistan for talks on economic cooperation with leaders of the Soviet-installed Government, India and Pakistan are to hold talks in Islamabad soon on a proposed nonagression treaty and Mrs. Gandhi has announced plans to visit Washington and Moscow later this summer.

headline: Pabst-Olympia Merger Accord
abstract: A definitive merger agreement between the Pabst Brewing Company and the Olympia Brewing Company of Olympia, Wash., was signed yesterday, Pabst said, after Olympia's directors met and unanimously approved Pabst's takeover bid.   Olympia agreed to add four Pabst representatives to its board, said Robert Siegfried, a Pabst spokesman in New York, and to advise its shareholders to approve the second step of a two-part takeover plan.

headline: TREASURY ISSUES OFF SHARPLY
abstract: Responding to an array of negative developments, prices of Government securities fell sharply yesterday, sending some yields to their highest levels since late February.   The Treasury's bellwether 14 percent bond due in 2011, offered at 100 28/32, fell 1 3/8 points, to yield 13.88 percent. As recently as May 11, it had traded as high as 107, during a burst of optimism in the credit markets, returning 13.04 percent.   At the outset of trading, the market had to contend with a greater-than-expected increase of $1.5 billion in the nation's basic money supply, as reported late Friday by the Federal Reserve. That announcement left the closely watched measure of money circulating in the economy higher than the Fed's short-run and long-run targets and dashed hopes that the Federal Reserve might ease monetary policy, allowing interest rates to drop.

headline: British Ford Job Cuts
abstract: The Ford Motor Company, Britain's most successful major car manufacturer, said today that it would cut 1,700 foundry jobs at its big Dangenham plant near London in an effort to keep the facility open. ''There was a danger that the foundry would have to close because it was uneconomic,'' a spokesman said.

headline: Investing; OFF WALL STREET, THEY DON'T LIKE STOCKS
abstract: IF the theory of investing by contrary opinion holds water, people o ught to be socking away common stocks these days. All across the c ountry, individual investors are snubbing equities -except for e lectric utilities generally - in favor of high-yield, low-risk c ommitments, a check of 16 brokerage branch offices found last week.   ''There's a real desire for risk avoidance,'' said Albert A.  Fagan, retail manager at the Boston office of L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin. ''The venturesome spirit began to ebb early last summer as it became less easy to make money in the stock market.''

headline: JEWISH PROTESTERS EVICTED FROM SINAI
abstract: The Israeli Army began evicting Jewish protesters from one of the northern Sinai settlements this morning as Israel's two chief rabbis pleaded with other militants not to carry out their threats to commit suicide.   The Defense Ministry ordered all journalists out of the area as the army moved into a small encampment called Talmei Yosef. There were no immediate reports of injuries on either side, although the more militant protesters, located in the township of Yamit, have threatened violence against Israeli troops.

headline: LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pitney-Bowes Move
abstract: Pitney-Bowes Inc. said today that it had settled with the Internal Revenue Service on its 1973 tax treatment of a write-off of its point-of-sales terminal business. It would not disclose the amount of the settlement but said it would come from a previously established reserve and would have no effect on 1982 earnings.

headline: Mexico Says Quake Area Is Still 'Very Dangerous'
abstract: Officials said today that a ''very dangerous situation'' still existed around a volcano 420 miles southeast of Mexico City and again warned peasants against returning to their farms.   The volcano erupted late last month and at least 19 people are believed to have been killed.

headline: SEAPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Superman Product To B.& B.
abstract: BENTON & BOWLES has become the first New York agency for the the Kane-Miller Corporation.  Your eyes betray nonrecognition of Kane-Miller.  They own Sunnyland Refining.  Still that look.  Sunnyland makes Superman Peanut Butter.  You say ''Superman what?'' Well, that's a one out of four recognition factor. Not bad for starters.  The blankness is understandable. Kane-Miller is a food processor specializing in the private label area, a real behind-the-scenes operator. And its Sunnyland Refining has a three-and-a-half-year-old peanut butter factory, which like most factories of its kind these days has excess capacity.

headline: Around the World; Warsaw Campus Upset Over Rector's Dismissal
abstract: Students and lecturers at Warsaw University halted classes for 15 minutes today and signed petitions in their first protest against the ouster of the school's popular rector, Henryk Samsonowicz.   University sources, who asked not to be identified, said the protest was peaceful and confined to classes, back in session after a brief Easter break that began after Mr. Samsonowicz's resignation was accepted last week.   Mr. Samsonowicz, who was a supporter of Solidarity, was dropped from the Communist Party after reportedly refusing to allow purging of faculty members under martial law.

headline: AFTER WAVE OF MERGERS, ANALYSTS DEBATE PLUSES
abstract: The roll call of the fallen includes some of the most distinguished names in American corporate ranks: Conoco, Marathon Oil, Kennecott, C.I.T. Financial, Sunbeam, Salomon Brothers, 2Oth Century-Fox, Standard Brands and Seven-Up.   The names remain, but independence is gone. All of these companies and thousands more have been swallowed up in the past three years, in what is shaping up as the third great merger wave in United States history.   The latest surge in merger activity ''has only two quantitative equals in United States industrial history,'' according to F.M.  Scherer, an economist and professor at Northwestern University. He cited the largely horizontal merger wave of 1898-1902, when the great industrial monopolies were formed, and the conglomerate wave of the 1960's, when large companies diversified by purchasing unrelated businesses.

headline: Economic Affairs; ALL TIED UP BY THE BUSINESS CYCLES
abstract: ARE the gods against us, or have we not brought the increasing e conomic chaos upon ourselves? Is the outcome of the supply-side t ragedy - sealed by last week's actions in the House - that we will h ave to live with high unemployment and volatile financial markets?  T o answer these questions, let's go back to basics.  Like the weather, capitalist economies are fundamentally unstable.  This instability arises because of the incessant turbulence from new products or producers, changing tastes, as well as good or bad harvests.  But unlike the weather, the inertia of our economy is very great, and this inertia leads to persistent business cycles. Because cycles persist, it is possible - using the Promethean contribution of John Maynard Keynes -to stabilize the economy. Stabilization requires lowering interest rates (monetary policy), or lowering taxes and raising government outlays (fiscal policy) to expand the economy or the reverse to slow the economy or contain inflation.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Hoechst Corp., Somerville, N.J., has formed three new business groups and named Harry Marty group vice president of the Petrochemicals and Plastics group; George W. Eckelmann group vice president of the Health Care group, and Gerald P. Elden group vice president of the fibers and film group.   * Batus Inc., Louisville, Ky., has appointed C.I. McCarty, president and chief executive officer, to the additional post of chairman.   * Beehive International, Salt Lake City, has named Joseph F.  Carbone Jr. vice president-operations.

headline: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRIP TO ARGENTINA IS SET BY THE POPE
abstract: Pope John Paul II will visit Argentina on June 11 and 12 after his trip to Britain, Government and Roman Catholic Church officials announced here today.   The Pope, who has long been scheduled to go to Britain for a sixday visit beginning Friday, requested permission to visit Argentina as well in a letter delivered today to President Leopoldo Galtieri.   Archbishop Achille Silvestrini, a papal envoy who arrived here this morning from the Vatican, made it clear that the Pope wanted to appear neutral in the Falkland Islands conflict.   ''The Holy Father understands perfectly,'' the Archbishop said to reporters at the airport here, ''that he could not travel to Britain without paying a brief but immediate visit to Argentina.''

headline: TEXT OF STATEMENT ON THE MIDEAST ISSUED BY LEADERS OF THE COMMON MARKET
abstract: Following is the text of the statement on the Middle East issued today by leaders of the European Economic Community (1)   The 10 maintain their vigorous condemnation of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. They are greatly concerned about the situation in that country and in particular in Beirut.   They believe that the present cease-fire must at all costs be preserved.  This cease-fire should be accompanied on one hand by an immediate withdrawal of Israeli forces from their positions around the Lebanese capital as a first step toward their complete withdrawal, and on the other hand by a simultaneous withdrawal of the Palestinian forces in west Beirut in accordance with procedures to be agreed between the parties.

headline: Interest Rates Rise Slightly
abstract: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday as traders were disappointed and cut prices because of the continued high cost of financing inventories and lackluster investor demand.   With financing costs still higher than expected at 14 percent, dealers are less willing to hold Treasury issues whose yields are less than the cost of financing. The willingness to lighten inventories was one reason why the price of outstanding three-and six-month Treasury bills declined enough to increase their rates by about an eighth of a percentage point, to 12.3 percent, in secondary market trading.   At the regular weekly auction of new Treasury bills, however, financing costs were less of an immediate concern since dealers need not pay for their purchases until Thursday. Thus, they were willing to pay prices that resulted in average rates of 12.189 percent and 12.187 percent for three- and six-month bills, respectively. A week ago, the average auction rate was 12.25 percent for three-month bills and 12.24 percent for six-month bills.

headline: Playboy Posts Loss in Quarter
abstract: Playboy Enterprises Inc. reported yesterday that it lost $22.6 million in its third quarter, ended last March 31. For the comparable period last year, the company had reported net income of $2.7 million, or 28 cents a share.

headline: GILMAN SERVICES
abstract: Gilman Services Inc., a drug and cosmetics distributor based in Braintree, Mass., announced that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws for itself and its subsidiaries, Rogers Wholesalers Inc. and Three P. Products. The company, which had started its intent to file last month, said it was still considering selling one or more of its units and was seeking additional capital. Irving L. Gartenberg, an attorney for the company, said that the cost of maintaining heavy inventories, coupled with high interest rates, drove the company into Charpter 11.

headline: S.E.C. DATA: DIFFICULT HUNT
abstract: It's midday at the public reference room of the Securities and Exchange Commission. A smartly dressed young woman, almost breathless with anxiety, hands James Brodie a form requesting detailed information on a dozen or so American companies.   The woman, whose mission is to find companies that have issued debt in the Republic of Argentina, is on an errand from the Treasury Department. But while Mr. Brodie, a soft-spoken, polite man, offers to do what he can to help, the look on his face tells another story: The information may be here, but don't count on finding it.

headline: SANDWELL & CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NARRAGANSETT CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Haig Arrives in Turkey; To Pursue Plane Deal
abstract: The United States and Turkey have started talks in recent weeks for the sale and joint manufacture of nearly 300 advanced American fighter aircraft to modernize Turkey's air force over the next decade.   Reporters traveling with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who arrived here today, were told the deal might combine costly F-16's and F-18's and an updated version of the less expensive F-5, the F-5G.

headline: SURRENDER EXPECTED TO BRING BETTER U.S.-LATIN TIES
abstract: Despite Latin America's dismay at American support for Britain in the Falkland conflict, Washington's relations with much of the continent may not have been permanently damaged by the crisis, according to diplomats, government officials and other experts in the region.   The sources said that Argentina's surrender in the islands had dampened Latin America's emotional response to the conflict and had opened the way for gradual normalization of ties with Washington.   ''I think this has been exaggerated,'' one senior Mexican official said, referring to the impact of the crisis on United States-Latin American relations. ''Yes, they have been affected, but not in a very serious way. In each country, it's the bilateral relationship with Washington that really counts.''

headline: LEVEL OF FIGHTING IN MIDEAST GROWS
abstract: Fighting between Israeli forces and Palestinian guerrillas intensified today, with artillery and rocket attacks on northern Israeli towns and Israeli air strikes on Palestinian bases in southern Lebanon.   As the fighting entered its second day, the cease-fire that had mostly held since last July appeared to have disintegrated. An Israeli invasion of southern Lebanon appeared imminent.   The shelling of northern Israel, begun on Friday after Israeli planes hit Palestinian installations in the southern suburbs of Beirut, continued through the night, resulting in the death of an 81-year-old man, who reportedly suffered a heart attack while running to a shelter. Four Israelis, including a 13-year-old girl, were wounded.

headline: NORTH KOREA IS SAID TO HOLD 105,000 FOR IDEOLOGY
abstract: South Korean intelligence officials say that at least 105,000 North Koreans are being held in camps for ideological offenders.   The existence of the camps, long suspected by intelligence officials, was disclosed in recent interviews here with three North Korean defectors and with high-ranking officials of the South Korean Agency for National Security Planning, formerly the Korean Central Intelligence Agency.   Until recently, the intelligence officials said, it was difficult to check the existence of the camps. But now, with the aid of the defectors from North Korea, and with information that is believed to derive from American aerial reconnaissance, eight major camps for political offenders have been located, according to experts in Seoul, in addition to 25 separate conventional prisons for ordinary criminals.

headline: MINNETONKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VW to Lay Off 400 From Staff in U.S.
abstract: Volkswagen of America Inc. announced today that it would lay off 400 salaried workers and speed up the transfer of its Englewood Cliffs, N.J., offices to Detroit-area facilities to cut costs.   ''We regret having to trim our work force, but the current economic climate, the depressed sales in the U.S. auto industry and our need to remain competitive leave us no choice,'' a VW statement said.

headline: SCHMIDT PLANS MOVES TO PERK UP CABINET
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, apparently in an attempt to give a sense of new activity and ideas to his Government, will announce Cabinet changes, including a new Finance Minister, in the next few days.   A Government spokesman, telling of Mr. Schmidt's plans, gave few details, but sources close to the Chancellor said the major change would be the appointment of Manfred Lahnstein, who has served as chief of staff in Mr. Schmidt's office, as the new Finance Minister.   The appointment is an unusual one in several respects. In naming Mr. Lahnstein, Mr. Schmidt is choosing a young official who is well liked and respected, but who has been under investigation for two months on suspicion of having taken bribes.

headline: City Stores' Losses Narrow
abstract: The City Stores Company, which operates the W.& J. Sloane furniture chain, said yesterday that its losses from operations declined to $1.46 million in the first fiscal quarter ended May 1 from a deficit of $3.5 million in the same quarter the year before.   Sales in the period dropped to $13.7 million from $39 million.

headline: U.S. Envoy Threatened By a Group in Bolivia
abstract: A paramilitary group has threatened to kill Ambassador Edwin G. Corr of the United States if he does not leave the country within three weeks.   In a statement sent to La Paz newspapers Thursday, the group, known as Sovereignty, accused the Ambassador of insulting Bolivia's armed forces.

headline: U.S. GENERAL GOING TO SEOUL
abstract: President Reagan has named Lieut. Gen.  Robert W. Sennewald of the Army to be commander of American forces in South Korea, the Pentagon announced today.

headline: Donaldson Rises 42%
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings for the first quarter of 1982 rose 42 percent, to $3.4 million, or 27 cents a share, from $2.4 million, or 25 cents a share, in the same period last year. Revenue increased 63 percent, to $104.4 million, from $63.9 million. The company said its higher earnings were a result of continued cost reductions and strong performances in areas including investment management and banking.

headline: BEGIN SAYS HE THREATENED TO DELAY SINAI PULLOUT
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he had personally warned Egyptian leaders that Israel would consider delaying its withdrawal from Sinai by a month or more unless what Israel said were Egyptian violations of the peace treaty were corrected.   Mr. Begin made his disclosure in an interview with the Israeli radio that was recorded for broadcast on Wednesday, Israel's Independence Day. The radio included a news item on the disclosure in its hourly report, and the Prime Minister's press secretary, Uri Porat, confirmed that such a warning had been given.   Several other Cabinet ministers, including Deputy Prime Minister David Levy, suggested publicly at the time that the withdrawal might be delayed, but Mr. Begin did not make the threat openly.

headline: JETERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Canada's Prime Rate
abstract: Royal Bank of Canada raised its prime lending rate today to 18.25 percent from 17.50 percent.

headline: COMSAT BOARD NOMINEE SEEMS EAGER TO LEARN
abstract: ''I have zero confidence in the direction of satellites,'' said Justin W. Dart, President Reagan's choice for the board of directors of the Communications Satellite Corporation. ''I've never had any experience with them.

headline: SATURDAY, APRIL 10, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The Producer Price Index fell 0.1 percent in March, marking the first time in more than six years that it has declined for two consecutive months, the Labor Department reported. The drop in energy prices was even sharper than in the first two months of the year, while food prices reversed course and turned down. Economists saw the latest figures as further evidence of the progress made against inflation. They cautioned, however, that much of the gain is a reflection of the recession, which many think has already touched bottom. (Page 1.)   House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. has agreed to further detailed talks with the White House to resolve the budget impasse, Congressional sources said. The Administration also released revised deficit estimates of $100.5 billion in the 1982 fiscal year, up from $98.6 billion, and $101.9 billion in 1983, up from $91.5 billion.  (10.)

headline: Around the World; Six Die in Indonesia As Volcano Erupts
abstract: A volcano erupted 125 miles southeast of here on Friday for the second time in less than a week, killing at least six people.   The authorities in Tasikmalaya, 15 miles from the volcano, said today that more than 40,000 people had fled the area.

headline: COLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Solidarity Aide Sent To Mental Institution
abstract: A senior official of the suspended Solidarity union movement has been sent to a mental hospital after a court acquitted him on charges of organizing an illegal strike, a Justice Ministry spokesman said today.

headline: BUSH TRIED TO SWAY A TAX RULE CHANGE BUT THEN WITHDREW
abstract: Vice President Bush, in an unusual move, intervened with the Treasury in March in connection with proposed rules that would have forced pharmaceutical companies to pay significantly more taxes.   Several weeks later, Mr. Bush withdrew from involvement in the tax issue because, he said, he felt ''uncomfortable'' about the ''appearance'' of a conflict of interest. When Mr. Bush took office, he owned $145,000 worth of drug company stocks, and he had been a director of Eli Lilly & Company from 1977 to 1979.   Government documents show that the Vice President initially signed a highly technical letter to Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, urging that the Treasury alter plans to modify a section of the tax law that has allowed drug companies to avoid billions of dollars in taxes on income earned by their operations in Puerto Rico. Letters Sent to Regan   According to Mr. Bush's counsel, who was a lawyer and lobbyist for a drug company before joining the Administration, the letter was written by a staff member who formerly headed the Puerto Rican agency that screened tax exemptions for American corporations.

headline: Opposition Party Ahead In St. Lucia Elections
abstract: St. Lucia's United Workers Party won in Monday's general elections on this Caribbean island, according to a preliminary count announced today.

headline: Pettibone Accepts A Merger Offer
abstract: The Pettibone Corporation, a material handling concern, said it had entered into a letter of understanding with a group of investors headed by Harold S. Geneen to be merged into a corporation being formed by the group.

headline: DOW ADVANCES 3.42, to 865.58
abstract: The stock market's six-week rally continued yesterday as prices ended moderately higher in active trading.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which has risen almost 65 points since March 12, advanced 3.42 points yesterday, to 865.58. Stocks that rose in price on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered stocks that declined by a 9-to-5 ratio.

headline: WEST CHEMICAL PROUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SPRINGS MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Stocks Mixed on Volume Rise
abstract: The stock market registered a mixed performance yesterday amid heavier trading.  The Dow Jones industrial average, moving in a narrow price range throughout the session, closed down 2.48, to 836.85.  However, the overall market did somewhat better, with advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering those that declined by 787 to 612.

headline: Western Air Gets Delay on Debt
abstract: Western Air Lines Inc. said its creditors had agreed to a two-month extension of waivers on $153 million in longterm debt on which the airline has been in technical default since December.   Within the next two months, Western and its lenders will work to devise new loan terms, revising the debt-to-equity ratio and minimum net worth requirements that now define the technical default, a spokesman said.

headline: E.E.C. Seeks Trade Talks
abstract: The European Economic Community has asked for trade talks with the United States, Japan and Canada before the seven-nation economic summit meeting in June, officials of the community said today.   The three countries have already indicated informally their willingness to attend such talks, most likely to take place in Paris in mid-May, the officials said.

headline: MONDALE BACKS 'FIRST USE' OPTION
abstract: Former Vice President Walter F.  Mondale, in an interview published today, endorsed the Administration's refusal to rule out the ''first use'' of nuclear weapons in case of a war in Europe.   An outright United States renunciation of the so-called ''first use'' policy might encourage the Soviet Union to attack Western Europe, Mr. Mondale told The Washington Post.

headline: A SOVIET PROJECT TEMPTS EUROPE
abstract: PARIS Beset by rising numbers of jobless people and ever gloomier recession, European leaders attending the Versailles economic summit meeting this week will undoubtedly ask President Reagan why he wants to sabotage the very project that they are counting on to help reverse their staggering job losses.   The project is the planned 3,700-mile pipeline that will carry Soviet natural gas from Siberia to Western Europe -a Soviet order for as much as $15 billion worth of heavy machinery and largediameter steel pipe that the Europeans hope will ease their unemployment woes but that the Reagan Administration has sharply criticized.   While there are now several pipelines that move Soviet gas to Western Europe, the new one is expected to substantially increase the flow. Behind arguments about just how vulnerable America's NATO allies would be to the Russians' control over the gas is the fact that this project would inject a stimulating dose of orders and jobs into the faltering European capital goods industry at a time of deepening recession.   It is a fact Western European leaders cannot ignore. Unemployment in West Germany, Britain, Italy and France - whose leaders will join those of the United States, Canada and Japan at the summit meeting - rose to an 8.7 annual rate this year from 5.9 percent in 1980, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

headline: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Squash
abstract: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''The Executives Who Are Hooked on Squash'' (March 21), please say it isn't true that low-seeded executives are doomed to the bottom rungs of the organizational ladder. I try hard and I really want to win, but my opponents are endowed with better skills - speed, coordination and more solid backhands.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The call Wednesday by four former Government officials for an allied pledge not to be the first to use nuclear weapons in Europe, coming on top of the movement for a freeze on nuclear arsenals, is new evidence that the nation is moving toward the first major debate on nuclear policy in more than a decade.   As the North Atlantic alliance was being formed in the late 1940's, isolationist and internationalist politicians engaged in a grand debate over whether this country should commit large ground forces to the defense of Europe. The outcome was the stationing of several American divisions on the Continent.   In the late 1960's, as the Johnson and Nixon Administrations were groping toward the first major strategic arms negotiations with the Soviet Union, there was another major debate, over whether to develop and deploy antimissile defense systems. Opponents contended that the systems would upset the strategic balance that rested on mutual Soviet and American vulnerability, and they largely prevailed.

headline: ABC TO BEGIN MOVIE-BASED TV NETWORK
abstract: In an effort to attract the sort of viewers who now watch pay television services such as Home Box Office, ABC yesterday announced a new movie-oriented service that can be delivered to homes equipped with video cassette recorders for a monthly subscription fee.   The Home View Network, using a combination of new technologies, will be transmitted by ABC each night to its owned stations and participating affiliates beginning in early 1983. Subscribers, equipped with a decoder developed by Sony, will be able to automatically tape the programs on their video cassette recorders, then play them back at any time.

headline: WHEN MANAGEMENT TAKES CARE OF ITSELF
abstract: IN these precarious economic times, many chief executive officers a re trying to figure out whether the bottle is half-full or h alfempty. Others have already decided the issue.  Extrapolating from the past, as they are wont to do, some of them see nothing but gloom and doom ahead. And because of this, they appear to be taking actions to shore up and then weatherproof their compensation packages, as well as those of their senior executives.  Some examples follow:  * One prominent company, which used to offer large and unlimited bonuses to executives and which had heretofore paid low salaries, reacted to the cessation of bonus payments (due to almost nonexistent profits) by folding into base salary half of what would have been the bonus in a good year. No longer are salaries low in this company. But the pressure on profits is even greater than before.

headline: Iran-Japan Oil Sales
abstract: Several Japanese trading houses and oil companies have agreed to long-term contracts with the National Iranian Oil Company to import Iranian crude, industry sources said today. In total, contracts that have been or are close to completion will involve the import of between 90,000 and 100,000 barrels daily, one source estimated.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The complexity of the tactical problem facing Rear Adm. John F. Woodward is gradually being recognized in London as the British task force he commands plows through the South Atlantic toward the Falkland Islands.   In military circles here, the optimism of a week ago has given way to recognition that if Argentina and Britain come to blows militarily, the naval task force will have to rely on guile in order to battle the Argentines under favorable conditions. This is particularly true because the British task force is relatively weak in terms of air power. an essential element.

headline: The Economy
abstract: The White House and Senate Republican leaders agreed on a budget compromise, and it was approved hours later by the Senate Budget Committee. The plan would increase taxes by $95 billion over three years. It envisions a deficit of $105 billion for the fiscal year 1983, $70 billion for 1984 and $42 billion for 1985. (Page A1.) Earlier, at a House Ways and Means Committee hearing, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and House Democrats discussed possible tax increases. (D19.)   Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, came close to supporting a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget. His testimony before a House panel and his remarks in an interview later marked an unexpected shift, although he warned against allowing the amendment to divert attention from solving the current budget crisis. (D1.)

headline: SUPERIOR SURGICAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GENERAL ASSEMBLY MEETING IS SOUGHT BY SOME DELEGATES
abstract: As fighting continued in Lebanon, delegates here continued discussions today on whether to call an emergency session of the General Assembly,   Pressure for an emergency seesion became intense after the United States on Tuesday night vetoed a Securtiy Council resolution that threatened Israel with sanctions for refusing to end its advance into Lebanon. The United States was the only one of the 15 members of the Council to vote against the resolution.   The 14 nations that voted for it were Britain, France, the Soviet Union, China, Japan, Ireland, Spain, Jordan, Guyana, Togo, Zaire, Poland, Uganda and Panama.

headline: SHEARSON SETS ENRTY INTO REALTY
abstract: The Balcor Corporation, one of the nation's largest real estate syndicators, will be purchased by Shearson/American Express Inc. in a two-step transaction worth up to $103 million, the two companies announced today.   The purchase of Balcor is the latest step in the expansion of American Express into a company able to offer a full range of financial services to its customers. The credit card company purchased the Shearson Loeb Rhoades brokerage in June 1981 for $900 million.

headline: Bid for Alden Is Canceled
abstract: Gustav & Gretz Schickedanz Holding K.G., which operates Quelle, Europe's largest mail order house, said yesterday in Nuremberg, West Germany, that it had revoked its letter of intent to buy 51 percent of the Alden Corporation, a mail order subsidiary of the Wickes Companies. Wickes, based in San Diego, is operating under the Chapter 11 protection of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: For a Toyota Deal, G.M. Favors Coast
abstract: The General Motors Corporation prefers to use one of its two idle California assembly plants in any joint venture with the Toyota Motor Company to produce small cars in the United States, G.M.'s chairman, Roger Smith, said.   Mr. Smith said that although negotiators for G.M. and the Japanese auto maker recently toured assembly plants in Georgia and Louisiana, the obvious facility to use would be one of the closed California plants in South Gate near Los Angeles and Fremont near San Jose.   Mr. Smith said that G.M. was still working independently on a new subcompact, despite an agreement to buy up to 200,000 subcompacts from Japan's Isuzu Motors Ltd. for sale in the United States.

headline: U.N. COUNCIL CALLS FOR CEASE-FIRE IN LEBANON
abstract: The United Nations Security Council, meeting in an urgent bid to halt the fighting in Lebanon, held an emergency meeting today and unanimously called for a cease-fire.   The resolution, put together rapidly by Japan, also called on nations with influence over the Israelis and the Palestinians to help stop the planes and guns. This section was clearly aimed at the United States and its strong ties with Israel.

headline: DALCO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PAIUTE OIL & MINING CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MILWAUKEE RAILROAD SALE ASKED
abstract: The trustee for the Milwaukee Road told a Federal judge in Chicago yesterday that he had signed a letter of intent to sell the railroad to the Grand Trunk Corporation.   As part of the deal, Grand Trunk would assume $253 million of the line's $500 million of debts, said Robert H. Wheeler, counsel to the trustee. The Government, he added, would ''forgive'' a $50 million loan granted in 1979 plus an equal amount of interest accruing since then. No other sale terms were disclosed. Grand Trunk, based in Detroit, is controlled by the Canadian National Railway.

headline: DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: RAYPAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARGENTINA REPORTS BOMBING BRITISH CAMPS NEAR STANLEY
abstract: The Argentine high command said tonight that it had repelled a British air attack on Stanley and had gone on to conduct an ''intense bombardment'' of British positions west of the Falkland capital.   The command said in a communique that it had sent air force planes over Mount Kent, ''hurling bombs and conducting roles of exploration and reconnaissance.'' It said there was no British response to its action.

headline: Commodities; Protecting Commodity Brokerages
abstract: PROTECTING the investor-speculator from manipulators and other unethical elements has long been the reason given by the Federal Government why it must regulate all commodity and securities markets, and even the kinds of goods and services traded on these exchanges.   In the past year, the efforts to protect the public participant in the commodity market has led to jurisdictional quarrels and peace pacts between the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission. Currently, many states are also seeking a role in protecting the public, and the industry itself is spending millions to set up the National Futures Association for the same purpose.   All this has led many in the industry to raise this question, but always in private: Who is protecting the commodity brokers from the unscrupulous customer? After all, it is the commodity broker who is held responsible for every transaction by each commodity exchange's clearinghouse at the end of every business day, not the persons for whom they execute orders.

headline: PATENTS; Portable Dance Floor
abstract: A portable, roll-up dance floor with internal lights was patented this week by William Loebner, a manufacturer of theater equipment in Newark.

headline: Saab-Fairchild Aircraft
abstract: The first Saab-Fairchild 340 twin-turboprop airliner will roll out of the new Saab-Scania aircraft plant here on Oct. 27, Saab-Scania A.B. said today. The first flight is scheduled for early next year, it added in a statement.  Saab-Scania and Fairchild Industries are cooperating on the joint development, production and marketing of the 34-passenger airliner and executive aircraft.

headline: Japan's Struggle
abstract: To the Business Editor: One seldom finds as good a summary of the flaws within Japan's business structure as in Steve Lohr's article ''Japan Struggling With Itself'' (June 13).

headline: RUSSIAN SAYS U.S. FASCINATES K.G.B.'S CHIEF
abstract: A former Soviet diplomat who defected to the United States in 1971 says that Yuri V. Andropov, who is regarded as a possible successor to Leonid I. Brezhnev, has long been fascinated by the United States and has more than a casual understanding of its culture and its political realities.   ''For example, I think he's likely to be more understanding than the present Soviet leadership of the internal constraints in this country, of the political facts,'' remarked the former Soviet diplomat, Vladimir Sakharov, who said that he had known Mr. Andropov in Moscow while a friend of his son, Igor.   Mr. Sakharov commented in an interview that Mr. Andropov, in addition to being aware of the political situation in the United States, was interested in American popular music, favored Western alcoholic beverages such as Scotch and French cognac and had Western books in his home library ranging from ''How Green Was My Valley,'' by Richard Llewellyn, to ''Valley of the Dolls'' by Jacqueline Susann. Stepped Down as K.G.B. Chief   Mr. Andropov, who will be 68 on Tuesday, stepped down last month as head of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and state security agency, after he was reappointed to the Communist Party's 10-member Secretariat, which manages party day-to-day affairs.

headline: Excerpts from article, page A14.
abstract: Four former senior Government officials urged the United States and its European allies today to consider a pledge not to be the first to use nuclear weapons in Europe. To compensate, they recommended the strengthening of the West's conventional forces on the continent.   In a magazine article and a joint statement, the four contended that the buildup of nuclear arsenals, divisions in the Atlantic alliance and official contingency planning for fighting limited nuclear war now make it imperative for the Western powers to abandon their three-decade-old strategy of threatening to counter a conventional Soviet attack in Europe with nuclear weapons.   ''Continuation of the present policy will add to the risk of nuclear war,'' said their joint statement, which was read to reporters by Robert S. McNamara, Secretary of Defense in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.

headline: SOUTH CAROLINA ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Grenade Wounds a Nun In West Bank Town
abstract: A nun was critically wounded in a grenade explosion this morning at a Greek Orthodox shrine in the West Bank town of Nablus, the Military Command here reported. A local Arab was also hurt in the blast.

headline: ARAB STUDENT, 18, IS SHOT DEAD IN GAZA
abstract: An 18-year-old Palestinian schoolgirl was shot dead today and another teen-ager was wounded as Israeli troops clashed with demonstrators in the occupied Gaza Strip.   An army spokesman said the incident occurred after an army patrol passing Al Awda girls' school in Khan Yunis spotted 10 masked men in the schoolyard pressing students to go into the street and demonstrate. The patrol entered the schoolyard, the spokesman said, arrested two of the men and ordered the students to disperse.   The students poured into the street and began throwing stones, cinder blocks, chairs and tables at the four soldiers, according to the army's account. Shots were fired into the air, then into the crowd. Two students were hit, one 18 and one 16.

headline: FRANCE UNEASY WITH IMAGE OF AFRICA'S GENDARME
abstract: An image evoked by mentioning the French presence in Africa is this: the sky over some dusty mining town deep in Africa's heart fills with parachutes, and swarthy legionnaires descend on rebel hordes, routing them and saving a dictator.   Or, a variant: another President becomes a little too obstreperous, so those same crew-cut young men with tattooed arms arrive by the banks of a jungle-fringed river, depose the leader and invite a new figure of their choice to ascend the steps of mortgaged power.   Often, the image becomes blurred, with whisperings of dark doings by agents from the French Secret Service working against the Paris Government, juggling African politicians like cardboard cutouts. The plot might be that of some tawdry thriller of the type that features aging C-47's rumbling low over mangrove swamps and white men with blacked-up faces fighting African soldiers on the steps of a stucco palace. Raw Material for Fiction   In the last four years, France has given the authors of such thrillers plenty of raw material to work on, with interventions in Zaire and the Central African Republic. And, these days, the visitor to French-speaking Africa can still see French soldiers on the streets of Bangui or Abidjan, wearing either their own uniforms or those of an African army in which they serve as advisers.

headline: SOVIET STILL THE MAIN THREAT, BRITON SAYS
abstract: Defense Secretary John Nott said today that the Falkland war might lead to some changes in Britain's military structure, including ''a different mix of forces,'' but that the Soviet Union remained the nation's main threat.   He indicated that Britain now faced increased military outlays, saying ''all the equipment lost in the Falklands conflict will be replaced.''   The defense chief, who has been criticized since the fighting for earlier cost-cutting that hit the navy's surface fleet especially hard, met with reporters to introduce a Government white paper, or official study, on military estimates. It was written before the Falkland war but its publication was delayed at the onset of fighting.

headline: MORTGAGE SUBSIDIES BACKED
abstract: In a drive to provide emergency help for the hard-pressed housing industry, House Democratic leaders cleared the way today for quick House action on legislation that would immediately allot $1 billion to subsidize mortgages for middle-income home buyers.   The bill, which would provide Federal payments to reduce mortgage interest rates on purchases of new homes, is scheduled to reach the House floor next week. Since similar legislation is also moving rapidly through the Senate, Congressional leaders say that some form of housing help is almost certain to reach President Reagan's desk this spring.

headline: COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Affiliated Bankshares of Colorado Inc. said it had agreed to purchase Littleton National Bank of Littleton, Colo., for $13 million in cash, subject to regulatory approval.   * Builders Investment Group of California and Mountainwest Savings & Loan of Utah said they had reached an agreement whereby Builders would acquire all of the outstanding stock of Mountainwest in exchange for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.   * Ceco Corp. said it had acquired 80 percent of the stock of Engineered Components Inc. of Stafford, Tex.

headline: MITTERRAND IS OFF FOR VISIT TO JAPAN
abstract: Until recently, France's sales of Perrier to Japan were drastically inhibited by the Japanese requirement that it be boiled. True, French cognac did not have to be boiled, but that, precisely, is the heart of one of the major complaints that President Francois Mitterrand was carrying along as he left today for the first visit ever made by a French head of state to Japan.   It is an elaborately prepared visit, the most elaborate of the many that Mr. Mitterrand has undertaken. He is taking his most important Cabinet ministers with him, as well as Jacques Ser@van-Schreiber, the leading purveyor of the view that if France does not learn to work like Japan it will become a Versailles staffed by 60 million caretakers.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Benguet Corp., a Philippine gold producer, said it was seeking a $25.6 million letter of credit to cover a 210-million-peso loan from Philippine-American Life Insurance Co.   * Chi-Chi's Inc. filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of $25 million of 20-year convertible subordinated debentures, to be underwritten by a group led by Shearson/American Express Inc.

headline: NEW YORK TESTING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Exxon Views Shale Oil Role
abstract: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it may yet resume work on the Colony Shale Oil Project in Colorado, the nation's most ambitious synthetic fuels plant, despite having quit the project earlier this month because of skyrocketing costs.

headline: Mead's Profit Drops by 54%
abstract: The Mead Corporation, a diversified forest products and packaging concern, said today that its firstquarter profit fell 54 percent from a year earlier, as its key markets struggled under the economic recession.

headline: WEINBERGER HAILS ASIAN TOUR
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W.  Weinberger returned from Asia today and said that he was convinced that he had eased concerns in Japan, South Korea and the Philippines that the United States might reduce its commitment to Pacific security.   Mr. Weinberger told reporters that ''It was more important than I had realized when I left that we reassure those countries that it is indeed our intention to remain and carry a fair share of the whole burden of the defense against an increasing threat'' from the Soviet Union.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bow Valley Industries Ltd., Calgary, Alberta, has appointed G.J.  Maier president and chief operating officer.   * Cadbury Schweppes U.S.A. Inc., Stamford, Conn., has appointed Robert E. Burpee president and chief executive officer of its Duffy-Mott Company subsidiary.   * Campaign Inc., Chesapeake, Va., has named Harry W. Kimball vice president of operations.

headline: BRITISH MERCHANT VESSELS ARE PLAYING VITAL ROLE IN SUPPORT OF COMBAT FLEET
abstract: The loss of the Atlantic Conveyor to two Exocet missiles illuminates the role played by the merchant ships of Britain in the Falkland Islands operations.   Before she was hit on Monday and abandoned, the Atlantic Conveyor had carried out her primary mission of carrying 20 Royal Air Force Harriers to the South Atlantic to reinforce the fleet.   In the fighting around the islands, Harriers had been parked on the Atlantic Conveyor overnight, then flown to the aircraft carrier Hermes to take on additional fuel and missiles for their missions.  All the Harriers had left the ship when the Exocets hit.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Detroit Edison Co. announced the public offering of 1.6 million shares of $4 series preference stock at $25 a share, to be sold through a Morgan Stanley group.

headline: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Allright Agrees To Takeover Bid
abstract: Allright Auto Parks Inc. of Houston, a major parking lot owner, said it reached a definitive agreement to be acquired by Deanlake Investments Ltd., a group of Hong Kong investors, for $101.6 million.

headline: Advertising; New Finish To Strong Beginning
abstract: THE question of how to top winning advertising is a troublesome one for ad agencies. No one wants to mess up a good thing.  The way that the Advertising to Women agency has solved the problem is just to add a new ending to a winning beginning.  The brand involved is the Jean Nate After Bath Splash and line from the fragrance division of Charles of the Ritz. The first commercial created for it by the agency four years ago increased unit sales 33 percent the first year and retail sales to $65 million from $32 million in four years.

headline: CONSERVATIVE LEADS IN COLOMBIAN VOTE
abstract: Belisario Betancur, the Conservative Party candidate, took a strong lead in presidential elections today.  The main candidates are former President Alfonso Lopez Michelsen of the ruling Liberal Party and Mr. Betancur of the Conservative Party.  But a Liberal dissident, Luis Carlos Galan, who started the New Liberal Party because of his opposition to Mr. Lopez Michelsen, could split the party's votes and help Mr. Betancur achieve a victory.

headline: EFFORT TO HALT SPREAD OF A-ARMS SAID TO FALTER
abstract: United States officials and nuclear policy specialists fear that they may be losing a 35-year-old battle to curb the spread of nuclear weapons.   Critics of the Reagan Administration say the White House has placed insufficient emphasis on stopping nuclear proliferation. A policy put forth in a paper approved last month by President Reagan, they argue, will lead to increased distribution of plutonium, a material used in nuclear weapons, which will undermine efforts to slow the spread of atomic arms.   Administration officials deny that this will be the effect of the policy. But officials and private analysts agree that efforts to discourage the spread of nuclear arms have been severely complicated by growing international and regional tensions that put pressure on nations such as Israel and Argentina to develop and test atomic devices.

headline: Woolworth Picks Chief For New Clothing Chain
abstract: The concept is fairly new in retailing: a big company creates a chain of stores to sell brand-name clothing at a price cheaper than at regular retailers.   The Melville Corporation has its Marshall's, Zayre has its T.J.  Maxx and Hit or Miss stores, and the F.W. Woolworth Company has its J. Brannam chain. Yesterday, Woolworth upgraded the chain to a full company division and named Donald F. Rowlett to the new position of president and chief executive officer.

headline: Around the World; Court in Turkey Rejects Ex-Premier's Appeal
abstract: A military court has rejected an appeal by former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit for his release from jail on bail pending trial, defense lawyers said today.   Mr. Ecevit's lawyers filed the appeal Friday, asserting Mr. Ecevit was not likely to flee or destroy evidence and could therefore be tried without being detained.   Mr. Ecevit was detained April 10 and formally charged a week later with ''injuring Turkey's reputation abroad'' in an interview he was said to have given to a Norwegian newspaper. Mr. Ecevit has denied giving the interview.

headline: Profits Up 3.9% at Mitsubishi
abstract: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. today reported a 3.9 percent rise in after-tax profits, to $52.7 million, in the year ended March 31, from $50.7 million in the preceding year. The company said that sales increased by 26.8 percent, to $7.04 billion, from $5.55 billion.

headline: Dreco's Canadian Operations Are Placed in Receivership
abstract: The Canadian operations of Dreco Energy Services Ltd., a leading oil drilling equipment company based in Alberta, went into receivership yesterday after most of its United States subsidiaries filed for protection in this country under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act late last week.   Touche Ross Ltd., appointed the receiver by an Alberta court yesterday, will encourage Dreco Energy to continue to operate and the company does not intend to go into ''a liquidation mode,'' a Touche Ross spokesman who asked not to be identified said yesterday.   A steep decline in American orders earlier this year left the United States operations unable to meet their commitments to creditors and forced them into bankruptcy proceedings last Friday.

headline: Tass Reports British Landing
abstract: The official Soviet press agency Tass reported today's landing by British troops on the Falklands, saying it was believed to be the start of a large-scale military operation to seize the islands.

headline: Amdahl Contract
abstract: The Amdahl Corporation, a leading manufacturer of large-scale computers, said it was awarded a contract valued at $45 million, the largest in its history, to deliver 20 computer systems to the United States Army. Amdahl said it will act as a subcontractor under a contract awarded to the Electronic Data System Corporation.

headline: MEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A Czech Historian Is Reported Freed
abstract: The historian Jan Mlynarik, last of a group of Czechoslovak dissidents still detained after being rounded up by the police a year ago, has been freed, emigre sources said here today.   The news followed word that two other dissidents, Jiri Ruml, a former journalist, and Milan Simecka, a writer and historian, had been released.

headline: A FORMER PARTNER IS LEAVING SOLOMON
abstract: Richard G. Rosenthal, 40 years old, one of Wall Street's bestknown arbitragers, has resigned as a managing director and member of the executive committee of Salomon Brothers, the big investment banking concern, which has $719 million in total capital.   He is the first of the former general partners at Salomon to leave since its acquisition last fall by the Phibro Corporation, a worldwide commodity trading concern.   Mr. Rosenthal said his departure was not related to the acquisition. ''There is no issue with Salomon Brothers or Phibro,'' he added. ''In fact, they have been quite supportive.''

headline: NARDA MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BOTSWANA'S BRIGHT PICTURE SHADOWED BY 2 WORRIES
abstract: It is arid, remote and hugely dependent on transport outlets through white-ruled South Africa, but landlocked Botswana has a lot to show for 16 years of independence.   Having started as one of the most unpromising and undeveloped of African countries, with virtually no surfaced roads, it can now boast of being the most durable multiparty democracy in the Organization of African Unity. It can boast, too, that its politicans and public service are uncorrupt by any standards; and that it has achieved rates of capital investment and real economic growth - thanks to some stunning mineral discoveries, notably diamonds, and plenty of foreign aid -that are just as unusual.   But now when President Quett K. Masire tries to look into the immediate future he finds himself preoccupied by two problems that are almost entirely beyond his control. One is the decision of the International Diamond Cartel -managed by De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. of South Africa, a partner with Botswana in its three diamond mines here - to cut back drastically on its purchases in order to maintain the prices of gemstones.

headline: MARSHALL ISLAND LANDOWNERS PROTEST U.S. MISSLE BASE PACT
abstract: About 40 people who own land on the Marshall Islands have camped out on part of a $1 billion United States missile testing facility on Kwajalein, the largest of 34 atolls in the chain.   They say their occupation is to protest an agreement that would extend American political and military links with the islands, which lie about 2,500 miles southwest of Hawaii. The protesters, who represent an influential segment of the total Marshallese population of about 32,000 people, have been urging a negative vote on an Aug.  17 plebescite on the agreement.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: President Reagan's first comprehensive speech on East-West relations seems to mark a major shift in his own thinking about dealing with the Soviet Union that may even overshadow his specific proposals on sharply reducing each side's strategic arsenals.   By calling for the start of talks on strategic arms as soon as next month without any conditions, and in suggesting that he and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, could achieve ''positive results'' when they agree on a time and place to sit down and talk, Mr. Reagan has moved a long way since his early post-election statements that tightly linked arms control talks with Soviet ''policies of aggression'' around the world.   Also, the generally firm but conciliatory speech in Eureka, Ill., in which he said that Soviet leaders shared his ''overriding interest in preventing the use of nuclear weapons,'' showed that after 16 months in office, Mr. Reagan was talking in a much more diplomatic way than in his first Presidential news conference, on Jan. 29, 1981, when he said that Soviet leaders had reserved ''the right to commit any crime, to lie, to cheat.''   Mr. Reagan, Administration officials said today, is being driven by a combination of factors. On the one hand, a senior aide said, despite the initial bluster of the Administration toward the Russians, Mr. Reagan personally has always believed in the value of discussion to resolve issues.

headline: Air Canada Delays Boeing Jet Orders
abstract: Air Canada said it would delay until fall a decision on whether to exercise options it holds to purchase six more Boeing Company 767 aircraft.

headline: Japan Trade Easing Seen
abstract: The Japanese Government has decided to liberalize quotas on nine farm and fisheries products and cut tariffs on 40 others as part of a general trade package to open Japan's markets to foreign goods, a Japanese newspaper said today.   Tokyo Shimbun, quoting Government sources, said that Japan will tell the United States in talks in Washington on Monday that it is willing to expand import quotas on peanuts, kidney beans, peas, tomato ketchup, tomato sauce, canned pineapple, fruit puree, fruit paste and herring.

headline: 0.6% RISE ESTIMATED FOR G.N.P.
abstract: The Government today reported the first official indication that the recession, which began last July, may be over.   The so-called flash estimate of the gross national product in the second quarter shows that the economy grew six-tenths of 1 percent at an annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, according to Commerce Department figures.   This preliminary number, based on incomplete data for the quarter, is the first time that the G.N.P., the broadest measure of the nation's economy, has risen since the July-through-September quarter of last year. Eighth Since World War II   But while the recession, the eighth since World War II and the second in two years, appears to be over, according to the G.N.P.flash estimate, the economy could remain stagnant and the strength of the hoped-for recovery is unclear. This means that the unemployment rate, which was 9.5 percent in May, might not climb much higher, but the hoped-for decline might be some months off.

headline: GOODRICH MAY BE FIRST TO GET IRAN PAYMENT
abstract: The B.F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that it expected to be the first company to receive a payment from the $1 billion security account set up to pay settlements of claims between the United States and Iran.   Goodrich said that the company had reached a privately negotiated settlement with Iran on one of several claims. The company did not specify when the settlement was reached but said that it occurred after the Jan. 19 deadline for filing claims.

headline: PROGRESSIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HAIG, IN VISIT TODAY, MAY FIND THE TURKS ARE FIRM
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig, when he begins his visit here Thursday, is likely to find that Turkey is eager to demonstrate what it says are urgent military needs but is not prepared to make significant concessions to Greece in return for increased military aid.   The message from Turkey's military regime is that although it shares American concern over the continued dispute with Greece, it is in no mood to give in.   Nazmi Akiman, Turkey's Foreign Ministry spokesman, said that Turkey would not ask Mr. Haig to act as a mediator that it would would accept any initiative by him to persuade the Greek Government to resume negotiations. Turkish Flexibility Sought   Both Turkish Government officials and the United States Embassy describe American-Turkish relations as excellent and say they expect no major problems to come up in Mr. Haig's 22-hour visit. Turkish officials say, in fact, that because the ties are close and cordial, they suspect Mr. Haig may ask Ankara to show greater flexibility in its dealings with Greece.

headline: CITICORP DOUBLES ITS OPERATING NET
abstract: Citicorp, New York's largest bank, led a number of major banks reporting profits yesterday. Citicorp doubled its net operating earnings in the first quarter from the level of a year earlier.   Also reporting, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation had a 30 percent rise, to $53 million, while the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago had a 12.4 percent rise, to $71.7 million, and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company had a 4 percent increase, to $62.5 million. The Wells Fargo Bank, the nation's 12thlargest bank, said its figure dropped 3.1 percent, to $37.4 million, from $38.7 million.

headline: Synthetic Crude
abstract: Sasol Ltd. said its Sasol 3 plant had produced its first synthetic crude oil and that refined petroleum products from the plant should be marketed in August.

headline: RCA Expands Videodisk Line
abstract: The RCA Corporation announced an expansion of its videodisk player line from one to four models, including its first player with stereo sound, despite unimpressive sales of the Selectavision videodisk system last year.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Anacomp Inc. said it had agreed in principle to sell the micrographics centers of D.S.I. Corp. Anacomp had previously agreed to buy D.S.I. Corp. but the antitrust division of the Justice Department said the micrographics centers had raised anticompetitive problems. The identities of the buyers were not disclosed.

headline: Polish Leaflet Reports Nationwide Strikes
abstract: An underground leaflet made available today reported that there were nationwide strikes and demonstrations last week to protest martial law and that dissenters plan an expansion of a clandestine network called Radio Solidarity.   ''On the day marking four months of martial law,'' said the April 16 edition of the underground leaflet Druk in reference to April 13, ''strikes lasting from 5 to 30 minutes took place all over the country,'' The reports of widespread strikes could not be confirmed.   The newspaper Express Wieczorny said that ''about 270 seamen, including two ship captains,'' had jumped ship since martial law was declared.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Water Works Co., Wilmington, Del., has elected to its board Marilyn Strode Lewis, president of the Solanco Publishing Company, Quarryville, Pa., and Paul W. Ware, director of the Business and Industry Fund of Franklin & Marshall College, Lancaster, Pa.   * Arizona Public Service Co., Phoenix, has elected to its board Rep. John J. Rhodes, Republican of Arizona.   * Burger King Corp., Miami, has named Paul R. Dobbert vice president, information management, and Robert H. Sorensen vice president, general counsel.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: U.N. Rights Aide Forced Out
abstract: Theo van Boven, a Dutchman whose appointment as head of the United Nations human rights division has not been renewed, said today that Argentina ''took the lead'' in forcing him out of his post. Mr. van Boven, 47 years old, a former Dutch Foreign Service official, leaves the job on Friday at the end of a five-yearappointment.

headline: PATENTS; Vaccine Protects Cats Against Leukemia
abstract: For the protection of cats, a new feline leukemia vaccine has been invented. Richard G. Olson was granted patent 4,332,793 this week, assigning it to the Ohio State University Research Foundation in Columbus.

headline: BROCKWAY GLASS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Stride-Rite Shoes to Humphrey Browning MacDougall for its Sperry Top-Sider.   * Mauna Loa Macadamia Nut Corporation to Rapp & Collins, subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach.   * Amalgamated Bank of New York to Jim Johnston Advertising.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bank of New York has elected Ronald R. Komar, Roy P. Lanza, James A. Mottola and Kenneth G. Pittius vice presidents.   * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Walter Amaral, Elizabeth A.  Bahlke, Dong Soo Choi, Luan DeMirali, Marie T. Eiter, Ted V. Finkel, Thomas J. Fogarty, Harry P. Haldt 3d and John J. Joyce vice presidents.   * Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., Greenwich, Conn., has appointed George F. Goebeler president of the international division.

headline: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Argentina must turn to its air force, to date its most effective service but one that, if British assertions are correct, could now be seriously depleted, if it is to turn the tide of the war in the South Atlantic.   A renewal of Argentina's air offensive, however, will entail a greater variety of missions and higher risk than the successful attacks on British shipping off the Port San Carlos beachhead earlier this week, British military sources said.   Two columns of British troops, reportedly well equipped with antia@ircraft missiles, are now said to be pushing eastward toward Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, and its airfield, the most important prizes of the campaign. Troops in the open field are not easy targets for enemy fighter-bombers, especially when they are also protected by Harrier fighters.

headline: Advertising; Shasta Remakes Its Image
abstract: WHEN the advertising budget for your soft drink budget is only 0.013 percent of the country's total annual beverage advertising, then you had better use it wisely and well.   That's the position that Shasta Beverages of Hayward, Calif., will find itself in even after it increases its budget 86 percent, to $14 million, in its new fiscal year starting July. It is going to have to be heard against a background of more than $1.1 billion of soft drink and hard drink advertising, with $318 million alone being spent on carbonated and noncarbonated soft drinks, according to Leading National Advertisers.   And the corporate executives with their new agency, Needham, Harper & Steers of Chicago, expect to be heard through the competitive din by giving the brand name the personality it never had, and using the media, especially television, more innovatively.

headline: Pabst to Press Bid for Olympia
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company said that the Justice Department's decision on Monday not to allow a merger between Pabst and the G.  Heileman Brewing Company did not come as a surprise and that it would pursue its merger with the Olympia Brewing Company.   But Heileman's president, Russell Cleary, said it was considering ways to fight Justice Department opposition to such a merger.

headline: 9 Youngsters Facing Trial by Guatemala
abstract: Nine youngsters accused of belonging to a guerrilla organization will be tried on charges of participating in leftist subversive activities, the President, Gen. Efrain Rios Montt said.   President Rios Montt said in his weekly television speech on Sunday night that 12 youngsters, whose ages range from 14 to 17 years, had been arrested and accused of burning several gasoline stations and restaurants here in recent weeks.

headline: MESA BID FOR CITIES SERVICE
abstract: The Mesa Petroleum Company said last night that it had offered to buy the Cities Service Company for $50 a common share in a deal valued at $3.8 billion.   In what Mesa described as a ''friendly offer,'' the Amarillo, Tex., company said it would pay $50 in cash for about half of Cities Service's 78 million shares outstanding. For the second half of the shares, Mesa said it was offering Mesa stock or a combination of stock and senior debt valued at $50.   Mesa already owns 4.1 million, or 5.2 percent, of Cities Service, which is based in Tulsa, Okla.  Wall Street sources had said last week that Mesa was preparing an offer for 51 percent of Cities Service at about $45 a share.  Cities Service executives were unavailable for comment late Monday night.  T.B. Pickens, Mesa's chairman and chief executive, said the offer was being made ''in the mutual interest of our respective shareholders and to avoid the expense and disruption of a protracted dispute.''

headline: FRIDAY, MAY 28, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The House rejected all three budget plans for fiscal 1983, the Republican version, the bipartisan one and the Democrats'. The vote put the budget negotiations in limbo, and signaled the collapse of the coalition of Republicans and conservative Democrats that had brought President Reagan his economic legislative victories of last year. (A1.) The Senate acted to repeal tax benefits it had voted for itself and to end a filibuster against a housing relief bill. (A16.)   Deep cuts in personal income tax rates and the repeal of many deductions were proposed by two Democrats. The two, Senator Bill Bradley and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, like many others in Congress, are seeking to simplify the income tax. Their plan envisions a maximum rate of 28 percent, with deductions on charitable contributions and home mortgage interest retained. (D1.)

headline: BONN AIDE UPHOLDS ATOM-ARMS POLICY
abstract: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher made clear today that the West German Government wanted no part of a proposal by four former American officials calling on the Atlantic alliance to consider a policy of not being first to use nuclear weapons in the event of a Soviet conventional attack in Western Europe.   Mr. Genscher expressed his support for the traditional strategy of flexible response, reserving the option of parrying Soviet aggression with nuclear warheads. He spoke as he and Ambassador Arthur F. Burns signed an accord providing support for United States troop reinforcements in West Germany in a time of war or crisis.

headline: Old Stone Acquisition
