abstract: The Old Stone Corporation said today that it had received a favorable ruling from the Internal Revenue Service, which judged as tax-free its previously announced acquisition of the Pacific-Southern Mortgage Trust. It said the deal is expected to be closed within the next few days.

headline: F.C.C. REPEALS CURBS ON PAY TV STATIONS
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission today repealed regulations that have restricted the number of cities where pay television stations may operate.   The decision, reached unanimously with little debate, could stimulate additional growth in an industry that has already developed from only two pay TV stations in 1977 to more than 40 either authorized or operating today.   Pay TV stations, formally known as subscription television stations, transmit a scrambled signal that can only be received with the aid of a special decoder.

headline: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 30, 1982; Markets
abstract: The Treasury sold $4 billion of four-year notes at a price that produced the highest interest cost in more than three months. The average rate at the auction was 14.96 percent, the highest since the 14.05 percent recorded last March 24. The record average rate on such notes was 15.91 percent, set on Sept. 23, 1981. (Page D1.)   Stock prices held steady, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 0.28, to 812.21. Despite the market's resilience this week, however, some analysts expected further declines. (D8.) The value of the dollar fell sharply in foreign currency trading. Gold prices rose $4.25 an ounce, to $314.25, in New York. (D12.) Livestock and meat futures prices were mostly lower. (D12.)

headline: TANKER ATTACKED IN SOUTH ATLANTIC
abstract: A 100,000-ton supertanker, bound from St.  Croix in the Virgin Islands to Alaska, reported that it was bombed and hit by aircraft rocket fire 480 miles northeast of the Falkland Islands yesterday.   British military sources in London said the planes that attacked the ship were apparently Argentine C-130 transports converted for use as bombers. As of late yesterday, the Argentine Government had made no comment on the attack. No injuries were reported by the tanker, the Liberian-registered Hercules.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; Markets
abstract: The stock market dropped sharply amid growing concern over persistent high interest rates and the condition of the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 12.46 points, to 845.32. The decline was the biggest since Feb. 22, when the Dow fell 13.04 points. In the last six sessions, it has tumbled almost 24 points.  (Page D1.)   Interest rates rose modestly as dealers cut prices because of concern about the continued high cost of financing inventories. (D9.) The dollar rose against most major currencies, while gold prices fell $4 an ounce, to $334, in New York. (D14.) Heating oil futures prices eased amid profit taking after last week's surge. (D14.)

headline: Soft Bifocal Lens By Ciba Approved
abstract: Ciba Vision Care, a division of Ciba Geigy of Switzerland, said that the Food and Drug Administration had approved its bifocal soft contact lens for marketing.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Allied Stores Corp.'s $175 million of 6 percent notes due in 1992 are offered by Goldman, Sachs & Company at 56.741 to yield 14.25 percent.   * Arizona Public Service Co. offered 2 million shares of $3.58 cumulative preferred stock at a price of $25 a share, plus accrued dividends, to be sold through a Dean Witter group.

headline: COMMON MARKET HOLDS OFF ON EXTENDING ITS SANCTIONS
abstract: Delegates from Western Europe's 10 Common Market countries were unable to reach agreement today on a plan to extend sanctions against Argentina in support of Britain in the Falkland conflict.   The lack of agreement, after several hours of meetings, was a setback to Britain's hopes for a quick and dramatic sign of continuing support for its efforts to recover the islands.   The sanctions, scheduled to expire Monday midnight, may still be extended. But the decision must now be taken by the foreign ministers at a meeting in Luxembourg on Sunday, before a gathering of defense officials the next day.

headline: ARGENTINE CHIEF COURTS POLITICAL LEADERS
abstract: The retired general who is Argentina's newly designated President said today that he wanted to meet Thursday with civilian politicians to discuss the policies of his coming transition Government.   But some of the politicians refused the invitation, apparently sensing the weakness of the military government, now led by the army alone. The navy and air force withdrew Tuesday in protest over the army's insistence on naming Maj. Gen. Reynaldo Bignone, and not a civilian, to replace Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri, who was forced out last week after Britain defeated Argentina in the Falkland Island war.   Carlos Contin, who as leader of the Radical Party heads a loose coalition of the five principal political organizations, called for the immediate lifting of the ban on party politics in force since the military took power in 1976.

headline: SARGENT-WELCH SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Papal Envoy in Warsaw To Discuss Pope's Visit
abstract: Msgr. Luigi Poggi, a Vatican envoy, met Poland's Roman Catholic primate, Archbishop Josef Glemp, and other church officials in the first round of talks on a planned visit by Pope John Paul II, Catholic sources said today.

headline: Patents; Drying Up Of Water Measured
abstract: WASHINGTON AN evaporimeter, which measures the speed of evaporation of water and other liquids, was patented this week for the RCA Corporation.  Its potential applications are in meteorology, agriculture, control of water reservoirs and the protection of moisture-sensitive books and antiques in libraries and museums.

headline: MAY INCOME AND SPENDING UP
abstract: A healthy gain in wages and salaries helped push total personal income seven-tenths of 1 percent higher in May than in April, the biggest increase since November, the Government reported today.   Consumer spending rose an even sharper 1.3 percent, the most since last August.  Welcoming the figures, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted that, ''as we move through the summer, higher employment levels should result in further recovery of private wages and salaries, bolstering the growth of personal income.''

headline: A SOILDER IS RESCUED
abstract: The Israeli Army spokesman reported today that Syrian and Israeli troops had exchanged artillery fire east of the Beirut international airport.   There was also an announcement here today that the Israeli army had recovered one of its men captured by Palestinians early in the invasion.

headline: PROVIDE
abstract: The United States informed Britain in general terms today of the kinds of military assistance it will provide now that it has taken Britain's side in the Falkland Islands dispute with Argentina.   Foreign Secretary Francis Pym met with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and later with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger here today for a review of the political, military and economic aspects of the Falklands situation. He later went on to New York to have dinner with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to discuss possible United Nations involvement in settling the dispute.   Mr. Pym told reporters that he had not come with ''a shopping list'' of specific military items but rather had discussed ''in very general terms'' what the United States was ready to do to assist the British forces.

headline: Pabst Proxy Suit
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, the leader of a group of dissident shareholders of the Pabst Brewing Company, announced that his group had filed suit Tuesday against Pabst and Torray Clark & Company, a Maryland investment advisory concern, in the United States District Court in Delaware, alleging violations of Federal securities laws and Delaware state law. The suit seeks to enjoin the counting of about one million shares voted by Torray Clark's clients in favor of Pabst's management at a recent proxy meeting. Mr. Jacobs' group, which controls 16.3 percent of Pabst's voting shares, has been trying to disqualify from the counting more than 12 million shares controlled by Torray Clark.

headline: ON BOSPORUS, OLD AND NEW ARE MINGLING
abstract: ''Too short are our lives to love this enchanting spot,'' Yahia Kemal, the Turkish poet, wrote of the Bosporus early in this century.   Many changes have taken place along this strait that separates European and Asian Turkey since the days when the area was the summer playground of sultans.   While nightingales still sing in mulberry trees on the Asian side of the waterway, they are being driven away by crows and construction projects.   The hills are said to be greener today because the woods are Government controlled. But the yalis, or great waterfront mansions made of wood, are threatened with extinction because of fire, water, squabbling families and lack of funds.

headline: New Chief Takes Over At Magnuson Computer
abstract: Selling products that are compatible with computers of the International Business Machines Corporation is a precarious business, in which a company's fate depends as much on the giant of Armonk as on its own prowess.   If anyone is familiar with the difficulties of such a business, it is Charles S. Strauch. Until last week, Mr. Strauch was the president and chief operating officer of the Memorex Corporation, a maker of I.B.M.-compatible data storage devices that had been in financial difficulty before it was bought by the Burroughs Corporation in December. Starting this week, Mr. Strauch is the president and chief executive officer of Magnuson Computer Systems, another troubled manufacturer of I.B.M.-compatible computers.

headline: LONDON TOLD ISLANDERS FACE NO HARDSHIP
abstract: In the first official report on conditions in the Argentine-occupied Falkland Islands, a former colonial administrator told the British Government today that the population there was facing no serious hardships.   The official, Richard Baker, was deported today along with a number of his senior aides. They were among a group of 31 Britons and 4 Canadians, about 15 of them children, who arrived in Montevideo, Uruguay, on a regular Aerolineas Argentinas flight. From there, Mr.  Baker sent a brief report that was quoted in the House of Commons by Francis Pym, the foreign secretary, during a debate on the Falklands.

headline: VTN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PEKING TO RESTORE POST OF CHIEF OF STATE
abstract: China has decided to restore the post of Chief of State, equivalent to the presidency, which Mao Zedong abolished as a threat to his authority during the Cultural Revolution.   The decision, which had been expected by diplomats here, came to light Thursday at the opening of a new session of the standing committee of the National People's Congress, China's nominal parliament. The standing committee does all the major legislative work for the congress.   At the top of its agenda is the approval of a new constitution, which will be the fourth since the Communist takeover in 1949. A constitutional revision committee announced on Wednesday that it had completed and adopted a new draft, which was originally expected last year.

headline: SLUMPING SALES CLOUD ELECTRONIC SHOW
abstract: The Consumer Electronics Show this year is a subdued affair, despite record attendance of nearly 70,000 people and a dazzling display of video games. The mood reflects the state of the industry. Sales of many products are below 1981 levels. The threat of new restrictions on audio and video taping hangs in the air. And even in areas of increasing sales volume, prices and profits are plummeting.

headline: MIDWAY AIR FINDS FARE WAR CAN HURT
abstract: Midway Airlines first made a name for itself in 1979 by offering fares as much as 50 percent cheaper than those of the major airlines. Initially, the larger carriers ignored Midway, saying it and other low-fare airlines did not have enough capacity to be a threat.   But hard times in the airline industry have changed that, and in a fight for passengers, the large carriers now have largely matched Midway's fares.   A one-way trip from Chicago to Philadelphia on Midway, United Airlines and Trans World Airlines, for instance, costs the same: $115. United has also matched Midway's $85 one-way fare to Omaha. For a one-way trip from Chicago to Washington, United, T.W.A. and American Airlines had met the Midway fare of $109 until recently, when United and American raised their fare to $136. They figured that most of the passengers on that route are business travelers who are not so concerned about fares.

headline: Sale of Mirage Jets To India Reported
abstract: The independent daily Le Monde said today that France had signed a deal with India for the sale of an unknown quantity of Mirage 2000 fighter-bombers, the most advanced French combat jet.

headline: South Yemen Sentences 12 To Death for Sabotage Plot
abstract: The Supreme Court today sentenced 12 Southern Yemenis to death on charges of engaging in sabotage with the complicity of the United States.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * ARA Services Inc., Philadelphia, has appointed Robert J. Franco president of the newly created transportation sector and chief executive officer of Smith's Transfer Corporation.   * Bear, Stearns & Co. has named Palmer Sessel a special limited partner to head the newly established regional corporate finance office in San Francisco.   * Drew Chemical Corp., Boonton, N.J., has appointed Gordon E. Haym vice president and general manager, industrial chemicals division, United States.

headline: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 7, 1982; The Snow
abstract: The blizzard led many businesses to shut down early throughout the metropolitan area. Three futures exchanges and a number of securities dealers closed at midday or not long after, although the stock exchanges and the Comex stayed open for a full day, as did many investment houses. Business was all but dead for most retailers, however, and in offices meetings were canceled, travel plans were scrapped and employees were sent home early. (Page A1.) International   Poland and its Western creditor banks signed an accord in Frankfurt to delay repayment of $2.4 billion that Warsaw failed to pay in 1981. The accord stipulates that in 1982 Poland must repay 5 percent of the total due in 1981. Then, starting in December 1985, it would pay the rest in seven semiannual installments. (D1.)

headline: A SHIP'S LOSS IS WITNESSED AT BEACHHEAD
abstract: Brian Hanrahan, a correspondent for the British Broadcasting Corporation, watched the frigate Antelope sink on Monday. Here is his report, which was passed by military censors:   Antelope went the way of the two other British ships lost so far, destroyed in a fire started by enemy action. She was hit on Sunday afternoon when the Argentine Air Force resumed its raids on San Carlos Bay. Although only a few planes broke through the defensive screen, Antelope was badly damaged.

headline: Basque Group Says It Put Bomb on French Train
abstract: A Spanish ultrarightist group opposed to the Basque separatist movement said today it planted the bomb that killed five people and injured 27 on the Paris-Toulouse express train in France Monday evening.

headline: REEVES BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Skywriting Squadron
abstract: Today will be commissioning day at La Guardia Airport for the East Coast Miller Squadron, five World War II airplanes that will be skywriting advertising messages over what large crowds it can find.

headline: FREED AMERICAN FLIES HOME FROM CHINA
abstract: A young American teacher accused of stealing state secrets left China today after being detained and interrogated for nearly a week before being expelled.   Lisa Wichser, who hoped to turn her long fascination with China into an academic career, was seized by Chinese security agents last Friday. She was held incommunicado until Monday, when United States Embassy officials were permitted to visit her.   She was released early Thursday evening after she signed a confession. She was told to leave China within 48 hours. A United States Embassy protest over her treatment was rejected by the Chinese Government.

headline: Economic Scene; Grim Reality Of the Budget
abstract: THE grim reality needs to be faced: The budget is out of control.  Unless President Reagan makes a remarkable deal with Congressional leaders in a meeting with them today, the nation faces a string of the biggest deficits in its history. And, if nothing dramatic is done now, those deficits will climb in the next few years, weakening the national economy.   Congressional and White House budget negotiators, although unable to effect a deficit-shrinking compromise in the face of a deadlock between President Reagan and the Speaker of the House, Thomas P.  O'Neill Jr., have at least been facing up to that reality. They have agreed that, without additional budget savings, the following figures will result from the President's program:   Expenditures will climb from $742 billion in the current fiscal year to $827 billion in the fiscal year 1983, $918 billion in 1984 and $1,013 billion in 1985. In the aggregate, counting both military and social outlays, this represents hardly any slowdown in the rate of increase in Government spending.

headline: SAUNDERS LEASING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POPE ASKS ACCORD ON FALKLAND ISSUE
abstract: Pope John Paul II today used his traditional Easter greeting, ''To the City and the World,'' to implore Britain and Argentina to settle their conflict over the Falkland Islands without bloodshed.   ''I express the fervent hope and the particularly pressing appeal to the parties involved to seek diligently, with responsible commitment and with all good will, ways of a peaceful and honorable settlement of the dispute while there is still time to prevent a struggle involving bloodshed,'' the Pope said in his address from the balcony of St. Peter's Basilica to a crowd estimated at 200,000.   The papal message of peace was televised directly to 27 countries, including the two feuding nations.  The Pope also deplored the war between Iran and Iraq before appealing to Britain and Argentina, what he called ''two countries of Christian tradition.''

headline: CPT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: F.A.A. Denies It Is Unfair
abstract: Officials of the Federal Aviation Administration denied today charges by airlines that they were being unfair in awarding the landing rights made vacant last week when Braniff Airways suspended its flights.   ''Our guidelines in distributing the slots were to grant them in those cases where it would ease the impact on the Braniff passengers,'' according to Fred Farrar, spokesman for the F.A.A. ''We said at the time all of these would be good for no more than seven days and could be canceled at any time on 24 hours' notice.''

headline: WARNER ELECTRIC BRAKE & CLUTCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. FALKLAND PLAN GETS ICY RESPONSE
abstract: The United States has presented Britain with a set of new proposals to avert a conflict over the Falkland Islands, but a British source said tonight that they were ''unsatisfactory'' from his Government's point of view.   A British official said before Foreign Secretary Francis Pym's final session with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that Mr.  Pym would carry back to London tonight ''American proposals for a settlement'' that were given to him by Mr. Haig during their two days of talks. Mr. Pym refused to discuss the contents of the ideas as he spoke to reporters on his way to the airport. He later left for London.   The British, in describing the American plan as ''leaving a lot to be desired,'' cast a shadow over the chances for a peaceful settlement of the dispute with Argentina.

headline: Boeing Brazil Sale
abstract: A Brazilian airline, VASP, has agreed to buy 13 Boeing 737-300 twin-jet airliners at a cost, including spare parts, of about $350 million, according to industry sources. The sale must be approved by the Brazilian Government, but the sources said that no hitch was expected.

headline: I.B.M. Plans U.S. Videotex
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation announced its entry into the videotex business in the United States.The company said that in December, it would begin selling software and hardware that would let companies set up private videotex systems, in which employees or customers could call up graphic and textual information on computer screens or terminals.

headline: Clash in Zimbabwe Reported
abstract: A Zimbabwean soldier has been killed and three were wounded in a clash with dissident troops loyal to the opposition leader Joshua Nkomo. The Zimbabwe national press agency, quoting ministers in Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's office, said today that the rebels were former guerrillas from Mr.  Nkomo's forces who had deserted from the national army.

headline: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES SLIGHTLY TO 9.5%
abstract: With 10.5 million people out of work, unemployment rose in May to 9.5 percent, a post-World War II high, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. The Reagan Administration said the slight rise, from 9.4 percent in April, proved that the recession was bottoming out. Budget Director David A. Stockman said the economy would stage a recovery in the second half.

headline: China Backs Cambodians
abstract: China expressed support today for plans by three anti-Vietnamese groups in Cambodia to unite. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said, ''It is a good thing that after making efforts they have reached agreement on the joint declaration.'' The three groups are led by Pol Pot, who ruled Cambodia from 1975 to January 1979; Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former head of state, and Son Sann, a former Prime Minister.

headline: ITALIAN IN SCANDAL FOUND DEAD
abstract: The body of a missing Italian financier, Roberto Calvi, the central figure in a $790 million bank fraud scandal, was found hanging from a London bridge Friday, the police said today.   Mr. Calvi, dismissed as head of Italy's second-largest private bank, had been missing for nine days. The police said a stroller came across his body early Friday hanging from the scaffolding of Blackfriar's Bridge over the Thames River in the heart of London's financial district.

headline: U.N. CHIEF INTENSIFIES EFFORT TO COME UP WITH SOLUTION
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar began an intensive diplomatic effort today to find a solution for the conflict over the Falkland Islands.   Until now, Mr. Perez de Cuellar has held back to avoid interference with the mediation efforts of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. But the collapse of the Haig mission has brought the United Nations leader to the center of the diplomatic stage.   His aides declined to label Mr. Perez de Cuellar's labor as mediation. Britain objects to being put on a par with Argentina, whose forces seized the islands and refused to heed a Security Council demand to withdraw.

headline: U.S. AIDES CALL THE SANCTIONS SYMBOLIC
abstract: The Reagan Administration's economic and military sanctions against Argentina will have little practical effect, State Department and Pentagon officials said today.   After Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. announced that the United States had decided to come down firmly on the side of its longtime ally, Britain, in the Falklands crisis, Administration officials made it plain that the sanctions imposed against Argentina were designed mostly for political purposes.   ''In practical terms the full panopoly of American economic or trade or financial leverage may not be instrumental in changing the situation,'' a ranking State Department official told reporters.  ''Our signals are essentially political.''

headline: RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Venture magazine to Catania, Mackie Advertising for trade and promotional advertising.

headline: THE MEMBERS OF THE PANEL
abstract: The Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues was established in 1980. It took as its model the Brandt Commission on development problems, a group headed by former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany. That commission had some success last year when 22 leaders of industrialized and developing nations met in Cancun, Mexico.

headline: SERVICEMASTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The establishment of a secure and expanding beachhead on East Falkland Island was the primary objective of Britain's amphibious operation today. The exercise may, however, be preliminary to landings elsewhere on the island, analysts said.   Scorpion light tanks, Rapier surface-to-air missiles and artillery were reported to have been moved into the beachhead at Port San Carlos in preparation for an offensive. But military opinion is that the beachhead cannot be exploited to its fullest until Harrier fighter jets of the Royal Air Force are established ashore.

headline: DISARMAMENT SESSION OPENS AT THE U.N.
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar called today for an end ''to the madness and immorality of the arms race'' as the General Assembly began a five week special session on disarmament.   He described as ''grotesque'' a world ''in which we can destroy ourselves many times over without having the political will and moral impetus to save great masses of our fellow human beings from starvation.''   The developing nations, which make up most of the United Nations' 157 members, are expected to dominate the session with similar themes and to blame the United States and Soviet Union largely for the arms race. The Secretary General declined to share this view.

headline: GERMANS WORK TO RID TEXTS OF ERRORS ON JEWS
abstract: Jews and Christians are working together in West Germany to remove incorrect information about Judaism from German textbooks on religion and politics, according to two speakers at the American Jewish Committee annual meeting in New York City last week.   Both speakers said at the meeting on Tuesday that a ''subtle anti-Semitism,'' based partly on political opposition to the Government in Israel and partly on traditional Christian dogma, continued to cloud relations between West Germany's Christians and Jews.   The speakers, Prof. Dietrich Goldschmidt of the Max Planck Institute for Education and Human Development in Berlin, and Prof.  Edna Brocke of the University of Duisberg, said that in Germany ''there is an honest attempt to overcome anti-Semitism in the teaching of the Christian religion.''

headline: OHIO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Coke Cancels Deal To Get Outlet Co.
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company has canceled an earlier agreement to acquire the Outlet Company, a Rhode Island-based owner of radio and television stations, the companies announced today.   In a brief statement, Coca-Cola said its agreement in principle to acquire Outlet had been canceled after ''an evaluation of an audit of Outlet and a review of Outlet's business.'' A Coke spokesman, Carlton Curtis, declined to elaborate on the announcement.

headline: Terms of Danish Credit
abstract: Terms have been fixed on the $100 million Eurocredit for the Danish Oil and Gas Company, banking sources said here. The 10-year credit, guaranteed by the Kingdom of Denmark, will carry a spread of three-eighths of 1 percent over the London interbank offered rate and will have a five-year grace period, they said. Hambros Bank is arranging syndication.

headline: Family Circle to Trim 4th Quarter Rate Base
abstract: Family Circle, a 17-times-a-year publication owned by The New York Times Company, is cutting its rate base for the fourth quarter to 8 million, from 8.2 million.

headline: Italians Will Investigate Alitalia's Midair Fright
abstract: Transport Minister Vincenzo Balzamo called for a Government inquiry today after a pilot reported a midair explosion near his airliner over an area of southern Italy where NATO maneuvers were taking place.   The blast shook the Alitalia DC-9 as it was carrying 110 people over the Tyrrhenian Sea on a flight from Milan to Palermo in Sicily, Capt. Salvatore Murabito reported.

headline: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TV IN LEBANON FOURISHING AMID CIVIL STRIFE
abstract: Night life in Beirut these days features mainly shootouts, explosions and kidnappings. Understandably, most people prefer to stay at home and watch television.   ''It's really a captive audience,'' Charles Rizk, chairman of the Lebanese Television Company, commented recently with a wry grin.  ''People are trapped in their houses because of the insecurity, and so they look at television.''

headline: INDUSTRIAL NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Gilman Services
abstract: Gilman Services Inc., a drug and cosmetics distributor in Braintree, Mass., announced that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws for three of its units: Gilman Brothers Inc.; Rogers Wholesalers and Three P Products. The company said that it had sought relief after three creditors filed a Chapter 7 involuntary petition in Federal court in Boston last week against Gilman Brothers. The creditors, Du Pont, Abbott Laboratories and Baxter Travenol Laboratories, refused to enter into a standby agreement that Gilman reached last January with other creditors.

headline: P.L.O. IS SAID TO BE COMMITTED TO LEBANESE TRUCE
abstract: The Palestine Liberation Organization remains firmly committed to the cease-fire with Israel in southern Lebanon despite the growing impatience of radical factions, Palestinian sources said today.   ''Everything is under control,'' a P.L.O. official declared, dismissing as ''rhetoric'' calls for action by some of the restless guerrilla groups, particularly the Marxist Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine.   The Democratic Front issued a statement in Damascus on Wednesday taking responsibility for a grenade attack Tuesday in Jerusalem that police sources there said damaged parked cars but caused no casualties.

headline: TUESDAY, MAY 4, 1982; International
abstract: U.S. Steel will file new unfair trade complaints against foreign competitors on Friday, the company said. The action will widen the industry's case against the foreign steelmakers to include every major category of steel imports. The company also said that, because of a sharp decline in steel demand, it is thinking of shutting down its huge integrated steel mill at Fairfield, Ala. (Page D1.)   A Saudi group has acquired a 17.87 percent share of IBH Holding, a West German construction machinery concern in which G.M. owns a stake of the same size. The acquisition is part of a deal to raise $64.6 million in new equity capital for IBH. The Saudi group, the Dallah Establishment, is also involved in entertainment. (D1.)

headline: MITTERRAND ENDS TENSE VISIT TO SPAIN
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand ended a three-day visit to Madrid today after failing to assuage Spanish suspicions that France is delaying this country's entry into the European Economic Community and allowing Basque terrorists to operate with impunity north of the Pyrenees.   During his stay, Mr. Mitterrand had sharp exhanges with Spanish leaders, notably King Juan Carlos, who declared bluntly in a dinner toast Tuesday night that ''the Europe of liberty'' should not offer a haven to terrorists who want ''to annihilate by force the social and political orders chosen in freedom by our peoples.''   In equally frank language, the French leader suggested that terrorism in the northern Basque provinces was rooted in Spain's social problems and not a result of France's longstanding policy of granting guerrillas political asylum. To the appeal from the King and other political figures that France hasten Spain's entry into the Common Market, Mr. Mitterrand said swift admission would add ''another misery to the current miseries of Europe.''

headline: Latin Leaders Discuss Moves Against Britain
abstract: Latin American leaders today discussed possible reprisals against Britain over the fighting in the Falkland Islands.

headline: ENERGY SOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRANSCON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tunis Premier to Visit U.S.
abstract: Prime Minister Mohammed Mzali of Tunisia will make an official visit to the United States on April 29, official sources said today. It will be his first visit to Washington since taking office in April 1980.

headline: Brezhnev Accepts Offer For Visit to Nicaragua
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, accepted an invitation today to visit Nicaragua on an unspecified date. The invitation was made at the close of a six-day tour of the Soviet Union by Daniel Ortega, head of the Central American state's three-man junta.

headline: Market Place; Weak Quality Of Margin Debt
abstract: SIDELINED investors who are aware of the current weak condition of margin accounts may be looking for a stock market selling climax.  A selling climax usually occurs over the course of a single day.  Share prices drop suddenly and precipitously as a result of unanswered margin calls. But during that same trading session, the market recovers with a rush as well-financed investors snap up bargains. After a true selling climax, the market will enter a prolonged recovery phase.   The extended market weakness of recent weeks may well have laid the foundation for a selling climax. Here is what has happened. The market weakness has meant lost equity for investors who borrowed to finance their share purchases. When the equity in a given account drops below a certain level, the customer's broker will send out a call for more money, or ''margin.''

headline: Wickes Halts; Sale Accords
abstract: The Wickes Companies said that it had terminated previously announced agreements to sell its agricultural division to the Pillsbury Company, and a two-thirds interest in its Red Owl supermarkets and Snyder drugstores to Thorofare Markets Inc.   Late last year, Wickes had said it planned to divest a number of its subsidiaries to help pay off debt and to satisfy its banks.

headline: FALKLAND DOCTOR IS CREDITED WITH HELPING SET UP TRUCE
abstract: A young doctor, braving shell fire, is said to have brought about the first contact between British and Argentine commanders on the Falklands for talks that led to the Argentine surrender.   The physician, Dr. Alison Bleaney, 30 years old, who is a general practitioner, ran through the shells first to save the lives of islanders and then to induce the Argentines to talk, two Daily Telegraph reporters, A.J. McIlroy and Tony Snow, said in a pooled despatch.   Her husband, Michael, 44, who is a factory manager of the Falkland Islands Company, said: ''If it was not for her - and I know, I am talking about my own wife - then I don't believe there would have been a truce.''

headline: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Commodities; The Price Distortion In Wheat
abstract: Rarely have wheat growers and traders seen as bizarre a distortion of prices as they have recently because of poor weather and high interest rates. While the weather improved over the weekend, interest rates did not, and many analysts expect a further warping of prices this week.   Last week, for example, wheat buyers at Gulf of Mexico ports, the main export terminals, were paying a record premium of 60 cents a bushel over the Kansas City price as they scrambled to find enough grain to fill overseas orders and avoid having to pay high demurrage charges to ship owners whose vessels were riding idle at anchor.   In Kansas City last Friday, wheat prices were 23.75 cents a bushel higher than those in Chicago; the premium was 18.5 cents the week before. This distortion comes at a time when the new long ''unit trains'' are able to pick up huge loads at elevators and deliver as much as 100 carloads at once to Gulf terminals.

headline: ARGENTINE SUMMONS CABINET TO DISCUSS FALKLAND DISPUTE
abstract: President Leopoldo Galtieri of Argentina called an emergency meeting of the Cabinet early today amid reports that his forces were poised to invade the Falkland Islands.   The news agency Noticias Argentinas said the military planned to occupy the disputed British colony in the South Atlantic before the arrival of British naval units in the area.   Neither the President's office nor the Foreign Ministry would confirm the landing plan.  A British Embassy spokesman, asked to comment on whether a landing was imminent or already under way, said, ''It certainly sounds like it.''

headline: Swede Kills 2 in Rampage
abstract: An outpatient at a Stockholm medical center went berserk today, killing two doctors with a knife and injuring four staff members and a policeman, the police reported. The male assailant was caught by a taxi driver outside a nearby subway station after seriously wounding a policeman who pursued him as he fled from the medical center, the police report said. The attacker was not identified.

headline: FALKLANDS' IMPACT ON LATIN BORROWING
abstract: Lending officers for big United States banks can usually be found traveling through Latin America at this time of year, meeting with government and corporate officials eager to arrange new loans. This year, however, the war between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands has kept the bankers at home.   ''They're staying here doing their homework and keeping a close watch on what's going on,'' said one leading international banker who requested anonymity.   ''There is now a sense of nervousness about Latin America that was not present a year ago,'' added Donald G. McCouch, senior vice president and deputy general manager-international at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. ''The Falklands contribute to that.''

headline: Around the World; 2 Whites Added To Zimbabwe Cabinet
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe added two new whites to his Cabinet today and promoted loyal members of the opposition party in order to strengthen national unity.   The shuffle came only two months after Mr. Mugabe dismissed the opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo, and two ministers after allegations that they were planning a coup.   Mr. Mugabe told a news conference that he was adjusting the Government ''in accordance with my policy of national reconciliation and national unity.''

headline: Esso Exploration
abstract: Canada and Esso Resources Canada Ltd.  have concluded six agreements on the company's plans for a $600 million exploration program in the Northern Mackenzie Delta-Beaufort Sea region, the Government said today.

headline: Casualties Are Hard to Determine
abstract: A combination of chaos and military censorship has made it difficult to obtain precise information on the casualties in the Lebanese fighting.   Various Palestinian and Lebanese sources have placed the death toll in the thousands.

headline: TIR-CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for As of Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Panel Backs Blue Bell
abstract: Blue Bell Inc. said Friday that a committee of outside directors set up to review company operations had expressed confidence in the company's management.   The committee, which was set up in February after D.E. Morris, a Blue Bell director, accused the management of incompetence, attributed the company's deterioration in earnings to the economic climate, foreign-exchange fluctuations and industrywide problems.

headline: U.S. BACKS OFF CASTRO REPORT
abstract: The State Department appeared today to back away from a report that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had told a group of businessmen that Fidel Castro was ''anguishing'' over his ties with the Soviet Union because of Cuba's economic problems.   A department spokesman, Alan Romberg, was asked for evidence to support Mr. Haig's statement on Wednesday that Mr. Castro was considering rejoining the West.

headline: Bridgestone Tire
abstract: The Government will pay 1 billion yen, or about $4.1 million, in overseas investment insurance to the Bridgestone Tire Company, whose joint venture project in Teheran was seized by the Iranian authorities, Bridgestone officials said.

headline: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS; LOBBYING:SHAKEDOWN ON CAPITOL HILL
abstract: THE growing hoards of lobbyists on Capitol Hill armed with campaign c ontributions for members of Congress is more than a political s candal. It is a serious threat to the conduct of United States e conomic policy.  Economics is a difficult and underdeveloped science, and formulating a sensible economic policy is never easy. But when the people who help shape tax laws and the budget are courted for their votes by lobbyists bearing large gifts, the likelihood of developing sensible economic policies is sharply reduced.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Schlitz, in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that with Goldman, Sachs & Company, its adviser, it had ''explored the possibility of and in some instances held preliminary discussions with certain other persons.''   Schlitz said the talks included its possible acquisition, joint ventures and the ''possible combination of the company with other companies.'' It said that no agreements had been reached and that there was no assurance of any, adding that disclosure of any terms or company names ''would jeopardize the continuation of such discussions.''

headline: Cairo Cabinet Protests 'Aggression' by Israelis
abstract: The Egyptian Cabinet today denounced Israel's attacks in Lebanon and ordered the Egyptian Ambassador to Israel to lodge a formal protest with the Israeli Foreign Ministry.   In a statement issued late today, the Cabinet said ''Israel's aggression'' was ''a blatant violation of international law'' and undermined efforts for a comprehensive peace in the Middle East.

headline: Business Productivity Registers a Slight Gain
abstract: Business productivity rose slightly in the first quarter, after a record decline in the last quarter of 1981, the Labor Department reported today.   The bureau put the gain in productivity on an annual basis at three-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting a 3 percent drop in output that was more than offset by a 3.3 percent decline in working hours. The preliminary figures are seasonally adjusted.

headline: DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CAUGHT IN A WORLD OF CHANGE, BALINESE GO THEIR OWN WAY
abstract: The fighting cocks fly into the air in a flurry of feathers and squawks. When they land, one is dead, dispatched by the blade tied to its opponent's leg.   ''Cockfighting is not legal,'' said a woodcarver, I Wayan Barak, on the sidelines. ''Many lose money.'' He said he thought Indonesia's central Government, in Jakarta on the island of Java, was trying to force the predominantly Hindu people of Bali to abide by Islam's strictures against gambling. But, he said, ''we cannot change.''

headline: Construction In May Up 7%
abstract: Construction contracts in May rose a seasonally adjusted 7 percent, recovering from April's sharp drop, according to the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company, which reports on construction activity. Despite the improvement, the total of $11.8 billion in new construction starts in May is 11 percent less than the value of contracts in May 1981.

headline: FOR MEXICO AND ITS CHIEF, THE GOLDEN DAYS DECLINE
abstract: For over five years, President Jose Lopez Portillo seemed to personify Mexico's new image of self-assurance as he presided over an unprecedented economic boom.   But now, with a severe economic crisis suddenly convulsing the country, the confidence of Mexicans in the Lopez Portillo administration has been shaken and during his final months in office the President is watching his popularity tumble.   The change in Mexico's mood has been dramatic. The optimism prevalent barely a year ago has been swept away by uncertainty, while rumors of the wildest nature are busily repeated by ordinary Mexicans who appear willing to believe the worst about the country.

headline: NEW BONDS UNCERTAIN
abstract: Large corporations may or may not take advantage of a hiatus in Treasury note and bond financings by rushing to market their own debt issues. Analysts at Salomon Brothers estimated that only $291 million of new corporate issues were scheduled this week, though a survey of underwriters showed they planned to sell more than that amount.   In the Treasury market, the only financing is the regular Monday auction of three- and six-month bills, totaling $9.4 billion. As of late Friday, three-month bills were bid at 13.2 percent while the six-month issue was 13.03 percent.

headline: Brazil Line Buys Airbuses
abstract: VASP, the Brazilian airline, confirmed today that it would buy nine European Airbus A310 jets for almost $400 million, but no American-made Boeing 737's.   The airline had requested permission from the Government to purchase the 737's and the Airbuses.

headline: SOFT OIL PRICES FORCING CUTBACK IN NORTH SEA PLANS
abstract: Faced with stagnant oil prices, soaring development costs and high taxes, big oil companies operating in the North Sea are sharply scaling back plans to develop new fields.   Phillips Petroleum, British Petroleum and a Shell-Esso joint venture have canceled three fields that collectively could have produced 100,000 barrels of oil a day at their peak.   The decision to shelve the fields comes at a time when oil is in oversupply and no new development plans have been filed with the British Government in nearly two years. Moreover, it would have taken five years to bring the fields into production, and that is when wells that now produce about 1.9 million barrels a day will begin to run down.

headline: ARGENTINA FAVORS PROPOSAL BY PERU
abstract: Argentina has accepted a Peruvian proposal for a 72-hour truce around the Falkland Islands and is waiting for a British response, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.   The proposed truce was to have gone into effect at 1 A.M. Tuesday, Buenos Aires time (11 P.M. Monday, New York time), Argentine officials said. The truce is designed to avoid hostilities as Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., now in London, continues in his efforts to find a peace settlement. Mr. Haig is scheduled to return here Tuesday.

headline: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * AVX Corp. of Great Neck, L.I., said it had formed three new operating divisions within its multilayer ceramic capacitor operations.   * American Telephone and Telegraph's Advanced Mobile Phone Service subsidiary said it had agreed with North West Telephone Co. of Tomah, Wis., to offer cellular radio service in Milwaukee.   * Bass Brother Enterprises Inc. and Bass Enterprises Production Co. told the S.E.C. they now hold 333,300, or 10.3 percent, of Trans World Corp.'s series C cumulative preferred stock.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bank of New York has elected Eric S. Salat, Richard W. Dodd, Dennis Hodne and Louis A. Rivera vice presidents.   * CPC International, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has elected Gene A.  Burns a senior vice president.

headline: I.T.T. Seeking Agency For Long Distance
abstract: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation is searching for a new agency for its long-distance telephone service, it confirmed yesterday.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Niagara Mohawk Power Co.'s $75 million of 10-year, 15 3/4 percent coupon bonds due in 1992 were priced at 99.25 to yield 15.90 percent by underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.   * Pfizer Inc. said it had agreed to exchange newly issued shares of its common stock for up to $17.1 million face value of its 8 1/2 percent sinking fund debentures due in 1999, and 9 1/4 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2000 that are owned by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co.   * Texas Utilities' Texas Power and Light Co. offering of $50 million in 30-year bonds was priced at 99.50 with a 15 7/8 percent coupon to yield 15.955 percent by underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: New Zealanders Protest
abstract: About a thousand demonstrators marched through Auckland today protesting the visit of the American nuclear-powered cruiser Truxtun. The police said the march was peaceful, and there were no arrests.

headline: Genetic Systems
abstract: The Genetic Systems Corporation said it planned a $9.5 million joint venture with a subsidiary of the Syntex Corporation, the Syva Company, to develop monoclonal antibodies for diagnosis and treatment of human cancer. The initial focus is to be on leukemia and breast, prostate, colon and lung cancer. Final terms are subject to a definitive agreement and approval of both companies, Genetic Systems said.

headline: Backer & Spielvogel Assigned Raintree Line
abstract: Backer & Spielvogel, which already does the Lestoil advertising for the Noxell Corporation, yesterday was assigned its Raintree Skin Care Line, that was introduced by SSC&B.   The billings in 1981, according to Leading National Advertisers, was $4.4 million.

headline: CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 2 MORE OUTPOSTS CLAIMED BY BRITISH IN STANLEY THRUST
abstract: British troops driving toward Stanley, the Falkland Islands' capital, have taken two more settlements, the Defense Ministry confirmed today.   The ministry said a battalion of Royal Marine commandos had captured Douglas and that a battalion of paratroopers had captured Teal Inlet. The two settlements, about 30 miles from the capital, on the north coast of East Falkland Island, were reportedly occupied without resistance.   It was also disclosed that 12 British soldiers were killed and 32 were wounded at Goose Green on Friday in the biggest battle of the war. A spokesman said the paratroopers who took Goose Green were outnumbered by 2 to 1 in a ''hard, slogging match'' against entrenched Argentine forces.

headline: U.N. LOWERS ESTIMATES OF POPULATION IN 2000
abstract: Because of population-control programs, the world's population in the year 2000 will be 20 percent less than the 7.5 billion that major international agencies had predicted, according to a report by the United Nations Fund for Population Activities.   Rafael M. Salas, the agency's director, said in the report that the world's population growth rate dropped from 1.99 percent in 1960-1965 to 1.72 percent in 1975-1980. He said the United Nations was now predicting that the annual growth rate could fall to 1.5 percent by the year 2000. That would mean the world's population would reach 6.1 billion by the end of the century instead of the 7.5 billion that had been predicted.

headline: SCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Caterpillar Salaries
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it would indefinitely freeze the salaries of its 23,750 United States managers, weekly salaried employees and others working abroad, starting June 1, and would suspend cost-of-living adjustments and salary rises normally granted at this time of year. It cited market slumps.

headline: MONETARY USE OF GOLD IS REJECTED
abstract: The United States Gold Commission today formally rejected the use of gold in either the domestic or international monetary systems.   The 17-member commission, after studying the question for more than eight months, concluded in its final report that, while there might be a future occasion when gold's role should be enlarged, ''the majority of us at this time favor essentially no change.''   The commission did, however, decide to recommend that Congress authorize the Treasury to mint a new gold ''coin,'' dubbed the American Eagle, that would provide an alternative to sending dollars abroad for investing in gold coins issued by such countries as South Africa, Mexico and Canada.   The American Eagle would have no dollar denomination, would not be considered legal tender and would be exempt from both capital gains and sales taxes. It would be sold only for its gold content.

headline: INGERSOLL-RAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Arab Nations Urged To Deny U.S. Base Rights
abstract: Algeria's Foreign Minister urged Arab nations today to deny the United States use of their territory for basing of the Rapid Deployment Force.   Opening a conference of four hard-line Arab nations and the Palestine Liberation Organization, Foreign Minister Ahmed Taleb Ibrahimi said Israel's withdrawal from the Sinai was being used to lure other Arab nations into a more moderate stance and into accepting the Camp David peace process between Israel and Egypt.   Mr. Ibrahimi addressed his keynote remarks to foreign ministers from Syria, Libya, Southern Yemen and the Palestine Liberation Organization, which with Algeria constitute the Arab Steadfastness Front that has refused any compromise solution with Israel.

headline: 4 Annual Andy Awards Go to Needham, Harper
abstract: The Advertising Club of New York sponsored the Annual Andy Awards last night at the Sheraton Centre. Needham, Harper & Steers, with four awards, was the top winner.

headline: Jackson Sees Chrysler Aides
abstract: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met with officials of the Chrysler Corporation today to discuss how the auto maker could increase its dealings with black businessmen and promote more blackowned dealerships, officials said.   In a telephone interview before the meeting at Chrysler headquarters in the Detroit enclave of Highland Park, the civil rights leader skirted the issue of a boycott of Chrysler products but said, ''Obviously, we will trade with people who trade with us.''

headline: PAMOUR PORCUPINE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The British Defense Ministry's decision to prepare 10 Vulcan bombers for operations in the South Atlantic is seen by military planners here as a deterrent to Argentine air attacks against the British fleet now moving toward the Falkland Islands.   The difficulty, as it is with the entire British operation, is time. The Vulcans, which have been armed with nuclear weapons, must be fitted with racks for conventional bombs and the crews must be trained for the planes' new mission.   The time element overshadows the other steps announced Monday to strengthen British military resources. These included the dispatch of 900 men of the Second Battalion of the Parachute Regiment with supporting artillery and engineers to join the Falklands task force.

headline: ASSOCIATED COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A Winter Storm Eases In the Falkland Area
abstract: As winter closes in on the Falkland Islands, the weather in the South Atlantic has gradually worsened. Although a blackout of weather data from the area has impeded forecasters, F. Gordon Barnes, the meteorologist for the Cable News Network and WDVM-TV in Washington, has compiled data from passing ships, Argentina and Chile to assess conditions on the islands.

headline: SINAI PENINSULA: THE YEARS OF CONFLICT
abstract: 1948. Israeli troops, pursuing retreating Egyptian forces, captured parts of northeastern Sinal, including Abue Aweigila, Kusseima the approaches to El Arish. Israel withdrew after pressure from the United States and threats of military intervention by Britain.

headline: OPPOSITION PARTIES IN INDIA JOCKEY FOR POSITION
abstract: A month before key elections are to be held in four Indian states, the leaders of the fragmented opposition factions are flirting and feuding with each other in the hope of establishing advantageous coalitions.   With the ruling party of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi facing its own serious conflicts and internal tensions, the coming elections offer the opposition groups their best opportunity for recovering some of the influence they held until their Janata Party alliance disintegrated three years ago. At the same time, the same rivalries and personality clashes that undermined Janata are still making unity elusive if not impossible.   For example, Morarji R. Desai, 86 years old, the former Janata Prime Minister, said last week that he had been ''stabbed in the back'' by Charan Singh, 80, the leader of an agrarian populist faction that was a component of the Janata amalgam. Mr. Singh played his part in the discordant political fugue by expelling three influential Members of Parliament from his party after they advocated joining forces with other centrist offshoots of the Janata Party.

headline: FED POLICY MEETING AWAITED
abstract: The fear that interest rates might rise in the second half of this year is widespread in the credit markets, but the more immediate concern of traders and investors is the prospect of a modest loosening of the Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy.   ''To ease or not to ease'' was the way economists at Money Market Services Inc., a San Francisco-based consulting concern, described the choice faced by makers of monetary policy at this week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.   The committee, made up of Federal Reserve Board governors and a rotating group of presidents from Federal Reserve Banks, seeks to chart a policy for money supply growth that is aimed at simultaneously encouraging stable prices, a healthy financial system and maximum employment.   The latest signals from the economy show that inflation is subsiding, but that bankruptcies are rising and unemployment is at a postwar high of 9.4 percent. At the same time, the closly watched M-1 measure of the money supply is more than $1 billion above the Fed's growth target of 2 1/2 to 5 1/2 percent from the fourth quarter of 1981 to the fourth quarter of 1982.

headline: AIDE SAYS INTERNAL FORCES STILL THREATEN HANOI
abstract: A senior Vietnamese official interviewed in a Polish newspaper has depicted his country with unusual candor as one troubled by grave military, economic and political problems.   The official, Hoang Tung, a secretary of the Vietnamese Communist Party's Central Committee, told a correspondent of the Communist daily, Trybuna Ludu, in an interview published here on Monday that Vietnam was threatened directly by China, which he said is supported by the United States. The external threat, Mr. Tung said, is matched inside the country by supporters of the South Vietnamese regime that was defeated seven years ago.   Mr. Tung said ''classes'' connected with the former Saigon Government, though overthrown, had not yet been completely destroyed. He also said the existence of ''more than a million people formerly closely connected'' with the old regime ''complicates the social situation.''

headline: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; June 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL   Meets at 3 P.M.

headline: Safeway Outlook
abstract: Safeway Stores, the country's largest supermarket chain, told shareholders at its annual meeting in Baltimore that it expects improvement this year in both sales and profit despite its firstquarter decline in net income. In the first quarter ended March 30, Safeway reported a 17.1 percent decline in earnings, to $16 million, or 61 cents a share, from $19.3 million, or 74 cents a share. Sales rose 10.9 percent, to $3.98 billion.

headline: Xerox Computer
abstract: The Xerox Corporation introduced a new personal computer, the 820-II, designed for business and professional use.

headline: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Stockbroker Is Enjoined
abstract: A stockbroker, Meyer Blinder, and his firm, Blinder, Robinson & Company, have been permanently enjoined from selling common stock and warrants connected with construction of a gambling casino and hotel in Atlantic City.   In a suit filed two years ago by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Blinder was charged with fraud involving the sale of $25 million in common shares of the American Leisure Corporation, prospective builder of the casino.   Judge Richard Matsch ruled on Tuesday in United States District Court that Mr. Blinder and his firm were guilty of fraud and had violated Federal law in the 1980 stock sale. Mr. Blinder said that he would appeal the decision.

headline: Oil Merger Is Set
abstract: The Texas International Company, an Oklahoma City-based gas and oil exploration company, said it had agreed to acquire the 48.5 percent of the Phoenix Resources Company's common shares that it did not already own for a total of about $74 million. A Texas International official said the company would exchange 1.1 of its shares for each of the remaining 5.33 million shares of Phoenix, following the approval of both boards of directors. Texas International has controlled 51.5 percent of Phoenix Resources, an oil and gas company, since 1978. Yesterday, Texas International's stock closed on the New York Stock exchange at 13 7/8, down 1/4, after reaching a high of 14 3/8 earlier in the day.

headline: WARSAW PRESSES ATTACK ON SOLIDARITY
abstract: In the midst of what the Polish Government calls a ''public discussion'' on the future of the trade union movement, the officially controlled press and broadcasting outlets are stepping up a campaign against the suspended Solidarity union.   The press, television and radio have charged that some of the union's leaders had ties with Western centers of subversion and were turning to terrorism to overthrow Communism.   The impression created among Poles by the campaign is that the martial-law authorities are unlikely to permit Solidarity to be revived as an independent union or that they may decide to abolish it. Such a course was advocated in print for the first time this week.

headline: Text of address is on page A14.
abstract: President Reagan proposed a two-step plan today in which the United States and the Soviet Union would initially reduce by one-third their arsenals of nuclear warheads on land- and sea-based ballistic missiles.   Administration officials, in a briefing earlier, estimated that each side had deployed about 7,500 missile warheads. A one-third reduction would cut to about 5,000 the number of warheads for each nation. This would be the first step toward the second phase of the proposal, in which the two nations accept an ''equal ceiling'' on the ''throw weight'' or total payload, of all nuclear missiles, the President said in a speech here.   Mr. Reagan told the graduating class of Eureka College, his alma mater, that he had written a letter to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, suggesting that the two Governments begin formal negotiations by the end of June.

headline: Dow Off 1.81 Despite Rate Cut; Early Rally Dissipated
abstract: The stock market, despite a cut in interest rates, registered a moderate decline yesterday in accelerated trading. The biggest price movers were issues responding to specific news developments.   At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 1.81 points, to 834.57. In the overall market, stocks that fell on the New York Stock Exchange outpaced advancing issues by 730 to 681.

headline: INDUSMIN LATD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TITAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The Economy
abstract: A pessimistic forecast was released by the nation's leading business economists. They look for only a weak recovery in the last half of 1982, with high unemployment and high interest rates. But they also expect inflation to remain in check, with price increases averaging under 6 percent this year and next. (Page D1.)   A bill to dissolve the Department of Energy was submitted by the Administration. Under the plan, modified at the urging of Congress, most of the department's duties would be transferred to the Department of Commerce, with separate deputy secretaries named there to oversee its military and energy programs. (D1.)

headline: Franc Rumor Denied
abstract: French Economy Minister Jacques Delors today denied rumors of an imminent devaluation of the franc. Speaking on French radio, he said that the economic approach adopted by the Socialist Government did not merit the criticism that some economists had made. On Friday, foreign-exchange dealers said, the Bank of France sold around 200 million West German marks, the equivalent of about $86 million, to support the franc.

headline: Elan Magazine Halted
abstract: Publication of Elan, a national magazine for black women, was suspended Tuesday after three issues, and most of the staff was dismissed. Cecile D. Barker, founder and chief executive officer, said the bimonthly would be restructured and would resume publication within 30 days.

headline: HIGH-TECH COMPANIES CASHING IN ON TODAY'S COMPUTER BATTLEFIELDS
abstract: The weaponry goes by such names as Shrike and Hawk and Wild Weasel a nd, as these names imply, they are instruments of destruction.  F illed with sophisticated electronics, they brought a new dimension t o the battles that raged in Lebanon and the Falklands war. If there i s any lesson to be learned from these conflicts, it is that e lectronics have gone to war.   And so have such companies as I.B.M., RCA, Eaton, TRW and GTE Sylvania, hardly the sort of names that spring to mind when it comes to weaponry. These well-known companies and hundreds of others are providing the electronic gadgetry that makes these weapons so lethal. Along with a cluster of little-known companies that specialize in high-technology weaponry, they make the electronic brains that allow missiles to chase after their target, that render destroyers vulnerable to a single missile and that can turn an opponent's radar against him by making it a homing path for an enemy projectile.   More than a miracle of technology, electronic warfare is lucrative business. Worldwide sales of such products are expected to reach nearly $7 billion in 1982, according to the International Countermeasures Handbook, an industry trade publication. And analysts report that investor interest in makers of electronic war equipment has always been strong and remains so.

headline: Checker-Potamkin Pact
abstract: The Checker Motors Corporation and its majority owner, the Checker Taxi Company, have settled litigation with Victor H. Potamkin, a Manhattan Cadillac dealer, and certain Potamkin affiliates, it was announced yesterday. The settlement with Mr. Potamkin involved the sale by Checker Motors of all the stock outstanding of the National Transportation Company to that Potamkin affiliate for $7 million in cash.

headline: Guatemala's Envoy Named
abstract: Guatemala's military Government named Jorge Luis Zelaya today as Ambassador to the United States.

headline: NORTHERN TELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RESIGNATION AT HARVESTER
abstract: International Harvester's beleaguered chairman, Archie McCardell, (left) stepped down Monday at his board's request.

headline: U.S. Trade Deficit Rose To $2.6 Billion in March
abstract: The nation's merchandise trade deficit rose to $2.6 billion in March as a surge in imported automobiles offset a decline in foreign oil purchases, the Commerce Department reported today.   American merchandise exports totaled $18.6 billion, down fivetenths of 1 percent from February, the department said, while imports were up 6.7 percent, to $21.2 billion.   The trade deficit was the largest since January's $5.1 billion.  February's deficit was $1.2 billion.  All figures were seasonally adjusted.

headline: Bell Scientist Objects to Bill
abstract: Pending telecommunications legislation could weaken Bell Laboratories, possibly threatening a vital part of the national program for pure scientific research, a Bell Labs vice president told the House Committee on Science and Technology today.   The Bell official, Arno Penzias, said the House bill would do harm by requiring stricter accountability to regulatory agencies for its research programs. Dr. Penzias, a co-winner of the Nobel Prize in 1978 for his work in radio astronomy, said this would make the laboratories more market-oriented and disturb the contemplative atmosphere that contributed to many past discoveries.

headline: Around the World; An American Climber Is Killed on Everest
abstract: A mountain climber from New York City plunged to her death from a point 3,000 feet below the summit of Mount Everest, the Chinese Mountaineering Association said today.

headline: U.S. WARNS ISRAEL AGAINST NEW ATTCKS ON BEIRUT
abstract: The United States has told Israel that it supports an end to the Palestine Liberation Organization's military presence in west Beirut but that barring major provocations, Washington will not countenance further military activity against the city, Administration officials said today.   A high State Department official said, however, that despite the Israeli Cabinet's affirmation today of the cease-fire in Lebanon, the United States has been advising Saudi Arabia and other Governments with influence on the P.L.O. that it cannot guarantee that Israel will adhere to the truce much longer unless the Palestinians surrender their arms.   The official said the United States was basing its efforts to end the Palestinian military presence in Lebanon not on Israeli policy but on public statements made by the Lebanese Government at the United Nations and at the Arab League meeting in Tunis today.   He said Lebanon had received significant support in Tunis from other Arab nations for its demand that the P.L.O. forces lay down their arms and end their military presence in Lebanon.

headline: EASTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LITTON PRESIDENT HAS HOMECOMING
abstract: Eight years after he left Litton Industries to run a small semiconductor company, Orion L. Hoch, 53 years old, will come home to Litton to become president and chief operating officer, succeeding Fred W. O'Green, 61, who will remain chairman and chief executive officer.   Mr. Hoch, who will rejoin Litton on June 3, noted that his company, Intersil Inc., had been acquired by the General Electric Company about a year ago. ''I had agreed with G.E. that I would stay after the acquisition for a transition period,'' he said. ''We had just completed that transition.''

headline: TEST LINK OF EXCHANGES IS AUTHORIZED BY S.E.C.
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved an experimental computerized trading network that links leading brokerage houses with the nation's seven major stock exchanges.   The network is a major step in setting up the national stock trading system that Congress in 1975 told the S.E.C. to establish.  The experiment approved today allows market-makers in brokerage offices to trade certain securities directly with specialists on the floors of any of the seven participating exchanges, with the order going electronically to the exchange offering the best price.  Currently, most trades must be executed on the floors of specific exchanges by representatives of the brokerage houses that receive customer orders.

headline: SPACE TRANSPORTATION SEEKS CAPITAL
abstract: It sounds like the brainchild of a mad scientist and an eccentric millionaire. The Space Transportation Company of Princeton, N.J., has a billion-dollar plan to sell tickets to outer space.   On the other hand, its organizer and investment banker, William Sword & Company, also of Princeton, is on the hunt for capital, and a chunk is apparently forthcoming from one financial heavyweight, the Prudential Insurance Company of America.   Specifically, Klaus Heiss, the 40-year-old president of Space Transportation, has offered to buy a $1 billion space shuttle from the Rockwell International Corporation and give it to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which already has four of the orbiters.

headline: Advertising; High Cost Of TV Ads Examined
abstract: THE art director on the set where a television commercial was being shot rejected a dining room table that was scheduled to be used in the ad.   A cost-conscious client representative, realizing that the table would be covered by a cloth during the shooting, questioned the creative genius.   ''But I would know what's under the cloth, and it just wouldn't be right,'' the art director responded. The delay cost the client an additional $5,000.

headline: CHIEF AT BRUNSWICK RESIGNS SUDDENLY
abstract: K. Brooks Abernathy, 63 years old, chairman and chief executive officer of the Brunswick Corporation, a diversified conglomerate based in suburban Chicago, abruptly resigned as chief executive officer at the company's annual meeting Friday.   Jack F. Reichert, 51, Brunswick's president and chief operating officer, was named chief executive officer by the board of directors. Mr. Reichert was reportedly told only minutes before the annual meeting of Mr. Abernathy's decision. Mr. Abernathy will continue to serve as chairman.

headline: 2 ARABS ARE KILLED AS ISRAELI ATTACKS DOME OF THE ROCK
abstract: An Israeli soldier with an automatic rifle shot his way into one of Islam's holiest shrines, the Dome of the Rock, and sprayed the inside of the mosque with gunfire today, killing at least two Arabs and wounding at least nine.   Israeli policemen and border troops in riot gear swarmed onto the Temple Mount, stormed the mosque and captured the gunman within about 20 minutes. They escorted him out through a howling mob of Moslems who had streamed to the site from all corners of the Old City.   The police identified the assailant as Alan Harry Goodman, 37 years old, who apparently moved to Israel from Baltimore in 1977. Link to Extremists   Among the belongings found in his room in the Beit Hakerem section of Jerusalem were fliers from the Kach Movement, a small extremist group of ultranationalists led by Rabbi Meir Kahane. They advocate the expulsion of all Arabs from Israel and the replacement of the mosques on the Temple Mount with a Jewish temple. (A spokesman for the group denied any connection with the attack, United Press International reported, and said, ''We do not condone it and we condemn it.'')

headline: GERERAL FOODS NET DROPS 27%
abstract: The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday that net income in its fiscal fourth quarter ended April 3 declined 27 percent, to $52.9 million, or $1.07 a share, from $72.5 million, or $1.47 a share, a year earlier.   Sales for the quarter rose 23.7 percent, to $2.13 billion, from $1.73 billion a year earlier, the country's largest producer of coffee said.   The company said that, discounting special charges from the sale of its Burger Chef restaurant chain, profits for the fiscal fourth quarter amounted to $99.7 million, or $2.02 a share, a 37.5 percent increase.   For the fiscal year 1982, General Foods, which is also a leading manufacturer of packaged convenience foods, reported that net income declined 21.6 percent, to $200.2 million, or $4.05 a share, from $255.4 million, or $5.14 a share, in the fiscal year 1981.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Graphic Scanning Corp. said it had acquired all of the stock outstanding of California Satellite Systems in exchange for 457,523 shares of Graphic common stock valued at about $7 million.   * Gulf and Western Industries said it had purchased an additional 1.2 percent, or 155,800 shares, of the Clark Equipment Co., a Michigan-based producer of trucks and construction equipment, for $3.6 million.

headline: Sumitomo Chemical Net
abstract: The Sumitomo Chemical Company today announced a 72.7 percent drop in consolidated net income for all of 1981, to $995.8 million, from $3.6 billion a year earlier, on sales of $2.86 billion, down 3.3 percent, from $2.95 billion in 1980. It cited sluggish demand for petrochemical products and a decline in product prices.

headline: Gasoline Futures
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today unanimously approved the Chicago Board of Trade's plan to trade futures of leaded and unleaded regular gasoline. James Culver, director of economics and education for the commission, said that the terms were nearly the same as those for the Board of Trade's heating oil futures contract, which calls for delivery of a depositary receipt against the contracts, rather than immediate physical delivery of a product.

headline: Canadian Pacific Net Falls 64.8%
abstract: Canadian Pacific Ltd., a diversified transportation, natural resources and financial services concern that is Canada's biggest company, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1982 plunged 64.8 percent, to $46.9 million, or 65 cents a share, from $133.4 million, or $1.86 a share, in the first quarter of 1981.  Revenues, however, increased 10.4 percent, to $3.09 billion, from $2.8 billion.   The company's results are stated in Canadian dollars. The Canadian dollar is worth about 82 cents in United States currency.F.S. Burbidge, CP's chairman, told shareholders attending the company's annual meeting at its Montreal headquarters that two of the company's transportation units, CP Air and CP Ships, incurred losses in the latest quarter while CP Rail and its trucking operation showed an earnings decline.

headline: HELPING A LARGE COMPANY DECIDE NOT TO LEAVE TOWN
abstract: Paine Webber Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, became fed up with Manhattan office rents. Last year it was planning to move all of its back-office operations to Jersey City, which would have meant a loss of 2,000 jobs for New York City.   The company was working with a developer in Jersey City on a new 15-story building, with a helicopter pad on the roof, to link employees with their colleagues in Manhattan.   A few months ago Paine Webber changed its mind. Several factors resulted in the switch, including a deal from the New York City Industrial Development Agency to sweeten the financing for remodeling the existing space at 25 Broad Street. New computers, not luxury, dictated that the back-office space be altered if Paine Webber were to remain in the city.

headline: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Decision to Bury Dead On Islands Causes Row
abstract: A dispute has erupted over the Government's decision to bury on the Falkland Islands the bodies of British servicemen killed there.
