The controversy has intensified since the decision to bury those killed at Goose Green in a mass grave, a decision made by the commander of the task force, Rear Adm.

headline: TRADERS IGNORE PRIME RATE
abstract: The credit markets remained stalled yesterday, ignoring Citibank's reduction of the prime rate as well as an easing of the pivotal Federal funds rate. The market's malaise, dealers said, sharply cut trading activity.   The rate on 90-day Treasury bills rose to 11.65 percent yesterday from the average yield at Monday's auction of 11.480 percent. The rate on the companion 26-week bills rose to 11.77 percent from 11.677 percent. Among the longer coupon maturities, prices were basically unchanged.

headline: INVASION VICTIMS SWAMP THE HOSPITALS OF LEBANON
abstract: The driveway was lined with stretchers.  Every so often today ambulances, some of them caked with mud and camouflaged with twigs and greenery, pulled into the driveway, their sirens wailing.   Attendants and medics attached to the American University Hospital here rushed to the vehicles, removing some of the victims of Lebanon's latest bout of carnage, and rushed them to the emergency room.   Other victims straggled in on foot seeking assistance. One elderly woman, tears in her eyes, walked painfully up the driveway today and said to a stranger: ''Please, I'm with the diabetes and my home is gone. Where can I get the free help?''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Dow Slips 1.62; Defense Group Gains
abstract: Stock prices retreated slightly yesterday in what analysts viewed as a normal response to a sustained four-week recovery.  The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.62 points, to 841.32.  However, for the first time in a year, the industrials posted gains for four consecutive weeks. The average set its low for this year at 795.47 on March 8. It finished last Thursday, before the Easter holiday weekend, at 842.94.

headline: House Passes Copyright Bill
abstract: The House passed today and sent to President Reagan for signature a bill designed to curtail the billion-dollar-a-year business of illegally counterfeiting and selling copyright motion pictures, tapes and records.   People who tape at home for their own personal use will not be affected by the new legislation, which features stronger penalties for counterfeiting.

headline: MISSOURI PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 19 Die in Air Crash At Bombay Airport
abstract: An Air India jet carrying 111 people crash-landed in a blinding rainstorm at Bombay International Airport today, killing 19 people and injuring dozens, airline officials said.

headline: Dow Advances 3.14, to 798.71
abstract: Lending encouragement to investors, the Dow Jones industrial average edged up yesterday, thanks to a burst of short-covering activity in the final minutes.  The Dow finished at 798.71, up 3.14 points. But it was touch-andgo yesterday. At 3 P.M., the Dow was ahead 2.66 points. But by 3:30 P.M., it had slipped back to 795.09, below the Wednesday close of 795.57, the lowest level since March 8.

headline: MAN OF HOUR IN ARGENTINA
abstract: As he stood on the balcony of the pink presidential palace, tens of thousands of delirious Argentines below chanted his name.   Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Fortunato Galtieri, the President of Argentina, beamed back and, in a pontifical gesture, turned from side to side, presenting himself with outturned hands to the crowd.   The scene Friday in the Plaza de Mayo as the crowd celebrated Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands was reminiscent of another time and another man, Gen. Juan Domingo Peron, who with his wife, Evita, filled that same plaza with admirers 30 years ago.   As if on cue, Julio Romero, a former Peronist governor of the province of Corrientes, returned from two years in exile in Paraguay Sunday and at an airport news conference praised General Galtieri as a man who could unite ''the armed forces and people as Juan Peron did.'' Political leaders here say it is an exaggeration, but most agree he has greatly enhanced his political power and future.

headline: ALLIS-CHALMERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FLIGHT TRANSPORTATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 100,000 on Strike in Spain
abstract: More than 100,000 workers went on strike today to demand greater Government investment in the northern Spanish region of Asturias, union spokesmen said. Virtually every sector of production was affected, especially mining and steel.

headline: WICKES'S BIGGEST TASK: DEALING WITH SUPPLIERS
abstract: Last Friday evening, top executives of the Wickes Companies, one of the nation's largest retailers, gathered at the plush Century Plaza Hotel in West Los Angeles to discuss the company's shaky finances.   By the time dinner was over, it was clear to Sanford C. Sigoloff, Wickes's new chairman, that the company was rapidly failing and that bankruptcy was the best solution.   Difficult though the company's problems were, Wickes's biggest problems may lie ahead. In particular, the company faces the task of convincing its suppliers, who have already shied away from filling orders, to resume shipments to stores already depleted of stock.

headline: 3 Bombs Hit Buenos Aires
abstract: Three small explosions damaged a hotel bathroom, an American bank's facade and the entrance to a store today, but no one was injured, the police said.

headline: Y.& R. Coast Unit Gets Suzuki Motorcycles
abstract: The U.S. Suzuki Motor Corporation, the marketer of Japanese-made vehicles, has slipped its motorcycle account to Young & Rubicam, Los Angeles, from Eisaman, Johns & Laws.   Leading National Advertisers recorded $3.8 million worth of advertising in all major media except newspapers and spot radio for the motorcycles last year.

headline: British Video Plant Set
abstract: The joint video product venture set up by Thorn Emi PLC, the Victor Company of Japan Ltd. and Aeg-Telefunken A.G. will make video cassette recorders in Britain as well as in West Berlin, as previously announced, Thorn said here today.

headline: TELECO OILFIELD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARGENTINE VESSEL IS REPORTED SUNK IN THE FALKLANDS
abstract: British forces have sunk an Argentine ship, believed to be an oil tanker, in the narrow waterway that separates East and West Falkland Islands, a correspondent's dispatch from the scene said tonight.   The correspondent, Brian Hanrahan of the BBC, reported from the aircraft carrier Hermes, the flagship of the British task force, that a Royal Navy frigate had spotted a vessel on radar and put up illumination shells. The ship, he reported, tried to escape and was fired upon. Mr. Hanrahan said ''a huge fireball stretching to the clouds'' rose from what British officers presumed to be an oil tanker.   The Defense Ministry asserted that the action in Falkland Sound demonstrated that Britain had established total military superiority around the islands.

headline: 3 MONTHS INTO STRIKE, BOMBAY'S WORKERS BEAR UP
abstract: For the last three months, Bombay's quarter of a million textile workers have been on strike, following the lead of a physician who has confronted both industrialists and established labor unions and seriously disrupted the economic life of India's richest city.   The cost of the strike has been punishing to all sides. The workers and their families, who account for more than a million of the city's eight million people, receive no strike benefits, and their meager savings have long since vanished. They are now pawning their marriage ornaments to obtain cash from money lenders, who are charging 114 percent interest a year. With little or no hope of temporary work, the idle laborers spend their days sleeping and playing cards at the chawls, or housing units, where groups of up to 12 people live in 12-feet-by-12-feet cubicles.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: REAGAN'S ISLAND IN THE SUN
abstract: In an era when American Presidents have been careful to take American vacations on Colorado ski slopes, California golf courses or Georgia trout streams, President Reagan this week relaxed at a Caribbean oceanfront cottage where the ''Bleep-bleep-bleep'' of tiny tree frogs echoes through the evening air.   During the day, the ocean shimmers in the bright sunlight with differing shades of aquamarine and blue. Goats meander occasionally on the nearby roads. Lizards scamper through the trees, bats come out at night, and the neighbors complain that entire families of monkeys come in and rip the orchids to shreds.

headline: American Home Gains
abstract: The American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter profit was up 13.8 percent, to $145.1 million, or 93 cents a share, from $127.5 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 6 percent, to $1.11 billion, from $1.05 billion.  The company's products include prescription drugs and packaged foods.

headline: Economic Scene; Negotiating On the Budget
abstract: IT looks as though the impasse between President Reagan and Congress over the fiscal year 1983 budget is soon to be broken. Mr.  Reagan and House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. have said that a ''summit'' conference on the budget is in the offing.   The President has been loath to move from ''listening,'' with James A. Baker 3d as his ear on Capitol Hill, to a negotiating posture, lest he weaken his bargaining position. His aides had warned him against the danger of ''negotiating with himself'' by offering terms for a budget settlement before Congressional leaders could produce one of their own.   But there was danger that the Republicans and Democrats in Congress would be unable to reach a deal of their own unless the President took a hand in it. The Democrats were especially wary of agreeing to cuts in Social Security or other entitlement programs, and then finding that the President had moved to blame them for hurting the aged and the poor. And they hesitated to expose themselves to the possibility of a Presidential attack for undermining the nation's defenses or aggravating the recession by raising taxes. They insisted that a deal could not be made unless the President involved himself in the negotiating process and shared responsibility for the deal.

headline: MIDCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MAKE NO AID OFFER
abstract: A sharply divided Arab world has so far failed to offer any assistance to the Lebanese and the Palestinians in the face of Israel's invasion today of southern Lebanon.   ''Arab silence is stunning,'' said the state-controlled Radio Lebanon. The leftist daily As Safir added editorially, ''The Arab world has been as quiet as the grave about Israel's aggression.''

headline: A.& P. Agreement
abstract: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company and the United Food and Commercial Workers Union said yesterday that A.& P. would form a new subsidiary that would open 20 to 24 currently closed stores in the Philadelphia area by the end of the year. The subsidiary, Super Fresh Food Centers Inc., will operate under an agreement with the union that will include incentive and investment programs for union members. A.& P., which has been closing hundreds of stores recently in an effort to increase profitability, lost $72.9 million in its fourth quarter, ended Feb.27, far wider more than its year-earlier loss of $4.2 million.

headline: LOUISIANA LAND STAKE RAISED BY HUNT FAMILY
abstract: A group headed by the Hunt brothers of Texas disclosed yesterday the purchase of an additional $36 million of stock in the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company, increasing the group's stake in the company to about 12 percent from 9 percent.   The group, officers and directors of the Placid Oil Company of Dallas, a Hunt family company, has been purchasing the stock since 1979, when it acquired an initial stake of 7.3 percent of the 38 million outstanding shares. The group said that while it had no plans to seek control of the company, it reserved the right to do so later.

headline: Construction Costs Up 5.3%
abstract: The cost of construction materials and labor around the nation rose 5.3 percent, down from 6.2 percent last year, according to an annual survey by the McGraw-Hill Information Services Company.   The highest construction cost increases this year, up 6 percent, were in the Northeastern, North Central and New England states.

headline: PRIME MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRACES OF 'ENEMY' ABOUND IN ARGENTINA
abstract: They have taken the Queen's picture off the wall at the Hurlingham Club and renamed Plaza Britania after the Argentine Air Force, but Buenos Aires still bears many traces of the people identified in daily communiques from the military high command as the ''enemy.''   The British-built ''subterraneo'' runs on the left-hand tracks and residents combat the drizzly autumn chill in trenchcoats and tartan scarves. Bankers call their working district ''la city'' and lunch in restaurants with stags' heads on the walls and meat pies on the menu. Late each afternoon, corner cafes fill with tea takers.

headline: BRITAIN CRITICIZED BY PRESS IN SOVIET
abstract: The Soviet Union published press commentaries today attacking Britain and the United States over the Falkland Islands dispute but gave no indication of any direct Soviet involvement in the crisis.   The Soviet stance since Britain sent its warships toward the Falkland Islands has been to accuse Britain regularly of imperialist and colonialist aggression and to accuse Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., even before Washington's declaration of support for London on Friday, of siding with the British in pursuit of American ''military-strategic goals in the South Atlantic.''   On Friday, when Washington announced limited sanctions against Argentina and support for Britain, the Soviet press agency Tass said: ''As is known, Washington from the very start vigorously supported its NATO partner, Britain, in its dispute with Argentina. Today's statements by Ronald Reagan and Alexander Haig mean only that Washington has discarded the mask of a 'mediator' between London and Buenos Aires, a role that it so far tried to play.''

headline: Pope Returns to the Vatican; Urges Swift Aid for Lebanese
abstract: Pope John Paul II pleaded today, less than three hours after returning to the Vatican from Argentina, for emergency aid to Lebanon.

headline: SENATE PANEL REJECTS NUCLEAR FREEZE
abstract: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee rejected a resolution today that called for a freeze in Soviet and American nuclear arsenals and instead endorsed a measure acceptable to the Reagan Administration.   The committee adopted a resolution that omits the word ''freeze'' and commends the Administration for its strategic arms reduction plan. The resolution, adopted by a vote of 11 to 4 after a sharp debate, urges President Reagan to continue to refrain from undercutting the limitations of the first and second strategic arms limitation agreements with the Soviet Union as long as Moscow shows equal restraint.   The vote was the first Congressional test of support for a freeze on the production of nuclear weapons. The freeze movement has been gaining momentum as a result of a vigorous grass-roots campaign, but it has faced considerable skepticism in professional arms control circles.

headline: DOW OFF 4.57 IN SLOW TRADING
abstract: The stock market declined moderately yesterday in slow trading, with concern over interest rates continuing to inhibit investors.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the session, fell 4.57 points, to 814.97. Yesterday was the 12th trading day in the last 14 in which the Dow fell.   In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday outscored stocks that advanced by 947 to 484.  Turnover on the Big Board fell to 41.7 million shares from 43.9 million shares on Friday. The stock market was closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day.

headline: BANQUET, MASQUE, FIREWORKS
abstract: President and Mrs. Reagan dined in the fabled Hall of Mirrors at the Palace of Versailles tonight, watched a 45-minute musical masque in the 210-year-old palace opera house and witnessed a fireworks display in the gardens of the Grand Trianon, the Louis XIV chateau now used as an official residence for visiting heads of government.   Two contingents of regally dressed Gardes Republicans greeted the approximately 250 guests as they crossed the courtyard to the palace for the major social event at the eighth economic summit conference.  As the seven heads of government arrived, a contingent of Gardes on horseback drew sabres to present arms, and 75 buglers sounded a fanfare.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: POPE MAKING 12-HOUR TRIP TODAY TO RED CROSS AND I.L.O. IN GENEVA
abstract: Pope John Paul II will take his message of peace and social justice to Geneva Tuesday in his third foreign trip in less than three weeks.   As part of the 14th trip of his 44-month-old pontificate, John Paul will address the 148-nation International Labor Organization and visit Red Cross headquarters, which has been monitoring human rights conditions in his native Poland under martial law.   The all-Swiss humanitarian agency announced today that it had arranged for a neutral zone in the Falkland capital of Stanley to protect the civilians. During his visits to Britain and Argentina this month, the 62-year-old Pope repeatedly called for an end to the fighting and led hundreds of thousands in prayers for peace.

headline: THE BITTER WAR IN COMPUTERS
abstract: The arrest of Japanese businessmen for trying to steal computer secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation represents the latest twist in what has become an increasingly tense and bitter Japanese-American battle for world supremacy in electronics.   Japanese companies, backed by their Government, have begun an ambitious effort to become major exporters of virtually all computer and telecommunications products. I.B.M. clearly sees the Japanese companies as its major threat - more so, even, than the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.   Companies like Hitachi Ltd. and the Nippon Electric Company have captured more than 50 percent of the world market for a popular computer memory chip, the 64K dynamic RAM, or random access memory.  They have surpassed I.B.M. in sales of large computers in their own country and are making inroads worldwide.

headline: GOLDEN NUGGET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRITAIN RETAKES ANOTHER ATLANTIC ISLAND FROM ARGENTINA
abstract: Britain said today that it had reclaimed the last of its South Atlantic possessions from Argentina without a fight.  It said troops based on the Falkland Islands swooped onto Thule, the southernmost of the remote South Sandwich Islands, and captured a team of Argentine scientists. Britain said the scientists were there illegally, but Buenos Aires, which confirmed the takeover, said an agreement had been reached years ago authorizing their presence.

headline: A DEALER IN BONDS DEFAULTS ON DEBT
abstract: A big dealer in Government bonds and notes, Drysdale Government Securities, informed creditors yesterday that it was unable to meet more than $160 million in interest payments, creating considerable concern throughout the financial community.   The Chase Manhattan Bank, which said it was a clearing agent for Drysdale, led a broad decline in bank stocks on the New York Stock Exchange, slumping 3 1/2, to 48 1/2.   Drysdale's inability to meet its debt payments prompted the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in an unusual late-afternoon statement, to tell Government bond dealers that it ''stood ready as lender of last resort'' to help commercial banks meet ''unusual credit demands related to market problems.''   Drysdale had borrowed Government securities from other dealers, and its failure to pay interest on those borrowings could leave the dealers short of funds to meet their own obligations. The Fed statement appeared aimed at assuring the availability of financing in case some of the dealers needed it to survive.

headline: Voting in Papua New Guinea Starts and Will Last 3 Weeks
abstract: Voing began today in Papua New Guinea in one of the world's longest election processes.

headline: GLENMORE DISTRILLERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Canadian Aide Deplores U.S. Policy on Acid Rain
abstract: The United States policy on acid rain was criticized by Canada here today at the United Nations conference on the global environment.   J.B. Seaborn, Canada's Deputy Environment Minister, called for joint action to deal with the long-range drift of air pollution, particularly acid rain.

headline: WISCONSIN POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SPANISH COMMUNIST PARTY LEADER AGREES TO WITHDRAW RESIGNATION
abstract: Santiago Carrillo, Secretary General of the Communist Party, agreed today to withdraw his resignation after a week of internal debates that opened new fissures in the organization's leadership.   Mr. Carrillo abruptly resigned as Secretary General four days ago after two senior party leaders implicitly blamed him for the Communists' poor fourth-place showing in last month's regional elections in southern Andalusia.

headline: FRIDAY, MAY 14, 1982; The Braniff Shutdown
abstract: Braniff International filed a bankruptcy petition, becoming the first major domestic airline ever to seek court protection from its creditors. The carrier submitted the Chapter 11 papers to a judge in Fort Worth, near its headquarters, after suspending all its flights.  Braniff said a sharp drop in passenger traffic had created a severe cash squeeze. (Page A1.) As a result of the shutdown, most of Braniff's 9,500 employees were out of work and hundreds of passengers were stranded far from their destinations. (D3.)   Financial problems similar to Braniff's are being experienced by other airlines. Few analysts believe, however, that any of them will be forced to suspend operations. (D3.) A number of other airlines agreed to honor Braniff tickets, while, in Washington, Braniff's former competitors applied to the C.A.B. to take over what remains of the carrier's international routes. (D3.) The C.A.B.'s chairman said Braniff had been hurt by poor management and the recession. (D13.)

headline: Alcoa Cuts Back Wages and Prices
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, said yesterday that it had frozen the salaries of its top 1,800 managers, cut increases for other salaried employees in half and is trimming all discretionary expenses.   It also said that it would match the price cut of 6 cents a pound on the body stock for cans that Alcan Aluminium Ltd. announced last week.

headline: ISRAEL TO PROTEST P.L.O.'S USE OF U.N. REFUGEE INSTALLATIONS
abstract: Israel intends to protest to the United Nations over the use of United Nations refugee installations in Lebanon for Palestinian military purposes, a senior Israeli official said today.   The Israeli Army has found extensive arms caches in Palestinian refugee camps and schools run by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, known as Unrwa, which receives about 25 percent of its annual budget from the United States. The agency has been responsible since 1948 for providing assistance to Palestinian refugees and has received a total of $1 billion in American funds during its lifetime. The United States is the largest single contributor.

headline: Market Place; Views Vary On Akzona
abstract: AKZONA INC. has dipped its fibrous pen in red ink, raising fears that directors may trim or omit the dividend at a meeting tomorrow.  Akzona's problems grew with its appearance on a list, published last week by Standard & Poor's, of 39 stocks to avoid.  The service, in its Outlook report, spoke of the ''soft market'' for synthetic fibers that has hurt Akzona's American Enka division.  Setbacks in the fiber division added to companywide losses in the first quarter.   Analysts now estimate that Akzona will earn about 70 cents for the full year - 10 cents less than the annual dividend.

headline: Hewlett Net Up
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported that earnings for its second fiscal quarter rose 34.3 percent on a 22.3 percent gain in revenues.  Hewlett-Packard, a supplier of computers and electronic instruments, said earnings for the three months ending April 30 were $94 million, or 76 cents a share, up from $70 million, or 57 cents a share, in the same quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose to $1.06 billion from $867 million a year earlier.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS REPORT DEATH OF AN AMERICAN ON THEIR SIDE
abstract: A rebel radio broadcast reported today that an American fighting alongside Salvadoran guerrillas was killed by Government troops last month in northeasten Morazan province.   The guerrillas' clandestine Radio Venceremos said Joseph David Anderson was shot April 27 in a Government drive to roust guerrillas from the province.

headline: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. STEEL TO CLOSE BIG ALABAMA MILL
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would close its Fairfield plant, the South's largest integrated steel mill. Until the late 1970s, the mill was one of the biggest employers in Birmingham, Ala.   The company said it was closing the plant in mid-June and laying off 3,500 workers because it could not reach an agreement with the United Steelworkers union to reduce the work force at the mill.   No employees will be recalled until early 1984, when a new seamless pipe mill begins operations there, the company said. Already, 4,000 employees at the plant have been laid off.

headline: RCA TV Tube
abstract: The RCA Corporation said that it was completing development of a new color television picture tube system designed to lower the manufacturing cost of sets and to improve performance and reliability. The company said the system has a new color tube design that can be used in all tube sizes from 13 inch to 25 inch.

headline: Corporate Philanthropy
abstract: Despite the recession, American corporations are willing to give more to philanthropy, according to results of a survey issued today.   ''It is clear that chief executives are not looking for cop-outs, that they're willing to do more than they're doing,'' said Arthur White, vice chairman of Yankelovich, Skelly & White, which conducted the study for the Council on Foundations.

headline: THE PROFESSOR AS PAID EXPERT
abstract: Franklin Fisher, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, earned as much as $125,000 a year by providing testimony for the International Business Machines Corporation during its 13-year antitrust case with the Federal Government.   And a consulting firm founded by James Rosse, an economist at Stanford University, was paid $241,000 last year for studies used by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to support its arguments in its eight-year-old antitrust case.   While the two economists' fees are considered unusually large for such work, they do reflect the increasing importance of consulting work to professors who supplement their university salaries by doing research or offering expert testimony for both business and the Government.   At present, more than 50 percent of the nation's faculty members do some form of consulting, compared with only 13 percent in 1960, according to a study by Robert Linnell of the University of Southern California.

headline: PHIBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUCYRUS-ERIE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELI IN MOSQUE CASE DECIDES TO CHANGE LAWYERS
abstract: The American-born Israeli Army recruit accused of last Sunday's murder on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem today dropped his court-appointed counsel and agreed to be defended by an attorney hired by Rabbi Meir Kahane, the Jewish Defense League leader.   Rabbi Kahane's Israeli Kach movement, which last week deplored the killing and called the accused man, Alan H. Goodman, ''a sick Jew,'' is expected to make the murder case a political trial.   The movement, which was beaten in all national elections, has strongly attacked the Government policy that has given Moslems exclusive use of the Temple Mount as a place of worship and has assigned Jews the Wailing Wall at the foot of the mount.   Under Jewish religious law, the ground where the holy temple stood until its destruction 2,000 years ago is so sacred that it is forbidden to set foot there without going through a complex purification ritual.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Electric Power Co. shareholders approved a proposal to increase the number of authorized common shares to 200 million from 175 million.   * American Financial Corp. said it had lowered its North American Mortgage Investors stake to 11.6 percent, following the sale of shares to Southmark Properties.

headline: Spain's Coup Defendants Face 30-Year Sentences
abstract: The prosecution refused today to reduce charges of military rebellion against 33 men accused in last year's attempted coup in Spain and requested 30-year prison sentences for the three main defendants.   The prosecutor, Gen. Jose Manuel Claver, said that he believes the the involvement of 32 military officers and one civilian in the bungled coup has been sufficiently proven.

headline: Standard-Coosa To Be Acquired
abstract: The Standard-Coosa-Thatcher Company, a textile concern based here, said it had reached agreement in principle to be acquired by a group of company executives for $28 million - $1.5 million more than the group offered last month.   The group would team with a New York investment firm, Wolsey & Company, to complete the acquisition.

headline: Your Money; Replacement Cost Insurance
abstract: IF you suffer a loss of some or all of the contents of your home because of a fire or theft, will your homeowner's insurance cover the replacement cost?   The answer to that question is ''maybe,'' as is the answer to so many questions involving insurance coverage today. But in this instance, the ''maybe'' can be turned into a ''probably'' by purchasing a special replacement cost policy or rider to your existing policy.   In the standard homeowner's policy, the holder is reimbursed for the current cash value of the property, or cost minus depreciation.  For example, if a television set purchased for $500 three years ago had a current value of only $250, the policyholder would receive only $250 after a loss.

headline: Sugar Futures Decline On Reagan Quota News
abstract: Prices of world sugar futures fell again yesterday as President Reagan agreed to the reimposition of quotas on foreign sugar. While the move had been expected, the lack of details about the quotas endorsed by the President caused wild price swings in the world sugar ring of the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.   For example, the most active delivery, the near July contract, closed down 0.17 cent a pound, at 8.71 cents. Earlier, the price of this pivotal futures contract had swung between 8.75 and 8.35 cents, which was the delivery's life-of-contract low. The previous intraday low, 8.83 cents, was registered last April 22, while the contract high, 26.5 cents, was posted on Feb.4, 1981. Each cent move represents $1,120 per contract of 112,000 pounds of raw, or unrefined, sugar.

headline: LAID-OFF PILOTS SEEK TO RAISE BUSINESS FOR TWO AIRLINES
abstract: Wally Majure strode with determination up to the little glass window. ''Hello, I'm Wally Majure,'' he told a woman behind the sevice desk at American Management Associations, a business education group in midtown Manhattan. ''I'm a pilot with Western Airlines, and I'd like to talk to someone who handles your travel.''   ''Have you ever heard of Western?'' he asked. ''No I haven't,'' replied Teri Moore, who normally deals mostly with messengers and delivery people. ''But I'll be glad to take your brochures.''

headline: UNION COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hungary Set To Join I.M.F.
abstract: The 145 countries that make up the International Monetary Fund have voted to accept Hungary as a new member in their organization, an I.M.F. spokesman said today.   Hungary will join the international lending authority 10 years after Rumania, the only other member from the Eastern European bloc, Monetary sources said Hungary's application for membership, submitted last November, had been approved by a wide margin, with the United States lending its support.

headline: PATENTS; Delaware Still First On Per Capita Patents
abstract: A summary issued this week by the Patent and Trademark Office shows that, with one patent issued for every 1,787 residents, Delaware continued in 1981 its 47-year reign as the state getting the most patents on a per capita basis.

headline: U.N. LUMINARIES OF PAST AND PRESENT HONOR ROOSEVELT
abstract: With appeals to idealism and a considerable helping of nostalgia, officials and scholars at the United Nations today recalled the role of Franklin Delano Roosevelt in creating the organization more than 40 years ago.   The daylong session of panel discussions and convocations, part of the centennial celebration of Roosevelt's birth, brought together some leaders from the United Nations' earlier days. Madame Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, president of the General Assembly in the 1953-54 session, paid tribute to President Roosevelt's role in forming the organization's charter. Mrs. Pandit, 81 years old, was warmly greeted by the gathering.   Henry Cabot Lodge, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations from 1953 to 1960, said Roosevelt might well emerge as ''the 20th century's outstanding presence.'' He said the President would have understood the pragmatism necessary in the organization's work.

headline: AKZONA APPOINTS PRESIDENT AND CHIEF
abstract: Akzona Inc. says it will name G. John Coli, now president of its American Enka division, as its new president and chief executive officer.   Akzona, of Asheville, N.C., is 66 percent owned by Akzo, the big Dutch chemical company. Akzo earlier this month offered $16.25 a share for the 34 percent of Akzona stock that it does not own.

headline: Pabst Meeting Is Adjourned to April 27
abstract: The annual meeting of the embattled Pabst Brewing Company was adjourned here today until April 27 to allow election inspectors time to tally the vote in a bitter and apparently close proxy battle.   Irwin Jacobs, the leader of a group of dissident shareholders, charged that there were gross voting irregularities and threatened legal action, which could delay the results even longer.   Pabst's management did not assert that it had won, but its lawyers said that Mr. Jacobs was trying to void the election results with his allegations.   Mr. Jacobs, a Minneapolis businessman and investor, led a slate of 11 candidates for the Pabst board that included Fran Tarkenton, the former quarterback of the Minnesota Vikings football team, in an effort to replace the entire board.

headline: Excerpts from speeches, page 18.
abstract: In the birthplace of English Christianity, in the noble Gothic cathedral that Anglicans everywhere consider their mother church, the Bishop of Rome and the Archbishop of Canterbury embraced today.   They came up the aisle together, Pope John Paul II a half step ahead of the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, to a most un-English storm of applause - the Pope in a red cape and stole embroidered in gold, the Archbishop in white, a towering miter on his head and a gold shepherd's crook in his right hand.   They knelt at the altar, simply dressed with a yellow cloth, a cross and two tapers, a few paces from the spot where Thomas Becket was martyred in 1170. The congregation said the Lord's Prayer.

headline: IN CAIRO, ANGUISH AMONG PALESTINIANS
abstract: ''It will be like a disease,'' said Haj Massoud Abdelmagid, a Palestinian merchant. He said the guerrillas ''will become more violent, and they will go all around the world.''   For Mr. Abdelmagid and others among Egypt's prosperous 125,000 Palestinians, the war in Lebanon has stirred anguish, pride and foreboding that a sharp defeat in west Beirut will simply shift guerrilla activity to other battlegrounds.   Egypt's Palestinians have been holding meetings, collecting relief funds for Palestinians in Lebanon, listening to war news on the radio and worrying about the fate of relatives in Beirut.

headline: Braniff, Pan Am Plan Discussions
abstract: Executives from the Braniff International Corporation plan to meet with executives from Pan American World Airways soon to discuss a plan presented by Pan Am to operate some of Braniff's former routes.   Sam Coats, vice president of domestic and international affairs for Braniff, said in a telephone interview that no date had been set for the meeting and that there were still ''hundreds of questions to be answered'' regarding the proposal.

headline: United Slashes Hawaii Fares
abstract: United Airlines said it would slash its oneway coach fare to Hawaii from Los Angeles and San Diego to $119.98 from $310, effective next month.

headline: Iran Diplomat in Soviet Asks The Netherlands for Asylum
abstract: The Second Secretary of the Iranian Embassy in Moscow has requested political asylum in the Netherlands, and the request is being studied, a spokesman for the Dutch Foreign Ministry said today.   The spokesman, Aafke Suringar, said the diplomat arrived in the Netherlands several days ago on a visa obtained from the Dutch Embassy in Moscow. Miss Suringar would not name the man seeking asylum.

headline: Commodore Move
abstract: Commodore International introduced three new personal computers, which its chairman, Irving Gould, said would sell for far less than comparable products on the market and would be shipped by September.

headline: TEXAS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Aluminum Co. of America filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $250 million of debt securities and warrants to purchase debt securities, to be underwritten by First Boston Corp.   * Comserv Corp. of Mendota Heights, Minn., said it would offer $20 million of convertible subordinated debentures through Shearson/American Express Inc.   * Exxon Corp. filed with the S.E.C. for the sale of up to 350,000 shares of its capital stock held in its corporate treasury and expects to exchange these shares plus cash for its 6 percent debentures due 1997 and 6 1/2 percent debentures due 1988 that are owned by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber.

headline: FIVE THEORIES ON THE RIGHT MARKET TRACK
abstract: THE financial markets are giving off conflicting signals. A few p eople detect the glimmer of a turnaround in both stocks and bonds, w hile many others see only more of the dreary same. It isn't easy forp eople with nest eggs to worry about to know whether to stay liquid, t o keep their cash in money funds until the economy revives, to buy b onds, enter the stock market, or go back to bed.   Five professionals - a closely followed individual investor, investment advisers at two top-tier Wall Street firms and two leading investment counselors - were asked their choices for investing a hypothetical $100,000, on the assumption that the safety of the nest egg was important.

headline: Car Sales in Japan Up
abstract: Japan's domestic sales of passenger cars, trucks and buses reached a record monthly high in March, totaling 529,950 units, up 6.5 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said today. The association attributed the sharp increase to major passenger car sales campaigns and remodeling. Sales of trucks and buses declined.

headline: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CSR of Australia Completes Loan
abstract: CSR Ltd., an Australian energy concern and sugar producer, said it had completed a borrowing package totaling $950 million (in United States currency) to refinance its previously announced purchase of the Delhi International Oil Company.

headline: Franc Off After Mitterrand Devaluation Comment
abstract: France's battered franc has come under renewed pressure on foreign-exchange markets following President Francois Mitterrand's surprising acknowledgement that he may be forced to devalue the currency for the second time since taking office a year ago.   At a breakfast meeting with American reporters on Friday, Mr.  Mitterrand appeared to accept the possibility of another franc devaluation and hinted that he might also withdraw from Europe's fixed exchange rate monetary system, rather than waste valuable resources trying to peg a declining franc to the strong West German mark and its other five member currencies.   ''All hypotheses are open,'' the President said, adding that he would not ''fall into hell'' if he was forced to devalue again. He complained about ''aggressive'' speculation against the franc and pointedly said that he had ''no religious attachment'' to the European Monetary System, which his predecessor, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, helped found in 1978.

headline: Huffy Assets Sale
abstract: The Huffy Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, said it had sold the assets of its automotive products division to the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation for an undisclosed amount of cash ''substantially in excess'' of the division's book value. Huffy said it had decided to sell the division because it did not have long-term high-growth potential.

headline: WELSH MOUNTAIN HOLDING SECRET AND LAWSUIT
abstract: FFESTINIOG, Wales -Hidden inside a Welsh mountain is a secret that has pitted a soft-spoken Welshman against the British Government.   Owen Glyn Williams, the 36-year-old director of Cwt-Y-Bugail Slate Quarries, is engaged in a legal battle with the Government over rights to a squat and barren mountain named Manod, where British art treasures were stored during World War II.   Although its lease expired 21 months ago, the Property Services Agency, which administers the Government's estate, refuses to budge from the site. A two-man maintenance team continues to guard closely six warehouse-sized chambers deep within Mount Manod.

headline: Filmways Loss Is Expected
abstract: Financially troubled Filmways Inc. disclosed in a proxy statement that it expects to report a ''substantial but still undetermined loss'' for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Feb. 28. In the comparable 1981 period, the company lost $46.4 million and lost $66.3 million in the fiscal year 1981.

headline: TREASURY BILL YIELDS JUMP AT AUCTION
abstract: The Treasury auctioned three- and six-month bills yesterday at sharply higher yields compared with last week's auction.  The average rate on the three-month bills jumped to 13.269 percent from 12.588 a week earlier, while the companion six-month bill rose to 13.419 percent from 13.031.   The rise in bill yields, which was not unexpected because of the pressures resulting from huge Treasury financings scheduled for this week, brought the average rate on the new 90-day bills to the highest level since last March 29, when the average was 13.339 percent. The average six-month yield was the highest since last Feb.16, when it was 14.360 percent.

headline: URUGUAY OUSTS U.S. EMBASSY'S POLITICAL AIDE
abstract: The State Department said today that the chief of the political section of the American Embassy in Montevideo had been declared persona non grata by the Uruguayan Government, accused of ''interfering with internal Uruguayan matters.''   No details of the purported interference were immediately available, either from the military regime in Montevideo or from the State Department, although there were indications among Reagan Administration officials that the ouster was related to Britain's war with Argentina over the Falkland Islands.

headline: MIRRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; A Wine That Pops Its Cork
abstract: Last night marked the debut on the home screens in the New York area of Champs D'ore, a new French sparkling white wine that has a cork cork (as opposed to a plastic cork) that pops like champagne.   Of course it isn't a champagne because it's from Alsace, not the Champagne region. But, what's in a name if it sells for about $5.50?  Behind the brand is Frank S. Berger, 45-year-old one-time president of the House of Seagram, who resigned in 1979 with his eye toward putting together his own conglomerate.   First there was Quadrillon Investments, which was followed by the purchase of Toiletry Products of America, maker of the Hazel Bishop line of cosmetics.

headline: India Lowers Oil Goal
abstract: India has lowered its oil output target for the year ending March 31, 1983, by 2 million tons, to about 18 million tons, a spokesman for the Oil and Natural Gas Commission said here today. The new target is the equivalent of 360,000 barrels a day, down slightly from last year's estimated production of 360,000 barrels a day.

headline: Massey Shutdown
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. has said that it will extend by two weeks its normal August inventory and vacation shutdown at its plants in Toronto and Brantford, Ontario. About 2,650 workers will be affected by the closing, which will last from July 19 to Sept. 7. The company attributed the extension to deteriorating sales of combine harvesters.

headline: Alcan Halts Potline
abstract: Alcan Aluminum Ltd. said that its Australian unit had deferred commissioning a third potline at its Kurri Kurri aluminum smelter in New South Wales because of continuing poor demand for aluminum worldwide. The $155 million facility would have started production at the end of this year or early in 1983, increasing the smelter's rated capacity to 135,000 tons from 90,000. Alcan Australia is 70 percent owned by Alcan, which is based in Montreal.

headline: Around the World; 2 Hostages in Honduras Released to Papal Aide
abstract: The Vatican representative negotiating with four hijackers holding 27 hostages boarded the plane twice today and brought off two of the hostages, whom the authorities identified as Hondurans.   Msgr.

headline: Ogilvy & Mather Unit Gets Chemlawn Billing
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather Direct Response, the Ogilvy & Mather International subsidiary with 25 offices worldwide, has just landed the account of the Chemlawn Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, whose $9 million in current billings makes it the biggest account ever landed by the five-year-old agency.   The client, whose previous advertising was done by Stone & Adler, is a lawn-care service organization with some 3,000 employees working out of 150 offices in 80 markets.

headline: BEYOND MILLS:MONEY IN THE BANK
abstract: RALEIGH, N.C.  The Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, although best known for organizing J.P. Stevens & Company, is much more.  The union also owns the Amalgamated Bank of New York, with about $1.3 billion in assets.

headline: Germans Extend Trade Pact
abstract: The Governments of West and East Germany have agreed to extend a controversial, interest-free credit arrangement used to finance their bilateral trade, according to a West German Cabinet official.   The credit arrangement, known as the ''swing facility,'' is an interest-free overdraft account at Bonn's central bank with which the East Germans finance their exports.

headline: Nucorp Energy Is Sued 4 Times
abstract: Nucorp Energy Inc. confirmed it had been sued four times by vendors for canceling orders for tubular oilfield goods in an attempt to deal with excess inventory.   ''We've been trying to cancel as many of the orders as we could,'' Morris Sievert, vice president, said in an interview.

headline: A PRIMER FOR DOING BUSINESS IN CHINA
abstract: MANY American businessmen will have a ''China card'' to play in the d ecade of the 80's as deputy chairman Deng Xiaoping rapidly expands h is nation's trade relations with the West. Whether that card will bea n ace or a deuce depends on how each company plays the game, as w ell as the state of relations between our two countries.  Having just returned from a one-week business visit to Peking, I remain very optimistic about China-United States business prospects, despite a recent cooling of diplomatic relations over the proposed sale of arms to Taiwan.  After three days of in-depth meetings with representatives of the various ministries, on March 25, in the Great Hall of the People, I signed an agreement for the Occidental Petroleum Corporation with the China National Coal Development Corporation. The accord calls for a feasibility study that it is expected will lead to a joint venture to develop the world's biggest coal mine - the Pingshuo open cut mine in Shanxi Province, which will have production of 12.5 million tons of coal a year in 1986, compared with 20 million tons from Occidental's 27 mines.

headline: HAIG REGRETS INDONESIA'S VETO OF ENVOY
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. issued a statement today regretting that Indonesia had refused to accept one of the Foreign Service's top Asian experts as the next Ambassador to that country.   The statement, read by Dean Fischer, the State Department spokesman, was meant both as a rebuke to the Indonesians for the unusual action in turning down President Reagan's nominee, and as a sign to the Foreign Service that Mr. Haig was not indifferent to the fate of the nominee, Morton I. Abramowitz, whose last post was Ambassador to Thailand.   ''Mort Abramowitz is a truly outstanding Foreign Service officer, who has served with distinction in a variety of responsible and challenging positions,'' Mr. Haig said. ''There has never been any question in the President's mind or my own that he was an excellent choice for the post in Jakarta, and we expressed to the Government of Indonesia our full confidence in him.''

headline: Real Estate; Big Project In Midtown Hits Snags
abstract: FAIRVIEW, the giant Canadian developer, may be backing away from its plan to build a major office tower opposite the Citicorp Center at 53d Street.   Real estate experts say that such a move need not signal a serious erosion of the city's office market, which has been booming in recent years, but that it would be another illustration that office rents have stopped soaring.   At a price of $105 million for the block front on Lexington Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets, real estate and financing analysts note that the building would have to produce rents of $60 a square foot to pay for itself and maybe $70 a square foot to produce a profit. Rents may be that high someday, but many experts doubt it will happen in two or three years, when the Cadillac-Fairview building would be completed.

headline: An Argentine Captive Being Sent to Britain
abstract: The commander of the Argentine garrison on South Georgia island when it was recaptured by British forces is to be brought to Britain.   The commander, Capt. Alfredo Astiz, who is suspected of having led torture operations in Argentina, is being held on Ascension Island.

headline: REPORTS OF ARMED IRANIAN EXILES IN EASTERN TURKEY ARE DISCOUNTED
abstract: Iranian refugees cross daily into Turkey in hopes of getting visas to move on to Western Europe and the United States, but Western intelligence sources here say Iranians have not established any significant paramilitary organization in the country.    These sources discount reports in American and British newspapers that paramilitary forces opposed to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and numbering up to 10,000 men have been using Turkish territory. Turkish officials have also repeatedly denied the reports.   Western intelligence sources say there were about 500 Iranians in Turkey several months ago reportedly trying to form armed opposition units. But these, the intelligence sources say, have been dispersed by the Turkish authorities.

headline: FIRST INTERSTATE BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Shamrock Lifts Its Price for Oil
abstract: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, a diversified chemicals and energy company, has raised its buying price for domestic crude oil by $2 a barrel in a change that it says reflects ''a stabilizing market'' in its purchasing areas.   Diamond Shamrock said Monday that it would pay $32 a barrel, up from $30, for low-sulfur domestic crude purchased from certain fields in Texas, Oklahoma, Wyoming, Montana and North Dakota.

headline: BANGLADESH RULER OFF TO SLOW START
abstract: Despite all efforts to show that the military takeover on March 24 spells a better future for Bangladesh, there is a growing feeling here that the martial-law administration of Lieut. Gen. H.M. Ershad has had a less auspicious first week in power than many predicted.   In particular, according to foreign and Bangladeshi sources, the usual saving graces of military rule - administrative stability, elimination of corruption, forceful economic programs - do not look as if they will automatically follow now that the military has overthrown a constitutionally democratic Government that was by most accounts both corrupt and impotent.   Virtually all analysts agree that the coup had been expected for months and seemed somehow inevitable. In fact, several sources say, the coup's military planners were so careful and, for the first time in this nation's coup-ridden history, so open about their intentions that before finally seizing power they not only pushed publicly for a bigger role in Government but actually made inquiries into the likely reactions to its takeover by all the influential sectors of Bangladeshi society.

headline: BELL'S LEVY ON TIE-INS RISING 50%
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission today allowed the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to increase by about 50 percent its charges for connection with local phone systems. The charges would be levied on A.T.& T.'s competitors for long-distance service, such as MCI Communications.   In its decision, the commission set aside Bell's proposal to double the rates, saying that it needed about five months more to study the plan. The higher connection charges will also increase income for other local phone companies, such as those owned by the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.

headline: BREZHNEV IS REPORTED IN HOSPITAL
abstract: Rumors have spread here that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the 75-year-old Soviet leader, has been hospitalized. A Soviet press spokesman said he had no information on the matter nor was it possible to substantiate the rumors through other sources.   Renewed speculation about Mr. Brezhnev's health began after he completed a visit to Tashkent on Thursday, and the homecoming ceremonies were not shown on television, as they usually are. Before the trip, he had participated in a labor union convention here.

headline: INDIA CHOOSES FRENCH JET OVER A SOVIET PLANE
abstract: The French Defense Ministry announced today that India would buy 40 Mirage fighter-bombers and had taken an option to purchase 110 others.   The deal, which involves the advanced Mirage 2000 model, is worth $850 million so far and promises to reduce India's dependence on Soviet arms, according to French officials.   In a communique, the Defense Ministry described the sale as ''the first step in a program of French-Indian industrial cooperation that will lead to the construction of this French-designed aircraft in India and underscores the determination of the two governments to develop their relations in all areas.''

headline: The U.N. Today; April 19, 1982; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
abstract: Meets at 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M.

headline: CREDITORS ACCEPT ITEL REORGANIZATION
abstract: The Itel Corporation, a computer leasing company that had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with its secured lenders' and unsecured creditors' committees on terms to treat most of its $330 million in secured debt in a proposed plan of reorganization.   Primarily, the agreement provides for changes in the terms of Itel's equipment trust certificates, secured by railroad cars, the company said. Payment terms of the certificates would remain unchanged. The certificates account for more than 80 percent of Itel's secured debt.

headline: ANDERSON GREENWOOD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SPRING TAKES TORONTONIANS BY SURPRISE
abstract: A history professor at the University of Toronto has a private theory on spring in this special North American city.According to him, every year about this time there is one very long night when city crews in silent trucks work their way up and down the many miles of well-kept streets in Canada's largest metropolis, methodically replacing the tall, leafless and barren trees that have stood there so starkly for the last eight months.   The next morning, when the residents of this former Indian winter camp glance out their bedroom windows, they find regiments of bushy green trees billowing in gentle breezes.   The professor has not yet completed his theory to explain why, come September, those same city crews spread tons of dry old leaves on every yard for residents to rake into the street for cruising city bulldozers to remove. But his theory must be correct. Spring doesn't come to Toronto; it erupts here, well after it is entrenched to the south. And a special kind of happy spirit of appreciation seems to infect the place.

headline: POPE SPEAKS ON THE SANCTITY OF MARRIAGE
abstract: Pope John Paul II reminded British Catholics today of the sanctity of marriage and condemned divorce, contraception and abortion.   The Pope told a crowd estimated at more than 200,000 people squeezed into the Knavesmire Racecourse that marriage was an unbreakable alliance and that the future of society rested on family bonds.   While praising positive developments in family life, the Pope, who has taken a firm, conservative line on many social issues, said he ''could not fail to draw attention to the negative phenomena.''   In particular, he cited ''a corruption of the idea and experience of freedom, with consequent self-centeredness in human relations; serious misconceptions regarding the relationship between parents and children; the growing number of divorces; the scourge of abortion; the spread of a contraceptive and antilife mentality.''

headline: NEW YORK PENSION SYSTEM CALLED VULNERABLE TO FRAUD ON DISABILITY
abstract: Inefficiencies and staff shortages have made New York City's largest pension system vulnerable to fraud by workers seeking to retire on tax-free disability pensions, according to the city's Department of Investigation.   Unless changes are made, the city faces the possibility of a ''significant financial loss,'' the department warned in a report released yesterday.   Stanley N. Lupkin, the Investigation Commissioner, said that medical records were too incomplete to verify what the report called ''allegations that numerous bogus accident claims had been successfully processed.''

headline: Funds' Assets At $201 Billion
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $1.06 billion during the week ended Wednesday, to another record high of $201 billion, the Investment Company Institute, the industry trade organization, said yesterday.   The increase for 211 funds, including three new ones, followed a $3.69 billion rise in the prior week, to the previous record of $199.93 billion.

headline: BRITISH OFFICER DESCRIBES 24-HOUR BATTLE FOR ISLAND
abstract: British military officials reported today that South Georgia Island did not come entirely under British control until 10 o'clock this morning after considerable additional fighting during the night.   In a briefing this afternoon, Lieut. Col. Jim Donkin told of a 24-hour military engagement by outnumbered British forces in which the first shot was fired by the Argentine submarine Santa Fe, which was later disabled by British helicopters.   The operation included the landing of reconnaissance parties by helicopter in the mountains, a ''major bombardment'' of the main port, Grytviken, and a further battle in darkness at Leith, 10 miles up the coast.   Colonel Donkin, a member of the staff of the Royal Marines commander, said that 156 Argentine servicemen had been captured, together with the 38 scrap metal dealers whose arrival on South Georgia a month ago led to the present crisis.

headline: MAY ORDERS FOR TOOLS FELL 56.7%
abstract: Orders for new machine tools fell 56.7 percent in May from their level a year earlier, the National Machine Tool Builders Association said yesterday.   The decline indicates that companies are pessimistic about the prospects for an economic recovery in the third quarter, analysts said. Because of the lag before delivery, companies generally order new tools several months before they expect to need them.   ''The month of May was an absolute disaster,'' said Eli S.  Lustgarten, an analyst with Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins Inc.  ''Conditions have not stabilized and most corporations are still in the process of scaling back their capital spending plans.''

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Banknote Diplomacy   By itself, the Administration's decision to suspend official credits to Argentina wasn't much; the sanctions imposed by Britain and the European Community were far harsher. However, the possibility of further actions - a freeze on Argentine assets in the U.S., for example - could induce a speedy end to the Falklands crisis. It seems that in the modern age, banks can do more damage than battleships.   The Argentinian effort is the latest in a series that began in Iran, flowed into Afghanistan and was most recently seen in Poland and Eastern Europe, a region where official pressure on banks to rethink loan polices and portfolios continues.

headline: WHITAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: O.E.C.D. IS GLOOMIER ON GROWTH
abstract: Industrial nations face another year of stagnant economic growth and higher unemployment because of the continuing high interest rates in the United States, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned its 24 member countries.   At a meeting of top economic policy planners here that ended on Friday, the organization's secretariat, which monitors the performance of the industrial economies, said that it had revised downward its earlier growth forecasts as a result of the persistent tight monetary situation in the United States.   The organization reported that it now expected economic growth to average only three-tenths of 1 percent during 1982, down from last December's prediction of 1.25 percent and a recorded growth rate of 1.25 percent by the industrialized nations in 1981.

headline: FIRST OF MICHIGAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A STEEL SCAPEGOAT
abstract: To the Business Editor: As American citizens we do not have to look further than our own State of Hawaii for similar economic and political polices in favor of Japan and Japanese companies. Take it from one who lived there for eight years.

headline: Salvador Rebels Report Downing Army Copter
abstract: Salvadoran guerrillas said today that they had shot down an American helicopter that was carrying the country's Deputy Defense Minister and a senior combat commander.   There was no official confirmation of the report in a broadcast on Venceremos, the rebels' clandestine radio station.

headline: A GLOOMY VIEW FROM VERSAILLES
abstract: ONE goes to a summit for the view. But the view from this year's economic summit at the palace of the Sun King is not particularly inspiring. In fact, it seems somewhat depressing.   Dark clouds from the current recession - the second in three years - hang over Western Europe, North America and even Japan, and official policies seem incapable of blowing them away.   The jobless rolls in Western Europe have climbed above 10 million, two million more than a year ago. In the United States, the unemployed exceed 10 million, also two million more than last year at this time.

headline: An All-Ad Catalogue Of the Catalogues
abstract: American Theatre Press, publishers of Playbill, is moving into a quite different type of publication in a joint venture with the Print Project.   The Print Project, which has already brought out three mail-order buying guides that have been selling from 20,000 to 40,000 copies at $12.95 each in bookstores, will supply a lot of expertise for the new ''Mail Order Buying Guide.''

headline: FINAL CHAPTER WRITTEN IN SAGA OF WESTGATE
abstract: C. Arnholt Smith's financial empire has officially disappeared.  With the filing of final liquidation papers in a Nevada court on Tuesday, the ill-starred Westgate-California Corporation, which had struggled along for eight years under Chapter 10 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, vanished from corporate rosters.   Checks were mailed Monday to some 6,000 persons who held the two million outstanding shares of the company, in keeping with a previously announced plan to distribute the nearly $62.5 million in assets. Shareholders were paid at a rate of $28.25 a share, more than some had originally paid for their stock.

headline: REPAYMENT BY POLAND POSTPONED
abstract: Poland and the Western banks to which it owes money signed an agreement in Frankfurt today to delay repayment of $2.4 billion that Poland failed to pay the banks last year. Thus ended a months-long financial tug of war.   The agreement promises to save Poland from default and afford it an economic breathing space, but it is also thought likely to open a more difficult chapter in the country's financial ties with the West.    The signing clears the way for talks on rescheduling the repayments that Poland is due to make this year, but the declaration of martial law in Poland in December has made it likely that the banks will await directions from their governments before reaching an accord on this debt.

headline: FRIDAY, MAY 7, 1982; Markets
abstract: Prices advanced and yields dropped on both short- and long-term Treasury securities. The trading was the most buoyant in weeks as investors, perceiving yields topping out, rushed to buy. At the close, three-month Treasury bills were quoted at yields of 12.32 percent, down 30 basis points on the day. (Page D1.)   A computerized trading link of seven major stock exchanges and brokerage houses that make markets in stocks was approved by the S.E.C. The experimental system, to begin May 17, is a major step toward the national market system ordered by Congress in 1975. (D1.)

headline: Conagra's Option For Peavey Stake
abstract: Conagra Inc., the Omaha-based food processing company that last week said it would merge one of its subsidiaries with the Peavey Company, another food processor, said it had aquired the option to buy 18.5 percent, or 1,084,000 shares, of Peavey's common stock.

headline: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KOWTOWING AND THE ELDERLY
abstract: To the Business Editor I wish it were possible for Mr. Penner, Resident Scholar at the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research, to be forced to come down from his ivory tower of contempt for the poor and struggling, and join the ranks of those who have toiled all their lives, without respite, with little savings, with little hope, with great fear, with aching bodies and weary minds.

headline: STOCKS POST MODERATE GAINS
abstract: The stock market posted a moderate advance yesterday in active trading.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the session, closed up 2.86 points, to 843.42.  Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered stocks that declined by 841 to 598.

headline: Bolivia Sets Elections in 1983 For a Constituent Assembly
abstract: President Celso Torrelio announced today that elections for a constituent assembly would be held in the first half of 1983.   In a television broadcast, he said the military Government would eventually lift a ban on political parties so that they could take part in the elections.   Political parties were banned when the democratic caretaker Government of Lydia Gueiler was ousted by a military coup.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: U.S. IS GOING AHEAD WITH TAIWAN SALE
abstract: The Reagan Administration announced today that it was going ahead with the sale of $60 million in military spare parts to Taiwan despite Peking's warnings that this could lead to a "retrogression" in Chinese-American relations.   There was considerable uncertainty within the Administration on what Peking would do about the development, which has been pending for several months as Peking and Washington discussed but did not resolve the question of American military sales to Taiwan.   "We have some experts who believe that china may grumble but in the end do nothing to set back relations," one Administration official said. "But there are others who say that they would not be surprised if China degraded relations by pulling back ambassadors."

headline: Advertising; Conde Nast Goes After 'Good Life'
abstract: NOW that we've thoroughly digested the news that Vanity Fair is coming back, Conde Nast Publications has another surprise from the wonderful world of magazines. It is changing its 81-year-old House & Garden magazine from moderate mass to extreme class with the January issue.   William F. Bondlow Jr., publisher, said Friday that the cover price - on a cover, by the way, that will have a new logo on stock that is going from 70-pound to 100-pound - will soar to $4 from $1.50. And efforts are already under way to trim the 1.1 million circulation to about 550,000 to 650,000.

headline: Pittston Controls Burlington Unit
abstract: The Pittston Company, a diversified Connecticut-based coal producer, said it had completed the aquisition of Burlington Northern Airfreight Inc., a unit of Burlington Northern Railroad, for $177 million.

headline: BAD APPLES
abstract: ''We're a victim of our own success,'' said Stan Devaughn, a spokesman for Apple Computer Inc. The victimization of the company that has sold more than 450,000 Apple II personal computers since the model was introduced in 1977, and captured almost a quarter of the bustling home computer market lies in counterfeiting. A handful of Apple II knock-offs has popped up in Asia.   The sad fact first surfaced with rumors reaching employees of an Apple test facility in Singapore, according to Mr. Devaughn. That prompted Apple, the largest seller of personal computers in the United States, to investigate.

headline: Nissan to Introduce New Economy Car
abstract: The Nissan Motor Corporation displayed a new front-wheel-drive small car called the Sentra that is estimated to get 43 miles a gallon in city driving and 58 miles a gallon on the highway.   The Environmental Protection Agency's rating gives the Sentra the highest mileage among gasoline-powered cars, according to Nissan, which also makes Datsun cars.   Nissan's new model will go on sale in the United States later this month with a base price of $4,949, or $150 more than the Datsun 210 model it replaces, C.P. King, vice president and general manager of Nissan U.S.A., said in Los Angeles.

headline: Taiwan Arms Sales Plan Going to Congress Soon
abstract: The Reagan Administration will soon give Congress notification of a proposed $60 million sale of military spare parts to Taiwan, a Senate source said today.   The source said the notification, a test of President Reagan's China policy, is expected to be made by midweek.

headline: POLISH ARCHBISHOP CALLS FOR TALKS
abstract: The Roman Catholic Church has appealed for talks to end ''the present political impasse'' in Poland.  A 10-page letter signed by the Polish Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, was sent to Poland's 27 bishops and to the authorities.

headline: SIGNODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Guatemalan Bishops Say 200,000 Have Fled
abstract: Roman Catholic bishops say that political violence in Guatemala has driven at least 200,000 peasants into neighboring Central American countries.   Meanwhile, military authorities today reported 67 deaths around the country in army clashes with guerrillas or attacks by unidentified gunmen on Indian villages in western Guatemala.

headline: Steel's Plight
abstract: To the Business Editor: Your article ''The Year the Bottom Fell Out of Steel'' (June 20), accurately describes the current troubles of the steel industry.  However, there was no mention of a major cause of today's troubles for steel: the strong dollar.

headline: Head of Rohr Sees Role as 'Rebuilder'
abstract: Harry W. Todd is the fifth man in six years to tackle the post of chairman and chief executive of troubled Rohr Industries, a maker of aviation equipment. Profits have been on the rebound, but with cancellations for new aircraft abundant in the foundering airline industry, running Rohr is not expected to become any easier.   ''I see myself as a rehabilitator, a rebuilder,'' he said. ''I want to continue to improve the performance of the company, improve profits and launch our six to eight new programs. We have quite a plateful of work in front of us.''

headline: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Soviet Gives P.L.O. Pledge
abstract: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko pledged today that the Soviet Union would continue to support the struggle of the Palestine Liberation Organization for the creation of a Palestine state.

headline: Roundup of Quarterly Profits and Sales at 271 U.S. Companies; Many Concerns Report A Continuing Fall in Net
abstract: Profits of the nation's major corporations took a giant step backward in the first quarter of 1982 as high interest rates and a depressed economy helped to cause some of the worst earnings declines in years.   A compilation of quarterly earnings of 271 companies by The New York Times shows that 59.8 percent of the companies showed a loss or lower earnings in the latest three months, compared with the first quarter of 1981, while 38.4 percent showed gains.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: With the annulment or suspension of most of the land redistribution effort and with the country controlled by the political right and the army, El Salvador's politics have come almost full circle, to where they were before a coup two and a half years ago. And United States policy appears to be boxed in.   Before the coup, the United States was giving El Salvador no military support and only minimal economic assistance. Now the Reagan Administration is asking for $166.3 million in military assistance and about $250 million in economic aid. Only Israel, India and Egypt get more American assistance.

headline: TEXT OF FALKLAND SPEECH BY PRIME MINISTER THATCHER IN HOUSE OF COMMONS
abstract: Following is the text of a speech in the House of Commons today by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, as made available by her office:   Mr. Speaker, seven weeks ago today, the Argentine Foreign Minister summoned the British Ambassador in Buenos Aires and informed him that the diplomatic channel was now closed.   Later on that same day, President Reagan appealed to President Galtieri not to invade the Falkland Islands. That appeal was rejected.   Ever since 2 April, Argentina has continued to defy the mandatory resolution of the Security Council.  During the past 24 hours, the crisis over the Falkland Islands has moved into a new and even more serious phase.  On Monday of this week our Ambassador to the United Nations handed to the Secretary General our proposals for a peaceful settlement of the dispute. These proposals represented the limit to which the Government believed it was right to go. We made it clear to Senor Perez de Cuellar that we expected the Argentine Government to give us a very rapid response to them.

headline: A JERSEY BUILDER'S STRUGGLE
abstract: Marshall S. Klein is a home builder who tends to wear a suit more often than his work clothes these days.  After all, he does not have much construction to oversee.   ''I can't say we're overwhelmed by what's happening in the field,'' he said wryly. ''What am I going to do? Look at all the buildings I'm not putting up?''

headline: One of the Founders Resigns at Coachmen
abstract: In 1964, three brothers founded Coachmen Industries of Middlebury, Ind., which now is No.2 to Fleetwood in the recreational-vehicles industry. Yesterday, Keith D. Corson, 46, resigned as president for personal reasons, leaving only Thomas H. Corson, chairman and chief executive, to carry on the family name in management.   Thomas Corson assumed the added post as president.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Arizona Public Service Co. said it plans to offer two million shares of a new series of cumulative $25 preferred stock near the end of this week.   * Citicorp said an average rate of 14.147 percent was set at the weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, down from 14.355 percent at last week's auction.

headline: Trudeau Visiting Macedonia
abstract: Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau of Canada, who is on a three-day official visit to Yugoslavia, left today on a sightseeing visit to the Lake Ochrida area in the southern republic of Macedonia.

headline: New York Fund Official Gets Rothschild Post
abstract: Madelon DeVoe Talley has been managing New York State's $16 billion common retirement fund since 1979. Yesterday, Rothschild Inc.  announced that she would be joining the firm as president of its investment management unit July 6.   ''I'll be in charge of money management, planning portfolio strategy, visiting clients, looking at the economy - doing things that most money managers do,'' Mrs. Talley said yesterday.   The unit she will head is called New Court Capital Management Inc.  Robert S. Pirie, who was appointed in April as president and chief executive officer of Rothschild, said that Mrs. Talley's ''proven experience will be an important new professional strength for us in the field of money management, which has always been the core business for Rothschild's in the United States.''

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The Greater Albany Area Chevrolet Dealers Association to Berger, Stone & Ratner.   * Nippon America to Shailer Davidoff Rogers, Fairfield, Conn., for the introduction of Saboten garden tools.

headline: I.B.M. Wins On 3 Appeals
abstract: A United States appeals court in San Francisco has upheld the International Business Machines Corporation in an antitrust suit filed by Forro Precision Inc., a small computer components manufacturer.   The three-judge panel from the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit upheld Federal District Judge Ray McNichols.
