headline: Kennecott Divestiture
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had approved the Kennecott Corporation's proposal to divest itself of its Filter Media division to Midwesco Inc. of Niles, Ill., which designs and builds commercial cooling and ventilation systems. A 1981 F.T.C. order required that Kennecott divest itself of the assets to a commission-approved acquirer, as a result of Kennecott's acquisition of Dorr-Oliver Inc., which is also in the air filter bag market.

headline: BT Mortgage Merger Barred
abstract: BT Mortgage Investors said Friday that its shareholders had not approved the trust's acquisition by Charan Industries by the requisite two-thirds vote.

headline: Volcker Cites Latin Risks
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the recent pace of Western lending to Latin America would have to be cut back.   But he said an abrupt cutoff of loans to Latin America by Western countries would be disastrous and should be avoided at all costs.

headline: G.I.'S IN WEST GERMANY MEET RISING WALL OF BIAS
abstract: The United States Armed Forces Television Network is broadcasting a series of reports this week called ''Off Limits.'' The title is stark, but the programs deal only in passing with discrimination against American soldiers in West Germany, a problem that has become increasingly sensitive in the last few months.   Although the official position at Seventh Army headquarters is that discrimination against ''U.S. personnel is sporadic and unpredictable,'' recent incidents have intensified concern about it.   Over the last two months, the Army has acknowledged that bias against the 200,000 G.I.'s in West Germany is increasing in bars, clubs and discotheques.

headline: Doyle's First Account
abstract: As its first account, week-old Doyle-Heekin has landed Securities Groups, previously with Doremus & Company. The account, formerly billing in the very low six figures, is now expected to bill in the seven figures, according to the new agency. Things always look brighter at an address like 500 Park Avenue.

headline: Around the World; Havana-Miami Air Link Temporarily Reinstated
abstract: More than 2,000 travelers stranded in Havana and Miami because of the Reagan Administration's crackdown on a company operating charter flights between the two cities were today guaranteed passage home.   The Treasury Department agreed to allow American Airway Charters Inc. to continue flying between Havana and Florida through Monday to accommodate the stranded passengers.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: NICARAGUAN LEADER WHO QUIT LAST YEAR DENOUNCES EX-ALLIES
abstract: Breaking nine months of silence, Eden Pastora, one of the most popular leaders of the Nicaraguan revolution, criticized the Sandinists today for the direction they have taken their revolution.   Mr. Pastora charged in a news conference here that the Sandinists have adopted a policy that omits ''political pluralism, the practice of free elections and respect for individual rights.''

headline: Beatrice Adding Coke Bottlers
abstract: The Beatrice Foods Company said it is spending $125 million to buy Coca-Cola bottling companies in California and to start bottling operations in Venezuela. The company said that the new businesses were expected to increase the company's beverage sales 70 percent this year from $705 million in the year ended Feb. 28.

headline: DOCTORS MEET IN ENGLAND ON EFFECTS OF NUCLEAR WAR
abstract: An international convention of doctors concerned about the effects of nuclear war began a five-day meeting here today with a series of graphic accounts of the devastating power of atomic weapons.   A Soviet scientist, Leonid A. Ilyin, told the group of nearly 200 participants and observers that a ''comparatively restrained'' nuclear war in Europe would kill about 170 million people.   Dr. Ilyin, the director of the Soviet Health Ministry's Institute of Biophysics, estimated that about 100 million would be killed outright and 68 million would die from radiation. A further 150 million would be seriously hurt, he said.

headline: Bid to Cut Israel Ties Rejected by Egyptian
abstract: Egypt's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Boutros Ghali, has rejected suggestions that Egypt sever diplomatic relations with Israel because of its invasion of Lebanon.

headline: EUROPEANS WEIGH SANCTIONS FOR ISRAELIS
abstract: The foreign ministers of the Common Market worked today on what is expected to be a major Middle East declaration that might include a call for economic sanctions against Israel because of its invasion of Lebanon.   At the same time, diplomats attending the meeting disclosed that Israel had severely rebuffed the Europeans' attempt to gain assurances about Israel's political and military intentions in Lebanon.   On the second day of their three-day meeting here the Foreign Ministers discussed several European issues, including aspects of Portugal's future entry. The 10 members, except Britain, also agreed to lift as of Wednesday the trade sanctions imposed against Argentina after its troops occupied the Falkland Islands in April.

headline: A SYRIAN CITY AMID RUBBLE OF REBELLION
abstract: Hama is a broken city.  In the first three weeks of February, Syrian armed forces and local Moslem rebels fought building to building in the alleyways, mosques and covered bazaars of this western city of 180,000 people, the traditional center of religious opposition to the secular Government of President Hafez al-Assad.   At the time, the Syrian Government played down the events as a relatively small-scale police operation. The uprising was described in more ominous terms by diplomats in Damascus and by the insurgents here, but it was difficult to establish with certainty what had taken place as long as the Government kept this city sealed off.   In the last few weeks, however, the authorities have reopened Hama, 115 miles north of Damascus, to foreign journalists, and the picture that emerges, that of a city half damaged or destroyed, is chilling.

headline: Harvester Sells Holding in Mine
abstract: The International Harvester Company, the troubled manufacturer of farm machinery and construction equipment, said it had sold its 15 percent interest in the Empire iron ore mining partnership in Michigan's Upper Peninsula to one of its partners, the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Ore Company of Cleveland.   In a separate transaction, Cleveland-Cliffs acquired the McLouth Steel Company's 25 percent interest in the partnership at a public auction in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Detroit.

headline: ARGENTINA APPEALS FOR THIRD WORLD SUPPORT
abstract: Argentina appealed ''with true passion'' today for third world support in the Falkland crisis. It accused Britain and the United States of planning to convert the islands into a military base as part of a new South Atlantic alliance.   Addressing a conference of nations professing nonalignment, Argentina's Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, said the United States and Britain planned to join South Africa in an alliance that would threaten the independence of much of Latin America and Africa.   ''This mention of military bases is not a rhetorical trick,'' he warned. ''The United Kingdom has made statements which have not been denied. The Prime Minister and Foreign Secretary have made their intentions perfectly clear.''

headline: Market Place; Beneficiary Of an Upturn
abstract: ANALYSTS seem to be differing widely these days on the state of the economy and when it will turn upward. But once the upturn gets into full swing, one of the beneficiaries is expected to be the Parker-Hannifin Corporation of Cleveland, an industrial giant with $1 billion in annual sales, 21,000 employees, 131 plants and 100,000 products for 300 industries.   One of the nation's leading producers of parts for hydraulic and pneumatic power systems, Parker-Hannifin makes thousands of such items as hoses, fittings, valves and cylinders. Its vast array of components go into cars, planes, farm implements, robots, space vehicles, machine tools and air-conditioners.

headline: Zimbabwe to Enlist Ex-Rebels to Keep Order
abstract: The Zimbabwe Government announced today that it was calling up former guerrillas to combat mounting violence in the country.   It declared that as many of the former guerrillas as possible would be drafted into a special police paramilitary force and said a people's militia would be formed to give paramilitary training to civilians throughout the country.

headline: CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CAIRO AFFIRMS VOW ON PEACE PROCESS
abstract: President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East met today with President Hosni Mubarak and said the Egyptian leader had affirmed that the Camp David accords were ''the only existing basis'' for peace in the Middle East.   The remarks by Deputy Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel Jr.  were made after he met with Mr. Mubarak for more than an hour. Mr.Stoessel later left for Israel for talks with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and other Israeli leaders.   Egyptian Foreign Ministry officials said that the Mubarak Government had rebuffed an Israeli request for a written reassurance of Egypt's commitment to the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty before Israel's scheduled final withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula next Sunday.   According to the officials, the Egyptians feel that such a reassurance would be superfluous because of the terms of the peace treaty Egypt and Israel signed in 1979.

headline: KOWTOWING AND THE ELDERLY
abstract: To the Business Editor: Regarding Mr. Penner's article, Social Security is not a system for redistribution of wealth. It is a pension plan to which working people have been compelled to contribute, comforted only by the promise that, when they grow old, this money - their own money - will be given back to them.

headline: A STEEL COMPANY FIGHTS FOR ITS LIFE
abstract: LAST Monday evening, hundreds of steelworkers and members of their families boarded a fleet of buses in the industrial ''downriver'' area here. All night they rode, more than 600 miles, to Washington.  There, they demonstrated loudly at the Capitol and the White House, demanding Federal aid for the bankrupt McLouth Steel Corporation.   McLouth is a major casualty of the recession, a stubborn downturn that has plagued the Middle West and its key industries - steel and automobiles - for almost three years. In early December, the company filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code, listing debts of more than $300 million.   Since then an increasing number of large companies have found themselves in similar predicaments. By the beginning of April more than 6,200 companies had failed, almost as many as in all of 1978.  Some big names are among the casualties, including AM International, Saxon Industries and the Wickes Companies. Outstanding debt at Wickes alone totaled $2 billion.

headline: Javelin Actions Taken
abstract: A Quebec Superior Court judge today suspended the board of directors of Javelin International Ltd. and named a Montreal lawyer as receiver-manager to supervise the natural resources exploration and development organization for two years.

headline: CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Alfa Resources Inc. said it had incorporated a wholly owned subsidiary, Granite Alpha Corp. for the primary purpose of raising drilling funds through the sale of limited partnership interests.   * Arkansas Best Corp. signed an agreement for its subsidiary, A.B.F. Freight System Inc., to acquire East Texas Motor Freight Lines Inc., a unit of Bright Industries, a company based in Dallas.   * Bayuk Cigars Inc. said it had sold its Phillies brands and related assets other than accounts receivable to Phillies Cigar Co., a subsidiary of Havatampa Inc., for about $5 million.

headline: West German Outlook
abstract: West Germany's five leading economic research institutes, in a gloomy report on the country's economy, warned today that unemployment could stay high for years as economic growth was likely to remain weak. The joint study dismissed the Government's $5.4 billion job-creation program as ill suited and not long enough to have much impact. The study predicted economic growth at a rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in 1982, after a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in 1981, but a decline in unemployment to rise further, to an average 1.8 million, or 7.5 percent of the labor force, from 1.3 million in 1981.

headline: Steelmet Plant
abstract: Steelmet Inc. of Pittsburgh, a leading processor of scrap metal, said it was negotiating the sale of its Ostend Street plant in Baltimore to two officers, Arnold I. Plant, senior vice president, and Morton B. Plant, a director, who resigned effective immediately.  Alan Amper, chairman and chief executive officer, said he hoped the sale would be closed in 30 days but he would not disclose any details until then. Steelmet has two other processing plants in Baltimore and facilities in other states and in Europe.

headline: NORTHWEST BANKCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IN IRAN'S WAR, YOUTH AND ISLAM
abstract: A curious military force of professional soldiers, mullahs, neighborhood militiamen and schoolboys as young as 13, linked by an intense Islamic fervor, broke the long deadlock in the Persian Gulf war by routing entrenched Iraqi troops.   The tanks that have dug into new positions are marked by battle flags - solid green for Islam, red for martyrdom, lettered with verses from the Koran.   Everything stops for midday prayers as a lean, fiery-eyed, young mullah leads staff officers in their devotions in a tent near a headquarters dugout. And, universally, the fighters describe their motivation in theological terms.

headline: Around the World; Reagan-Brezhnev Talks Termed 'Highly Possible'
abstract: A meeting between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev is ''highly possible, even probable'' in 1982, though no arrangements have been made, Edwin Meese 3d, the President's counselor, said today.

headline: VOEST-ALPINE PLANS PRODUCT EXPANSION
abstract: Voest-Alpine, the state-owned steelmaker that is Austria's biggest corporation, has traditionally depended for growth on the country's strong technical base, low inflation rate and labor peace. Methodically, it exploited these central European strengths to haul energy and raw materials from Eastern Europe, and to ship its products and skills around the world.   Then came the oil shocks of 1973-74, and Voest began to look beyond steel for lines of business that could help it withstand recession and soaring energy costs.   In 1980, as overcapacity and collapsing prices sparked Europe's worst postwar steel crisis, the company also began to have second thoughts about its ties to Eastern Europe, which in good years accounted for 30 percent of sales. The doubts began to emerge as a series of financial problems shook Poland and Rumania, two of Voest's best customers.

headline: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Other Business; MONOPOLY GOES ELECTRONIC
abstract: In the age of Pac-Man, it had to happen. Monopoly is going electronic.  Parker Brothers, which has sold more than 80 million Monopoly games since 1934, has come out with an electronic accessory intended to speed up and jazz up the slow but stately real estate board game by adding blinking lights, music and new elements of strategy.

headline: EASIER STATE RULES ON INSURERS URGED
abstract: A special panel appointed by Governor Carey to study the insurance industry today recommended a sweeping program of deregulation that would substantially ease restrictions on how insurance companies can invest their money.   It also recommended lifting most price regulations, but aides to the Governor said that he almost certainly would not endorse those proposals. He is, however, likely to propose the expansion of investment opportunities, the aides said.

headline: A Move to Y.& R.
abstract: Michael Slosberg, 48-year-old president and chief operating officer of Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, is moving beneath the Young & Rubicam umbrella to become executive vice president and creative director of Marsteller, a slot that has been open for a year.

headline: Macmillan's Schools To Della Femina
abstract: Be nice to everyone on the client side. You never know where they will turn up next.

headline: Vice President Named At Atlantic Magazine
abstract: David Auchincloss, publisher since March of The Atlantic magazine, confirmed yesterday that he was bringing in Carol A. Decker as vice president, associate publisher-advertising, from Reader's Digest.

headline: VENERABLE 'LTD.' LIMITED IN BRITAIN
abstract: Because of an obscure Common Market regulation, nearly all of Britain's largest and most venerable companies are being forced to drop the unmistakably British ''Ltd.'' from the end of their corporate names.   Such companies as British Petroleum, Unilever and the National Westminster Bank will henceforth end their official designations with ''PLC,'' a not entirely elegant abbreviation of public limited company.   The change arose from the Common Market's Second Directive, adopted in 1976, which set uniform definitions for limited liability companies. Among the requirements was that public and private limited companies be distinguished in name, something that only Britain, among the major Common Market members, did not do. West Germany, for example, uses A.G. (stock company) for publicly traded companies and G.m.b.H. (company with limited liability) for privately held or subsidiary companies.

headline: Economic Scene; Crises Feeding On Each Other
abstract: THE fighting between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands is the latest example of the ways economic and political instability play off each other and intensify each other. The Argentine attack on the Falklands itself largely stemmed from economic troubles.   The effort of the Government of Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri to bring inflation, running at more than 100 percent, under control by tightening the growth of the money supply, devaluing the peso and liberalizing imports resulted in growing unemployment, falling real wages and reduced living standards for the working class.   Demonstrators had taken to the streets against the Government in the week before Argentina seized the Falklands. It is hard to believe that the Government did not undertake the invasion as a means of distracting the people and unifying them against a common ''enemy,'' Britain. Strong Argentine nationalism was there to be exploited.

headline: Blocker Properties
abstract: The Blocker Energy Corporation said its directors had authorized management to pursue the sale of substantially all its oil and gas properties, now carried on the books at $50 million but with a fair market value of $29 million.  Thus it expects a charge of about $21 million in the second quarter.

headline: DELOREAN PLANT MAY CLOSE MONDAY
abstract: Receivers for the DeLorean Motor Company's sole manufacturing unit in Belfast, Northern Ireland, said yesterday morning that they would close the plant next Monday, suspending production and laying off most of the 1,500 employees.   Hours later, however, John Z. DeLorean, president of the sports car company, announced that he had signed an agreement with a team of two backers who would provide a $37 million investment that could keep the plant open, though with a sharply curtailed staff. He declined to identify the backers but described them as ''an individual and a bank.''

headline: Economy Slow, France Reports
abstract: French business activity weakened in the first three months of 1982, according to recently released figures, dealing a blow to President Francois Mitterrand's plans to revitalize the economy.

headline: 2 ARGENTINE JETS DOWNED IN ATTACK OFF THE FALKLANDS
abstract: Two Argentine A-4 Skyhawk attack planes were shot down today when they attacked a Royal Navy warship off the Falkland Islands, the Ministry of Defense announced tonight.   The ship was not identified in the initial ministry statement, but it appeared to have been one of Britain's new frigates, either the Brilliant or the Broadsword, both of which were commissioned in the last three years. They are usually assigned to provide antiaircraft protection to the aircraft carriers Hermes and Invincible in the British battle fleet.   Unofficial reports said the American-made Argentine jets were brought down in dense fog and cloud by new shipborne Sea Wolf missiles 20 or 30 miles west of the Falklands. The Sea Wolf had never before been fired in anger. It was said that the jets had been acting as escorts to transport planes trying to run the British blockade.

headline: LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Possible DeLorean Backer Withdraws
abstract: Peter Kalikow, the New York investor who had offered to invest $35 million in the DeLorean Motor Company, withdrew his offer. But John Z. DeLorean, president of the car maker, said immediately afterward that Mr. Kalikow had never been a ''prime candidate'' for financing and that a similar investment was being lined up with a new backer.

headline: Toyota's Edge
abstract: To the Business Editor: Regarding your article on Toyota, ''The Company That Stopped Detroit'' (March 21), I submit that even if Detroit can overcome the labor ($500) and manufacturing ($1,500) disadvantage per car you quote, it will still be unable to compete against Japan.   Why? Because no one running a car company in the United States seems to care about giving the consumer his money's worth.

headline: JAPANESE TRUCKS IN NEUTRAL
abstract: Although the dismal sales figures suggest that Detroit has been singularly unsuccessful in convincing consumers that its new, fuelefficient passenger cars are worth their high sticker prices, recent entries into the lightweight truck market are proving highly popular.   In the midst of another bleak sales year, that news must encourage domestic manufacturers.

headline: VENEZUELA WANTS LAND TALKS WITH GUYANA
abstract: Venezuela will seek talks with Guyana on the two nations' territorial dispute when a 12-year moratorium on the issue expires next month, Venezuela's Ambassador to the United States said today.   The Ambassador, Marcial Perez-Chiriboga, said in an interview that Venezuela preferred to resolve the dispute over 58,000 square miles of Guyana - five-eighths of the country - in direct negotiations between the two Governments rather than through international organizations. Venezuela has been critical of United Nations action in the Falkland Islands crisis.   The Ambassador sought to discount Guyana's fears that Venezuela would use force to back its claim.

headline: POPE BEGINS VISIT TO BRITAIN TODAY
abstract: Pope John Paul II will arrive in London soon after dawn on Friday for a six-day visit to a country utterly preoccupied with war rather than spiritual pursuits.   For British Roman Catholics, the long-planned visit, the first ever by a reigning Pope, is a reward for dogged perseverance during the weeks when it seemed inevitable that the conflict over the Falkland Islands would force cancellation of the trip. For the British Government it is a diplomatic triumph, because cancellation would have been cited by Argentina as ''proof'' that Britain was an aggressor.   As part of the bargaining with the Vatican, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher agreed that neither she nor other members of her Government would meet the Pope during his stay. And he agreed to visit Argentina on June 11 and 12 to show impartiality.

headline: Advertising; Needham Gets Gallo Account
abstract: AT long last, California's little old wine makers have made up their minds. Eight months after Young & Rubicam resigned a major portion of the E.& J. Gallo Winery advertising account, the client has decided to assign its Premium Wines and Andre Champagne to Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, and give a special unnamed assignment to the agency's Los Angeles office.

headline: U.S. STEEL SELLS 50% OF ITS SHIPPING UNIT
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 50 interest in its ocean shipping subsidiary to Federal Pacific Ltd., a Montreal-based shipping company controlled by the Pathy family.   The price of the transaction was not disclosed.

headline: Around the World; Sweden Seals Off Bay After Sub Is Sighted
abstract: The Swedish Navy and Air Force sealed off the Gulf of Bothnia in the northern Baltic Sea today to prevent the escape of an unidentified submarine believed trapped there, a naval spokesman said.   Officers of three separate lighthouses spotted the submarine in Sweden's territorial waters Thursday sailing north toward a 60-footdeep channel at the southern end of the Gulf of Bothnia.

headline: Sierra Leone Voids Some Election Returns
abstract: Authorities threw out election results in 8 of Sierra Leone's 66 constituencies today because of ''serious irregularities'' in voting to elect a new Parliament.

headline: MERCANTILE TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: APPLIED DEVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FALKLAND MISSION: HAIG'S LONG DAYS IN ARGENTINA
abstract: For almost four days, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was doggedly persistent, at times even pleading, in his negotiations here to find a way to avert a war over the Falkland Islands, according to Argentines present.   ''He would tell us, 'Do you know what this means?' '' one recounted. '' 'It means war. Do you know what war means? We have to try to avoid it by all means.' ''

headline: Gasoline Prices Rising
abstract: Gasoline retailers have begun to put prices back up after a steady decline, with rises averaging 0.66 cent a gallon since mid-April, an oil industry analyst, Dan Lundberg, publisher of the Lundberg Letter, reported today. During the April 16-May 7 period the average retail price, including taxes, for all grades of gasoline rose to $1.1849 from $1.1783.

headline: 9 Arrested Off Sinai Coast
abstract: Nine people belonging to a group protesting the planned Israeli withdrawal from Sinai were arrested today when they tried to land on the Sinai coast from a yacht.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: OIL STOCKS HELP DOW CLIMB 9.70
abstract: Energy stocks rallied yesterday to lead the market to its highest level in 12 weeks. Trading was heavy.  The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.70 points, to 853.12. This marked its best closing since 871.10 on Jan. 29. The Dow ended last year at 875.   With bank trust departments, investment counseling firms, insurance companies and other institutional investors stepping up their activity, volume expanded to 64.5 million shares, the largest turnover in a month, from Wednesday's 57.8 million shares. Over all, advances led declines by more than a 2-to-1 ratio.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN EDITORS FIGHT MOVE TO LEGISLATE CONDUCT OF THE PRESS
abstract: South African newspaper editors held emergency talks today about a bill that would force newspapers to submit themselves to a disciplinary body. The editors fear that the Government will rush the measure through Parliament before Friday night's recess.   A spokesman for the opposition Progressive Federal Party said in an interview that the Government had ''double-crossed'' the press by suddenly introducing legislation while talks with newspapers for voluntary regulation were underway.

headline: HARVESTER TO MODIFY DEBT PACT
abstract: The International Harvester Company, the financially troubled manufacturer of farm and construction machinery, said today that it had obtained its lenders' consent to modify a $4.2 billion debt restructuring agreement and thus avoid technical default.   The new agreement would lower Harvester's minimum net worth requirement to $800 million, from $1 billion, and raise its permitted ratio of total liabilities to net worth to 5.2 to 1, from 4 to 1.   The modification was expected because Harvester had disclosed to its 193 lenders earlier this month that it would be in technical default on the compact, which had converted mostly short-term debt into a three-year revolving fund.

headline: American General, NLT Hearing Set
abstract: John C. Neff, state insurance commissioner, says he plans a public hearing June 1 on the American General Corporation's $1 billion takeover attempt of the NLT Corporation.   Directors of the Nashville-based NLT oppose the Texas insurance company's stock swap offer to NLT stockholders.

headline: U.S. Veterans' Group On Its Way to Vietnam
abstract: A group of seven American veterans of the Vietnam War arrived here this morning en route to Hanoi and described its hopes of promoting reconciliation between the United States and Vietnam.   Thomas A. Bird of New York City, the leader of the group, said its members planned to talk with Vietnamese officials about American soldiers still missing in action as well as about possible cooperation between Washington and Hanoi in studying the long-term effects of the defoliant Agent Orange.

headline: North Sea Well
abstract: -The British National Oil Corporation said today that as operator it had completed a successful North Sea oil well. The well flowed at a stabilised rate of 5,100 barrels daily with no water through a one-inch choke.

headline: Times of London Strike Ends
abstract: A strike by electricians that stopped publication of The Times of London for two days ended today when four men who had been dismissed for refusing to do maintenance work were reinstated, the paper's management said.

headline: Advertising; American Heritage to Accept Ads
abstract: SOON after American Heritage magazine went to soft cover in 1978 after 25 years as a hard-cover publication, there appeared within its covers an ad for subscriptions along with a bound-in card. It was the first ad the magazine had ever carried. Some time later, the six-a-year publication began to carry ads for American Heritage catalogue products.   Subscribers may not have realized it at the time, but that was the nose and the ears of the camel of advertising coming into their tents. The publishers were testing the waters for public reaction, and got five negative letters at most.

headline: Little Impact on Economic Outlook Seen; Economic Analysis
abstract: What did the Versailles conference do to end the worst slump of the postwar period? And how did it change the outlook for a decade of stagnation that so many business executives, economists and unemployed workers fear, with high unemployment, high interest rates and sluggish growth?   The short answer seems to be ''Not much.'' Unfortunately, this international economic conference never really came to grips with those questions.   The Versailles summit conference wound up validating a cartoon published in The Times of London just before the conference began: The cartoon showed a mob demanding jobs surrounding the chateau, with a voice from within the palace responding, ''Let them eat monetarism.''

headline: INTERNORTH OFF 8.9%
abstract: The Sperry Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1982 fell 11.5 percent, while revenues edged up 1.9 percent.   Sperry, a major factor in the electronic data-processing industry through its Univac division, said that earnings in the three months ended March 31 dropped to $81.8 million, or $1.92 a share, from $92.4 million, or $2.19 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose to $1.57 billion from $1.54 billion.

headline: BRITAIN AND SPAIN DEFERRING GIBRALTAR SETTLEMENT MOVES
abstract: Spain and Britain agreed today to postpone the opening of the land frontier to Gibraltar and the start of negotiations on the future of the British colony because of the crisis over the Falkland Islands.   A statement issued in Madrid and London said the two nations had decided to put off the moves toward resolving one of Europe's oldest diplomatic quarrels from April 20 until June 25. But the two sides said they remained committed ''to solve all of their differences over Gibraltar.''   Argentina's seizure of the Falklands, a British colonial possession like Gibraltar, has aroused conflicting tides of opinion in the United Kingdom and Spain, and diplomats in London and Madrid quickly concluded that the atmosphere of crisis was not propitious for discussing the eventual decolonization of the Rock.

headline: Protest At Hanover
abstract: Employing the same strategy used in the battle to unionize J.P.  Stevens, more than 200 people supporting the workers striking a Texaco refinery attended the annual meeting of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation yesterday.   They sought unsuccessfully to block the re-election of John F.  McKinley, Texaco's chairman, to the board of directors of Manufacturers Hanover.

headline: SOUTHAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Beverly Enterprises, responding to an announcement by the Justice Department challenging the company's proposed purchase of Mediplex, a Flowood, Miss., nursing-home owner and operator, said that the parties had agreed to a restructured acquisition plan.   * British Columbia Resources Investment Corp. said its B.C. Timber unit had agreed to sell its Kootenay Forest Products lumber mill and its plywood plant at Nelson, British Columbia, to Crestbrook Forest Industries.

headline: Addendum
abstract: Money magazine increasing by 5.3 percent both its advertising rates and circulation base, to one million from 950,000, effective with the July issue.

headline: INVESTING; IN UNCERTAIN TIMES, TRY CONVERTIBLES
abstract: AFRAID of stocks? Leery of bonds? Consider convertibles. They come i n two models - convertible debentures and convertible preferreds.  A nalysts emphasize that not every convertible is an attractive p urchase, but the hybrid securities, with their two-way play, can p rove rewarding.  The debenture bears something less than market rates on equivalent straight bonds, but is convertible into a given number of common shares anytime before the debentures are retired. Conversely, the preferred, also convertible into a given number of common shares, tends to pay, in terms of dividends, somewhat more than the common yields.  In both cases, security is offered in the form of a relatively high yield, while opportunity is there to cash in on a jump in the common stock.

headline: Heinz Deal In Zimbabwe
abstract: Heinz Inc., the United States food-processing concern, is close to giving Zimbabwe's twoyear-old Socialist Government its biggest foreign investment in a joint takeover of a local concern, diplomatic and business sources said today.   The diplomats said the $20 million deal being negotiated would give Heinz 51 percent and the Zimbabwe Government 49 percent of Olivine Industries, a family-owned concern that produces vegetable oils, margarine and related products.

headline: Egypt Offers to Give Asylum To P.L.O. Leaders in Lebanon
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak said today that Egypt was willing to provide asylum for Yasir Arafat and other Palestinian leaders under a plan proposed by Lebanese mediators to end the fighting in their country.   In an interview with the Cable News Network, Mr. Mubarak also said that the Israeli invasion of Lebanon had badly damaged the United States image in the Arab world and that failure to devise a quick solution to the crisis would affect relations between the United States and all Arab countries.

headline: PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELI GENERAL SAYS MISSION IS TO SMASH P.L.O. IN BEIRUT
abstract: Israel's Chief of Staff said today that Israeli troops had trapped guerrilla forces in West Beirut and had as their mission the smashing of the Palestine Liberation Organization's political and military nerve center there.   The Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, said, according to the Israeli Government radio, that the Palestinians had suffered heavy losses in fighting that continued today after a cease-fire with the Palestinians broke down on Sunday night.   The radio said fighting also flared early in the day between Israeli and Syrian forces in the area of the Beirut-Damascus highway near Beirut.   ''The Syrians suffered heavy losses,'' the broadcast said, ''and, when the fighting ended, the Syrian positions in Beirut had collapsed.''

headline: Construction Value Down
abstract: The recession in construction markets deepened in April, with the value of new construction down 16 percent from the month before, according to a company that monitors construction.

headline: BRITAIN CHARTING A COURSE FOR FUTURE OF FALKLANDS AS ITS TROOPS REMAIN POISED TO RETAKE THE CAPITAL
abstract: The British Government has begun to map long-term development plans for the Falkland Islands that would maintain British sovereignty over the islands for the indefinite future, according to officials here.   Meanwhile, British troops remained poised to retake Stanley, the islands' capital. Little news was forthcoming again today from the battlefield, but the assault will occur as soon as weather conditions improve and needed supplies and troops are positioned, probably within the next day or two, according to correspondents on the scene and military sources here.   ''British troops are knocking on the door of Port Stanley,'' said a pooled dispatch received today from the Falklands.

headline: ARMS CURBS URGED ON 2 SUPERPOWERS
abstract: Several industrial and third world nations that are often at odds on major issues joined today in calling for the two superpowers to take the lead in in bringing about world peace and disarmament.   In the first full day of debate at the General Assembly's special session on disarmament, nations as diverse as Sweden, the European Common Market countries, Sierra Leone and Iran repeated the theme that the United States and the Soviet Union were primarily responsible for curbing production of both nuclear and conventional arms.   The most belligerent attack on the superpowers, especially the United States, was by Ali Akbar Velayati, the Foreign Minister of Iran, a nation whose troops are poised for an invasion of Iraq.

headline: Khomeini Son Away From Car When Bullets Hit It in Attack
abstract: The car of Hojatolislam Ahmad Khomeini, the oldest son of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, was hit by bullets in a grenade and machine-gun attack today, but he was not in the car and its driver was unhurt, a spokesman for the Ayatollah's office said by telephone.   The evening newspaper Etelaat said guerrillas of the leftist People's Mujahedeen ambushed the armor-plated Mercedes-Benz on a central Teheran avenue.   Mr. Khomeini, a senior clergyman, has no official post but acts as a link between the Government and his father.

headline: Bonn Invites Reagan To Address Parliament
abstract: President Reagan has been invited to address the West German Parliament when he visits Bonn in June, Government officials said today. If Mr. Reagan accepts, he would be the first American President to speak in the West German legislature.

headline: BEVERLY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A March by 50,000 Basques Protests Separatist Slaying
abstract: About 50,000 Basques marched through central Bilbao Friday night to protest violence by separatist guerrillas, especially the killing Wednesday of the director of a nearby nuclear power plant.   The demonstration, sponsored by virtually all political parties and trade unions in the region, was directed against the military wing of the separatist group E.T.A., which took responsibility for the killing.

headline: Kodak and China In Joint Venture
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had entered into a cooperative agreement with China to assemble slide projectors at a plant in Shanghai.

headline: ANCHOR HOCKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PANDICK PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Key Schlitz Executive Stays After Takeover
abstract: With the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee being tucked under the wing of the Stroh Brewing Company of Detroit in a $500 million transaction, Stroh is moving its top people into key Schlitz posts.   Peter W. Stroh, Stroh's chairman and chief executive officer, will hold the same posts at the Schlitz subsidiary. Roger Fridholm, president and chief operating officer at Stroh, will also hold the same posts at Schlitz. That leaves Frank J. Sellinger of TVcommercial fame the only Schlitz man to remain in top Schlitz management.

headline: OUTSIDE BUENOS AIRES, BITS OF NEWS ADD TO THE RISING TIDE OF PATRIOTISM
abstract: For the people of this quiet town west of the capital, it was just another day in a 149-year-old fight.  Lujan, home of the shrine to Argentina's patron saint, is a place where pilgrims come by droves and news comes by dribbles. While word of the attempted British invasion of the Falklands, known here as the Malvinas, swept through the capital, this afternoon for the people of Lujan - relying largely on the radio - it did not yet seem to exist.   In the capital, where the national newspapers are published, people still gather in front of their bulletin boards to read the latest news.

headline: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Patents; Multiple Sensors for Aircraft
abstract: WASHINGTON A Control system used successfully in the second and third space flights of the space shuttle makes decisions by the ''votes'' of a number of sensors. The apparatus, invented by Hendrik J.C.  Gelderloos, an employee of Honeywell Inc. of St. Petersburg, Fla., was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

headline: Conrail Pares Quarterly Loss
abstract: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said today that it lost $25.7 million in the first quarter, the smallest loss for that period in the railroad's six-year history.   In the comparable 1981 quarter, Conrail lost $65.9 million.

headline: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STANDARD REGISTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RCA Wins Court Case; Over Satellite Service
abstract: A Federal appeals court declined today to block a regulatory order that allows RCA American Communications Inc. to begin taking orders for service on its newest satellite, according to an attorney for the company.   The decision means the company is free to solicit orders from any company willing to pay a record $13 million up front for satellite service through 1989.   Jay E. Ricks, a Washington attorney representing RCA, said the court's decision was relayed to him late today. RCA officials were not immediately available to say what deadline would be set for accepting orders.

headline: FRIDAY, MAY 21, 1982; International
abstract: OPEC oil ministers, meeting in Quito, Ecuador, disagreed over whether their two-month program of production limitations should be continued. The split developed as the officials celebrated the apparent success of the program in stabilizing declining world oil prices by cutting production. (Page D1.)   France is drafting suggestions for changes in Britain's status in the Common Market, Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said. The possible changes, which would be a way out of the decision-making crisis that erupted this week, were not specified, however. (A3.)

headline: JOYFUL CHEERS ATTEND THE ROYAL BIRTH
abstract: A long day of waiting for a royal birth ended tonight. A crowd of about 500 people waving Union Jacks and holding bottles of champagne cheered the arrival of the second-in-line to the throne shortly after 9 P.M., when the word flashed through the crowd that it was a boy.   The news came from a reporter carrying a small walkie-talkie, and it moved through the crowd like a wave and came back in the form of cheers. Within a minute there were ''hip hip hoorays'' followed by a chant of ''We want Charlie!''

headline: MONEY FUNDS: A NEW PLATEAU
abstract: In only a decade, money market mutual funds have captured the fancy, and the savings, of millions of Americans. When the latest figures are announced today, the money funds - more than 165 in all - are expected to pass the $200 billion mark in total assets, up from $10 billion at the end of 1978 and $74 billion at the end of 1980.   As they have mushroomed, the funds have transformed the role of the consumer from one of unwitting subsidizer of business loans and home mortgages into a full-fledged investor with access to the same high market interest rates as the big institutions. While they have not increased the total pool of savings, most economists say, they have clearly altered the flows.   Most notably, the funds pulled deposits away from the nation's thrift institutions, operating under Federal regulation and holding large portfolios of low-interest mortgages. And they encroached on the traditional preserves of commercial banks as well.

headline: MINE SAFETY APPLIANCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DOW UP 0.48 IN WEAK MARKET
abstract: Stock prices finished mostly lower yesterday in the slowest trading since the end of March.  At the final bell, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.48 point, to 836.38, after being off almost 3 points at 3 P.M. Analysts attributed the improvement in the last hour of trading to the news that Bankers Trust had cut its broker loan rate to 14 3/4 percent from 15 1/2 percent. Later, several other banks followed suit.

headline: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dutch Queen Consults With Parties in Crisis
abstract: Queen Beatrix consulted party leaders on the Dutch political crisis today after the collapse Wednesday night of the country's three-party coalition Government.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Dow Up 8.85 in Slow Trading
abstract: Stock prices posted brisk gains yesterday with energy, technology and selected blue chips leading the advance. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.85 points, to 811.93.   Reflecting the continued caution of investors, however, the trading pace remained slow. The turnover of 40.7 million shares compared with Friday's 38.7 million, the lowest volume in nearly five weeks.

headline: MITTERRAND URGES COOPERATIVE EFFORT ON RESEARCH
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France opened the formal working sessions of the conference of the seven leading industrialized nations with an appeal for formal planning and cooperation in managing the revolution brought on by technology.   ''The past bears witness,'' Mr. Mitterrand said in a report submitted to the meeting, that ''the first phase of each of the two previous industrial revolutions in the West was characterized by rising unemployment, protectionism and inflation.''   Mr. Mitterrand presented a series of proposals for establishing common goals and programs in technological research and development.  He also set before the conference participants proposals for insuring that, in the course of development, jobs are being created even while other jobs are being lost.

headline: Beverly Hills Savings
abstract: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association announced yesterday the re-election of its five-member board of directors at its annual shareholders meeting. In early May, the association filed suit charging Severyn Ashkenazy, a Beverly Hills hotel owner, and a group of associates with illegally conspiring to acquire control of Beverly Hills Savings by acquiring its capital stock. The group is also the target of a similar suit by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: SOLIDARITY AND MARTIAL LAW BRING CHURCH AND POLAND'S INTELLECTUALS INTO AN ALLIANCE
abstract: In these days of martial law, when Poles find little to give them cheer, one positive development has been the emergence of an alliance between the Roman Catholic Church and the intelligentsia, according to intellectuals.   Because of the restrictions on political life in the Communist world, the cultural milieu, more than in Western countries, makes up for the absence of an open exchange of political ideas by funneling a measure of unorthodoxy into public life.   From the late 1950's through the mid-60's and again in the 70's, Poland's theater and films treated subjects drawn from real life with a minimum of the smile-even-if-it-hurts optimism that is required by socialist realism, the Communist approach to culture. Music and graphic and plastic arts went their own way and Polish writers, by constantly pushing at the borders of the permissible, carved out for themselves a considerable area of literary freedom.

headline: HUNGARY OFFERS POLES 'BENEFIT OF EXPERIENCE'
abstract: Hungary is trying to help Poland out of its political-economic morass by ''placing our experiences at their disposal,'' according to Jozsef Marjai, the Deputy Prime Minister in the Budapest Government.   Hungary, which has what is widely acknowledged as the most successful of the economies and the most open society in the Soviet bloc, cannot serve as a formal model for Poland, Mr. Marjai, who is visiting Washington, asserted, but can share ''a way of thinking and an approach'' that could help Warsaw.   This was partly the purpose of the talks Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish party and Government chief, had with Hungarian leaders in Budapest last month, he said, adding that even before martial law was imposed last December the Jaruzelski Government had spoken of wanting ''to apply Hungarian solutions'' to Polish problems.   ''We can't contribute financially to Poland, but we place our experiences at their disposal - not specific forms, but a way of thinking and an approach,'' he said in an interview Monday. ''Because everybody must decide specific forms by themselves.''

headline: A.T.&T. IN PACT ON CELLULAR UNITS
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it had reached joint agreements with 19 other telephone companies to develop cellular radio systems.   One of the 19 is Cincinnati Bell, in which A.T.& T. holds a minority interest. Of the other 18 independent telephone companies involved, the largest players included the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, United Telephone System Inc., Continental Telecom Inc. and the Mid-Continent Telephone Corporation.

headline: DUARTE PARTY FIGHTS TO PREVENT RIGHTISTS FROM JOINING FORCES
abstract: With nearly all of the votes from Sunday's election counted, El Salvador's Central Elections Council announced today that the centrist Christian Democratic Party of President Jose Napoleon Duarte appeared to have won 24 of the 60 seats in the new constituent assembly. Leaders of the party moved to deter the five other parties from joining in a conservative coalition that would deprive them of power.   ''There have been some phone calls,'' said Julio Alfredo Samayoa, secretary general of the Christian Democrats. ''We have invited the others to talk, and we are waiting for them to answer. As of now they haven't said anything.''

headline: House Takes Gluten Stand
abstract: The House today passed a resolution urging President Reagan to oppose European efforts to restrict imports of corn gluten, an ingredient in animal feed, with a warning that the issue could start a trade war.

headline: India to Investigate Murders Of Religious Sect Members
abstract: The government of India's West Bengal state decided today to open a judicial inquiry into the killing last week of 17 members of a religious sect.   The Press Trust of India news agency reported that a judicial commission, headed by a high court judge whose name has not been announced, would investigate the deaths of the 17 members of the Ananda Marga sect.   The deaths occurred in Calcutta last Friday when angry crowds in the southern outskirts of the city attacked sect members with spears, knives and iron rods following rumors they had kidnapped children.

headline: Schmidt and Genscher Discuss Cabinet Changes
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt met with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher today to discuss planned Cabinet changes in their increasingly strained coalition Government, officials said.   Mr. Genscher leads the Free Democrats, a junior partner in the Bonn coalition.

headline: K.G.B. CHIEF QUITS FOR HIGHER DUTIES
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov stepped down today as head of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and internal-security organization, two days after being appointed to a senior position in the Communist Party secretariat.   A brief announcement by Tass, the Soviet press agency, said the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, had ''relieved'' Mr. Andropov as chairman of the K.G.B. ''in connection with his assignment to other duties.''   Western analysts here believed that Mr. Andropov's departure from the powerful intelligence bureaucracy after 15 years as its head improved his position as a successor to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader. The analysts had considered it unlikely that he would be allowed to continue as K.G.B. chairman because of the broad powers that would be concentrated in his hands if he did.

headline: END OF TORTURE IN NICARAGUA SEEN
abstract: The torture of prisoners such as has been ''routinely practiced'' in some Latin American countries has been ''effectively eliminated'' in Nicaragua, according to a report on human rights in Nicaragua by the Americas Watch Committee.   The report, issued at a news conference in New York yesterday by the private human rights organization, took issue with a contrary finding on Nicaragua by the Reagan Administration in February. The Watch report, while citing inadequate prison facilities and ''harsh'' interrogation practices in Nicaragua, said the State Department's finding of ''credible reports'' of torture there was ''not substantiated'' by the available evidence.

headline: UNION ADVISERS INVITED TO POLISH TALKS
abstract: Nine advisers and lawyers for the Solidarity union who are not in detention have been invited to join in an officially sponsored conference Friday and Saturday on ''the future of the trade union movement'' in Poland.   The conference is believed to have the backing of several moderate members of the party's Politburo, and is regarded as the first significant move by the authorities to establish some kind of discussion with people close to the suspended union.   The prospect that any kind of an understanding will emerge from the conference, however, is diminished because most of the invited Solidarity experts have decided not to attend. They met as a group and decided that only two or three would participate and that they would attend as individuals, not as representatives of the union.

headline: Control Data Adds Computer Line
abstract: The Control Data Corporation introduced a new family of large-scale computers that it said would offer the widest range of computing power of any system in its history.   Control Data, one of the largest suppliers of computer services, large-scale computer systems and computer peripheral equipment, said that its new Cyber 170 series 800 models would compete with largescale computers produced by the International Business Machines Corporation. At the top of the line, where prices reach about $4.58 million, the Control Data machine competes with I.B.M.'s biggest computer, the model 3081K.

headline: Patents; A Device For Missile Guidance
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation of Detroit received a patent this week for electronic equipment that informs spin-stabilized projectiles and missiles of their vertical orientation so that they can respond properly to guidance signals.  The inventors named in Patent 4,328,938 are Lawrence L. Goldberg and three fellow staff members at the company's Aeronutronic Division in Newport Beach, Calif.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Gulf and Western Industries' Associates Corp. of North America unit filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $300 million of senior debt securities and warrants to purchase such securities.   * Richmond Tank Car Co. said it had entered into a $40 million revolving line of credit with five banks led by Capital Bank in Houston.   * Wm. E. Wright Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a stock offering of 300,000 shares, to be underwritten by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc.

headline: First City Adds Stake
abstract: The First City Financial Corporation, a British Columbia-based company, said yesterday that it had purchased 2.1 million shares, or 8.6 percent, of United States Industries, a New York-based apparel and building products producer, for about $21 million. The shares were purchased from the Clabir Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., for $8.9 million in cash and a promissory note for $12 million. A spokesman for U.S. Industries said the company did not expect that First City Financial would attempt a takeover. U.S. Industries stock, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, closed yesterday at $10, down 12.5 cents a share.

headline: TIMEX PLANS COMPUTER TO RETAIL AT ABOUT $100
abstract: The Timex Computer Corporation, an affiliate of the company that introduced the world's first inexpensive wristwatch, yesterday introduced the first personal computer to retail at around $100.   The Timex Sinclair 1000, with a suggested retail price of $99.95, will go on sale in July and be aimed at the first-time computer customer and the educational market, two areas that have not yet been well tapped, industry analysts said.   The computer is a four-chip design that connects to any television screen, is only 6 by 6 1/2 by 1 1/2 inches, weighs 12 ounces and has its own keyboard. The device is a slightly improved version of one of the world's best-selling personal computers, the Sinclair ZX81.

headline: Around the World; West German Kills 3, Including 2 U.S. Blacks
abstract: A West German political extremist shot and killed a black American soldier, a black American civilian and an Egyptian Thursday night, then took his own life after shouting a Nazi slogan, the police said today.   The authorities said that Werner Oxner, 26 years old, a roofing worker, drew a pistol when asked to pay a cover charge at a discotheque frequented by American soldiers.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE POPE'S REMARKS
abstract: Following are excerpts from remarks in Spanish by Pope John Paul II as he arrived here today, as translated by the Vatican: Special to the New York Times   BUENOS AIRES, June 11 - Following are excerpts from remarks in Spanish by Pope John Paul II as he arrived here today, as translated by the Vatican:   My desire was to come here so as to put into words the feeling I expressed in the personal letter that, at the end of last month, I addressed to you, dear sons and daughters of the Argentine nation, on the eve of my pastoral trip to the churches of England, Scotland and Wales.   Even though during such an apostolic visit - which was intended to be and, in fact, was an endless prayer for the sake of peace as well as of service to the cause of ecumenism and the gospel - my thought and affection have also been with you. My presence here is meant as the visible proof of that love, at such a painful historical moment as the present one is for you.

headline: LEVI STRAUSS DATA GENERAL TUMBLE
abstract: Levi Strauss & Company, the San Francisco-based apparel maker, reported yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1982 fell 46.5 percent, to $18.6 million, or 45 cents a share, from $34.6 million, or 83 cents a share last year. Sales for the period declined by a smaller margin, 10.7 percent, to $612.5 million, from $686.1 million in the second quarter of 1981.   The company said the earnings decline was a result of falling sales in the Womenswear and Youthwear divisions - both down more than 20 percent - and in Latin America. Also a factor was the devaluation of some Latin American currencies. About a third of the company's revenue comes from foreign sales.

headline: Investing; BUYING A PIECE OF A SHOPPING CENTER
abstract: Limited partnerships used to mean oil wells, especially in the days before supply caught up with demand. But there are limited partnerships that invest in other ventures - like shopping centers - and the returns sometimes can be stunning.   One example is a partnership that was syndicated by J.M.B. Realty Inc. of Chicago. Burton Glazov, executive vice president, said that in 1974 its J.M.B. Properties No.2 put $1.46 million into the Manchester Shopping Parkade, Manchester, Conn., and sold units in the partnership for $1,000 each   For six years, the investors received an average, annual cash flow distribution of 9 percent. In 1980, J.M.B. sold the center for $6.35 million. That meant that an investor who put up $5,000 for five units received the 9 percent each year and $21,500 from the sale. ''We do better than that in some cases,'' Mr. Glazov said, ''and we do worse.''

headline: MUSKIE CALLS FOR A U.S. RESOLUTION VOWING TO ABIDE BY '79 ARMS PACT
abstract: Former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie has suggested that Congress pass, and President Reagan sign, a joint resolution by which the United States would promise to abide by the unratified strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979 so long as the Soviet Union does.   Mr. Muskie, who served as a Democratic Senator from Maine before becoming Secretary of State in 1980, made the suggestion in a commencement address at Marquette University in Milwaukee on Saturday.   He described his proposal as a ''compromise'' meant to bridge the period between the present to what Mr. Muskie called ''the laudable goal of major reductions'' that President Reagan proposed on May 9 at Eureka College in Illinois. Mr. Muskie said President Reagan's proposal for strategic arms reduction talks were so far-reaching that they would require ''many years to negotiate.''

headline: 322 Refugees Arrive In Paris From Lebanon
abstract: An Air France jetliner carrying 322 European and American refugees from Lebanon arrived in Paris today.  On board were 44 Americans, 22 Britons and a number of West Germans, Canadians, Spaniards, Italians and French nationals.  The 322, who were evacuated from Lebanon by French military personnel, were taken by a French warship to Cyprus before boarding a special Air France flight for Paris.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM JOHN PAUL'S REMARKS AT AIRPORT AN CATHEDRAL
abstract: Following are excerpts from remarks by Pope John Paul II on his arrival this morning at Gatwick Airport and from the homily he delivered in Westminster Cathedral during a mass. The text was made available by Vatican officials traveling with the Pope. At Gatwick Airport   My visit is taking place a time of tension and anxiety, a time when the attention of the world has been focused on the delicate situation of the conflict in the South Atlantic. During the past weeks there have been attempts at settling the dispute through diplomatic negotiations, but despite the sincere efforts of many the situation has developed into one of armed confrontation. It has claimed numerous lives and has even threatened to expand to still more dreadful proportions.

headline: Pope Bids the Faithful Pray For Him on His Argentine Trip
abstract: Pope John Paul II today asked the faithful to pray for him on his trip to Argentina this week and thanked all those who made possible his trip to Britain last week.   ''I ask for the prayers of all for this important initiative of my ministry,'' the Pope told 60,000 tourists and pilgrims in St.  Peter's Square in a reference to his visit to Argentina.

headline: Around the World
abstract: A firebomb was hurled at an Israeli army patrol in Bethlehem today and two Israeli girls were injured near the West Bank settlement of Kiryat Arba when Arab demonstrators threw rocks at their bus, Israeli military authorities said.

headline: U.N. PRESSES NEED TO SAVE GLOBAL RESOURCES
abstract: The second United Nations Conference on the Global Environment ended today with a call for increased national and international efforts to preserve the earth's basic resources.   A declaration adopted by the 105 nations attending the conference urged ''all nations and peoples of the world to discharge their historical responsibility, collectively and individually, to insure that our small planet is passed over to future generations in a condition which guarantees a life in human dignity for all.''   The conference recommended the creation of an independent commission to prepare strategies for protecting the environment beyond the year 2,000.   It also, for the first time, declared the issues of war and peace to be matters of environmental concern and, in its declaration, said that ''the human environment would greatly benefit from an international atmosphere of peace and security, free from the threats of any war, especially nuclear war, and the waste of intellectual and natural resources on armaments.''

headline: Boeing Antitrust Investigation
abstract: The Boeing Company confirmed reports that it is under antitrust investigation by the Federal Trade Commission, but said that no formal complaint had been issued against it.   The reports stemmed from documents prepared by the F.T.C.'s Seattle office for a House government operations subcommittee.

headline: Trade Official To Resign
abstract: Bill Alberger, chairman of the United States International Trade Commission, today announced his intention to resign effective June 16, opening up a vacancy on the six-member commission during a period of one of its heaviest caseloads.   The agency, successor to the Tariff Commission, acts chiefly as a fact-finder for the Government in what has been a proliferation of cases brought by domestic industry for protection against imports.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET BEGIN TO DISCUSS STRATEGIC ARMS
abstract: Talks between the United States and the Soviet Union on reducing strategic nuclear weapons began today with the American delegation presenting a letter from President Reagan that appealed for a reversal of the trend toward increasingly unstable strategic relations between the two countries.   The letter, presented by the chief American negotiator, Edward L.  Rowny, to the Soviet delegation chief, Viktor P. Karpov, blamed a Soviet missile buildup for the instability, but said the talks were a historic opportunity ''to reverse this process and to reduce substantially both the numbers and the destructive potential of nuclear forces.''   ''As the two leading nuclear powers in the world, the United States and the Soviet Union are trustees for humanity in the great task of ending the menace of nuclear arsenals and transforming them into instruments underwriting peace,'' the President's letter said. Mr.  Reagan said he was confident that with seriousness on the Soviet side, positive results could be achieved. First in 3 Years   The meeting at the Soviet Mission on the Avenue de la Paix was the first on strategic weapons between the two countries in more than three years. The discussions, which basically deal with intercontinental ballistic missiles and long-range bombers, are a complement to Soviet-American talks on European-based intermediaterange missiles, which began here last November.

headline: ARGENTINE UNIONS PROTEST IN CAPITAL
abstract: Several thousand workers from the General Confederation of Labor, an illegal organization, gathered today with left-wing splinter groups in the heart of this city to celebrate May Day. They chanted anti-British slogans and demanded a restoration of democracy.   Though small, the rally, which was not troubled by the police, gave the flavor of long suppressed forces that have increasingly come to the surface of Argentina's political life since the Argentine takeover of the Falkland Islands on April 2. Laying wreaths on a monument dedicated to laborers, the trade unionists observed a minute of silence for a comrade who died in Mendoza after the police had repressed a demonstration on March 30 against economic conditions.

headline: KOWTOWING AND THE ELDERLY
abstract: To The Business Editor: Mr. Penner's fine article illustrates two major flaws in the Social Security debate. Most scholars and politicians alike discuss Social Security retirement benefits while ignoring the rate of return that recipients earn.

headline: TREASURY OFFERINGS SET
abstract: Dominating the new-issue calendar once again, the Treasury this week will sell $17 billion in bills and notes. Moreover, investor reception of these issues promises to set the tone - and yield levels - for the credit market over the next several sessions.   Scheduled for today is the sale of $9 billion in three- and sixmonth bills, instead of the $10 billion typically offered at the weekly auction.

headline: Your Money; Employees Get More Benefits
abstract: AT the Phillips Petroleum Company, every dollar an employee decides to save is matched by a 50-cent company contribution to his thrift plan. Sound good? It gets better. When stockholders meet at the end of April, they are expected to approve a plan that would match employee savings dollar for dollar. In addition, the funds in the thrift plan are not taxed as they accumulate and receive favorable treatment at termination.   The plan is certainly liberal, but not unusual at major oil companies and at other companies where employee benefits are generous. In fact, said Ron Leibig, domestic benefits director at Phillips, the reason benefits are being expanded is to stay competitive with the rest of the oil industry. ''The new plan puts us right up at the top now,'' he said.

headline: Dissident Professor Gets 2 Years in Polish Trial
abstract: A military court here sentenced Prof.  Ryszard Herczynski, a dissident, to two years in jail today for passing information termed harmful to the state to two United States diplomats who were expelled last month.   Professor Herczynski, who is 56 old, was arrested May 9 when the police raided his apartment as he was meeting with the diplomats, J.  Daniel Howard and John Zerolis.

headline: FROM GREECE, A WAVE OF SUPPORT FOR THE PALESTINIANS
abstract: The Greek Government's strong criticism of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon has been bolstered in recent days by a wave of popular support for the Palestinians.   The support has included demonstrations, donations and a strong anti-Israeli position in most of the press and broadcasting. Greeks have also offered to go to Lebanon to fight the Israelis and to adopt homeless Palestinian children.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Oil Data Delayed
abstract: The American Petroleum Institute said yesterday that the Memorial Day holiday had delayed the release of its weekly energy data. The data will appear in tomorrow's editions.

headline: Tosco to Meet
abstract: United States District Judge Robert Takasugi denied a motion by Kenneth Good, a Tosco dissident shareholder, to delay the company's annual meeting here tomorrow.

headline: MOST OF ARGENTINE FLEET IS REPORTED TO LEAVE PORT
abstract: Argentina's only aircraft carrier and most of the rest of its fleet reportedly put out to sea today from a port 800 miles north of the Falkland Islands.   Military spokesmen declined to confirm the ships' departure or to say whether the navy intended to challenge the naval blockade imposed by Britain within 200 miles of the islands, which Argentina seized April 2. The sailing, however, was reported by Telam, the official press agency.   The ruling military junta reiterated tonight that it would take ''measures of self-defense'' within the blockade zone, a statement that it first made a week ago. But it said nothing about any fleet movements, nor did it say what measures might be taken.

headline: Advertising; Pan Am Begins Campaign
abstract: PAN AMERICAN WORLD AIRWAYS yesterday initiated its huge worldwide advertising campaign intended to introduce itself, with its increased services, as the experienced airline and to pull it out of the red and into the black.   The first ads, two-page spreads in newspapers in Pan Am's best eight markets and The Wall Street Journal, disclosed a new theme incorporating the line ''Pan Am. You Can't Beat the Experience,'' with plenty of nostalgia gleaned from the carrier's 55-year history of innovation.   And, gloomy economy notwithstanding, all was optimism yesterday as William H. Waltrip, president of the airline, led an airline team to Wells, Rich, Greene, his agency since January, to be greeted by Mary Wells Lawrence, agency chairman, and a platoon of agency brass.

headline: Chrysler Layoffs
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it would move the production of rear axles for rear-wheel-drive cars and trucks into a plant that produces engines and drive shafts for the vehicles. As a result, some of the 900 hourly and salaried workers at the Detroit axle plant will be laid off, but others will be transferred to the Mound Road plant in Detroit, where the consolidation will occur over the next 15 months, a company spokesman said. Currently, the Mound Road plant produces only engines and drive shafts for rear-wheel-drive vehicles.

headline: CBS Note Offering
abstract: CBS Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $150 million of 10-year notes, to be sold by underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company and Lazard Freres & Company.

headline: QE2 IS TAKEN AS TROOPSHIP BY THE BRITISH
abstract: The Queen Elizabeth 2, one of the world's most elegant and luxurious ocean liners, has been commandeered by the British Navy to take troops to the South Atlantic.   The ship, which has seven cocktail bars, four swimming pools and a casino, among other amenities, will be taken over Tuesday, when she is due to arrive in Southampton from the United States. Military modifications to the vessel will begin immediately, and her schedule of regular crossings and cruises has been suspended.

headline: American Satellite, Tandem Venture
abstract: Tandem Computers Inc., based in California, said it had agreed to work with the American Satellite Company of Maryland to develop and market a computer satellite network that will be available next year.    Under the agreement, Tandem will provide the basic computer hardware for the system and will install and maintain the network, which has been named Infosat.

headline: SPS TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PATENTS; A Method to Select The Sex of Mammals
abstract: A method of controlling the sex of mammalian offspring produced through artificial insemination, both animal and human, was patented this week by Wallace Shrimpton, head of an agricultural consulting firm in San Francisco.  As explained in patent 4,327,177, certain sperm cells contain X chromosomes, which carry female-producing genes, while others contain Y chromosomes, the male-producing kind.

headline: UNIMAX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: People
abstract: * Kenneth H. Lavey named chairman, and Charles A. Rockefeller, executive vice president, of Lavey/Wolf/Swift, a subsidiary of BBDO/Health and Medical Communications.   * John Citron elected a senior vice president of Backer & Spielvogel Inc.

headline: ISRAELIS DISMISS ANOTHER MAYOR IN THE WEST BANK
abstract: Israeli authorities continued their crackdown on Palestinian nationalists today by dismissing a fourth elected mayor on the occupied West Bank.   Mayor Wahid Hamdallah of Anabta, a town about 40 miles north of Jerusalem, was removed from office on the order of the army commander of the central district, Maj. Gen. Uri Orr.   Mr. Hamdallah, who was elected Mayor in 1976, was convicted by a military tribunal on April 25 of two offenses - violating a military order restricting him to his hometown and possessing literature of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine. He had been given a suspended prison sentence and a fine, but it has been clear from the beginning of the case that the authorities wanted him dismissed.

headline: CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IRAN AND IRAQ SAY THEY GAIN IN WAR
abstract: Heavy fighting was reported in the western Iranian province of Khuzistan today, the second day of an offensive by Iran to regain Iraqi-held territory in its oil-producing province at the northern end of the Persian Gulf.   The official Iranian press agency said Iranian troops opened an attack on Iraqi forces west of the town of Susa this morning, capturing a strategic height and 700 Iraqis. Four Iranians were wounded and the Iraqis lost 100 men, the agency said.   The official Iraqi press agency quoted a military spokesman in Baghdad as saying that units of the Iraq Fourth Army in northern Khuzistan had ''completely crushed'' an Iranian attack.

headline: Text of O.A.S. resolution, page A19.
abstract: The United States made an urgent appeal today to Argentina and Britain to accept a new set of American proposals for averting a major military confrontation over the Falkland Islands.   Warning again that ''the crisis has reached a critical point,'' the Reagan Administration said Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  was ready to resume his diplomatic shuttle immediately if that would help bring about a solution.   Although the situation was described as grim, Administration officials said they were encouraged by Mr. Haig's talks this afternoon with the Argentine Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez. Argentines Consider U.S. Plan   The officials said Mr. Costa Mendez came to the State Department to tell Mr. Haig that Argentina had not rejected the latest American proposals and that he expected a formal response to them soon.

headline: COMPASSIONATE PASTOR OF ENGLISH CATHOLICS
abstract: As he waited at Gatwick Airport for Pope John Paul II to arrive on a visit he had fought hard to save from the political difficulties that menaced it, Basil Cardinal Hume was asked by a television reporter, ''And how do you feel personally?''   Cardinal Hume's long, delicate features reflect every nuance of his emotions. For a moment it looked as if he might collapse; it was like asking a mountain climber, l00 feet from the top, if he felt tired. ''All this is for the church,'' he said. ''I can't tell you about my feelings.''

headline: Centronics Offer
abstract: The Centronics Data Computer Corporation said it had signed agreements to sell 4.9 million of its common shares, or 45 percent, to the Control Data Corporation, the NCR Corporation and International Computers Ltd. for $25 million.  Control Data would acquire a 35 percent interest in Centronics, with the other two concerns each taking 4.7 percent.
