Centronics said it would also trade additional stock for the printer business of Computer Peripherals Inc. which is jointly owned by the three other companies and has a book value of $28 million.

headline: COMMENT; LE BUDGET
abstract: AS a ''moderate'' Frenchman, who feels by inclination nearer to M ontesquieu than Rousseau, I came to this country a few months ago r eady to admire the working of the checks and balances that are meantt o be the basis of the American political system. But the budgetary c ivil war gives one pause about the effects of these famous checks a nd balances.  The consequences of the present situation must be obvious to everyone. First, important people are being kept away from other tasks; and this in itself is no trivial matter. That the President of the most powerful country in the world should spend so much time thinking about budgetary tactics is an alarming phenomenon and probably helps to explain what many Europeans see as a lack of clear thinking of basic foreign policy principles.

headline: REAGAN IN EUROPE AVOIDS THE PUBLIC
abstract: In a program about President Reagan's arrival in West Germany, a television station here showed film this afternoon of past visits by Mr. Reagan's predecessors. Presidents Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon and Carter were all seen speaking outdoors, waving from open motorcades and working the crowds.   By contrast, Mr. Reagan is doing in this country what he did in France, Italy and Britain since the beginning of his trip to Europe a week ago: staying entirely out of public eye, and communicating on television.   At times, Mr. Reagan's isolation -dictated by a security-conscious White House - has created an eerie atmosphere surrounding the pomp and ceremony of his travels.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 10, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: PHILIP MORRIS CLIMBS BY 22.9%
abstract: Philip Morris Inc. reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1982 climbed 22.9 percent, while revenues increased 11.2 percent.   The nation's second-largest cigarette producer after R.J. Reynolds Industries said that net income in the latest three months advanced to $167.7 million, or $1.34 a share, from $136.4 million, or $1.09 a share, in the first quarter of 1982. Revenues increased to $2.79 billion from $2.51 billion.   The company said that improved margins for its major operating units accounted for the higher rate of increase in net earnings versus revenues.

headline: Toyota, Nissan Exports
abstract: The Toyota Motor Company said its vehicle exports in May fell 8.9 percent, to 149,900 units, from 164,500 in April and down 4.4 percent from 156,800 a year earlier.

headline: Northern Trust Purchases Seen
abstract: The Northern Trust Corporation, Chicago's fourth-largest bank, said it intends to acquire an undisclosed number of suburban Chicago banks later this year, and is now negotiating with several institutions.   Charles H. Barrow, president of Northern Trust, did not elaborate on the size or number of banks, but said at the bank's annual meeting that acquiring ''a small group of strategically placed banks'' would propel the company toward its expansion goals.   The acquisitions would follow a change in Illinois law, effective Jan. 1, that liberalizes state banking regulations.

headline: BORROWERS HELP KEEP RATES HIGH
abstract: The unusual volume of short-term borrowing by business has helped keep interest rates high, but with the economy in a recession some analysts expect weaker credit demands to help reduce interest rates.   Indeed, that has been the pattern of past business cycles. But many analysts are questioning just how much of a drop in short-term business borrowing - and interest rates - is likely this time.   Without an increase in sales of long-term bonds and notes, it is generally agreed that businesses will continue to rely on shortterm, variable-rate borrowings. It's a vicious cycle, economists say, since too much reliance on short-term borrowing puts upward pressure on money supply growth and short-term interest rates, which in turn helps keep long-term rates high enough to discourage issuance of notes and bonds.

headline: U.S. ENVOY SEES LEBANESE LEADERS AS ISRAEL-P.L.O. FIGHTING SUBSIDES
abstract: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy to the Middle East, held a fourth day of talks with Lebanese political leaders today in an effort to find a political solution to the situation created by the Israeli invasion.   The complex, and inconclusive, round of meetings around Beirut lasted until late into the night. Quiet on the Battlefront   On the battlefront, it was the quietest day since the Israeli invasion began on June 6.  (Israel, reacting to reports from Beirut of a brief artillery duel and a ground clash, said its guns were silent in Lebanon. Page 6.) The Palestinian guerrillas appeared to be using the respite to improve their defenses, erecting dirt ramparts around their refugee camps and laying mines around the perimeters.

headline: U.A. AGENCT ASSERTS SOVIET SOLD $9.6 BILLION IN ARMS IN '79
abstract: The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency said today that the Soviet Union exported $9.6 billion in military equipment to other countries in 1979, as against $5.1 billion in United States deliveries.   Agency officials said the report did not reflect the fact that the Reagan Administration, reversing the policy of President Carter, had stepped up arms sales. But they said that even with the projected increase in United States deliveries in the 1980's, the Soviet Union would remain the world's most active weapons merchant.

headline: A POSTWAR ROLE IN THE FALKLANDS STUDIED AT U.N.
abstract: Persuaded that a cease-fire is almost impossible, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has begun considering the United Nations' role in the Falkland Islands after the Argentine collapse, the Secretary General's aides said today.   Mr. Perez de Cuellar has been exploring what forces might replace British troops in the islands, the nature of a United Nations administration there and the conduct under United Nations auspices of face-to-face talks between Britain and Argentina, they said.   The Secretary General has also been pursuing one last effort to reduce bloodshed and lessen Argentine humiliation in what are regarded here as the final days of the conflict: He has been talking to the British about deliberately slowing their advance on Stanley, the islands' capital. Magnanimity Urged by Haig   That would enable Argentina to evacuate members of the large garrison there with their arms and some measure of honor.

headline: U.S. URGES ISRAELIS TO MAINTAIN TRUCE
abstract: The United States appealed to Israel today to allow time for Philip C. Habib, the special Middle East envoy, to work out a political arrangement in Beirut that would lead to the end of the Palestinian military presence there.   There is growing concern at the highest levels of the Administration, however, that Israel will carry out its threats in the next few days and begin an all-out attack on west Beirut, shattering the four-day-old cease-fire, if an accord acceptable to Israel is not reached by the Lebanese Government and the Palestine Liberation Organization.   The United States appeal came as Common Market leaders, meeting in Brussels, issued a call for a simultaneous withdrawal of Israeli and Palestinian military forces from Beirut. The Western Europeans also repeated a condemnation of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. (Page A12.)

headline: PIPELINE BAN OF U.S. IRKS JAPAN
abstract: Japan, like some Western European nations, is upset by the Reagan Administration's decision last Friday to strengthen the ban on the sale of American oil and gas equipment to the Soviet Union.   The move by the United States threatens the future of a joint Japanese-Soviet petroleum project off the coast of Sakhalin Island, 480 miles north of Japan's northernmost island of Hokkaido. The Sakhalin Island project began in 1974 and the Japanese side has already invested about $200 million in it.

headline: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FIDELITY SAVINGS SUES U.S. AGENCY
abstract: In one of the first lawsuits of its kind against a Government agency, the financially troubled Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco, the 20th-largest such institution in the nation, is seeking $114 million in damages from the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco. This regulatory institution lends money to savings and loan associations.   A.C. Meyer Jr., president of Fidelity, said it was charging in the suit that it was illegally forced to pay ''punitive and discriminatory'' interest rates on money it borrowed and that it was required to pay higher rates than other savings and loan associations paid. Before Fidelity filed the suit last Friday, he said in his statement, it had sought administrative relief from the Federal Home Loan Bank but had been refused.

headline: TWO WHO LED THE PUSH TO BEAT F.T.C. ON CARS
abstract: Frank E. McCarthy, executive vice president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, and H. Thomas Greene, its director of legislation, had a chance to relax after Congress defeated a proposed Federal Trade Commission rule that would have required dealers to disclose major defects and car warranties.   The two had been working for the last year for the defeat of the used-car rule, and the lopsided votes in support of the veto in both the House of Representatives and Senate seem to indicate that their efforts had paid off.   Congress Watch, affiliated with Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, contends that contributions from the group's political action committee of about $750,000 during the 1980 elections and $75,000 in the first four months of 1982 directly affected the Congressional vote.

headline: CBI to Cut Back
abstract: CBI Industries said its Chicago Bridge and Iron Company subsidiary would phase out the manufacturing portion of its operation in Greenville, Pa., this year. About 320 of the 400 employees at Greenville will be affected.

headline: ISRAEL PLANS HALT TO TV BROADCASTS
abstract: A senior Israeli official said tonight that Israel intended to bar the transmission over its broadcasting facilities of television material for American networks gathered by their correspondents based in Beirut.   The three major networks have accused Israel of political censorship for refusing to transmit film obtained in Beirut and elsewhere in Lebanon by crews accredited to that country and to the Palestine Liberation Organization. Syrian soldiers have shut down Beirut's satellite facilities, and the networks' correspondents have been turning over their material to their colleagues based in Israel for transmission from here.   ''They expect us to allow them to cover the fighting from the Israeli side but expect us also to provide coverage from the enemy side,'' said Zeev Chafets, director of the Government Information Office. ''Material by correspondents accredited in Israel is subject to no political censorship but only to censorship for military security reasons.''

headline: Canada Technicians to Stay
abstract: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau rejected opposition demands today that Canada recall its nuclear technicians from Argentina, whose nuclear ambitions have drawn new attention because of the Falkland Islands crisis. Seventy-one Canadian technicians are helping build a Canadian-designed nuclear reactor at a site 120 miles from Buenos Aires.

headline: RULE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEW YORK BANK PROFITS LEAD
abstract: Most of the leading banks in New York reported strong net operating earnings in the first quarter, while earnings remained under pressure at the big California banks, a compilation of the results shows.   Analysts are divided, however, whether the first-quarter results were part of a trend that began in the last quarter of 1981 or whether the stronger earnings in New York and the weaker earnings in California represented a temporary situation.   ''We've probably seen a cyclical high for New York banks,'' said Thomas H. Hanley, vice president and chief bank stock analyst for Salomon Brothers.   But to George M. Salem, vice president of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields & Company, the money center banks' first-quarter results were a good omen.

headline: Careers; Retailing Offers Job Prospects
abstract: For new holders of B.A. and M.B.A. degrees, there is a business offering good jobs that might be overlooked - retailing.  ''It offers a better opportunity than any other industry I can think of,'' Joseph J. Carideo said. He is a principal of Thorndike Deland Associates, the management recruiting firm that has long taken a special interest in retailing.   Furthermore, retail chain personnel departments tend to be willing to consider applicants with almost any college major. Training programs of large department stores often start several times a year, perhaps June, September and January, a convenience for students who need time after graduation to decide on career paths.

headline: KAPLAN'S NEW CHIEF CONFIDENT ON DIAMONDS
abstract: The diamond industry may be in the doldrums right now, but Howard Herzog, 43, voices confidence in its future. Yesterday he was named president and chief executive officer of Lazare Kaplan International. The company, he says, is the only major diamond cutter and polisher that is publicly owned. Its shares are listed on the American Stock Exchange.

headline: U.S. WILLING TO REVIVE ISRAELI ACCORD
abstract: President Reagan indicated tonight that he was eager to revive the agreement of strategic cooperation with Israel that he suspended in December after Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.   Amid indications of an improving political climate, Administration officials said the President was expected to meet with Prime Minister Menachem Begin on June 20 or 21 after Mr. Begin attends a United Nations disarmament conference.   With lower-level exchanges on the strategic agreement already under way, Mr. Reagan was asked at his news conference whether he was prepared to reinstitute the agreement. He said he regretted having had to suspend it, adding, ''We look forward to when that will be implemented again.'' He gave no timetable.

headline: 2 BRITISH SOILDERS ARE KILLED BY I.R.A. IN ULSTER AMBUSH
abstract: Irish Republican Army guerrillas waiting in ambush in an apartment that they had seized shot dead two British soldiers in civilian clothes riding in an unmarked van today.

headline: Cuba Reports Getting 'Huge' Supply of Arms
abstract: Cuba has recently received ''huge quantities of modern and sophisticated weapons,'' the Cuban Vice President, Dr. Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, said today.

headline: AUSTRIA'S PROBLEMS WORRY ECONOMISTS
abstract: In Austria, there have been no giant bankruptcies, like Belgium's Cockerill-Sambre Steel Company, or any controversial remedies, such as France's industry nationalization plan. But beneath the surface of apparent tranquility, there is an undercurrent of concern about the economy this spring.   Last year, Europe's recession lapped over into this Central European nation, causing the economy to stagnate after more than 3 percent growth the year before.   To complicate matters, unemployment, virtually nil in recent years, hit 3.5 percent by the end of the first quarter as a new wave of young persons began entering a labor market already clogged by Austrians returning home from neighboring countries where jobs are scarce.

headline: 32d Session of A-Talks Held
abstract: American and Soviet negotiators met for two hours and 20 minutes today in the 32d session of talks aimed at reducing nuclear arsenals in Europe. United States officials said the next session was scheduled for Tuesday. Details of the talks have not been disclosed.

headline: Egypt and Israel Resume Talks on Sinai Dispute
abstract: Egypt and Israel resumed talks here today in an attempt to settle a dispute over their new border.

headline: SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. AND PANAMA FACE NEW STRAINS
abstract: A quiet change in leadership in Panama and a controversy here over the appointment of a new United States Ambassador to that country have introduced new uncertainties into relations between the two Governments, according to State Department officials, Congressional aides and Panamanian business leaders.   At the same time, while Panama maintains generally good relations with the United States, its Foreign Minister, Jorge Illueca, has been presenting an increasingly pro-third world, anti-Western image in international forums.   On Saturday at the United Nations, Mr. Illueca commended Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands as an act of anticolonialism and called for a resolution urging Britain to ''cease its hostile conduct'' and ''refrain from any threat or use of force.''   A House Merchant Marine subcommittee has introduced an amendment to a bill updating the 1978 Panama Canal Treaties that could give new life to the debate over the decision to relinquish control of the canal to Panama. Full ownership of the waterway is due to go to Panama in 1999.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., has elected Albert J.  Costello group vice president, and appointed Darryl D. Fry president of the Agricultural division.   * AMF Inc., White Plains, has appointed John M. McDonagh staff vice president, corporate development.

headline: Soviet Pentecostalists Say Family Was Beaten
abstract: The Soviet Pentecostalists who have taken refuge at the United States Embassy here said today that their brothers and sisters in the Siberian city of Chernogorsk were badly beaten recently when they staged a demonstration to demand their emigration.    Among those beaten, they said, was Lidiya Vashchenko, 31 years old, who lived at the embassy until she staged a hunger strike early this year and was evacuated to a Soviet hospital.

headline: CAPTURED CASTLE IS VISITED BY BEGIN
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin flew to Beaufort Castle in southern Lebanon on Monday to meet with Defense Minister Ariel Sharon shortly after the castle was captured by Israeli forces.   Clearly aware of the symbolic character of the site, Mr. Begin chose the 12th-century Crusader castle that overlooks settlements in northeastern Israel to receive Mr. Sharon's account of the progress of Israel's invasion of Lebanon.   Beaufort Castle had come to be regarded by Israelis in the border region in much the same way the Golan Heights were before the 1967 Middle East war, as a high ground from which enemies observed and threatened their towns and settlements. The castle, situated atop a peak, is three miles from the Israeli town of Metulla.

headline: THE MANY FACES OF BARLOW RAND LTD.
abstract: JOHANNESBURG WHEN foreigners take notice of big business in South Africa, their attention is normally drawn to the vast Anglo-American Corporation and its chairman, Harry F. Oppenheimer, whose place in the moneyed portion of this society makes him a one-man aristocracy.   But the second-biggest industrial and mining group in South Africa is also very big. It is called Barlow Rand Ltd. and the last time anyone counted, at the end of its financial year that ended Sept. 30, it had 325 operating companies, employed 196,000 persons and reported consolidated after-tax profit of $441 million. That represented a 23 percent leap from the previous year and didn't include the returns on another batch of companies, nearly 600 of them, in which Barlow Rand has either an equity or management stake.   Barlow Rand also has a chairman and chief executive officer whose statements on sensitive social and political issues are perused almost as carefully as Mr. Oppenheimer's.

headline: Mitterrand Visits Ivory Coast In His 3-Nation African Tour
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France arrived today for a three-day visit on his first African tour since taking office a year ago.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA PRESSES CUBAN TROOP ISSUE
abstract: A South African Government delegation has told State Department officials that the withdrawal of Cuban soldiers from Angola is the key issue in working out an independence agreement for South-West Africa.   South African diplomatic officials said Monday that talks with American officials were set to wind up this week, and that ''a feeling of urgency'' hovered over the long negotiations. The diplomats said negotiations on a plan to grant South-West Africa independence as the new country of Namibia had ''gathered momentum.'' They said several crucial issues involving constitutional rights and the role of United Nations forces appeared to be on the way to resolution.

headline: Holders Fight Sale Of Milwaukee Road
abstract: Major stockholders of the Chicago Milwaukee Corporation have asked the trustee of the bankrupt Milwaukee Railroad subsidiary to end talks on its planned sale to the Grand Trunk Corporation unless terms can be renegotiated.   Grand Trunk and the trustee, Richard Ogilvie, said they would proceed with the proposed takeover of the 3,000-mile rail system.

headline: SINAI PRESS CURBS DEFENDED BY BEGIN
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that news coverage of the Israeli withdrawal from northern Sinai this week was being restricted as part of efforts to ''prevent bloodshed'' in the area.   He contended that ''the presence of television cameras and recording apparatus are factors that may lead indirectly to demonstrative tragedies.'' Some of the hundreds of Jews protesting the return of Sinai to Egypt have threatened suicide.

headline: World Air Loses Plea
abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board today denied a request by World Airways that the agency impose restrictions on fare discounting. World has been one of the leading discounters but now finds that prices have fallen to the point of being uneconomic.

headline: Knight-Ridder Declines
abstract: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. said today that first-quarter earnings fell 26.7 percent while revenue increased 7.2 percent.

headline: TEXT OF STATE DEPT. STATEMENT
abstract: Following is the text of a statement issued today by the State Department on the fighting in Lebanon: Special to the New York Times   WASHINGTON, June 7 - Following is the text of a statement issued today by the State Department on the fighting in Lebanon:   We deeply regret that the spiral of violence that began with the assassination attempt against the Israeli ambassador to Britain and that moved on to Israeli air strikes on Lebanon and Palestinian shelling of Israel has now reached new heights, threatening the lives and property of a great many innocent people in Lebanon.   The United States has been doing its very best, not only in recent days, but also as far back as last year, to forestall the terrible tragedy that is now unfolding. Two nights ago, the United States joined in the Security Council's call for a cease-fire yesterday at dawn, which - if observed by all sides - might have prevented these present developments. The U.S. has been in touch not only with the Israeli Government but with all governments and quarters which have influence on the situation. Our counsels of restraint and caution have been intense and constant.

headline: DAZED REFUGEES DELUGE A GRACEFUL PARK IN BEIRUT
abstract: Think of Gramercy Park, that intimate enclave of green in Manhattan. Sanaye Park in the center of Beirut used to be very similar to it.   Sanaye Park today is a place of graceful trees - weeping willows and bougainvillea. It is also filled with desperate refugees uprooted by the Israeli invasion that began June 6. There are hundreds of them living in the small park. The more fortunate have tents. Many are living in crude lean-tos, some of them fashioned from colorful tablecloths that once graced the dining-room tables of evacuated or destroyed homes.

headline: U.S. SEEKS TO IMPROVE TIES WITH GUATEMALA
abstract: The Reagan Administration indicated today that it hoped to establish a ''closer, more collaborative'' relationship with the conservative military regime that seized power in Guatemala last month.   Testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, the Deputy Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, Stephen W.  Bosworth, said the March 23 coup that ousted the hard-line Government of President Romeo Lucas Garcia ''may have ended the political paralysis which had gripped the country.''   Mr. Bosworth said that the new junta, headed by Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, had adopted concrete measures against corruption and that indiscriminate violence ''has been brought virtually to an end.''

headline: Taiwan's Premier Sees Chance of Peking Accord
abstract: Prime Minister Sun Yun-suan of Taiwan said today that reunification with China could become possible as differences between the two sides narrow.   ''If the political, economic, social and cultural gaps between the Chinese mainland and free China continue to narrow, the conditions for peaceful reunification can gradually mature,'' Mr. Sun said at a reception.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: All United States stock and commodities markets and most businesses were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day. Some foreign markets were also closed in observance of the Whitsun holiday.

headline: Patents; TV Screen Lies Flat On Wall
abstract: WASHINGTON THE RCA Corporation has made progress toward the development of a flat color television receiver that can be mounted on a wall like a picture. Marvin A. Leedom, director of manufacturing systems and technology research at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J., was granted patent 4,330,735 this week for an assembly to guide electron beams to the screen.

headline: Company News; National Patent Files 4 Lens Suits
abstract: The National Patent Development Corporation and its subsidiary, NPD Technologies Inc., said they had filed patent infringement suits in four district courts covering soft contact lens patents validated in a recent California Federal court decision.   Named in the suits are Ciba-Geigy; Alcon Optics, a division of Alcon Laboratories; Burton Parsons, and American Optical, a unit of Warner-Lambert.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The Reagan Administration has apparently decided to make the best of Israel's military moves in Lebanon by trying to translate them into a long-term political solution for Lebanon.   In part, State Department officials said, this course was dictated when Prime Minister Menachem Begin told President Reagan on Thursday that he would agree to a cease-fire but would not pull Israeli forces out until certain conditions were met -namely, the creation of a Lebanese government free of Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization pressure and the ending of the use of Lebanese territory as a military base for attacks on Israel.   Officials said Middle East experts advised Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that, because Mr. Begin was adamant, there was no way the United States could obtain an Israeli withdrawal except as part of an overall settlement of the Lebanese crisis. As a result, the Administration decided to welcome Israel's announcement today of a cease-fire and not to make an issue of Israel's refusal to accept the United Nations Security Council demand for an immediate withdrawal.

headline: VOTE DUE TOMORROW IN PHILIPPINE REBEL AREA
abstract: Legislative elections, postponed twice this year, are to be held on Monday in the Moslem-dominated southern part of the Philippines, and opposition politicians are charging that the balloting will not be fair.   The party led by President Ferdinand E. Marcos is expected to win a majority in the balloting, which he pledged would be held as soon as possible after he returned in late March from a visit to Saudi Arabia, this country's principal supplier of oil and employer of 150,000 overseas workers from the Philippines.   Government security forces are expected to be highly visible at the polling places on Monday to discourage guerrilla attempts to disrupt the elections for assembly seats in Regions 9 and 12 on the island of Mindanao. These are autonomous regions where martial law is still in effect.

headline: A FRENZY OF COUPON CLIPPING IN A BID TO CUT COSTS
abstract: They usually draw you to dog food, breakfast cereals or laundry detergents, but they have already appeared for Paul Masson and Gallo wines and Seagram's liquors, and in such unexpected places as on the back of college football tickets.   As hard times take more of a toll on consumer budgets, manufacturers' coupons are becoming increasingly valuable tools for Americans looking to cut corners.   ''People are trying to find every way they can to save money,'' said Martin Sloane, president of the American Coupon Club and a syndicated columnist. By using coupons, refund offers and supermarket specials, average consumers can cut their food bills by $1,000 a year, he said.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * California Life Corp. said it had again extended its offer to purchase $16 million of its 11 percent sinking fund debentures at $45 for each $100 principal amount.   * Champion International Corp.'s industrial revenue bonds were downgraded to BBB-plus from A-minus by Standard and Poor's Corp.

headline: Fact Magazine Is Sent To Value Line List
abstract: Arnold Bernhard & Company, which has been selling Value Line, the country's largest investment advisory service, to upscale interested parties for $330 a year, is now sending the 100,000 subscribers a free monthly magazine called Fact and subtitled The Money Management Magazine.

headline: Gallup Poll Finds Sympathy For the Israelis Has Increased
abstract: Israel's withdrawal from Sinai on April 25 came at a time when there was greater sympathy for Israel in the United States than there had been for almost a decade, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

headline: Chairman at Beeline Adds Two Other Posts
abstract: It may sound like a long road from banking to selling oil paintings at house parties. But John C. Colman, former executive vice president of the Continental Illinois Corporation and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, has just become president and chief executive officer of Beeline Inc., which organizes the sales from its headquarters in Bensenville, Ill.

headline: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NLT's Bid Raised In Takeover Battle
abstract: The NLT Corporation of Nashville, locked in a takeover battle with the larger American General Corporation of Houston, raised its bid to $55 from $50 a common share yesterday for the 11.2 million American General common shares it wants to acquire.   Each company is seeking to take over the other.

headline: CEMENT COMPANIES RECESSION VICTIMS
abstract: Cement has long been derided as the pasty gray material that covers too much of the country's landscape. In the 1960's, families opted for weed-free backyards of cement, architects used it to cut costs on skyscrappers and boat builders molded the heavy mud into yachts.   Nowadays, however, the cement business is having problems. Despite the widespread use of the material, its major customer - the construction industry - has been devastated by the recession.

headline: POPE & TALBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ALLBRITTON IN THE NEWS
abstract: Joe L. Allbritton (right), a Texas financier with a penchant for buying failing newspapers, last week agreed to buy The Daily News from its owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago. Mr. Allbritton has 30 days to negotiate staff cuts and other concessions with the New York tabloid's unions. If he is successful, he would buy the newspaper and its real estate holdings in Brooklyn and Queens but not the valuable Daily News building in Manhattan. Mr. Allbritton, chairman of the Allbritton Communications Corporation, is a former owner of the defunct Washington Star. Last fall he bought the ailing Trenton Times in New Jersey.

headline: Commodities; Financial Futures Linchpin
abstract: WHILE the default of Drysdale Government Securities shook the financial world last week, the affair was easily absorbed by the new linchpin of the Government securities market - financial futures.   Without the Treasury bond and bill futures market, the 30 or so major Government securities dealers would be hard pressed to distribute, or retail, an ever-increasing volume of Treasury debt.  Why? Because the futures allow the dealers to hedge, or insure, their inventory and other risks against adverse price moves.   Not only must the dealers hedge because the uncertainty over interest rates has made the Government securities prices as volatile as any other investment; they are also constantly ''pawning'' their inventory in order to raise cash with which to buy more of the Treasury's paper. (Dealers, however, prefer to use the term ''repurchase agreement,'' or repos, rather than pawning.)

headline: Stocks End Mixed in Toronto
abstract: Toronto stocks closed mixed in trendless trading today as markets in the United States were closed for the Memorial Day holiday.   Massey-Ferguson shares plunged.

headline: Arrow Electronics Loss
abstract: Citing weak semiconductor prices, Arrow Electronics Inc., distributor of electronic parts, yesterday reported a first-quarter loss of $1 million, contrasted with a year-earlier profit of $670,000, or 15 cents a share. Arrow also said that it had acquired two companies, Computrend Inc. and the Computer Products Supply Company; prices were not disclosed. Arrow said it would use the acquisitions to enter ''a prospectively major field for electronics distributors.''

headline: International
abstract: The U.S. foreign trade deficit narrowed to $322 million in April, the closest the nation has come to a balance in merchandise trade since a one-month surplus more than six years ago. Economists were cautious in their assessment, with one saying that the April result might be a ''fluke.'' (Page D1.)   Many big banks are cutting back on their international lending, especially to poorer nations, according to bankers at an International Monetary Conference. (D9.)

headline: INTEREST RATE HOPES SEND STOCKS HIGHER
abstract: The stock market, buoyed by expectations that interest rates will soon decline, rose moderately yesterday in active trading, with the energy-related issues leading the advance.   Reflecting the market's strength, the Dow Jones industrial average closed up 6 points, to 869.20, its highest finish since Jan. 29, when it ended at 871.10. For the week, the blue-chip barometer gained 20.84 points from last week's close of 848.36.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Iranian forces that are on the Iranian-Iraqi border about 100 miles northeast of Baghdad, Iraq's capital, may be planning a push toward that city, in the view of military analysts in Washington and Western Europe. These forces are in Qasr-i-Shirin, the Iranian border town that the Iraqis captured at the beginning of the war in September 1980 and that the Iranians retook late last year.   A successful Iranian move onto Iraqi territory, the analysts say, could bring the war to an end, with the Iraqis withdrawing from the areas of Iran they have occupied, principally in the oil-producing province of Khuzistan south of Qasr-i-Shirin. The Iranians are also near the border in Khuzistan west of Dizful, an area where they won a major victory recently, but at that point Baghdad is about 200 miles away.

headline: Advertising; Campaign For Chain Of Saloons
abstract: A television commercial full of big-beat music, flashing lights and b eautiful people that promotes a gin mill named Brannigan's as a fun p lace for young people to drink and eat began running yesterday in n ine major markets. ''Come on, get happy,'' is the important and t imely message.   ''It seems to us that this is the first saloon that is getting national-type advertising,'' said Malcolm D. MacDougall, president and director of creative services of SSC&B, who had just shown the 30-second videotape. ''And it's where the baby boom has moved after leaving Ronald McDonald.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Co. has appointed William G. Bishop 3d vice president-audits.   * American Standard Inc. has elected to its board Dirk De Bruyne, president of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company.   * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, has elected William F.  Kieschnick, president, to the additional post of chief executive officer, succeeding Robert O. Anderson, who will continue to serve as chairman.

headline: Advertising; Selling the Excitement Of Gaming
abstract: NEITHER New York State nor Pennsylvania allow casino gambling but they do supply most of the people who go to Atlantic City to enjoy it and the only nearby television stations to advertise it.   But television and radio broadcasters are restricted by their industry codes and are very leery about accepting commercials with references to gambling, even if that's what the Boardwalk city is all about these days.   Then there is that city's Casino Control Commission, which has strict guidelines on how gaming can be advertised. But they are less restrictive than the TV and radio codes.

headline: Washington Watch; Price Support For Air Routes
abstract: WASHINGTON IN the multibillion dollar Federal world of housing subsidies and dairy industry price supports, the Civil Aeronautics Board casts a scarcely discernible budgetary shadow. What's more, the small agency is scheduled to go out of business by the end of 1984, perhaps sooner.   But even this doomed arm of Government -though it now seems increasingly likely that the C.A.B.'s various constituencies will keep it alive until the last minute - has not been bashful about putting its hands into the taxpayer's pocket. It's one example of why it has been so hard for the Reagan Administration to get control of Federal spending.

headline: BARNES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: McLouth to Seek Asset Sale Delay
abstract: The troubled McLouth Steel Corporation will ask its secured creditors to extend the steelmaker's June 18 deadline to sell, merge or surrender its assets, according to its chairman, R. Milton Deaner.   ''In my opinion, our facility has far more value as an operating plant than if it were sold in pieces,'' Mr. Deaner said Monday.

headline: HOMESTAKE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WALL STREET'S ELECTRONIC EXPERIMENT
abstract: Tomorrow morning, after years of debate and some foot-dragging, a reluctant Wall Street is taking an important step into the electronic age. The step, an experiment in securing better prices for investors, already has some of Wall Street's most established firms fretting for the future of the nation's securities markets.   This new system, though limited, is heightening the rivalry between the stock exchanges, with their near-monopoly over trading in the best known stocks, and some brokerage houses, which itch to buy and sell shares themselves, without any need to cut the exchanges in.   A new electronic network is being introduced as a way to insure that investors get the best price for their shares. But the moment the system starts working, it will put traders at those brokerage houses on an equal footing with their long established counterparts on the stock exchange floor. This parity has never existed before.

headline: Dorsey Sells Unit
abstract: The Dorsey Corporation reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had sold the net assets of its glass container subsidiary to members of the subsidiary's management and a group of outside investors for $35 million in cash and a $5 million, 12 percent note.

headline: All Livestock Futures Fall by Daily Limits
abstract: All actively traded livestock futures fell their daily permissible limits yesterday in what many brokers said may have signaled the end of an extraordinary five-month advance in cattle, hog and pork bellies prices.   Yesterday's broad sell-off, which began moments after the opening of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, came after a holiday-shortened week in which the markets were generally weak and rallies shortlived, brokers noted. As a result, many traders who follow computerized strategies began selling last Friday. Yesterday, one broker quipped, ''The slower computers began issuing sell orders.''

headline: Trade Surplus Dips in Britain
abstract: Britain's trade surplus slipped slightly, to the equivalent of $339 million in April from $384 million in March, the Trade Department said Friday.   Exports rose to a record $8.18 billion from $7.92 billion in March mainly as a result of a large increase in oil shipments. Imports were also higher, at $7.85 billion, compared with $7.54 billion in March.

headline: DEEP TAX RATE CUTS PROPOSED
abstract: Two Democratic tax writers, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, today proposed deep cuts in personal income tax rates and the repeal of many deductions now allowed.   The joint statement by Representative Gephardt, a member of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Bradley, a member of the Senate Finance Committee, was the latest in a series of proposals for simplification of the income tax combined with deep rate reduction.   Many such proposals have been designed around a flat tax, or single rate, or just a few rates instead of the present 12-tier progressive rate table. The proposal announced today would reduce tax rates to a maximum of 28 percent. Although discussion about the flat tax is growing, it is still a long way from active consideration.

headline: Key's New Drug
abstract: Key Pharmaceuticals Inc., a Miami-based drug manufacturer, said it had signed an agreement in principle to acquire exclusive United States and Canadian distribution rights for Sobrerol, a bronchitis treatment made by Camillo Corvi S.p.A. of Italy.

headline: VOLUME UP
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average sank to 795.57 yesterday, piercing the 800-point mark widely regarded as a key support level.  The selling pressure reflected the combined pressures of the intensifying Middle East crisis, high interest rates, the weakening economy and the continued inability of Congress to reach a compromise on the budget deficit.   The blue-chip barometer, which was off almost 10 points at 3 P.M., recovered somewhat in the last hour of trading on bargain hunting. At the close it was down 6.66 points. In the last four weeks the average has tumbled 74 points.

headline: Del E. Webb Pact
abstract: The Del E. Webb Corporation said it had reached an agreement on the principal terms of an option to buy the 50 percent interest of Claridge Associates, its limited partner, in the Claridge Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City, and that the agreement was submitted to the New Jersey Casino Control Commission during license hearings. Webb said that the option price of $4.5 million included Webb's right to sell the property to a third party during or after the three-year option, although Webb had ''no plans to do that.''

headline: Allen Tells Japanese Premier He Will Work to Improve Ties
abstract: President Reagan's former adviser, Richard V. Allen, told Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan today that he would continue his efforts to eliminate communication gaps between the United States and Japan, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's office said.   Mr. Allen, who serves as chief foreign policy consultant to the Republican National Committee, told Mr. Suzuki during a courtesy call that Japan and the United States needed to deepen their mutual understanding, especially during this time of trade friction, the spokesman said.

headline: REDESIGNING SOCIAL SECURITY
abstract: Wisps of white hair curl down his neck and stick out behind his ears. His high forehead gives him a scholarly look. His voice is soft.   In all, Robert J. Myers seems more like a mild-mannered professor than a survivor of several decades of the grinding combat of the Federal bureaucracy. But he is a survivor, and possibly the nation's No.1 expert on Social Security.

headline: COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.E. NET RISES 5% IN QUARTER; SALES OFF
abstract: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that the diversity of its product line helped lift net income in the first quarter of 1981 by 5 percent, although revenues slipped 1.2 percent.   General Electric, the nation's largest manufacturer of electrical equipment, said that net income in the latest three months increased to $377 million, or $1.66 a share, from $359 million, or $1.57 a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Sales dipped to $6.02 billion from $6.09 billion.

headline: Research Spending
abstract: Businesses plan to increase research and development spending 17 percent this year, to $59.7 billion, according to a survey released yesterday by the McGraw-Hill Publications Company. Research and development spending rose 16 percent in 1981 from the previous year and is expected to be up at least 37 percent, to $81.9 billion, by 1985, the survey said.

headline: HAIG MOVE CAUSES ANXIETY IN EUROPE
abstract: Many officials and commentators in Western Europe reacted with trepidation yesterday to the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., whom they saw as their chief supporter and the leading moderate in the Reagan Administration.   But in many Arab countries, officials applauded the departure of a man they held responsible for American support of Israel's invasion of Lebanon.   The Soviet Union and China, however, remained officially silent on Mr. Haig's resignation and the selection of George P. Shultz, a former Secretary of the Treasury, as his replacement. Tass, the official Soviet press agency, initially attributed Mr. Haig's resignation to a dispute about his support for Israel, but deleted that suggestion in later dispatches.

headline: Israeli Official Warns P.L.O.  Against Violating Cease-Fire
abstract: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon today repeated Israeli warnings to the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon not to violate the cease-fire that was arranged there last July.   ''It would be best that our enemies not take adverse advantage of our capabilities for restraint and understand before it is too late that they are bound by the cease-fire agreement on all borders, all fronts and beyond,'' Mr. Sharon said at a ceremony to inaugurate two airfields in the southern Negev.

headline: ARGENTINE-RUSSIAN TRADE IS SURGING AS SOVIET TAKES 77% OF CROP EXPORTS
abstract: The Soviet Union's support for Argentina's position in the Falkland Islands crisis has focused attention on the close trade relationship that has emerged between the two countries over the last two years.   After having long been a minor commercial partner of the Soviet Union, Argentina in 1980 jumped to second place among the developing countries doing business with the Russians, who bought almost onefourth of all Argentine exports. Last year Argentina moved into first place among developing countries trading with the Russians, edging out India, the former leader.   The surge in Soviet-Argentine trade resulted from the imposition of a United States grain embargo on the Soviet Union after its military intervention in Afghanistan in late 1979. The Russians turned to Argentina for grain supplies, and Argentine exports jumped fourfold in 1980 compared with the 1979 level.

headline: PRODUCERS' PRICES OFF 0.1% IN MARCH FOR SECOND MONTH
abstract: The Producer Price Index for March fell onetenth of 1 percent from the previous month, the first time in more than six years that this broad inflation measure has declined for two consecutive months, the Labor Department reported today.   The index also declined by one-tenth of 1 percent in February.  Energy prices fell in March even more than in January and February while food prices, somewhat surprisingly, reversed course and turned down.   The figures were seen by economists as more evidence of the progress made against inflation, though they cautioned that much of the gain reflected the persistent recession that many think has already touched bottom.

headline: Short-Term Rates Decline; 2-Year Notes Bring 13.77%
abstract: A ''flight toward quality'' pushed down short-term interest rates yesterday as nervous dealers and investors sought Treasury bills and ignored longer Government securities, which were largely unchanged in price on the day.   The nervousness stemmed from the failure of a major Government securities dealer, Drysdale Government Securities, to meet $160 million in interest payments.   One prominent dealer who requested anonymity, although he said his house was not involved with Drysdale's operations, said that many dealers think they can ignore what happened because the securities involved were Treasuries and not commercial paper or other privatesector instruments. But, he added, the markets are more volatile than a decade ago and business cannot be put on the books at any risk.

headline: WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRAUN ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; May 11, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Unicef Executive Board - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: FOREIGN PRESS UNDER ATTACK IN EL SALVADOR
abstract: Stretched across streets and plastered on cars, banners and stickers admonish reporters: ''Tell the truth.  Betray your country, not ours.''   The message reflects resentment among Salvadorans toward the press. The message says, in effect, ''We think you have been lying about events here and as a result the 'Communists' are on the verge of taking over our country.''

headline: Drug Export Shift Weighed
abstract: 13 WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -The Reagan Administration is moving toward a new trade policy that would let American companies export drugs that are not allowed to be sold in this country because of potential hazards, according to Administration sources.   The proposed policy also would revise current regulations to make it easier for American companies to sell other hazardous substances they produce to foreign customers, the sources say.

headline: FRACNCHISING INSURANCE FIRMS
abstract: Rick Armstrong, a property and casualty insurance broker with Milum & Associates in Newport Beach, Calif., has been in the business for more than 10 years. But about a year and a half ago, his firm bought a franchise from Insurance Systems Unlimited, and now the franchiser's name and logotype appear along with Milum's in all of its materials.   ''We wanted to be more than a simple broker,'' Mr. Armstrong said.  ''We wanted to get involved with larger clients.'' ''I don't think we, as independents, have any choice, unless we have a rich grandfather,'' added Larry Lichti of Consolidated Brokers, a Kearney, Neb., concern that is part of another insurance franchising system, Insurance World. ''Image is so important.''

headline: C.F.T.C. IS COMING UNDER FIRE
abstract: A move is under way in Congress to curtail sharply or even eliminate the Commodity Futures Trading Commission's authority to approve stock index futures, an action that commodities industry officials fear could be the first step in removing the agency's responsibility for regulating financial futures.   At hearings opening on Monday, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, is expected to open an attack on the commission's recent approval of proposals by several major commodities exchanges to trade stock market index futures.   Stock index futures contracts allow a purchaser to speculate on the level of the index over a fixed period of   Commodity exchanges are struggling for dominance in trading of stock index futures. Page D3. time. The value of such a contract rises or falls as the index fluctuates, and speculators or hedgers can profit by correctly guessing its future direction.

headline: BILL TO AID THRIFT UNITS FACES ACCOUNTING SNAG
abstract: In an opinion that could mean another blow to the beleaguered thrift industry, a Treasury official said today that a House-passed bill designed to rescue savings and loan institutions might be useless because it did not comply with generally accepted accounting principles.   Roger W. Mehle, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, told a Senate Banking Committee hearing that the Net Worth Guarantee Act, which was approved in the House last week, would not conform with standards set by the Financial Accounting Standards Board for reporting net worth.   The board is an independent self-regulatory organization that establishes principles for the accounting profession.  By presenting the F.A.S.B.'s position, Mr. Mehle signaled the Treasury's own reservations on the House bill. The department favors an alternative bill now before the Senate that requires less Treasury involvement and that does not appear to raise accounting problems.

headline: ALBANY APPROVES SALE OF LOW-RATE FLEXINOTES
abstract: The New York State Legislature yesterday approved the sale of commercial paper and flexinotes, which are short-term securities that the state might issue at lower interest rates than on the notes it has traditionally sold.   The legislation would allow the sale of up to $250 million of commercial paper and $500 million of flexinotes. Governor Carey has yet to sign the legislation, but John Hull, Deputy Controller, said he was expected to do so.

headline: SYRIANS CONCEDE LOSSES TO ISRAEL
abstract: The Syrian high command conceded today that its troops had been forced to give up ground to the advancing Israeli forces along the strategic Beirut-Damascus highway.   A communique said the Israelis entered Bhamdun, one of the important villages in the mountainous part of the road.  The Syrian Defense Ministry accused Israel of using nerve gas in the fighting around Bhamdun. Israel denied the charge.  The Syrian communique minimized the scale of the Israeli advance, saying the Israeli tanks managed to advance only three miles and suffered heavy loses despite clear air superiority. It said hundreds of planes supported the Israeli thrust.

headline: ECONOMIC ISSUES DIVIDE LEADERS AS TALKS OPEN
abstract: In the grand setting of former French royalty, the leaders of seven industrial nations formally opened their economic summit conference tonight, still at odds over measures to ease the world recession and stabilize the value of their currencies.   At their first gathering, they set aside their discussion of the world recession, however, to confer on the future of the Falkland Islands - without urging Britain to pause before a final assault on Stanley, the capital. An official close to the conference said that none of the leaders had told Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain to refrain from the final assault.   The finance ministers of the seven countries, meeting at the same time as the heads of government, were reported to have narrowed the gap on such key issues as a tougher credit strategy toward the Soviet Union and closer monetary cooperation to reduce currency fluctuations.

headline: SHEFFIELD SKIPPER TELLS OF 'ROARING MASS OF FLAMES'
abstract: Capt. Sam Salt, the commanding officer of the destroyer Sheffield, says the Argentine missile that hit his ship on Tuesday turned it into ''a roaring mass of flames.''   ''We could feel the heat of the deck through our shoes,'' Captain Salt said Wednesday, in an interview with the British Press Association aboard the Hermes, the aircraft carrier to which some of the survivors from the Sheffield were taken after they abandoned the destroyer.   ''The superstructure was steaming,'' he said. ''Paint on the ship's side was peeling off. The area where the missile penetrated the hull was white hot.''

headline: FED SEEKS MERGER COMMENT
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board voted today to call for public comment on the proposed acquisition by the BankAmerica Corporation of Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm.   If the Fed approves the merger, it would allow BankAmerica, the holding company for the nation's largest commercial bank, to offer a full range of ''one-stop'' financial services, from checking accounts to the sale of stocks. It would mark the first time that an American bank has been allowed to acquire a brokerage house.

headline: Civilians Can't Enter Israeli-Held Lebanon
abstract: The Israeli Army tonight forbade all civilians, including journalists, to enter Israeli-occupied southern Lebanon.

headline: Storm Kills 12 in India
abstract: Twelve people were killed and 50 injured in a storm in part of northeastern India, the United News of India reported today. The storm, with winds up to 75 miles an hour, damaged hundreds of homes in Assam state Sunday, the news agency said.

headline: Two Soviet Diplomats Detained in Bangladesh
abstract: Two attaches of the Soviet Embassy here were arrested last week while attempting to burn 588 rolls of movie film, according to sources close to Bangladesh security agents.    The attaches, whose last names are said to be Lomovsky and Kirichuk, were said to have been stopped March 31 by a civilian official about 20 miles northwest of here on the road to Tangail.

headline: MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TEXT OF SURRENDER DOCUMENT
abstract: Following is the text of the Argentine surrender document, signed in Stanley on Monday by Gen. Mario Menendez, commander of the Argentine forces there, and issued today by the Ministry of Defense in London:   I, the undersigned, commander of all the Argentine land, sea and air forces in the Falkland Islands, surrender to Major General J.J.  Moore C.B., O.B.E., M.C., as representative of Her Britannic Majesty's Government. Under the terms of this surrender, all Argentine personnel in the Falklands Islands are to muster at assembly points which will be nominated by General Moore, and hand over their arms, ammunition, and all other weapons and warlike equipment as directed by General Moore, or appropriate British officers acting on his behalf.

headline: Base Car Prices Raised by Ford
abstract: The Ford Motor Company announced it had increased the base vehicle prices of its Mustang GT and Capri RS by $89, or 1.1 percent, raised the prices for optional equipment on some cars, and raised destination and delivery charges.   ''The company is trying to find where the market will permit us to increase our revenues,'' said Bill Peacock, a spokesman.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * American Health magazine to Franznick & Cusatis.   * Abbott Laboratories to Laurence, Charles & Free Inc. for Tronolane hemorrhoid cream and suppositories.

headline: E.E.C. Inflation Rate
abstract: The consumer price index for the 10 countries of the European Economic Community rose 1.2 percent in April, compared with an increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent in March and 1.6 percent in April 1981, the Common Market statistics office said today.

headline: ARGENTINA SAYS BRITISH DO NOT WANT TO NEGOTIATE
abstract: The Argentine Government, expecting a breakdown of mediation efforts at the United Nations in the conflict with Britain, charged today that the British did not want to negotiate.   With the British task force reportedly moving into position to invade the Falkland Islands, Argentine leaders met tonight to consider making an appeal in the United Nations Security Council aimed at putting international pressure on Britain to hold up military action. Argentine officials said such an appeal would be for a cease-fire in the islands, which Argentine forces seized April 2.   A Government spokesman said President Leopoldo Galtieri had spoken with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar by telephone. No details of the conversation were made public here, but Mr. Perez de Cuellar said in New York that he had appealed for an extension of the talks. Fueling the sense of crisis here, General Galtieri unexpectedly canceled a scheduled interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation tonight, citing the ''grave situation.''

headline: SOUTHEAST'S SHAKY DOMINION
abstract: The Southeast Banking Corporation, for years the commanding presence in Florida's lucrative banking market, appears to be losing its once-formidable dominion to a host of threatening challengers.   Its position as the state's largest bank holding company, for example, is being closely challenged by No.2 Barnett Banks of Florida, an aggressive Jacksonville-based competitor that is close to matching Southeast in terms of assets and has already outstripped it in terms of earnings and return on assets.   For now, the Miami-based Southeast remains Florida's biggest banking organization, with $6.5 billion in total assets and 119 offices statewide - including the state's single largest bank - compared with Barnett's $6 billion in assets and 184 branches.   But its earnings have been poor when measured against the earnings of most other Florida banks, its stock price has been depressed, a group of local businessmen has been threatening a takeover and it has lost many of its best officers. Costly Takeover Fight   If that were not enough, Southeast is locked in a nasty and costly battle to acquire Florida National Banks of Florida, a $2.6 billion holding company based in Jacksonville. Southeast has offered the equivalent of about $36 a share in cash and stock, or about $270 million, to acquire F.N.B.

headline: Lancia Imports Halted
abstract: Fiat Motors of North America Inc. has stopped importing and distributing the sporty Italian car Lancia in the United States because of poor sales and a halt in production in Chivasso, Italy, Fiat's national marketing manager said today.''We've had problems with the Lancia line over the years, and production has been stopped with the 1982 models,'' William Rude said from Fiat's American headquarters in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J.

headline: WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Personal Finance; WARM WELCOME FOR INCENTIVE OPTIONS
abstract: WHEN Congress created the incentive stock option last summer, there w ere high hopes that it would become a popular means of rewarding v alued executives. But while incentive options do offer executives c onsiderable tax advantages, they are also more costly for businessest han the usual ''nonqualified'' options, and some management s pecialists felt this would dampen the companies' enthusiasm.   The results are beginning to come in, and it seems that the doubters were wrong. The incentive stock option is rapidly becoming a standard offering in the compensation plans of large American companies. Almost 85 percent of 200 prominent corporations surveyed plan to offer incentive stock options in the future, according to findings recently released by Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby, a New York employee benefit consulting firm. The firm also analyzed the 1981 proxy statements of two-thirds of the country's largest 100 corporations and found that 52 percent had already adopted incentive option plans, including such giants as Exxon, Mobil, Ford, Chrysler, American Can, Bendix and Du Pont.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Batus-Field Deal Advances in F.T.C.
abstract: Batus Inc., the American arm of B.A.T. Industries of London, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the staff of the Federal Trade Commission that settles the agency's investigation of Batus's continuing acquisition of Marshall Field & Company. The action was seen as clearing the way for Batus to acquire the Chicagobased retail chain.   Batus said that the agreement was for settlement purposes only and did not represent any admission on its part that the takeover would violate antitrust laws.

headline: PHILADELPHIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Affairs; THE FAMILY: ANOTHER SAFETY NET
abstract: TWENTY years ago, when full employment implied an unemployment rate o f around 4 percent, a 9 percent rate would probably have caused p olitical turmoil and marching in the street. Currently, a 9 percent r ate is causing our leaders political problems, but not as much as w ould be expected when record numbers of individuals are unsuccessfuli n their search for work.  Clearly, the social safety net associated with the Great Society programs of the late 1960's has somewhat muted the pain of unemployment. Although the Reagan Administration has lowered the safety net a bit, the basic structures remain intact and there is no discussion of eliminating the core programs of the Great Society, such as food stamps, Medicaid and Medicare. Indeed, in future history, President Reagan may be more famous for sanctifying the Great Society than for cutting it, just as President Eisenhower placed the Republican seal of approval on the New Deal.

headline: Echlin Head Describes Link to Borg-Warner
abstract: Frank Edward Pilling, 57, the new president and chief operating officer of Echlin Inc., knows all about the ties that bind his company to the Borg-Warner Corporation.   Mr. Pilling not only comes from Borg-Warner, where he was vice president with responsibility for special projects, but he played an active role while at Borg-Warner in arranging the $62 million trade last July in which Echlin swapped 4.5 million shares of its stock for five Borg-Warner divisions that make or market automotive replacement parts.   The trade took place in July, but the Federal Trade Commission is reviewing it to determine whether it reduces competition in the sale and assembly of carburetor kits. Shortly after the swap, Mr. Pilling was named to the board of Echlin.

headline: OFFICIAL SALVADOR TALLY GIVES CENTRISTS 24 SEATS
abstract: The official results of El Salvador's elections were announced today, but political sources said the new Constituent Assembly might not meet until the end of this month.   Last Sunday's elections, which were boycotted by the left, gave the centrist Christian Democratic Party 24 of the 60 assembly seats, the largest number for any single party. But four right-wing parties, with the remaining seats, have agreed to act as a bloc.

headline: JAPAN, AT U.N., EXPLAINS PLAN TO REARM
abstract: The Japanese government said today that it is building up its military forces as a first step toward eventually reducing the level of armaments in the world.   This explanation of Japan's rising military budget was offered by Taizo Watanabe, a spokesman for the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, at a news conference elaborating on a speech by Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki to the General Assembly's special session on disarmament.   In his speech, Mr. Suzuki said that ''nations have been trapped in a vicious circle, seeking their security solely by building up their armaments, thus further intensifying mutual distrust.'' Because ''international peace and security are maintained by the balance of power,'' he said, ''we must start by lowering, even little by little, the level of the balance of power as we move toward disarmament.''

headline: CONSOLIDATED REFINING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hitachi Robot
abstract: Hitachi Ltd. said it had developed a new industrial robot with twice the memory capacity of a conventional machine.

headline: S.E.C. Settles Insider Case
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a former consultant with the Advent Corporation, a manufacturer of electronic components, with using insider information in trading in the company's stock.   The agency's action, filed Thursday, was simultaneously settled, with no admission or denial of guilt by the defendant, Guy O. Dove 3d.

headline: WHY A DEVELOPER IN CITY USES QUALITY ZONING RULE
abstract: Five years ago New York City enacted what it called a housing quality zoning ordinance. Its purpose was to give builders of multifamily housing an alternative to by-the-book, or as-of-right, zoning to encourage them to achieve certain quality standards.   The ordinance has been used only sparingly by developers, perhaps because of its seeming complexity and the uncertain and cumbersome review process the builder must accept.   One of the few buildings that has been developed under the ordinance is a condominium called Le Triomphe, under construction at 245 East 59th Street. The site is the west blockfront of Second Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets, across the street from the Roosevelt Island tramway terminal at the approach to the Queensboro Bridge.

headline: Frontier Gives $75,000 Raise
abstract: Glen L. Ryland, the chairman of Frontier Airlines, has been given a $75,000-a-year raise, according to proxy statements mailed to stockholders.   Mr. Ryland, 57 years old, earned $366,000 in salary and bonuses last year.

headline: TUESDAY, APRIL 13, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Retail sales fell 0.5 percent last month, the Commerce Department said, and they are likely to stay sluggish in the second quarter, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted. The results contrasted with a 2.6 percent rise in February that apparently only temporarily stemmed two previous declines. (Page D1.) February installment debt grew by only $75 million in February as consumers reduced credit purchases because of the recession. The rise, at an annual rate of gain of less than 0.5 percent, compared with an annual growth rate of 6.8 percent a year earlier. (D8.)   The Fed tentatively decided to change the way it reports weekly money supply figures, shifting to a four-week moving average. The change is an effort to lessen the numbers' impact on financial markets. (D1.)

headline: SALVADORAN TROOPS AND GUERRILLAS REPORT HEAVIEST FIGHTING OF WAR
abstract: Salvadoran Government troops and guerrillas are engaged in what a military spokesman says is perhaps the fiercest combat of the two-and-a-half-year-old war here.   ''The blood is running in Morazan,'' Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia said during a military ceremony Friday. He was referring to the fighting in the mountainous northern half of the eastern province that has long been a rebel stronghold.

headline: PRESIDENT APPEALS TO FALKLAND FOES TO SHOW RESTRAINT
abstract: President Reagan appealed to Argentina and Britain today to show restraint in their dispute over the Falkland Islands. He also urged the Organization of American States to delay any action on the crisis so long as the United States was engaged in trying to bring about a peaceful solution.   The O.A.S. permanent council voted 18 to 0 today, with the United States and two other nations abstaining, to convene a special foreign ministers' meeting Monday to consider collective action against Britain.   The American delegate, William Middendorf 2d, said such a meeting would inevitably cast the group ''in an unhelpful confrontational light'' instead of as a possible mediator.

headline: Hoechst Plans
abstract: Hoechst, one of the world's largest chemical companies, announced plans to invest 130 million German marks, or about $53 million, to expand the production capacity of its polyester film-manufacturing subsidiary in the United States. Hoechst, which is based in Frankfurt, said that its plant in Greer, S.C., would begin producing an additional 12,000 metric tons a year of polyester film beginning in early 1984. Most of the increased output is designated for Western European markets.

headline: UNITED PARK CITY MINES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Commodities; Boards Vie For Lead In Indexes
abstract: THE quiet but furious struggle to dominate the four-month-old stock index futures market is expected to quicken now that the Chicago Board of Trade prepares to open a market in futures based on the popular Dow Jones averages. Until now, lawsuits by Dow Jones & Company had held up these plans for more than a month, while rival markets gathered strength.   Last Friday, however, a judge in Chicago ruled that the huge Chicago exchange would not infringe on the Dow Jones trademarks, provided that the exchange's futures did not carry any mention of the Dow Jones name. However, the judge also granted Dow Jones time in which to file an appeal against the ruling to the Illinois Appeals Court.

headline: Estes' Son Gets 3 Years in Jail
abstract: Thomas P. Estes, son of the former president of the General Motors Corporation, Elliot Estes, was sentenced to three years in a Federal prison today on charges of making false statements to obtain $900,000 in loans.   ''Obviously, it's a personal tragedy,'' Mr. Estes said following his sentencing by Judge Patricia Boyle of Federal District Court.

headline: BOWMAR INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Other Business; IN BASEBALL CARDS, TOPPS STILL LEADS THE LEAGUE
abstract: For more than two decades, it was easier to find an underpaid free agent than a trace of competition in the flourishing baseball card industry. The Brooklyn-based Topps Chewing Gum Company put them out, and that was that.   No more. Now, Topps bills itself as ''The Real One,'' and is fighting to defend its traditional turf in the face of market entries from two new rivals.

headline: 1,000 PROTESTING STUDENTS IN SEOUL BATTLE OF RIOT POLICEMEN
abstract: More than 1,000 anti-Government students at a South Korean university battled hundreds of riot policemen for more than an hour Tuesday, according to university officials.  Yonsei University in Seoul said that 16 students had been arrested, although 12 were released.

headline: TEHERAN BARS TRUCE
abstract: Iraq said today that it halted all its military activities in Iran at dawn and began to observe a ceasefire in its war with Iran, which began 21 months ago.   A communique broadcast by the Baghdad radio said the action was in compliance with a decision Wednesday night by the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, which offered to withdraw Iraqi troops from Iran ''within a maximum period of two weeks'' and to use its forces against Israel.   However, the Iranian press agency said Iran's Islamic revolutionary Government had rejected Iraq's offer to halt hostilities because the offer did not include removal of Iraq's President, Gen. Saddam Hussein.

headline: THAIS CELEBRATE MONARCHY AS SYMBOL OF UNITY
abstract: Thais happily splashed each other with water this week to mark the start of the traditional Thai New Year.  Since the beginning of the month, they had been celebrating the 200th anniversary of Thailand's Chakkri dynasty of kings, and while technically it is being observed through 1982, its most spectacular features are on the wane.   Many foreign guests, including Senator Charles H. Percy, President Reagan's representative, have left town. While the royal barges and their chanting oarsmen are due to ply the muddy Chao Phraya River for another week, the focus for many this week has been the celebration of the New Year, which arrived on Tuesday.

headline: REAGAN SUGGESTS LIMIT ON TROOPS FOR 2 ALLIANCES
abstract: President Reagan, expressing sympathy with the goal of the European antinuclear movement but differing with its tactics, urged today that East and West agree to a ceiling of 700,000 ground troops for each alliance as ''a major step toward a safer Europe.''   But with 16 leaders of the Atlantic alliance gathered here tonight, Mr. Reagan also called for the Western allies to strengthen and modernize their conventional forces as the best way of making the possibility of nuclear conflict, or any conflict, ''more remote.''   The formal proposal on troop ceilings, a modification of an earlier Western position at East-West talks, is to be approved by alliance leaders Thursday. The Reagan Administration considers this session especially significant for projecting alliance solidarity at a time of popular unrest and political division in Europe.

headline: People
abstract: * Walter S. McKenzie elected a partner of Laird & Kudner Direct Marketing.

headline: STOCK TRADING LINK HAS SLOW START
abstract: The experimental electronic link between the nation's stock exchanges and the over-the-counter market got off to a slow start yesterday.   Specialists and brokers at the New York Stock Exchange said they spotted no drop in orders because of off-the-board trading facilitated by the new network that ties their paper-strewn trading floor to the upstairs offices of market-making firms. And, as often happens on the first day of a new procedure on Wall Street, mechanical problems arose, and the connection was broken a number of times.   ''It's a nonevent day as far as trading goes,'' said Pat Marchese, a floor broker for E.F. Hutton & Company. ''It had no effect on the volume of business.''

headline: EXPERT SAYS SOVIET MAY LOFT LASER GUN BUT DOUBTS EFFECT
abstract: The chief of Air Force research and development said today that the Soviet Union could launch a laser antisatellite weapon in the next five years but contended that it would be ''ineffective'' except as a political and propaganda weapon.    Lieut. Gen. Kelley Burke added, however, that an ''effective'' Soviet weapon system in space would probably not be possible until the late 1990's.

headline: E.E.C. MEETS TODAY ON FRENCH FRANC
abstract: France has bowed to mounting pressure against the franc and has asked for a significant devaluation of the currency against the West German mark, sources at the European Economic Community said here early today.   They said the French Government, ending months of speculation about a probable devaluation, asked other members of the E.E.C. Friday night for a realignment of the community's joint currency float.   According to the sources, France asked its partners for a devaluation of the franc by as much as 14 percent against the mark, through a combination of a downward shift in the French currency's parity and an upward revaluation of the mark.

headline: Senators Bar Renewal Of a '62 Threat to Cuba
abstract: The Senate refused today to renew a 20-year-old warning that the United States will use any means, including military force, to keep Cuba from spreading Communism to Central and South America.   The Senate voted 41 to 39 to sidetrack the conservative-backed proposal after suggestions that it might be used to portray the United States as committed to a policy of force.   With the vote tied at 39 to 39, Howard H. Baker Jr., the Republican leader. voted against the resolution, as did Senator Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
