abstract: * American Video Amusement Corp., a unit of Jackpot Enterprises Inc., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a sale of 800,000 common shares, to be sold through Rooney Pace Inc.   * Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. filed offerings of $36 million principal amount of 11 1/2 percent series F debentures, due in 1993, and $94 million principal amount of 8 percent series G convertible debentures, due in 2000.

headline: Nicaragua Reports 26 Slain
abstract: Twenty-one ''counterrevolutionaries'' and five soldiers were killed in battles near the Honduran border in recent days, Nicaraguan officials say.  Most of the rightist groups near the border are made up of former national guard soldiers who fled to Honduras in 1979 when President Anastasio Somoza Debayle was overthrown.

headline: IRANIANS SAY AN IRAQI COUNTERATTACK IS IN PROGRESS
abstract: Iran said 3,500 prisoners it claims to have taken in its latest offensive in the war against Iraq were evacuated from the battlefront today to Teheran.   The Iranian report broadcast by the Teheran radio said the prisoners were transferred from Ahwaz in southwestern Iran as Iraqi forces counterattacked along the main highway between Khurramshahr and Ahwaz, in the Iranian oil province of Khuzistan.

headline: Stocks Retreat; Dow Off 4.47
abstract: The stock market registered a moderate decline yesterday in active trading with bank and transportation issues posting the largest losses.   At the final bell the Dow Jones industrial average was down 4.47 points, to 840.85, its lowest closing since April 20 when it ended at 840.56.   In the last seven sessions the blue-chip barometer has dropped about 28 points mainly because of investors' belief that interest rates will not decline soon and that the recession shows no signs of a recovery.

headline: Vietnamese Attack Kills 20
abstract: Twenty people were killed and more than 100 were wounded when Vietnamese forces shelled a camp harboring Cambodian guerrillas and civilians in western Cambodia Saturday, Thai military officials said today. They said more than 40 artillery shells hit San Rorcha-Ngan camp.

headline: Dentsply Facing Suits
abstract: Dentsply International said yesterday that two suits had been filed against the company and its directors in the Delaware Chancery Court seeking to stop a $100 million transaction to take the company private with substantial ownership in the hands of employees and senior management. Dentsply said it intended to oppose the suits and would continue preparations for the annual shareholder meeting now scheduled for New York on June 28. The suits were filed by Robert and Peggy Corwin and Evelyn Sumers, shareholders who oppose the $25.50-a-share offer.

headline: U.S. IS WARNED ON A TROOP PULLOUT IN EUROPE
abstract: A withdrawal of American forces from Europe might prompt the weaker nations of the Continent to make individual accommodations with the Soviet Union and encourage large parts of Western Europe to fall under Soviet influence, former Under Secretary of State George W. Ball said today.   ''Without unity Europeans know that they could never defend themselves against an aggressive drive by the Soviet Union, with whom they share the European continent,'' Mr. Ball told a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee.   Mr. Ball, long a specialist in European affairs, described suggestions that American troops might be withdrawn from Europe as alarming and said that the costs of maintaining a military presence in Europe had been exaggerated.

headline: SCHMIDT WARNS PARTY ON FREEZE OF NATO ARMS
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, addressing a convention of the Social Democratic Party, warned advocates of a nuclear freeze today that its enactment in Europe would amount to accepting the ''unbelievable Soviet armada that is aimed at us.''   Mr. Schmidt said the West must not let the Soviet advantage become permanent.  He was referring to the intermediate-range Soviet SS-20 missiles targeted on NATO countries.   In Washington, President Reagan renewed an invitation to Leonid I.  Brezhnev to meet him in June at the United Nations, and said such a meeting would not preclude a full summit conference later in the year as proposed by the Soviet leader. (Page A7.)

headline: Alfa Group Cites '81 Loss
abstract: The troubled Alfa Group, Latin America's largest business conglomerate, lost more than $120 million in 1981 and spent nearly $11 million buying out the jobs of 4,300 workers, Bernardo Garza Sada, president, said here.   Mr. Garza Sada addressed about 1,000 shareholders at an hourlong session yesterday and attributed most of Alfa's troubles to delays in expected price rises of items Alfa makes, high prices of imports the company needs and the devaluation of the peso, which makes it much more expensive for Alfa to pay off its foreign debts, most of which are in dollars.

headline: ENGELHARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SORG PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Stock Groups For Options
abstract: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said it had selected six industry stock groups as underlying securities for an initial listing of proposed group options contracts.   The exchange said the six groups would be made up of five stocks each. The groups, it added, are aerospace, air transport, computers, drugs, paper and forest products and petroleum.

headline: FOSTER, L B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SHARING SEOUL'S PROSPERITY
abstract: Kang Jung Sub recalls vividly his early days in Seoul after he had fled from a farming village in Communist North Korea. Every day was a struggle to avoid starvation.   It was 1951, and when he could not find work as an errand boy, he would beg, going with a small tin cup to the doors of people who looked prosperous. ''Sometimes they would put rice in my cup,'' he said, ''sometimes a 10-won coin.''

headline: Dow Advances 6.09; Giant Block Traded; Average Up 4.37 in Week
abstract: The stock market rose moderately yesterday in accelerated trading in a session highlighted by the second-largest block ever traded on the New York Stock Exchange.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, closed up 6.09 points, to 842.94. For the abbreviated trading week, the blue-chip barometer rose 4.37 points.  The stock market will be closed today in observance of Good Friday.

headline: ARGENTINA SAYS ITS JETS DAMAGED A BRITISH TROOPSHIP AND A FRIGATE
abstract: Argentine jets struck today at British ground forces and naval units around their beachhead on the Falkland Islands, seriously damaging a troopship and hitting a frigate, the military command here reported.   It also said Argentine defenders at Stanley, the capital of the islands, had beaten back a raid by British Harrier jets.  Two communiques issued by the command said the raids by air force jets were intended to prevent any ''deepening of the beachhead established by English forces at Port San Carlos'' early Friday. British Beachhead Described A communique late tonight said the British had disembarked about 2,000 men and were holding a strip six miles by nine miles around a cove on East Falkland Island. The communique said the British were reinforcing their disembarkation with ''materiel, equipment and personnel'' and that Argentine Army units supported by air strikes were ''undertaking the task to neutralize the advance of the English forces.''

headline: GENERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Zero Mexican Growth Seen
abstract: Jesus Silva Herzog, Mexico's Finance Minister, forecast today that Mexico's economy will register zero growth over the next 12 months as a result of austerity measures adopted after the recent sharp devaluation of the peso.   Mr. Silva Herzog, who took over as Finance Minister six weeks ago in the wake of the economic crisis, also announced that Mexico's public sector foreign debt would increase by some $11 billion, to $65 billion, during 1982, although rescheduling of existing short-term debts would require the Government to raise between $25 billion and $28 billion this year.

headline: SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTRY NOW SAYS BREZHNEV IS ON A WINTER VACATION
abstract: After a week of unofficial reports that Leonid I. Brezhnev had been hospitalized, the Foreign Ministry's press department called Western news agencies here today with a statement saying that the 75-year-old Soviet leader was on a ''routine winter vacation.''   The press department spokesman, Aleksandr K. Voznikov, stopped short of denying that Mr. Brezhnev had been in a hospital, as reported by unofficial Soviet sources.

headline: Text of Carrington letter, page A6.
abstract: Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, resigned today because of what he called the ''humiliating affront'' of Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands.   Francis Pym, the leader of the House of Commons, was chosen to take over at the Foreign Office in the midst of a crisis that has generated a war psychology in London and shaken the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Mr. Pym, a senior figure in the Conservative Party, has a reputation for moderation. He was replaced in the Commons leadership by John Biffen, previously the Minister for Trade.   The resignation of Lord Carrington and two of his principal assistants came as the vanguard of the largest British fleet assembled since World War II sailed from Portsmouth Harbor on the morning tide. It will take the flotilla about two weeks to reach the area of the Falklands, which lie in the South Atlantic almost 8,000 miles away.

headline: BRITISH JETS POUND AIRPORT AT STANLEY FOR A THIRD TIME
abstract: British Sea Harrier jets carried out another bombing raid Friday night on the airport at Stanley, the main town in the Falkland Islands, the Ministry of Defense announced early this morning.   The bombing attack was the third by British aircraft in a month and was apparently intended to counteract Argentine efforts to repair craters in the runway left by earlier bombings. The Defense Ministry's announcement gave no other details.   A few hours earlier, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher warned that a negotiated settlement of the Falklands conflict ''may prove to be unattainable.''

headline: VIRGINIA NATIONAL BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Bechtel Petroleum Inc. said it had begun construction of a new lubricating oil producing facility at Chevron U.S.A.'s refinery complex in Richmond, Calif.   * Brigadier Industries Corp. said it had purchased a 94 percent interest in Centurion International Inc. The price was not disclosed.    * Chris-Craft Industries announced an extension, to May 24, of its offer to purchase all shares of its common stock held by holders of 99 or fewer shares.

headline: Israel Moves Managers Into Southern Lebanon
abstract: Israel has moved military administrators into the war-battered cities and towns of southern Lebanon, and there are indications they may remain for some time.   ''We are here to establish a military government, or as we call it, a civil aid unit,'' said Col. Zvi Elpeleg, the military chief here.

headline: MANAGEMENT GOSPEL GONE WRONG
abstract: BOSTON It is a long way from the manicured grounds of the Harvard Business School to the sweat and grime of an assembly line. Most of the students who emerge from this elite campus for choice jobs in industry will come no closer to steel mills than the case studies they dissected. But from this cloistered world, two professors, Robert H. Hayes and William J. Abernathy, have come forth with a stream of articles and ideas that are beginning to reshape the thinking of American business about why the nation's bedrock industries, such as autos and steel, have withered in the face of foreign competition.   The two men's teachings are challenging what is taught in the best business schools, promulgated by armies of consultants, and honed to a high polish at such citadels of management as the General Electric Company. With some success, they are chipping away at such notions as blaming the ills of American industry on heavy-handed regulation, the avarice of labor unions, the decline of the work ethic, the oil crisis or the Japanese.

headline: WISHFUL THINKING ON THE SPOT MARKET
abstract: MR. BROWN suggests that the United States Government should investigate the pricing of Saudi A rabian crude. Unfortunately, he has so little understanding of the S audi Arabian crude supply arrangements that his remarks border on t he ludicrous.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 24, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Ad Hoc Committee of the Special Session on Disarmament - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: President Adds Job At Payless Cashways
abstract: Payless Cashways Inc. of Kansas City, Mo., which operates a growing chain of do-it-yourself building-materials stores in the Sun Belt, announced the appointment yesterday of David Stanley, president and chief operating officer, to the additional post of chief executive.   Mr. Stanley, 46, replaces J. Stanley Covey, 52, who remains chairman. Mr. Covey decided to relinquish the title ''on his own initiative after 33 years,'' Mr. Stanley said.

headline: WORLD BANK INDIA LOAN
abstract: The World Bank said today that it would lend $200 million to India to help it expand the capacities of its four domestic oil refineries. It said that the loan, repayable in 20 years, included five years' grace and carried an annual interest rate of 11.6 percent. Some of the money for the refineries, two of which are in Bombay, one in Madras and one in Cochin, will be used to install secondary processing facilities to manufacture higher value products from fuel oil, the bank's statement said.

headline: FEW ISSUES SCHEDULED THIS WEEK
abstract: In this holiday-shortened week, investment bankers have scheduled only about $675 million of new notes and bonds for public sale.  Last week $1.5 billion of new issues were offered, according to Moody's Investors Service. Analysts said the reception was generally good for last week's issues, adding that more companies could come to market this week if prices are stable or higher.

headline: McDonald & Little Ends Ralston Assignments
abstract: The most interesting thing about the resignation by McDonald & Little, Atlanta, of its three cereal assignments from Ralston Purina last week - with more than $12 million in billings - is that there seems to be no reason for the step. William M. Claggett, vice president, advertising and marketing services at Ralston, said he thought the agency was doing a super job.

headline: West Bank Arab Dies Of Wounds in Protest
abstract: An Arab man died today of a bullet wound inflicted Friday by an Israeli soldier patrolling Nablus, an army spokesman reported.   Palestinian sources said he was one of about 10 Arabs shot this week by Israeli troops quelling stone-throwing demonstrations in the West Bank and Gaza Strip against Israel's invasion of Lebanon last Sunday.

headline: THE VIDEO GAME SALES WAR
abstract: Everyone, it seems, is trying to enter the home video game business, bringing forth a profusion of new game-playing machines and games.   Where there was once little more than Space Invaders, there are now such games as Space Raiders, Space Wars, Space Battle, Spacechase, Space Fury, Space Cavern, Space Hawk and Space Vultures, not to mention Communist Mutants From Space. Needless to say, the exhibits for all these new games take up a lot of space at the Consumer Electronics Show here, and are clearly the high point of an otherwise somber trade gathering.   The profusion of entrants is not surprising. Home video game cartridges, which sell for $20 to $25 apiece, have been one of the fastest-growing areas of consumer electronics, accounting for an estimated $1.2 billion in sales last year.

headline: Cominco Sale Set
abstract: Cominco Ltd. said that its subsidiary, Cominco American Inc., had agreed to sell oil and gas properties for $31 million to an unnamed buyer.

headline: Notre Dame Cathedral Fire
abstract: An exploding aerosol can set fire to a magazine stand in Notre Dame Cathedral today, interrupting a service. Fire brigades quickly extinguished the fire, damage was slight and there were no injuries.

headline: C.F.T.C. Appointment
abstract: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Fowler C. West, a longtime staff director of the House Agriculture Committee, to be a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Mr. Fowler, a 41-year old Democrat, would succeed David G. Gartner, whose five-year term expired in April.

headline: KEYSTONE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Money Funds Up in Week
abstract: Assets of the nation's 185 money market funds, including two new broker-dealer funds and a new institutional fund, rose by $2.13 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to a record total of $193.34 billion, according to the Investment Company Institute.   The average seven-day yield for major funds during the period, as reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report, was 13.70 percent, compared with 13.48 percent the previous week.

headline: MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Billy Graham, in London, Gets A Religion Prize of $200,000
abstract: The Rev. Billy Graham received the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion at Buckingham Palace today and said he would use the $200,000 award to fight hunger and promote evangelism.   At a ceremony in the palace music room, Mr. Graham received the prize from Prince Philip.  Mr. Graham stopped here en route home from a visit to Moscow, where his comments about the degree of religious freedom in the Soviet Union aroused some controversy.

headline: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CBS Boston Unit
abstract: New England Television Corporation signed an agreement to continue as the CBS affiliate in the Boston market, taking over Channel 7 on Saturday. New England Television, which purchased the building and assets of the station for $22 million from RKO General Inc., will change the call letters from WNAC-TV to WNEV-TV. RKO General lost the right to operate Channel 7 after the Federal Communications Commission ruled that it had failed to disclose that its parent, the General Tire and Rubber Company, was under investigation for bribery and illegal political contributions.

headline: Argentine Newspaper Seeks Government Help on Boycott
abstract: The Buenos Aires Herald appealed to the Government today to intervene in a boycott against it by newspaper distributors who accuse it of being pro-British in the Falkland Islands conflict.

headline: Mexico Orders Inquiry In Killing of 25 Peasants
abstract: Federal authorities have ordered state governments of Veracruz and Puebla to conduct an investigation into the killing of 25 peasants by hired gunmen in a land dispute, the official newspaper El Nacional said today.

headline: SATURDAY, JUNE 26, 1982; Markets
abstract: The nation's basic money supply fell $2.3 billion in the week ended June 16, the Federal Reserve Board reported. Analysts said that the larger-than-expected decline may ease interest rates at a time when the Treasury is planning to raise $18.6 billion in the credit markets. The Fed also revised upward the money supply figure that it reported for the previous week. (Page 31.)   The stock market declined moderately, with about half its losses coming after the announcement of the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.33 points, to 803.08. For the week, the Dow rose 14.44 points.  (35.)

headline: Codi Corporation Files for Chapter 11
abstract: The Codi Corporation and its principal subsidiary, Codi Semiconductor Inc. of Linden, N.J., announced they had filed petitions under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law.

headline: Acquisition by Dun Unit Rumored
abstract: According to unconfirmed Wall Street rumors yesterday, a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, the leading information service and publishing company based in New York, is planning to acquire McCormack & Dodge, one of the nation's top three financial software concerns and a private company based in Needham, Mass. Both companies, however, deny that the acquisition will take place, and Dun & Bradstreet's stock traded normally, closing at 70 3/8, up 7/8 on a volume of 27,900 shares.

headline: Market Place; A Vital Panex From Duplan
abstract: SHAREHOLDERS eliminated in the Duplan Corporation bankruptcy proceeding of August 1976 must envy the new holders in the company - now called Panex.   Its businesses improved so much in the year following its August 1979 reorganization plan that shareholders could have retained an equity -even if creditors had been paid in full, according to a bankruptcy expert.   Panex is one of the nation's leading button producers and is an important producer of children's and women's private-label underwear, according to Daniel Rosenbloom, company chairman. Mr.  Rosenbloom and Andreas Gal, president and chief executive officer, both joined the company in June of last year, after the reorganization was approved.   Edward I. Altman, professor of finance at New York University's Graduate School of Business and an expert on bankruptcy, was critical of theplan a year after it was submitted because of the company's improved circumstances after writing off locing operations.

headline: SYRIA CALLS FOR ATTACKS ON U.S. INTERESTS IN MIDEAST
abstract: The leaders of the political parties represented in the Syrian National Assembly tonight issued an appeal to ''Arab masses'' everywhere to show their solidarity with the Palestinians in Lebanon by ''attacking and destroying American interests'' in the Arab world.   The Syrian parties also called for the upgrading of Syria's friendship treaty with the Soviet Union into a full-scale ''strategic alliance,'' apparently along the lines of the strategic alliance concluded by the United States and Israel.   The declaration said all Arabs ''must know that Syria and our people have chosen to mingle our blood with that of the Palestinians and that we will continue to fight to protect the Palestinian people.'' It was issued by the leadership of the National Progressive Front, which consists of the ruling Baath Party of President Hafez al-Assad and several small parties.

headline: TASS INDICATES MOSCOW VIEW OF WARHEAD CUTS IS NEGATIVE
abstract: The Soviet Union did not comment today on President Reagan's proposal for missile reductions but indicated, in a Tass account, that it would apparently not accept his proposal for both sides to reduce their stock of warheads.   The official Soviet press agency indicated that it viewed Mr.  Reagan's call for a one-third reduction in missile warheads as a bid to gain concessions.   Tass delayed its report of Mr. Reagan's speech in Eureka, Ill., for more than 20 hours, suggesting that particular care was taken with the initial assessment. The impression of caution was reinforced by the fact that Tass offered no criticism of its own, only citing negative comments by Americans.

headline: CHIP MAKER'S TALE OF WOE
abstract: tech company he built into one of the most aggressive, profitable and quality-conscious in California's Silicon Valley is facing its first losses ever, with little relief in sight.   The company's fortunes changed quickly. Its 1981 fiscal year, that ended last May, was an occasion for cheering, as sales topped $1 billion and profits were a record $52.4 million. It seemed as though nothing could slow National as it joined Hewlett-Packard as only the second $1 billion company in Silicon Valley.

headline: Regulation of Agents Backed
abstract: The travel agency business should not be deregulated, an administrative law judge said today in a recommendation to the Civil Aeronautics Board.   Judge Ronnie A. Yoder said the industry's structure should not be changed and travel agents should be allowed to continue to act with immunity from antitrust laws through the Air Traffic Conference, as they have done for 35 years.

headline: MORE RESIGNATIONS ARE SOUGHT IN BRITAIN
abstract: Opposition members of Parliament called for more resignations today from the Cabinet of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher over its handling of the Falkland Islands crisis.   The demands came in the wake of reports that the Government was secretly warned at least 10 days ago of the imminent Argentine invasion of the Falkland Islands. And they came despite the resignation Monday of Lord Carrington, the Foreign Secretary, which has clearly left critics unsatisfied.   The invasion occurred last Friday.  ''With regard to resignation, no,'' said Mrs. Thatcher, almost shouting, when she was asked in the House of Commons to quit. ''Now is the time for strength and resolution.''

headline: AUCTION SET FOR MOTEL WHERE DR. KING DIED
abstract: The Lorraine Motel, where the Rev. Dr.  Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated on April 4, 1968, will be put up for auction at noon next Tuesday if a loan payment cannot be met.   Walter Bailey, who owns the motel, said he received a notice of foreclosure last weekend from Harry Sauer, a Memphis businessman.

headline: IN CORDOBA, ARAB HOAXER ISN'T OIL RICH
abstract: For a time there were visions at City Hall here of a great infusion of Arabs' surplus oil revenues to bolster Cordoba's sagging finances. But these visions seem to be fading.   At one point, they led to a confrontation between Mayor Julio Anguita, a 40-year-old Communist who has proclaimed his indifference to all religions, and the 62-year-old Roman Catholic Bishop of Cordoba, Jose Antonio Infantes Florido.   The visions began when the Mayor heard of the visit to Cordoba by an Arab who said he was an adviser to King Khalid of Saudi Arabia.  The story was told by Hamid Sellan, son of a Spanish father and a Moroccan mother, who used to call himself by his Christian name, Jaime, when he started work years ago in the Cordoba garden maintenance department.

headline: Semiconductor In Arizona Move
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., said it had expanded its successful systems division by opening an additional development center in Mesa, Ariz., and increasing research and development spending by 67 percent, to $10 million a year from $6 million spent in the year ended May 31, 1982.   The systems division, the nation's leading producer of supermarket checkout devices, captured 33 percent of last year's sales to the top 10 supermarket chains.

headline: AT U.N., TALKS ARE 'MOVING' BUT NEW PROBLEMS CROP UP
abstract: An intense round of talks to end the Falkland Islands conflict took place here today, but new problems reportedly raised by Argentina and Britain suggested that a substantial gap remains between the two sides.   Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar met separately this morning and again in the afternoon with Enrique Ros, the Argentine Deputy Foreign Minister, and Sir Anthony Parsons, the British delegate to the United Nations. Another set of discussions has been scheduled for Sunday, and Sir Anthony told reporters he expected that ''I will be coming and going two or three times a day for the next few days.''   After the long day of talks, the Secretary General's spokesman, Francois Giuliani, said that ''progress has been achieved on some issues'' and that Mr. Perez de Cuellar was working ''to bring the position of the parties closer on the remaining points.''

headline: MACAO, STILL AWAITING 20TH CENTURY, GAMBLES ON
abstract: The round casino on the first floor of the Lisboa Hotel here is always packed with gamblers.  Chinese grandmothers in silk pajamas shuffle across the floor in low-heeled mules carrying green and red plastic bowls filled with pataca, Macao's currency. Carefully dressed Hong Kong businessmen who arrived by hydrofoil from across the Pearl River estuary mingle with the more successful immigrants who walked to this Portuguese territory through the barrier gate from China.   In novels, Macao is the capital of intrigue where beautiful Eurasian women get mixed up with sinister drug dealers or smugglers who use this territory's ancient trading connections with mainland China, Hong Kong and Europe to move valuable pieces of Chinese art.   ''Macao is fiction,'' said Lee Tin Yau, a textile merchant. ''It is a place that exists most vividly in books. Today it is a place to gamble or buy antiques or daydream. Macao was once an important place, a hundred years ago. No more.''

headline: MORTON TO PROCEED WITH SALE OF UNIT
abstract: Morton-Norwich Products said it would proceed with the sale of its pharmaceutical division to the Procter & Gamble Company for $371 million in cash.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS
abstract: Lower interest rates would be good news for the American economy, but many economists are resigned to monetary and fiscal policies that point to double-digit rates through the rest of the year.   As desirable as lower interest rates would be during a recession, many economists said the Federal Reserve has little leeway to bring rates down by pumping more money and credit into the economy.  Shortterm rates have fallen in the last month, as the Fed made credit more available, but analysts said that course of action cannot continue long without igniting expectations of rising inflation, which in turn would cause lenders to demand higher interest rates.   Reductions in estimated Federal budget deficits would help lower rates by reducing Treasury borrowings, but many analysts on Wall Street do not expect meaningful progress on that front until after the fall elections.

headline: BRITAIN'S PREMIER FIRM ON FALKLANDS
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told an anxious House of Commons today that she sought ''a peaceful solution, not a peaceful sellout'' in the Falkland Islands crisis.   Moments later, her Foreign Secretary, Francis Pym, opened the Commons' fifth emergency debate on the crisis by warning members that ''military incidents may occur with increasing frequency as the net closes around the islands.''   The remarks of the two officials reflected both renewed pessimism here toward the peace negotiations at the United Nations and pressure from right-wing members of the governing Conservative Party who have become increasingly upset at signs that the Thatcher Government is prepared to make substantial concessions to achieve a settlement.   In part because the right-wing pressure has included demands for more military action, the day's developments helped reawaken a widespread expectation that a British invasion of the Falklands could come within days.

headline: Harvester Seeking Debt Shift
abstract: The International Harvester Company, the financially troubled manufacturer of farm and construction machinery, is seeking changes in its $4.2 billion debt restructuring agreement in an effort to avoid default, company sources acknowledged today.  Analysts predicted that the restructuring would be accomplished.

headline: ADMINISTRATION PLANNING TO PROCEED WITH TAIWAN ARMS SALES SOON
abstract: The Reagan Administration intends to go ahead with the sale of $60 million in military spare parts to Taiwan in the next few weeks despite warnings from Peking that such sales could endanger Chinese-American relations.   State Department and Congressional sources said today that, while a final decision had not been made yet, the Administration has informed members of Congress that Taiwan had a legitimate need for the spare parts and that a formal notification of the sale would be sent to Congress soon.   The Administration has been involved for several months in what Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has called ''extremely sensitive discussions'' with Peking in an effort to resolve the controversy.

headline: * Allied Corp. and Continental Group said the merger of Supron Energy Corp. into an Allied Corp. subsidiary had been approved at a special meeting of Supron shareholders and had become effective.
abstract: * Consolidated-Bathurst Inc. deferred its previously announced newsprint price increases until June 1.   * General Electric Co. announced the formation of a joint venture in medical imaging equipment with Yokogawa Electric Works Ltd. of Tokyo.

headline: BATTLE OF ARGENTINE ECONOMY
abstract: While the fight for the possession of the Falkland Islands appears over, a battle for control of Argentina's economy is just beginning.   At issue is whether trade patterns can be altered to favor those nations, largely Latin, that sided with Argentina in its conflict with Britain and whether the free market philosophy of Economics Minister Roberto T. Alemann can withstand the pressures on the junta for a policy of Government largesse to deflect the nation's disenchantment and resentment.   The winner of the struggle for control of the economy could emerge with as dubious a trophy as Britain gained in recapturing the islands. The Argentine economy and the windswept archipelago rival each other in bleakness.

headline: Peugeot May Get Japan Tie
abstract: Peugeot S.A., France's second-largest automaker after Renault, has asked the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation to jointly produce small Mitsubishi-style cars in France, the economic newspaper Nihon Keizai reported yesterday.   Mitsubishi is 15 percent owned by the Chrysler Corporation.

headline: BRITAIN REPORTS A FRIGATE DAMAGED IN RAID BY JETS
abstract: Argentine warplanes bombed and damaged the British frigate Plymouth and two landing ships tonight, causing at least five casualties, the Defense Ministry announced.   In the first intensive combat between British ships and enemy jets in the Falkland Islands war in 10 days, two Argentine aircraft were shot down, the ministry said in a statement issued just before midnight. At least five planes were reported damaged, with one possibly destroyed.   In Buenos Aires, the Argentine command said tonight that its planes had attacked British forces making an amphibious landing at Pleasant Bay, 16 miles southwest of Stanley, the islands' capital, sinking a frigate and damaging three landing craft. (Page A22.)

headline: Course Change At Woolworth
abstract: The F.W. Woolworth Company, which lost $16 million in the first quarter of the year, said it would expand its profitable specialty store operations in a departure from its traditional emphasis on variety and discount stores.   Woolworth, based in New York, will also try to bolster its sagging Woolco stores, a full-line discount operation, Richard L. Anderson, president and chief operating officer, told the annual shareholders meeting.

headline: OPEC's Output
abstract: The president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that the oil group was holding its total production to 16 million barrels a day, well below the ceiling of 17.5 million barrels set by the group two months ago as it sought to regain control over world oil markets. Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba also said that OPEC's production in April averaged 15.8 million barrels a day, the lowest in more than a decade.

headline: Economic Scene; Waiting For Recovery
abstract: APROVERB among economists goes, ''If you can't forecast accurately, f orecast often.'' And, as the economy continues to slither downward i n the springtime, economists inside and outside the Government have c ontinued to lower their forecasts. Indeed, it now looks as though t he average of economic forecasts has become the latest lagging i ndicator.   A certain poetic license in forecasting, to be sure, should be extended to the Administration's top politicians, including the President and the Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan. These men feel an obligation to be cheerleaders for the economy.

headline: EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Submarine Saves Refugees
abstract: A United States submarine, the Indianapolis, has rescued a boatload of Vietnamese refugees in the Gulf of Siam, the United States Embassy here said today. An embassy spokesman said that the submarine came upon about 30 refugees in a small craft Wednesday and took them to the Thai port of Sattahip. The submarine had been on its way to a port call at the beach resort of Pattaya in Thailand.

headline: Richard Brower
abstract: Joan Throckmorton, president of Throckmorton Associates (formerly Throckmorton/Zolfo), well known in direct marketing circles, has arranged for Richard Brower Inc., the graphics design firm, to replace Victor F. Zolfo, her creative director, who resigned.

headline: EUROPEANS VS. JAPAN ON TRADE
abstract: The European Economic Community formally asked Japan today to make dramatic changes in trade and foreign investment policies. The community outlined some of the steps it thought Japan should take.   This challenge to Japanese policies by the Common Market, as the community is generally known, is the broadest ever undertaken under provisions of the GATT treaty. It stems from growing frustration with the inability of businesses in Common Market countries to penetrate the Japanese market. The Europeans' trade deficit with Japan has reached about $14 billion a year.

headline: JOHN PAUL TO VISIT ARGENTINA TODAY
abstract: Pope John Paul II will arrive here Friday morning for a two-day visit that is focused on peace but that will be overshadowed by war and politics.   The Pope is coming to Argentina in a hastily arranged trip to balance his tour of Britain, which ended eight days ago. Vatican officials have insisted that the Pope's visit will be pastoral and that he will not be playing an intermediary role between the two countries, which are fighting in the Falkland Islands.   ''The Holy Father will come with words of peace, faith, hope,'' Msgr. Ubaldo Calabresi, the Papal Nuncio here, said in an interview.  ''He has said he supports all negotiations, but he has not been asked to be a mediator or anything similar.''

headline: Extra SSC&B Task
abstract: The Olympus Camera Corporation, marketer of Japanese-made photographic equipment, has given an additional assignment to its agency, SSC&B, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies. It is for its new portable video photography system. The ad budget has not been set yet.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Allis-Chalmers Corp. said it would supply 16 large compressors to the Great Plains Coal Gasification Project in Utah.   * American Hoechst Corp. said discussions had ended on the proposed acquisition by Bay Thermoform Inc. of the Hoechst plastic thermoforming plant in Sandusky, Ohio.

headline: 2 Boeing 757's Ordered
abstract: Lineas Aereas Costarricenses of Costa Rica has ordered two Boeing 757 airplanes worth about $90 million, Boeing said today.

headline: Awaiting the I.R.S.  .
abstract: To the Business Editor: We, who originated the Shared Apreciation Mortgage concept through our affiliate, Advance Mortgage, read Deborah Rankin's fine article (April 18) with great interest.   The main reason that more money has not flowed to this form of investment is not, in our experience, ''the indifference of potential investors.''

headline: Around the World; Soviet Calls Ottawa Ban On Envoy 'Unfriendly'
abstract: The official press agency Tass today described the expulsion of a Soviet diplomat from Canada as a provocation and ''an unfriendly act.''   The agency said there was no truth in the Canadian Government's charges against Mikhail N. Abramov, an official in the Soviet commercial office in Ottawa, who on Thursday was given 10 days to leave the country.   Canada's External Affairs Minister, Mark MacGuigan, said Mr.  Abramov had offered large sums of money for high-technology communications equipment that Western countries had agreed not to sell to the Soviet Union.

headline: ISRAEL AND P.L.O. AGREE TO START CEASE-FIRE AFTER DAY OF EXTENSIVE BOMBING IN BEIRUT
abstract: A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said tonight that as of 9 P.M. Israeli forces in Lebanon would cease firing at the Palestinians in the Beirut area. The announcement came after a day of bombing and shelling in the city and clashes with the guerrillas.   The cease-fire follows a halt to hostilities on Friday between Syrian and Israeli forces. The Foreign Ministry said Israel would retaliate ''with all our might'' if the Palestinians continued military action. Reports from Beirut after the deadline said the fighting had halted.

headline: Wages at Hecla
abstract: The Hecla Mining Company said that it was temporarily rolling back wages and freezing salary adjustments, effective Sunday. It said salaries and wages would be reduced 10 percent for a majority of employees. The directors, president and vice president have accepted a 15 percent reduction.

headline: I.R.A. Explodes a Car Bomb Outside a Nurses' Residence
abstract: A 200-pound car bomb exploded on a busy street outside a nurses' residence at lunchtime today, wounding 25 people with flying glass and brick, the police said.

headline: G.M. ADDS A JAPANESE CAR
abstract: General Motors said its Japanese affiliate, Isuzu Motors, will develop and produce a subcompact car that is expected to replace the Chevrolet Chevette by 1984.

headline: A Long Lines Account To McCann-Erickson
abstract: Ma Bell has picked McCann-Erickson, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to be its agency for the business segment of the Long Lines service, which has just been split off for special attention.  Billings could be more than $20 million.

headline: CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Money Fund Assets Rise
abstract: Assets of the nation's 198 money market mutual funds rose $301 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $191.9 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   The institute, a mutual funds trade organization, attributed the increase to renewed savings after three weeks in which fund assets had declined, largely because of money withdrawn to pay income taxes.

headline: G.M. Employees
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said it was recalling about 3,900 employees at its assembly division here and at a number of component plants to raise production of the Buick Skylark and Oldsmobile Omega.

headline: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EGYPT'S LEADERS GROPE FOR LEBANON SOLUTION
abstract: As criticism increased here of what is considered a dilatory and pro-Israeli response by the United States, President Hosni Mubarak spent the morning with his top aides discussing how they might best press for a rapid and total Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon.   Western diplomats predicted that pressure from Islamic fundamentalists and even the docile opposition parties would mount on the issue of the invasion.   President Mubarak seemed to be banking on a trip to Washington by two of his senior foreign policy advisers.  The two, Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali and Osam el-Baz, who is Mr. Mubarak's closest policy adviser, scheduled their trip to Washington before the invasion of Lebanon. They were originally planning to urge the United States to persuade Israel to back revival of the dormant West Bank autonomy negotiations.

headline: INCOME SURTAX AND LEVY ON FUELS ARE FOCUS OF BUDGET NEGOTIATIONS
abstract: A temporary increase in income taxes, perhaps only for taxpayers above some middle-income threshold, and a broad tax on energy have emerged as much-debated possibilities in the secret, three-sided budget negotiations that resumed today.   House, Senate and Administration negotiators held morning and afternoon sessions but apparently made little progress toward a consensus on how to cut spending and raise revenues. At the request of the House Democrats, the talks were suspended until next week.   A temporary rise in income taxes, in the form of a surtax, is being championed by Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who heads the Finance Committee, according to Senate Republican sources. They said he was talking about a surtax, probably 4 percent for two years starting in 1983, on taxes owed by people whose income surpassed some level, perhaps $30,000 to $40,000.

headline: Gulf Canada Well
abstract: Gulf Canada Ltd. said its East Tarsuit N-44 well in Canada's Beaufort Sea has an estimated sustained production capability of 3,500 barrels of oil a day. It said it had completed testing of the well and would drill further to assess the size of the oil reservoir. Partners in the well are Gulf Canada's Gulf Canada Resources Inc., Dome Petroleum Ltd., Norcen Energy Resources Ltd., the Mobil Corporation's Mobil Oil Canada Ltd. and the Canada Development Corporation's Canterra Energy Ltd.

headline: FOR BRITONS, 'ONLY TIME WE'RE TOGETHER IS WHEN WE'RE AT WAR'
abstract: With its landings on the Falkland Islands, Britain became a country at war today. But having been at a fever pitch of anticipation for days, the news seemed almost anticlimactic.    Well before the first bulletins of landings clicked across the Press Association news wire just after noon, Britain had passed, in the minds of most of its population, from the uncertainty of negotiation to the certainty of military confrontation.   ''It's not surprising,'' said Barbara Crayford, an executive with a multinational company. ''I don't think you can send out the forces without intending to use them.''

headline: COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OLD STONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOUTH AFRICA RECASTING ITS SECURITY LAWS
abstract: While South Africa's attention was focused this week on proposals for constitutional revisions that would give some nonwhites a role in the central Government, the ruling National Party was busy pushing a new version of its body of security laws through the all-white Parliament.   The new acts, which will add to the many restrictions already placed on political demonstrations as well as on the reporting of what are deemed to be matters of internal security, were presented as a refinement of the existing security laws. The authorities thus retain their full arsenal of arbitrary powers to ban organizations and publications; to silence individuals and bar them from political activities, or to detain them indefinitely without any charge or recourse to lawyers or the courts.   The Government of Prime Minister P.W. Botha draws a connection between the proposed political changes and the maintenance of such controls. ''In times of reform, the conflict potential is normally higher than in other times,'' the Minister of Internal Affairs, Jan Christian Heunis, told foreign journalists. ''Because we are a society in transition, it is unavoidable that tensions will rise.''

headline: TEXT OF ISRAELI PEACE PROPOSAL
abstract: Following is the text of Israel's peace plan for Lebanon, as issued here by the Cabinet today: The Cabinet resolved that: 1. Israel will maintain the cease-fire in Lebanon.

headline: PRICES EASE FOR ALL MATURITIES
abstract: After two days of rising prices, the credit markets cooled off yesterday as slight price declines resulted in higher yields for all maturities.   By late in the day, rates for most securities due in three months or less were higher by almost an eighth of a percentage point, except for three-month Treasury bills. They were 12.78 percent, compared with 12.85 percent at Monday's auction. Prices of many Treasury note and bond issues fell by half a point or more, with the 14 percent bond due in 2011 closing at 104 3/4 to yield 14.32 percent after being as high as 105 3/4 early in the day. At the end of last week the three-month bill was 13.12 percent and the 30-year bond was 102 3/8 to yield 13.66 percent.

headline: 2 Koreas Exchange Gunfire
abstract: North Korea and South Korea exchanged gunfire today for the third time this year across the demilitarized zone dividing the Korean peninsula, the Defense Ministry in Seoul said.

headline: Pratt & Whitney
abstract: Pratt & Whitney said that six American and European companies would begin collaboration with it on the development of a new aircraft engine.

headline: Consumer Debt Up Bit In February
abstract: American consumers took on only $75 million more in installment debt than they paid off in February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The report offered more evidence of the recession, with Americans reluctant to buy relatively expensive items on credit.   February's rise in the amount of credit outstanding translated into an annual rate of gain of less than five-tenths of 1 percent, the report said, compared with an annual growth rate of 6.8 percent a year earlier.

headline: VOLCKER ON BUDGET BALANCING
abstract: In an unexpected shift of view, Paul A.  Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, moved close today to support of a constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget. But he warned against allowing the amendment proposal to divert attention from solving the Government's present fiscal crisis.   Mr. Volcker, appearing before a House subcommittee, expressed sympathy for the idea of the amendment but ''great caution'' about the way it is now drafted.   He did not call for enactment of the amendment, as President Reagan did last week.  Nonetheless, Mr. Volcker's testimony and his comments in an interview afterwards were plainly more sympathetic to the proposed amendment than his last pronouncement, made a year ago. At that time he suggested that other methods of reducing budget deficits be tried first before resorting to a constitutional amendment to strengthen the Government's fiscal discipline.

headline: SENATE PANEL CLEARS BILL THAT COULD ASSIST TRADE
abstract: The Senate Finance Committee today overwhelmingly approved an Administration-supported bill strengthening the powers of the President to negotiate lower foreign trade barriers.   The bill, which its backers and the Administration say is intended to promote free trade, would give the President for the first time a specific legislative mandate to negotiate the reduction of trade barriers to American investments and services. Gives Tariff Authority   It also permits the President to offer to lower American tariffs on high-technolgy products such as computers and semiconductors in return for greater access for such American products in foreign markets.   The Reagan Administration is hoping to open negotiations for a reduction of trade barriers at a ministerial conference in Geneva in November of the 87 signatories to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The agreement sets up a process for negotiating solutions to trade disputes among member nations.

headline: EXECUTIVE PAY RISING
abstract: Recent statistics confirm that the recession and a slower rate of inflation are having a tangible impact on wage settlements among organized workers: First-year pay increases on contracts negotiated in the first quarter rose a paltry 2.2 percent. But assessments of trends in executive compensation differ on just how much the downturn is affecting what managers are paid.

headline: FOR SANDINISTS, AN EX-ALLY'S CHALLENGE
abstract: The denunciation of the Nicaraguan Government by one of its revolutionary heroes could signal the creation of a new center of opposition to the Sandinist regime, according to diplomats, Congressional aides who specialize in the area and Central American politicians here.   The challenge to Managua to rid itself of Marxism and the Soviet-Cuban military presence was made Thursday in San Jose, Costa Rica, by Eden Pastora - the ''Comandante Zero'' whose silhouette with a gun raised in defiance became a hallmark of Nicaragua's revolution.   Mr. Pastora, 45 years old, left the Government of Nicaragua in June 1981 after a long period of quiet disagreement over the influence of Cuba in the Sandinist leadership. He remains a dedicated leftist, he said, and has made clear through representatives in this country that he does not want United States Government help.

headline: FACET ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Visit to China Keeping Rumanian Leader Busy
abstract: Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, conferred today with Hu Yaobang, the Chinese Communist Party chairman, on the third day of an official visit.

headline: Getty Oil Planning Coast Energy Plant
abstract: The Getty Oil Company and the Southern California Edison Company said that they had signed an agreement to contract for a proposed cogeneration plant in the Kern River oilfield near Bakersfield, Calif.   The facility, if built, would produce about 17 percent of the steam that Getty needs to pump the heavy oil from the ground, as well as electricity for Edison's customers.   ''One of Getty's largest expenses now are associated with production costs to lift that heavy oil,'' said Sandi H. Sweeney, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein Inc. ''If this reduces their costs, it could be very helpful to Getty's bottom line.''

headline: CONSPIRACY CHARGED
abstract: Iran confirmed today that former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh had been arrested. The Teheran radio said that he was accused of plotting to assassinate Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and the members of Iran's Supreme Defense Council.

headline: CANADA CUTS LEVY ON ENERGY
abstract: The Canadian Government tonight announced financial concessions to the depressed oil and gas industry in a bid to revive exploration and development activity. The tax reductions and credits are designed to increase revenue to the industry by $2 billion (Canadian) by 1986.   But no concessions were made to American and other foreign companies that have complained both of discriminatory treatment and of a federal ''grab'' of their potential earnings.   Energy Minister Marc Lalonde, reacting to universal complaints from oil and gas companies of drastically reduced cash flows since the National Energy Program was introduced in October l980, declared in a House of Commons speech that the plan ''is working on all fronts and will continue to work.''

headline: P.&G. Confirms F.T.C. Inquiry
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company confirmed reports that it has been under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission for two years, but would not comment on reports of allegations that it was involved in anticompetitive practices.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: Last week's article on the steel industry incorrectly described the expense of the Inland Steel Company's mill expansion.

headline: 2 FRENCH CABINET AIDES REPLACED
abstract: Two Cabinet ministers were replaced today in France's first Government changes since President Francois Mitterrand's Socialists swept to power a year ago.   Announcing what Government sources described as a technical shuffle, the presidential spokesman, Michel Vauzelle, said Pierre Dreyfus, the Industry Minister, and Nicole Questiaux, Minister for National Solidarity, had stepped down.

headline: A SOFT VIDEO RECORDER MARKET
abstract: Until recently, Japan simply could not make enough videotape recorders to satisfy the world.  Not long after the market had its beginnings seven years ago, the videotape recorder boom was off and going. Led by Matsushita Electric, Sony and the Japan Victor Company, the manufacturers kept adding production capacity at a torrid pace, with an annual doubling of output becoming the norm.   Yet, try as they might, the companies seemed unable to keep up with the demands of buyers eager to record television shows for later viewing or to buy or rent movies for showing at home.

headline: AMERICAN GENERAL REJECTS NLT OFFER
abstract: Directors of the American General Corporation unanimously rejected a recent tender offer from the NLT Corporation at a special board meeting yesterday, charging that it was an attempt to thwart an earlier takeover bid for NLT by American General.   American General called NLT's bid of $50 a share, or about $600 million, for 48 percent of the company ''inadequate, unsound and of questionable legality'' and said that it had filed suit yesterday against NLT in Federal court in Houston to enjoin NLT from proceeding with its offer. Both American General and NLT are major insurance companies.

headline: Patents; Television Channel Identifier
abstract: WASHINGTON THE millions of users of video games, home computers and other facilities linked to television are promised a way to connect them quickly. A channel identifier patented this week for the RCA Corporation will signal the proper receiver channel to be plugged in.

headline: NO MOHASCO TAKEOVER, BUT BAIL OUT ANYWAY
abstract: ''Golden parachutes,'' the latest perquisite in the executive suite, help officers bail out of a bad situation if their company is taken over by another.   But at the Mohasco Corporation, a maker of carpets and furniture, including the Barcalounger reclining chair, four top executives were able to use their golden parachutes although no takeover took place.

headline: BREZHNEV AFFIRMS READINESS TO TALK ON STRATEGIC ARMS
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev voiced readiness today for talks on strategic nuclear arms but said President Reagan's plan for cuts was one-sided and prejudicial to Moscow's security. The Soviet leader countered with a proposal for a nuclear freeze as soon as the arms talks begin.   He said Mr. Reagan's announcement that the United States was now ready to resume talks was ''a step in the right di- Excerpts from speech, page A8. rection.'' He also said Mr. Reagan's call for reductions in strategic, or long-range, missiles was in line with the Soviet position in favor of substantial cuts.

headline: GREEK COMMUNISTS ASSAIL SOCIALISTS
abstract: Greece's governing Socialist Party and the pro-Moscow Greek Communist Party, which once followed similar anti-Western foreign policies, have split as a result of the Government's adoption of a more cooperative attitude toward the West and of moderate domestic policies.   Socialists say the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou can afford such a split because their party has strong electoral superiority over the Communists and has no need to share power. The Government holds 173 seats in the 300-member Parliament; the conservative opposition has 115 seats and the Communists have 12.

headline: Arafat Welcomed in Pakistan After 3 Days of Talks in India
abstract: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, was welcomed in Pakistan today after three days of talks in India with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who joined him in condemning what they called Israeli aggression.   Pakistani officials gave Mr. Arafat a rousing ovation when he stepped off a special plane from New Dehli for two days of talks, and honor guards fired a 21-gun salute.

headline: U.S. AND PERU PRESENT A NEW SET OF PROPOSALS
abstract: The United States and Peru discussed with Britain and Argentina today a new set of proposals for ending the fighting over the Falkland Islands, Administration and diplomatic sources said.   The latest effort to resolve the Falkland crisis through diplomatic efforts parallels a similar and concurrent move by the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, who has also sent ideas for stopping the fighting to both Argentina and Britain.   At the United Nations, Mr. Perez de Cuellar said the Argentines had given a ''positive reaction'' to the peace plan he presented. In Buenos Aires, the Argentine Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, awaited definite word on the scheduling of a Security Council meeting before leaving for talks in New York.

headline: GANDHI SIDE TAKING 3 OF 4 STATES
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's loyalists appeared today to have gained control of three of the four state legislatures elected last week, but they failed to win clear-cut majorities and declined in electoral popularity.   In two states the results were unambiguous. In West Bengal the Marxist-led alliance that has been in power five years increased its legislative representation handily, and in Kerala Mrs. Gandhi's Congress Party became dominant with the help of a handful of anti-Marxist groups.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: DEFENDER OF THE FAITH
abstract: Last July, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan was looking ahead. The President's spending cuts had been approved by Congress and the three-year tax cut was nearly assured.   The Secretary, in an interview then, talked about deregulation of the financial industry - the accomplishment he hoped would mark his years at Treasury.   Mr. Regan, out of Wall Street less than a year, was still new to Washington, Capitol Hill, taxes, economic policy, recessions and budget deficits. It was a measure of his political naivete at the time that he felt the battle was won.

headline: OUR TAXES HELP PAY THE SAUDI 'RANSOM'
abstract: PRICE differences and the lingering surplus in the international oilm arket in the first quarter appear to have placed the four Aramco p artners, Exxon, Socal, Mobil and Texaco - together with American t axpayers - in the unusual position of directly subsidizing Saudi A rabia with as much as $25 million a day and indirectly supporting t he preferred price structure of the Organization of Petroleum E xporting Countries. Whether that process should be termed subsidy or' 'blackmail,'' as others have suggested, is open to serious question.  During most of the first quarter, the companies were paying the official OPEC price of $34 a barrel while the spot market crude oil price was much lower. To do so in the face of earnings declines and continuing oversupply indicates that the partners in the Arabian American Oil Company found themselves relatively powerless to object to: (A) paying a $5 a barrel premium for Saudi oil, and (B) lifting approximately 5 million barrels of oil daily, whether they wanted that much or not. The four oil companies continue to carefully avoid protesting openly, presumably for fear of evoking Saudi anger that could lead to permanent expulsion of the first company to protest too much.

headline: Oil Imports Off in Europe
abstract: The 10 members of the European Economic Community imported 2.63 billion barrels of oil in 1981, substantially below the 3.47-billion-barrel target ceiling set in 1979, according to the annual energy survey by the community's executive commission.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE POPE'S REMARKS
abstract: Following are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's speech on the family at Knavesmire Racecourse near York today, as supplied by the Vatican Press Office:   In a marriage a man and a woman pledge themselves to one another in an unbreakable alliance of total mutual self-giving, a total union of love - love that is not a passing emotion or temporary infatuation but a responsible and free decision to bind oneself completely ''in good times and in bad'' to one's partner. It is the gift of oneself to the other. It is a love to be proclaimed before the eyes of the whole world. It is unconditional.   The love of husband and wife in God's plan leads beyond itself and new life is generated, a family is born.  Christian marriage is a sacrament of salvation. It is the pathway to holiness for all members of a family. With all my heart, therefore, I urge that your homes be centers of prayer; homes where families are at ease in the presence of God; homes to which others are invited to share hospitality, prayer and the praise of God.

headline: TPC COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Premiums, Incentives And Sales
abstract: THE first prospect to pass the comparatively small exhibition booth that Laurence F. Good of Wheeling, W.Va., was manning at the Premium Incentive Show at the New York Coliseum yesterday was inundated with a enthusiastic flood of information about the Personal History System. It is Mr. Good's creation.   Like about 200 of the 1,150 exhibitors, Mr. Good is a first-timer at the show, which will be running through Thursday, and, as for most of them, the show is Mr. Good's first attempt at the big time.

headline: Chicago Risks Losing 2 Stores
abstract: Two of the nation's biggest retailers, Sears, Roebuck and Company and Montgomery Ward & Company, may close their stores on State Street, once one of the nation's busiest shopping districts.   Sears and Ward's, both founded and based in Chicago, are ''evaluating their opportunities,'' said Charles G. Gardner, a business leader.

headline: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Chief of Allen-Bradley Adds Title of Chairman
abstract: Claude R. Whitney, 58, has been named chairman of the privately held Allen-Bradley Company, a Milwaukee-based manufacturer and marketer of industrial automation control products. Mr. Whitney, who currently serves as vice chairman and chief executive officer, will succeed I. Andrew Rader, 67, who will retire Nov. 30.   Mr. Rader will continue as chairman of the company's executive committee.

headline: PCA International Goes To Rosenfeld, Sirowitz
abstract: PCA International, in Matthews, N.C., which operates permanent and temporary photographic portrait studios in department stores in the United States, Canada and four other countries, is going to Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson for $14 million worth of broadcast, print and point-of-sale advertising.   The agency was selected by E. Michael Roche, vice president, advertising and sales promotion, recently arrived from McCann-Erickson, where he was executive vice president.

headline: Shawmut Bank Merger
abstract: The Shawmut Corporation and the Worcester Bancorp said today that they had completed their $47.3 million merger.   Shawmut has assets of about $4 billion, while Worcester has assets of about $1 billion.

headline: ILLINOIS SUIT AIMED AT PEOPLES ENERGY
abstract: The Peoples Energy Corporation, a holding company that owns two public utilities here, was accused today by the Cook County State's Attorney of conspiring to defraud natural gas consumers of $100 million.   The civil suit filed against Peoples Energy and other defendants, which asks for triple damages amounting to $300 million, contended that during the past five years, the holding company diverted utility revenue to high-risk investments in nonutilities, then divested these as the investments became profitable.   The suit charged that after the enterprises were spun off to the Midcon Corporation, another holding company named as a defendant, Peoples Energy ended a longstanding practice of putting part of the income it received from utilities back into them through stock purchases and loans.   As a result, Richard M. Daley, the Cook County Attorney, contended in the suit, the utilities have become so cash-starved that they have asked the Illinois Commerce Commission for permission to raise rates to natural gas customers by 45 percent, to generate $100 million.

headline: Massey Layoffs
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said it would lay off about 700 employees, or about half a shift, at its Brantford combine plant next Monday, and about 100 of the 1,000 hourly paid employees at its Toronto combine-parts facility. The company cited depressed worldwide sales for machinery.

headline: NEW FUNDS FOR ALSANDS
abstract: In an effort to revive the Alsands oil sands project, a $13.1 billion (Canadian) complex designed to extract oil from the tar sands of Western Alberta, the federal and Alberta governments said today that they would be willing to acquire a combined 50 percent equity stake in the project.   The two governments, which until today had resisted suggestions that they take a direct stake in the foundering project, said they would also guarantee up to 68 percent of any loans made by the private partners or other investors in the pre-production period.   Canadian Energy Minister Marc Lalonde said that the remaining 50 percent of direct investment would have to be made by the private sector. Currently, private interests hold a 33 percent stake and industry executives estimate that private funding of about $1 billion (Canadian) will be necessary to continue the project.

headline: GEOSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WHY ISRAELIS INVADED NOW
abstract: Israel's invasion of Lebanon came today as the culmination of months of military and political calculation in which Prime Minister Menachem Begin repeatedly allowed the troops to be massed and the saber to be rattled, only to pull back at what seemed like the last moment. Until today the crucial factors favoring a major assault never quite lined up, and the risks seemed greater than the potential benefits.   This time, however, Mr. Begin decided to make the military gamble and to pay the political costs that he and his advisers know exist.  The crucial reason was the intensive shelling of northern Israel by forces of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which began Friday afternoon after Israeli air strikes on Palestinian bases near Beirut.    The Israeli command described the air raids as retaliation for the shooting Thursday of Israel's Ambassador to Britain, Shlomo Argov, who was critically wounded in London. Five suspects, all traveling on passports from Arab countries, were captured. The P.L.O. denied any responsibility for the attack.

headline: OUTPOSTS IN ISLAND CAMPAIGN
abstract: The settlements of Goose Green and Darwin, situated two miles apart on a narrow isthmus that connects the two main sections of East Falkland Island, are clusters of farm houses surrounded by corrals, hen houses and auxiliary sheds related to the raising of sheep.   The settlements are each said to have a population of 80 to 140.

headline: NLT Offer Begins; New Bid on Table
abstract: The American General Corporation of Houston said that its tender offer of $38 a share in cash for 15 million common shares, or 43 percent, of the NLT Corporation of Nashville began yesterday.  However, American General noted that it had proposed a second, higher bid of $46 a share, conditioned on the approval and recommendation by NLT's directors.

headline: IN THE PUBS, BRITONS ARE LINKED BY CONCERN FOR PRINCE ANDREW
abstract: Because they almost always do on a Saturday, Alice and Hilda Morgan went down to the King's Arms Pub around noon today for a gin and tonic and a chat with their neighbors.   But the two women, sisters in their late 50's, said the tone of the place seemed different than usual.  ''Somber,'' Hilda Morgan said as she nibbled at a vinegar-flavored potato chip. ''I think everyone is thinking of the British boys over there on that cold island near Argentina.''

headline: MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The depressed economy slashed corporate profits in the first quarter. Hardest hit were the auto, steel, airline and other cyclical industries. Although banks profited handsomely from high interest rates, brokerage houses heavily dependent on retail trade showed large declines. (Page D1.)

headline: FIRST BANKERS CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WOMETCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr toMarch 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: C.A.B. Official to Be A Dean at Carnegie
abstract: Elizabeth E. Bailey, the 43-year-old vice chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, will resign in the summer of 1983 to become dean of the Graduate School of Industrial Administration at Carnegie-Mellon Univesity in Pittsburgh.   She will succeed Robert Kaplan, 41, the dean since 1977, who will return to teaching as a professor of industrial administration. She will be the first woman to head a major graduate business school, her office said.

headline: MUBARAK PRAISES ISRAELIS' ATTITUDE
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak said today that the restoration of Egyptian sovereignty over Sinai was a ''magnificant achievement'' and that in returning the land ''the people of Israel have shown an enthusiasm for peace.''   The Egyptian leader addressed a cheering Parliament on Sunday's return of the last portion of Sinai, which Israel captured in the 1967 war. The hourlong speech was nationally televised.

headline: STOCK MARKET DOLDRUMS
abstract: Equity investors had little reason to cheer last quarter, as tumbling corporate profits and the continuing impasse over the budget kept stock prices down. With only one or two exceptions, however, things were even worse on stock exchanges elsewhere in the world.

headline: Tobacco Plant to Close
abstract: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, a subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries, said today that it would stop production at its cigarette manufacturing plant here on July 30. The company, which said it would keep its corporate headquarters here, plans to shift its operations to a modern plant in Macon, Ga. The shutdown will eliminate more than 800 salaried and hourly jobs at the plant.

headline: Black Cleric Is Banned In South Africa Again
abstract: The Roman Catholic Church's top official in southern Africa received a three-year banning order today, the day his first five-year order expired, church officials said.   The Government order imposes a kind of internal exile on the official, the Rev. Smangaliso Mkhatshwa, secretary general of the Southern African Catholic Bishops Conference.

headline: REAGAN DEFENDS BRITISH ACTIONS, SAYING AGGRESSION MUST BE HALTED
abstract: President Reagan strongly defended Britain's military actions in the Falkland crisis today, asserting that ''armed aggression as originally took place there must not be allowed to succeed.''   In an interview with television reporters from France, Italy, Britain and West Germany, countries he will visit on his European tour, Mr. Reagan said he could not predict ''the right moment for a negotiated settlement.''   ''I would hope it could come before there is further loss of life on either side,'' he said. ''And we stand ready to do anything we can, as we have for all these many weeks, to bring about a peaceful solution and resolution of this problem.''

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE THATCHER ADDRESS
abstract: Following are excerpts from a speech delivered yesterday to the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, as provided by the British Mission to the United Nations:   The stated purpose of this Special Session is disarmament. The underlying and more important purpose is peace: not peace at any price, but peace with freedom and justice.   Leaders of countries from every part of the globe come to this session in search of surer ways of preserving that peace. Ways that enable the peoples of each sovereign state to lead their lives as they choose within established borders.   If arms control helps us to achieve those central aims more surely and at less cost, we must pursue it vigorously. But if it is carried out in a way which damages peace, we must resist it, recalling that there have been occasions when the known or perceived military weakness of an opponent has been at least as potent a cause of war as military strength. The true definition of disarmament should be the balanced and verifiable reduction of armaments in a manner which enhances peace and security.

headline: More Jingles
abstract: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''There's a Song in Their Art'' (May 2), jingles substitute for strong selling ideas, especially when these ideas are either in short supply, or the product is not significantly different than the competition, or in situations where the probability of brand switching is high.   Jingles have been used with all classes of products and services.

headline: Swift to Purchase Slaughtering Plant
abstract: The Swift Independent Packing Company, the processor of fresh meat that was spun off by Esmark Inc., announced that it had tentatively agreed to acquire an idle boxed-beef plant at Hereford, Tex., from Armour & Company. The price was not disclosed.

headline: BANGLADESH MILITARY LEADER SAYS HE FEARS SOVIET
abstract: Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad, this nation's new military ruler, said in an interview today that he believed the Soviet Union was ''very dangerous.''   He also said that Bangladesh felt nothing but friendship toward the United States and that he thought President Reagan was a strong leader.   General Ershad also confirmed reports that two Soviet Embassy attaches were arrested a week ago while trying, for thus far unexplained reasons, to set fire to nearly 600 reels of movie film. Firm on Rooting Out Corruption   In the 75-minute interview, the soft-spoken general, who on March 24 suspended constitutional government, also made the following points:   - Not even family ties with army officers will save the lives of former Cabinet ministers if they are found guilty by military tribunals of corruption. ''We can hang them,'' General Ershad said.

headline: LINK TO TRADE TALKS IS DENIED BY U.S.
abstract: A Justice Department official denied today that its charges accusing employees of two Japanese computer companies of trying to steal trade secrets from I.B.M. were intended to exert pressure on Japan in trade negotiations.   The statement, at a news conference here, followed the Government's announcement on Tuesday that an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation had foiled two separate efforts to steal computer secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation. The efforts reportedly involved employees of Japan's Hitachi Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, both major computer manufacturers.   In Tokyo today, Hitachi admitted making $540,000 in payments for I.B.M. information, less than the $622,000 that the F.B.I. said was paid by Hitachi officials. But the Japanese computer giant said that it was still studying the legality of the action. Mitsubishi denied any wrongdoing.

headline: Mortgage Aid Bill Is Backed
abstract: A Senate committee today approved a bill to provide substantial Government mortgage subsidies for low- and moderate-income families despite signs that the Reagan Administration would oppose any such moves as too costly.   The housing provision, which its sponsors maintain would permit the construction of more than 350,000 new homes this year and put 700,000 Americans back to work, was passed by the Senate Banking Committee.

headline: JAPAN, MEET WOODY ALLEN
abstract: TOKYO After nearly a decade, foreign celebrities are no longer the advertising novelty they once were. In the last year or so, Japanese advertisers have grown picky. Not just any famous foreigner will do.

headline: Economic Analysis
abstract: There is hardly a sector of the economy now that has not been stymied by high interest rates. But there is no agreement on how to bring them down. Congress wants more money growth, in exchange for lower deficits, while the ''monetarists'' contend that such growth would just push interest rates up by reigniting fears of inflation.
