At the center of the dispute, as always, stands the Federal Reserve Board, and the Fed, faced with a continuing sharp recession, is in the tightest corner it has been since its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, set his anti-inflation course in October 1979.   Mr. Volcker and other governors of the Fed, according to interviews with members of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee, contend that they have very little room to maneuver in and, at each turning point, face the risk of prolonging the recession, thwarting the recovery or losing much of the ground that has been gained on inflation.

headline: Gulf Resources Accord Is Sought
abstract: Lawyers for Alan E. Clore, leader of a dissident stockholders committee of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, said last week that the group had appealed to the company's directors to ''terminate wasteful litigation.''   The committee, which has won control of the company in a proxy fight, according to preliminary tally, charged in a letter mailed to all 14 directors that ''management's determination to continue this fight is harmful to the company and to the interests of its stockholders.''

headline: INVESTING; GOLD'S GLITTER THROUGH DARK GLASSES
abstract: Just how far can gold slide? Recession, unusual Soviet selling, high interest rates and declining inflation have knocked the stuffing out of gold. Not even a full-fledged shooting war has managed to revive the precious metal, traditionally the first refuge of frightened money.  Gold began the year just under $600 an ounce, sank to a low of $312, and now seems stuck in the middle $300 range, if not lower. The outbreak of fighting between Britain and Argentina has done no more than send gold on a spike to $367. In cash markets and commodity pits alike, it has been a dull showing indeed for gold.

headline: Coffee Makers Reduce Prices
abstract: The nation's major coffee producers have cut their wholesale prices as much as 10 cents a pound, effective immediately. But it will take two months for lower consumer prices to show up at supermarkets.

headline: BIRD & SON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dome Petroleum In Talks on Debt
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the largest independent oil company in Canada, has been holding discussions with the federal Government, its bankers and private financial sources in an effort to renegotiate the scheduling of its major principal repayments.

headline: Dillingham Corp., Ala Moana Sued
abstract: Ala Moana Hawaii Properties said that a class action suit had been filed against it, its general partners and the Dillingham Corporation in Federal District Court here, accusing them of violations of Federal securities laws.   The company added, however, that it had not yet been served court papers and would not comment on the suit.

headline: A LEADER OF SALVADORAN PEASANTS ASSERTS 25 ARE EVICTED EVERY DAY
abstract: The leader of one of the country's largest peasant agricultural organizations said today that 25 to 30 peasants were being evicted from their land daily. But he said the rate of evictions had declined since the country's provisional President and the Minster of Defense pledged to help the peasants.   Landowners began evicting peasants last month after the Constituent Assembly suspended Decree 207, commonly known as the Land to the Tiller Law. Under the 1980 law, future renting of land was prohibited and peasants renting at the time acquired the right to buy their plots.

headline: BIG 3 AUTO SALES UP 8.3% LED BY 15.5% G.M. GAIN
abstract: On the strength of a 15.5 percent increase in car sales by the General Motors Corporation, sales by the nation's Big Three auto makers rose 8.3 percent in the middle 10 days of April compared with the same period last year, the companies said today.  It was the highest sales increase this year.   Together, General Motors, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation sold 153,890 cars, compared with 142,153 sold a year ago. Ford's sales rose 1.7 percent and Chrysler's declined 12.4 percent.

headline: ELECTED HONDURAN GOVERNMENT'S PROBLEMS MOUNT
abstract: When elections last January led to the installation of this country's first civilian Government in a decade, Hondurans were hopeful that social and economic changes would soon bring an improvement in the quality of their lives.   The new President, Roberto Suazo Cordova, aware of the economic crisis that he inherited, warned against excessive expectations, but he too was confident that the United States would somehow reward Honduras for returning to democracy by providing a large injection of aid.   That optimism has now given way to disenchantment, not only among the population at large, which has watched unemployment grow and prices rise while wages have remained frozen, but also within the Government, which is openly disappointed with the Reagan Administration's response to its pleas for help. 'Later Could Be Too Late'   ''It is lamentable that we find little in this praiseworthy initiative to solve the short-term problems faced by this country and the region,'' Mr. Suazo Cordova said after the announcement of President Reagan's program to promote economic development in the Caribbean basin. ''Belated or insufficient economic aid could be like no aid. If no action is taken soon, later could be too late.''

headline: MOSINEE PAPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: P.L.O.-DOMINATED WEST BEIRUT: ARMED CAMP IN CROWDED CAPITAL
abstract: Much of west Beirut, particularly the coastline from the American Embassy to the airport and the Palestinian-controlled inland areas south of the Corniche Mazraa road, has been turned into an armed camp. Huge mounds of dirt have been heaped on the roads to deter tanks, and the streets have been dug up so mines can be planted.   If Israeli troops try to attack the remaining Palestinian strongholds in the refugee camps on the southern edge of Beirut, they could become embroiled in bitter house-to-house fighting throughout the western half of the Lebanese capital.   The effect of the fighting on west Beirut's civilian population was illustrated once again yesterday as Israeli gunboats shelled the apartments and closed embassies along the once lovely seafront. At least five shells fell into the New Malis building, a distinctive luxury high-rise inhabited almost entirely by Western diplomats and journalists. At least 20 people were killed by the coastal shelling, according to the police. On Wednesday Israeli planes strafed the nearby residential neighborhood of Raushe.

headline: Israeli Shelling Is Said to Hit Red Cross Center in Lebanon
abstract: A center of the International Committee of the Red Cross has been destroyed by Israeli shelling of the Lebanese port of Sidon, a Red Cross official said today.

headline: U.S. Opposes Grain Plan
abstract: The United States, Canada and Australia, the world's largest grain exporters, have expressed reservations about a grain reserve plan supported by the third world.

headline: McLouth Can Sell Its Trucking Unit
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge allowed the McLouth Steel Corporation to sell its trucking subsidiary to R-W Service System Inc. of Taylor, Mich., for $7 million, an official of the trucking company said.   Judge George Woods on Friday had postponed the sale to give Centra Inc. of Sterling Heights, Mich., a competing trucking company, a chance to examine financial records, including those of R-W, and make a bid on the subsidiary.

headline: HARVESTER CHAIRMAN RESIGNS
abstract: The International Harvester Company said today that Archie R. McCardell, its chairman and chief executive officer, had resigned, effective immediately. His departure followed by a month and a half the abrupt departure of Warren J. Hayford, who had been president and chief operating officer.   Harvester's board, which met for two hours on Sunday afternoon, asked Mr. McCardell, 55 years old, to step down. The controversial chief executive has led Harvester since 1977, a period of decline for the nation's biggest maker of heavy trucks and the second-biggest farm machinery manufacturer.

headline: Interest in Rentex
abstract: Sketchley P.L.C. said today that it had entered into a preliminary agreement with certain shareholders of the Rentex Services Corporation to buy 61.5 percent of Rentex's issued shares at $13 each, or a total of $13.6 million. Rentex is based in Mount Laurel, N.J.

headline: National Steel Sees 'Significant' Loss
abstract: The National Steel Corporation, the nation's No.4 steel company, said that it expected a ''significant'' loss in the second quarter of this year. As a result, the company said it had cut its dividend to 25 cents from 50 cents a share, payable June 30 to shareholders of record July 1.

headline: SUMMIT WORRIES ON RATES
abstract: Last July, when leaders of the West's seven-largest industrial countries gathered in Ottawa for their annual economic conclave, complaints about the damaging effects of high interest rates in the United States dominated the agenda. Since then, interest rates in the United States and elsewhere have declined substantially.

headline: Exxon Cutback
abstract: The Exxon Corporation wants to cut its staff because of poor economic conditions, company officials said.

headline: CUBA BRIEFLY HOLDS 3 AMERICANS ON BOAT
abstract: Miami, april 22 (UPI) - A cuban gunboat seized a 40-foot sailboat with three United States citizens aboard Wednesday and released them later in the day, officials said.   The sailboat, the Magic, was sailing near Old Bahama Channel when the gunboat appeared and ordered the three sailors to follow them into a northeast Cuba harbor near Antilla, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

headline: Edwards Offered Post
abstract: The trustees of the Medical University of South Carolina voted today to offer the presidency of the school to Energy Secretary James B. Edwards whenever he is in a position to assume it. Mr. Edwards took over the Federal department last year with the understanding that his principal job would be to preside over its dismantling. Reports circulated in Washington this week that the Reagan Administration no longer wanted to abolish the department, but Mr. Edwards has said that that will not keep him from leaving Washington this year.

headline: Prospects
abstract: Chaotic Credit Markets   After remaining at high but quite stable levels since last fall, interest rates seem about to take off again. Since the Drysdale collapse, the credit markets, which had been cautiously eyeing a projected $45 billion in Treasury financings during the third quarter, have turned skittish at the sight of new Government paper.  With the economy struggling to get out of its rut, the change in attitude could not have come at a worse time.   The bond investor is likely to purchase the new Treasury notes, says Edward Yardeni, chief economist at E.F. Hutton, but only at interest rates that insure a still-born recovery. And while most analysts acknowldege that recent upward movements in key short-term rates make a rise in the prime to 17 percent highly likely in the near term, that may not be the end of the increase, Mr. Yardeni says.

headline: BELL & HOWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bank Board Shift
abstract: Andrew DiPrete has resigned from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board for personal reasons, a spokesman for the agency said today. Mr. DiPrete, a 53-year-old Republican lawyer from Rhode Island, will leave the three-member bank board, which regulates savings and loans associations, June 30, a year before his term expires.

headline: Brief Falklands Tour Planned for Reporters
abstract: Officials here are planning to let non-British reporters into the Falkland Islands for a quick tour, the Defense Ministry said today.   But a ministry spokesman said the projected 36-hour tour was being held up by Argentina's refusal to agree to a formal truce.  The ministry provided no further details, but The Financial Times of London reported that the trip would involve a flight from London to Santiago, Chile, on British Caledonian Airways, another commercial flight to Punta Arenas at Chile's southern tip and a flight on a Royal Air Force jet to Stanley, the islands' capital.

headline: U.S. URGING ARGENTINES TO WITHDRAW PROMPTLY
abstract: The United States, in an attempt to persuade Argentina to agree immediately to withdraw its troops from the Falkland Islands, said today that there was no reason for Britain to accept a cease-fire until that condition was met.   With the conflict apparently near its climax, the Reagan Administration told Argentina privately and publicly that unless it accepted the two-month-old Security Council resolution calling for Argentina to withdraw its troops, there was nothing the United States would do to prevent an all-out British attack on the Falkland capital of Stanley.   Administration officials said the Argentines had been told that Washington would prefer the hostilities to end through an agreed, negotiated settlement that would lay the basis for some Argentine role in the future of the islands. But Argentina has also been told that it is risking the destruction of its forces on the Falklands if it does not agree to withdraw.

headline: Argentine Junta Issues Curbs for Journalists
abstract: The Argentine military command released a series of restrictions today that foreign and local journalists are supposed to obey or face the possibility of imprisonment.   ''News agencies and/or correspondents accredited in the country,'' said clared the regulations laid down by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, ''will be responsible for the control of all information that originates in the country or coming from abroad which is transmitted or retransmitted either abroad or to national correspondents.''   Under the category of ''national security,'' the guidelines prohibit information that produces panic, is against national unity, detracts from the credibility of, or contradicts, official information, upsets internal order, generates agressive attitudes toward the country's British community, affects the relationship with other countries, or, coming from abroad, tends to facilitate the achievement of the opponent's psychological goals.

headline: EVEN DEERE FEELS THE PINCH
abstract: This area has its own unmistakable signs of spring. John Deere turns its swans loose to strut around the manicured grounds of the company's headquarters. And the Deere factories usually switch into high gear to get ready for the year's peak selling season.   But spring has come late to the Middle West this year, and a slackening in the demand for agricultural equipment has been one result of that delay. Consequently, Deere & Company, the farm implement industry's largest and most profitable company, is cutting back at a time when it normally would be expanding.

headline: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRITAIN REPORTS SEIZING KEY HILLS OUTSIDE STANLEY
abstract: British forces have seized vital high ground about 10 miles west of Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, after only moderate fighting, military sources said tonight.   The sources disclosed that paratroopers and Royal Marines had ousted Argentine soldiers manning small outposts on the summits of 1,504-foot Mount Kent and adjacent hills, from which Stanley is clearly visible in good weather. The hills form a sharp ridge overlooking a featureless plain leading to the capital and would give the British valuable positions for observation and possibly for artillery.   British control of the whole ridge would expose enemy forces, bottled up on a thin finger of land jutting into the South Atlantic, to 105-millimeter howitzer fire from one direction and 4.5-inch naval gunfire from the other.

headline: NICARAGUAN TROOPS ARE REPORTEDLY JOINING REBELS
abstract: A group of 11 Nicaraguan soldiers crossed into Costa Rica today with plans to join a rebel exile movement headed by the former Sandinist commander Eden Pastora, Costa Rican officials said today.   The officials said that the group - 10 men and one woman - arrived this morning at Barra del Colorado, a small town in northeastern Costa Rica close to the Nicaraguan border, and immediately asked for political asylum. The defectors were dressed in fatigues, but carried neither weapons nor personal identification, they said.

headline: Mariah Acquires Rights To Resume Magazine
abstract: Bits and pieces from magazine land: Mariah Publications, publishers of Outside magazine, has announced that it has acquired the publishing rights to Rocky Mountain magazine, which ceased publication in April because of ''recessionary pressures.''   David Gordon, a Californian who used to publish a weekly newspaper called Beverly Hills People, plans in September to bring out Beverly Hills World, a monthly, controlled-circulation magazine that will be sent to 30,000 area homes.

headline: CAMERON IRON WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Grupo Alfa Snag
abstract: Negotiations have broken off between Grupo Industrial Alfa and the Mexican Government on the country's purchase of some of Alfa's subsidiaries.

headline: Around the World; Italians Strike to Press For Moves on Economy
abstract: About 14 million Italian workers staged a two-hour national strike today in what the unions said was a first move to push the Government into taking firm action on economic problems.

headline: G.P.U.'s Net Rises Sharply
abstract: The General Public Utilities Corporation said yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1981 soared to $18.4 million, or 30 cents a share, from $7.8 million, or 13 cents, in the first quarter of 1981. Revenues rose 23.6 percent, to $647.8 million, from $523.9 million.   G.P.U. said that, although earnings rose, profit levels were adversely affected by the removal of the capital and operating costs of its Three Mile Island units from customer rates.

headline: Around the World; South African Expects To Confer With Kaunda
abstract: Prime Minister P.W. Botha said in Parliament today that he was likely to hold talks in the near future with President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia. The South African leader gave no indication of when or where the meeting would take place, saying details would be announced at an appropriate time.

headline: Kaiser Aluminum Shifts Management
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation yesterday announced a management reorganization designed to refocus its aluminum operations and expand its businesses in chemicals and refractories.   Cornell C. Maier, who for 10 years has run the company as its chairman, chief executive officer, president and chief operating officer, retains the first two titles and has turned over the titles of president and chief operating officer to A.S. Hutchcraft Jr.   Mr. Hutchcraft, 51 years old, formerly served as corporate vice president and general manager of Kaiser's aluminum division, the company's largest enterprise. He was succeeded in that position by Howard Nelson, 46, who had served as corporate vice president and general manager of the company's industrial and agricultural chemical businesses and its refractories.

headline: AILING CANADIAN DOLLAR TOUCHES A RECORD LOW
abstract: For the second consecutive day, the Canadian dollar fell to an all-time low against its United States counterpart before support measures by the Bank of Canada brought a modest recovery.   The Canadian currency closed today at 80.37 cents American, up from Tuesday's close of 80.06. But in a morning of heavy speculative pressure, it dipped to as low as 79.92 cents, beneath the previous low of 80.08 set in the Depression year of 1931.   Today's rise, which began around noon, was attributed to heavy market intervention by the Bank of Canada and to the expectation that the bank would increase its trend-setting interest rate on Thursday, possibly by as much as a half point, to 17.5 percent.

headline: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.N. Extends Mandate Of Its Lebanon Troops
abstract: The Security Council, with the Soviet Union and Poland abstaining, voted 13-0 today to extend the life of the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon for 60 days, diplomats disclosed.

headline: 2 South African Blacks Plead Not Guilty to Treason Charges
abstract: Two men charged with being members of the banned African National Congress pleaded not guilty today in a magistrate's court here to charges of treason in connection with attacks on police stations and a power plant.   Thelle Simon Mogoerane, 23 years old, and Jerry Semano Mososloli, 25, also pleaded not guilty to 20 other charges of murder, attempted murder and terrorism.

headline: Disaster Relief Chief Named
abstract: Peter McPherson, administrator of the Agency for International Development, was appointed by President Reagan today to coordinate American disaster relief efforts for Lebanon. Mr. Reagan has already authorized $5 million in relief and has asked Congress for an additional $20 million.

headline: United Telecom Net Falls 50%
abstract: United Telecommunications Inc. reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1982 plunged 50 percent, to $50.9 million, or 64 cents a share, from $101.8 million, or 62 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1981.

headline: A.M.C. Backs Tax Leasing
abstract: The chairman of the American Motors Corporation, W. Paul Tippett Jr., told Congress today that repeal of a new law that makes it easier for businesses to buy and sell their tax benefits would result in severe unemployment.   The law, known as safe harbor leasing, will generate 10 percent of the $1 billion that American Motors needs by 1984 to develop a new engine and a car with front-wheel drive, Mr. Tippett told the House Ways and Means Committee.

headline: Market Place; Holly Sugar's Unclear Future
abstract: WILL Holly Sugar be sold? It's hard to say, but the idea has come up repeatedly. Whenever it does, the impact is stunning and speculators have a field day.   The shares plunged recently after the company's chairman, Michael S. Buchsbaum, announced in mid-March that he might form a group to buy the company at $65 a share. This was a few points above the current price - a level the stock had climbed to when speculators sensed that a buyout move might be in the works.

headline: Market Place; Pantry Pride: Lure of Losses
abstract: Pantry Pride is like a reluctant bride with a big dowry who will not wed unless treated in a manner suitable to her station. Thus, the deal this once-bankrupt supermarket chain had struck with Supermarkets General fell through following objections over terms.   Some common shareholders sued both Pantry Pride, formerly Food Fair, and Supermarkets General, charging that a securities package valued at $5.50 a common share that the acquirer intended to issue was inadequate. The would-be acquirer operates Pathmark supermarkets and the Rickel home centers.

headline: Court Seeks NLT Answer
abstract: The United States District Court of the Southern District of Texas told the NLT Corporation to answer the American General Corporation's contention that the early payment provision of its tender offer violated state and Federal laws.

headline: INA, Connecticut General Merger
abstract: The Connecticut General Corporation and the INA Corporation said they had completed their proposed merger, creating a major new insurance and financial services concern called the Cigna Corporation.

headline: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Stock Index Futures
abstract: THE quick growth of the stock index futures contract, first introduced by the Kansas City Board of Trade in February, is spurring various strategies for using it.   ''The contract is such a flexible tool, we feel this market is going to be very important for individuals and institutions, for aggressive investors and conservative ones,'' commented Richard L.  Sandor, senior vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.   A contract in a stock index works much like that in any other commodity. The purchase of a contract effectively gives the buyer the ownership of a market basket of stocks (based on a stock index) for a period of months. While the buyer does not actually own any stocks or hold any stock certificates, the gains and losses are essentially the same.

headline: RE-SLICING CORPORATE TAX PIE
abstract: Some of the most fiscally aggressive states in the country are scheduled to do battle before the Supreme Court today against some of the largest corporations in the world over a method of taxation that has already caused some foreign governments to threaten retaliation against American businesses.   It is called worldwide unitary taxation, and it is an increasingly popular way of computing the state tax bills owed by multinational corporations.   What makes this tax method unusual is that, if the corporation is deemed to be one unit, the tax computations take into account not only the business it does within the taxing state, but all its operations anywhere in the world.   The parties due to come before the court today are the Chicago Bridge and Iron Company, the State of Illinois, and the Caterpillar Tractor Company. Some Companies Benefit   The case is procedurally peculiar because Caterpillar, unlike most other multinationals, actually benefits financially from a worldwide unitary tax system, and therefore has allied itself with Illinois.

headline: HOW BIC LOST THE EDGE TO GILLETTE
abstract: BIC AND GILLETTE are at it again. Like two alley cats, the companiesw on't stop, having battled steadily for six years over the market fort hrow-away pens and shavers. But the heat of the conflict has been r ising of late.   The Bic Pen Company, which made its name in 19-cent ballpoint pens and held up to 80 percent of the market, has been losing market share steadily over the last three years to the Gillette Company and its Write Bros. pen line, the lower-priced product of Gillette's Paper Mate division. The drop has been such that many office suppliers now say that they are selling almost as many Write pens as Bics.   So Bic hit at the heart of Gillette's profit-making center - razors and blades - with a disposable single-edged razor. The effort foundered for a couple of years, but it has just been given a second wind.

headline: The Begins' Message To Mrs. Sadat
abstract: Following is the text of a telegram sent today by Prime Minister Menachem Begin and his wife, Aliza, to Jihan el-Sadat, widow of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, and made public here by the Government: Dear Mrs. Sadat: Our hearts, Madame, go out on this day to you and the children and grandchildren. Anwar Sadat, of blessed memory, should have been with us to see the glory of his efforts to make peace and achieve reconcilation between the good peoples of Egypt and Israel.

headline: Harvester Canada Plans Layoffs
abstract: International Harvester Canada Ltd., a unit of the International Harvester Company, will lay off 80 percent of its 1,800 workers and suspend operations at its agricultural equipment plant here for four months beginning May 31, a company spokesman said.

headline: CANADA'S NEW BUDGET ASSAILED
abstract: An attempt by Canada's Liberal Government to halt both high inflation and a deep recession through budget measures was met with hostility today in the stock market, in foreign exchange markets and among labor leaders.   In his second budget message in eight months on Monday night, Finance Minister Allan J. MacEachen proposed a program of voluntary wage restraints, tax increases and investment incentives as a means to ease Canada out of its worst economic crisis since the Great Depression.   As the cornerstone of the program, the minister announced that wage increases for 500,000 federal employees would be held to 6 percent over the next 12 months and to 5 percent in the following year.   The nation's private labor unions were invited to show ''similar restraint'' in negotiating new wage increases, which averaged 12.7 percent in Canada in the first quarter compared with 2.2 percent in the United States.

headline: Oasis to Buy Libyan Oil
abstract: The Oasis Group of oil companies has agreed to resume oil purchases from Libya, Leon Hess, chairman of the Amerada Hess Corporation, told the annual shareholders' meeting here today.

headline: Text of speech, page A8.
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the Reagan Administration, determined to maintain a nuclear deterrent to protect ''the essential values of Western civilization,'' would neither renounce a first use of nuclear weapons nor agree to a freeze at present levels.   In a speech on arms policy, Mr. Haig did not state any new initiatives. But the speech, given at the International Club and sponsored by the Foreign Policy Association and Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies, affirmed the Administration's opposition to any pressure that would keep the United States from matching what it sees as a Soviet advantage in some weapons systems.   ''Our own vulnerability to nuclear blackmail, as well as the susceptibility of our friends to political intimidation, depends upon our ability and willingness to cope credibly with any Soviet threat,'' Mr. Haig said.

headline: SOVIET DECREE ON SEA MINING SEEN AS PROD TO U.S.
abstract: The Soviet Union issued a decree today empowering Soviet enterprises to engage in deep-sea mining.  In so doing, Moscow served notice on the United States that Soviet concerns were ready to challenge American companies if the Reagan Administration continues to block an international seabed agreement.   The official Soviet news agency, Tass, published the text of the decree, which enables the Government to issue licenses to Soviet enterprises for prospecting and mining mineral resources on the seabed beyond the continental shelf. The decree made it clear that the permits could be issued for any area of the seabed worldwide that lies in international waters.

headline: Business Digest; THURSDAY, APRIL 29, 1982; The Economy
abstract: President Reagan and Democratic Congressional leaders failed to resolve a budget stalemate at a three-hour meeting. The collapse of the talks leaves little chance of a bipartisan compromise, participants said. (Page A1.) The task of drafting a budget for next year now falls to the leaders and committees of Congress. (B11.) Financial leaders expressed little surprise at the failure, but some were concerned it might harm the stock and bond markets (D1.)   A four-month market study of whether Federal controls have kept the price of ''old gas'' too low will be conducted by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. (D3.)

headline: REGENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LATIN DIPLOMATS WATCHING TO SEE WHAT U.S. WILL DO
abstract: Latin American diplomats watched closely today for some indication whether the Reagan Administration would renew its efforts to negotiate a settlement in the Falkland Islands conflict or would cast its lot more actively on the British side.   ''What the United States does in the next few hours and days is of utmost importance to us,'' Marcial Perez-Chiriboga, Venezuela's Ambassador to Washington, said in an interview today shortly before the United States announced that it was earmarking a range of miitary equipment for possible British use.   ''Should there be the perception that United States logistical support is enhancing British military capabilities that would create great difficulty,'' the Venezuelan Ambassador continued. ''It is very important that at this point the United States come back to a balanced position and be a factor for maintaining - or restoring - peace.''

headline: Around the World; Peking Frees the Last Of Nationalist Captives
abstract: All remaining Nationalist prisoners held for more than 30 years as spies and traitors have been released as part of an amnesty announced in March, the New China News Agency said today.   The amnesty covered 4,237 junior Nationalist agents, apparently including more than 1,700 who had already been released on health grounds and who have now been formally pardoned.   The agency said all those freed had been given clothes, bedding and the equivalent of $55 in cash.

headline: LONDON ORDERING 35-SHIP TASK FORCE TO THE FALKLANDS
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, speaking during the first weekend session of Parliament since the Suez crisis of 1956, said today that the Falkland Islands ''remain British territory'' and ordered a large naval task force to the South Atlantic.   In addition, Mrs. Thatcher announced that Argentina's financial assets in Britain would be frozen and other economic sanctions would be imposed.   In Buenos Aires, the military Government said it would ''not retreat'' from its seizure of the islands. It broke diplomatic relations with Britain, in response to a similar move by London on Friday, and froze British assets in Argentina. (Page 18.)

headline: Banc One Sets Ohio Takeover
abstract: The Banc One Corporation, a bank holding company in Columbus, Ohio, yesterday announced an agreement to acquire the Dayton-based Winters National Corporation for $122.1 million in stock. The merger would raise Banc One's assets to $6.2 billion, from $4.6 billion, and make it Ohio's largest banking organization.

headline: LONDON'S SUBWAY SERVICE IS SHUT DOWN BY STRIKE
abstract: All of London's subway service was halted by a strike today that resulted in mass congestion on roads and raised the prospect of still greater disruption Monday when trainmen plan to add a nationwide shutdown of British Rail.   Today's underground paralysis followed four days of increasingly effective disruptions by 15,000 members of the National Union of Railwaymen, a major London Transport union that is upset about new work schedules introduced as part of a reduction in service.   ''In a word, it's a disaster,'' said one taxi driver caught in the snarl of cars this afternoon. ''One trip this morning that should have taken 20 minutes ended up taking an hour and a half.''

headline: FOR BERMUDA, ANXIETY OVER A SISTER COLONY
abstract: Sir Richard Posnett, the Governor here, sat calmly overlooking the choppy ocean while the wind drove rain against Government House, where a predecessor and his aide-decamp were assassinated in 1973.   Bermuda is outwardly peaceful now, with only fading memories of the 1977 racial unrest that followed the hanging of the assailants.  The island's well-run tourist industry, last spring's costly strike behind it, now worries mainly about recession in the United States.  But Bermudians are feeling a distinct sense of anxiety over Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands and its dependencies, Bermuda's sister colonies in the South Atlantic.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: What appears to be a struggle for political power in El Salvador between the center, represented by the Christian Democrats, and the right, represented by four conservative political parties, is something both far more complicated and possibly far more dangerous.   There are at least five, and possibly six, major forces influencing the negotiations over who will lead the country's efforts to pull itself out of civil war and into some semblance of economic recovery.   They are the Christian Democrats; their rightist opponents, who may make up two factions rather than a solid front; the Salvadoran armed forces; the leftist rebels, and the United States. Centrists' Situation Tenuous   In a nation where fradulent elections, personal deal-making and military coups have been the traditional means of installing and removing governments, nearly every action involving democratic principles and political compromise is an experiment.

headline: BRITONS ARE TAKING DELIGHT IN THEIR VICTORY IN THE FALKLANDS
abstract: A wave of pride and elation cascaded over Britain today as joyous citizens delighted in the news of victory over Argentina on the Falkland Islands.   For many, the spirit was established last night when, in most un-British fashion, hundreds gathered outside 10 Downing Street to sing ''Rule, Britannia'' and ''God Save the Queen.'' At one point, they were greeted by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, her cheeks radiant and her smile broad.   ''Today has put the Great back in Britain,'' she told the group. As much as anything, Mrs. Thatcher's lofty language and frequent invocation of the principles of democracy have helped instill into Britain its new sense of self-adulation.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S REMARKS
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's Memorial Day address yesterday at Arlington National Cemetery in Arlington, Va., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:   Mr. President, General, the distinguished guests here with us today, my fellow citizens: In America's cities and towns today flags will be placed on graves in cemeteries. Public officials will speak of the sacrifice and the valor of those whose memory we honor.   In 1863, when he dedicated a small cemetery in Pennsylvania marking a terrible collision between the armies of North and South, Abraham Lincoln noted the swift obscurity of such speeches.   Well, we know now that Lincoln was wrong about that particular occasion. His remarks commemorating those who gave their last full measure of devotion were long remembered.

headline: POLISH POLICE AND PROTESTERS CLASH AT RALLY MARKING RIOTS
abstract: Polish policemen clashed briefly today with a crowd of young demonstrators who taunted them with cries of ''Long live Solidarity!'' and ''Gestapo!'' in Poznan, according to reports from the industrial city.   The clashes came, according to the reports. as the police dispersed an otherwise peaceful march by some 4,000 workers to mark the 26th anniversary of the fierce riots there in 1956 that left at least 75 dead.   Workers from the Cegielski engineering plant, where the 1956 disturbances began, marched in groups along the sidewalks to the two black marble crosses draped with rope that were erected near the city center last year to commemorate the uprising.

headline: Stroh-Schlitz Deal
abstract: The Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit announced that it had purchased 19.25 million common shares of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company under its initial tender offer, which expired on April 15.

headline: Batus Is Target Of Complaints
abstract: Batus Inc., the American holding company for B.A.T. Industries of Britain, said that complaints had been filed against Batus, Marshall Field & Company and the retailer's directors seeking to halt the pending acquisition of Field by Batus.   Batus said that Jack Dubow and Clarice Saltiel, in two separate suits filed in the Delaware State Court of Chancery, Newcastle County, Del., charged that the takeover would represent a breach of fiduciary duties by the Field board and that Batus had aided the directors in an effort to entrench themselves with Field.   The complaints by the two Field shareholders, filed as class action suits on behalf of other shareholders, seek an injunction against the acquisition and damages.

headline: Catholic Church Is Reopened In the Chinese City of Qingdao
abstract: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael in Qingdao, Shandong Province, reopened with an Easter Sunday mass, the official New China News Agency said today.

headline: U.S. IS FASHIONING NEW MILITARY STRATEGY FOR ASIA
abstract: The Reagan Administration has fashioned a new military strategy for Asia that emphasizes a shift in planning and forces from Northeast Asia to Southeast Asia and the Indian Ocean, according to Administration officials.   While no American forces are to be withdrawn from Japan or Korea now, the officials say, plans are being made to send United States Navy, Marine, and Air Force units based in Japan and Okinawa to the Persian Gulf area in the event of hostilities there.   Moreover, United States forces held in reserve, such as an Army division in Hawaii and a Marine division in California, could be deployed to the Persian Gulf rather than to Northeast Asia as reinforcements.   To carry out that strategy, officials say, the Administration is insisting that Japan and South Korea increase their responsibilities for security in Northeast Asia. The Administration plans especially to turn the United States relationship with Japan into an active military partnership.

headline: GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELI ASSURANCE OPENS BEGIN'S WAY TO SEEING REAGAN
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had been reassured by Israel that its troops would not seize Beirut. This, they said, insured that President Reagan would meet with Prime Minister Menachem Begin.   The meeting had been in doubt after remarks by State Department officials on Tuesday that the talks might not take place if the Israeli troops poised outside the Lebanese capital moved into the city.   With Mr. Begin in New York to address the United Nations special session on disarmament, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  telephoned him to arrange to meet with him on Friday morning.

headline: EUROPE'S SURGING HOME VIDEO MARKET
abstract: West Germany's video pioneers first set up business in this Bavarian capital several years ago, peddling prerecorded cassettes of B movies and pornographic films from what had once been candy stores. Early owners of videotape recorders, with little to chose from in the way of cassettes, flocked to the new shops.   The industry has changed dramatically from those days, and the rundown store fronts are now being replaced by the high-tech look of Videon video clubs, just one of the many retailers trying to cater to the booming European trade in home video entertainment.   With only two or three state-controlled channels and little or no cable television in most European countries, TV owners across the Continent are turning to videotape recorders and cassettes to add more spice to their viewing.

headline: A.& P.'s Loss Sharply Wider
abstract: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company said today that it posted a $72.9 million net loss in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Feb. 27, compared with a net loss of $4.2 million a year earlier.

headline: ACETO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TWO OIL CONCERNS FACE LOSS OF LEASE TO INDIANS
abstract: An official of the Interior Department has made a preliminary ruling that oil-producing leases held by the Amoco Production Company and the Sohio Petroleum Corporation on the Wind River Indian Reservation in Wyoming should be canceled. The official said that the oil companies had failed to pay the correct royalties to the tribes and had violated Federal record-keeping regulations.   The oil companies have 30 days to request a hearing to appeal the ruling, made by Ken Smith, Assistant Secretary of Indian Affairs. If the ruling stands, however, control of 24 producing wells would revert to the Shoshone and Arapaho tribes on whose land they were drilled.

headline: Other Business; ECONOMY PUTS THE BRAKES ON MOTORCYCLE SALES
abstract: The stagnant economy appears to have done what a generation of nervous mothers was never able to do: cut back sales in the Japanesedominated American motorcycle industry.  ''The ripple effect of the economy has finally affected sales,'' said Robert Moffitt, Kawasaki's director of market research in the United States. ''We wondered how we escaped the fate of the auto industry so long.''  For most of the last decade, motorcycle sales in the United States hovered around one million a year. But the American market declined last year by 5 percent and is expected to shrink by about 5 to 10 percent in 1982, with sales expected to fall to the 900,000 to 950,000 range, Mr. Moffitt and others in the industry forecast.

headline: Coast Developers Accused by S.E.C.
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had charged several California real estate developers with securities violations involving a scheme to gain influence in the control of the Financial Federation Inc., a savings and loan holding company.   The commission said the group, led by Severyn Ashkenazy, an investor in real estate projects who lives in Beverly Hills, violated several sections of the securities law, particularly Section 13D, which requires public disclosure when investors obtain 5 percent or more of the stock of a company.

headline: Marketers and Women
abstract: Since women were the most sought-after consumers before the feminist revolution, they have become even more desirable as wage earners.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: OPEC Buys Some Time   Three months ago, as its oil ministers gathered in Vienna, things looked bleak for OPEC. Production remained high, and the outlook for demand in major consuming nations was not good. Prices, which had been softening for much of 1981, seemed ready to dip even more. But conditions have now changed.   As the cartel gathers in Ecuador this week, experts say that recent production cuts - even steeper than those agreed to in March - are bringing supply and demand back into balance. If OPEC can continue such discipline, and maintain output at around 16 million barrels a day, the $34 contract price should hold through the summer, said Philip Verleger, an analyst at Booz Allen & Hamilton.

headline: Around the World; Zaire Plans Israeli Ties After a 9-Year Break
abstract: Zaire plans to renew diplomatic relations with Israel, which were broken in 1973, the Zaire press agency reported today.   Foreign Minister Yoka Mangono gave the news to Arab ambassadors here last night, it said.

headline: ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HAIG MISSION THROWN INTO DOUBT BY ARGENTINE'S STATEMENT ON TALKS
abstract: Future American mediation efforts in the Falklands crisis were thrown into doubt tonight when Argentina's Foreign Minister asked for a postponement of a meeting with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and later said Argentina had suspended talks because of Britain's military action in South Georgia.   Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez said he had decided not to see Mr. Haig as planned because the attack by the British led Argentina to believe that ''the negotiations with Britain had terminated.''   The State Department, however, declined to say the American effort had ended. It said, shortly before Mr. Costa Mendez spoke, that Mr.  Haig had had long telephone conversations this afternoon with the Argentine Foreign Minister and would speak with him   Monday.

headline: SEALED POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARGENTINES SAY PLANES ARE SET TO STRIKE
abstract: Argentine military officers said today that the nation's air force was poised to launch a heavy counterattack in the event of any British invasion of the Falkland Islands.   They said that the air force had been largely held in reserve until now, with the military Government pursuing a defensive strategy of saving its military forces while holding out for a diplomatic settlement.   But, the officers said, if the British invade, Argentina is prepared to use -and sacrifice, if need be - its numerically superior air force to defend the islands that Argentine forces took on April 2.   The officers said Argentine control of the air over the islands would be necessary to enable the forces there to resist any British assault.

headline: Now, Scientific American in Russian
abstract: Scientific American, one of America's oldest magazines, will get its first Russian-language edition in the Soviet Union beginning January.   Gerard Piel, president and publisher, who has already negotiated his magazine into Italy, Japan, France, West Germany and China (usually as a joint venture) has just returned from Russia with the agreement.

headline: CAPITALISM AND THE KINGDOM OF HEAVEN
abstract: Is capitalism inherently evil? No, says Michael Novak in his new book, ''The Spirit of Democratic Capitalism,'' published by Simon & Schuster. In fact, Mr. Novak pronounces democratic capitalism the best of all political-economic systems, in ideal as well as in results. His book is an against-the-grain examination of the theological and moral foundations of capitalism and of why, as he sees it, the system works so well. WHAT do I mean by ''democratic capitalism''? In short, three d ynamic and converging systems functioning as one: a democratic p olity, an economy based on markets and incentives and a m oralcultural system which is pluralistic and, in the largest sense, l iberal. Social systems like those of the United States, West Germanya nd Japan (with perhaps a score of others among the world's nations) i llustrate the type.   Democratic capitalism is neither the Kingdom of God nor without sin. Yet all other known systems of political economy are worse. Such hope as we have for alleviating poverty and for removing oppressive tyranny -perhaps our last, best hope - lies in this much despised system. A never-ending stream of immigrants and refugees seeks out this system.

headline: 'FRIENDLY' MESA OFFER IS REBUFFED
abstract: The chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, T. Boone Pickens Jr., said yesterday that his $3.8 billion takeover bid for the Cities Service Company had been rejected by Charles J. Waidelich, chairman of Cities Service.   Although Mesa has characterized its proposal as ''friendly,'' Cities Service, in a statement yesterday, called it a ''rather weak tactical maneuver'' in response to Cities Service's formal offer yesterday to pay $17 a share for 51 percent of Mesa.   Cities Service, in a move aimed at cutting off the financing for Mesa's bid, may sue its bankers to force them to testify about what they know of the takeover plan, sources close to Cities Service said. Other sources said that Cities Service was attempting to ''scare off'' Mesa's bankers, thought to be the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago and the Bank of Montreal.

headline: CHINESE ARMY'S QUEST FOR EGGS CREATES ECOLOGICAL NIGHTMARE
abstract: From a cluster of bleak islands in the South China Sea comes word of a beleaguered unit of Chinese soldiers locked in bitter ecological combat over a flock of chickens.   The islands, called the Xisha by China, also happen to be claimed by Vietnam, which refers to them as the Paracels.  To prove that the disputed islands are really the Xisha and therefore Chinese, Peking has stationed troops on some of the more hospitable atolls and reefs, which are prized for bird fertilizer onshore and potential oil reserves offshore.

headline: Itel and Lloyd's Settle Claims
abstract: The Itel Corporation said that it and Lloyd's of London have settled their claims relating to Itel's former computer lease financing business.

headline: Precise Arms Figures Difficult to Pin Down
abstract: Reagan Administration officials estimated today that the Soviet Union and the United States each had 7,500 nuclear warheads.   The figures differed from those reported in The New York Times last week.

headline: AAV COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; April 2, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on complaint by Nicaragua GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Non-Use of Force - 3 P.M.   Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Working Group on International Standards of Accounting and Report- ing - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: EGYPT GETS ENCOURAGING SIGNALS FROM OTHER ARABS
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak flew to the Sudan today for talks with President Gaafar al-Nimeiry, amid continuing friendly signals from some Arab nations that severed relations with Egypt after it signed a peace treaty with Israel.   Mr. Nimeiry, who did not break relations with Egypt in 1979, has been trying to narrow the breach between Egypt and some of the Arab nations that closed their embassies in Cairo.   Mr. Mubarak was accompanied on the one-day trip by Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali and Dr. Osama el-Baz, First Under Secretary at the Foreign Ministry and a key presidential aide.

headline: Noranda Outlook
abstract: Noranda Mines issued a pessimistic projection for 1982 1982 in its annual report.

headline: CLOPAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SHIITE MOSLEM AND LEFTIST FIGHTING SPREADS IN LEBANON
abstract: Shiite Moslem militiamen and armed leftist groups fought until dawn here today in the worst outbreak of hostilities in a year.   The fighting, which could lead to a breakup of the uneasy leftist-Palestinian alliance that holds sway over much of Lebanon, left 27 people dead and 89 wounded, according to Lebanese security officials. Similar battles were also reported in 16 villages in southern Lebanon; there, 15 people were said to have been killed and 49 wounded.   The violence began three days ago in southern Lebanon and spread at dusk Wednesday to neighborhoods throughout predominantly Moslem West Beirut. The boom of heavy artillery and mortar fire sounded through the night and tracer bullets and the flashes of explosions lighted up the sky.

headline: Bache Loses Webb Suit
abstract: The widow of Del Webb has been awarded $418,000 in a Federal suit accusing the brokerage firm of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. with mismanaging her investments.   Toni I. Webb, 61 years old, had sought nearly $1.2 million, complaining that the firm had depleted her $1.5 million investment by placing much of her money in highly speculative investments without her knowledge.   Mrs. Webb's husband - a millionaire builder, hotel owner and former owner of the New York Yankees -died in 1974.

headline: SEMICONDUCTOR MAKERS EXPAND RESEARCH FUND
abstract: To fend off growing Japanese competition, manufacturers of silicon memory chips today announced plans to expand university research spending to $20 million over the next two years.   The original program, announced in December, called for spending $5 million.  The program is intended to encourage long-term semiconductor research and to increase the supply of professional staff, said Robert N. Noyce, vice chairman of the Intel Corporation and chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association. The trade group, which includes about 50 companies, is sponsoring the effort through a new, nonprofit affiliate, the Semiconductor Research Cooperative.

headline: CALIFORNIA MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ENERGY REVISIONS PROPOSED IN CANADA
abstract: The Government has completed introduction of a controversial package of energy legislation designed to encourage and help finance a reduction of foreign ownership in Canada's oil industry.   In an apparent step to calm critics of the nationalistic bills' possible effects on overall foreign investment, which is still a crucial factor in the Canadian economy, the new measures do not include earlier proposals to constrain existing holdings by foreign shareowners. They do, however, allow Canadian oil companies to restrict foreign purchases of future stock issues.

headline: Volcano Blankets Tokyo With Dusting of Ash
abstract: Mount Asama, 7,626 feet high and 200 miles northwest of the capital, erupted for the first time in nine years today, sending a a lead-gray column of smoke into the sky and blanketing most of metropolitan Tokyo with fine volcanic ash.

headline: SAUDIS GET STAKE IN IBH
abstract: A Saudi Arabian group, in a major Arab entry into Western European industry, has acquired a 17.87 percent share of IBH Holding A.G., the West German construction machinery group that is partly owned by the General Motors Corporation, IBH announced today.   The acquisition will make the Saudis and General Motors the largest IBH shareholders, with equal participation. The deal with the Saudis is part of an IBH program to raise $64.6 million in much-needed new equity capital for the seven-year-old company, which has grown through acquisitions into the world's third-largest construction machinery company.

headline: Bath Iron Works
abstract: The Bath Iron Works Corporation, a subsidiary of the Congoleum Corporation, said yesterday that it had been awarded a $300 million contract by the Navy to construct combat cruisers.

headline: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MESA'S BID IS TAKEN TO HOLDERS
abstract: The Mesa Petroleum Company, pressing its takeover bid for the Cities Service Company in spite of an outright rejection by the company's top management, disclosed last night that it was taking its offer directly to stockholders of Cities Service.   The widely expected public bid - to start today without the endorsement of Cities Service officials - provides for Mesa to offer $45 a share for 12.1 million shares, or 15 percent, of Cities Service's shares outstanding. The offer is not conditioned on any minimum number of shares being submitted by shareholders.   Although this is substantially less per share than Mesa had offered to the management of Cities Service, Mesa hopes that shareholders will respond with such enthusiasm that the Cities Service management would be persuaded to withdraw its opposition.

headline: Reports on Oil Prompt Record Futures Volume
abstract: A record number of heating oil futures changed hands yesterday in what brokers said was an uncommonly volatile session on the New York Mercantile Exchange.   Equally aggressive buyers and sellers generally kept price moves within a range of 1.5 cents a gallon. But the buyers proved slightly more determined in the final moments: The spot May futures slipped 0.34 cent a gallon, to 78.21 cents, but the rest of the board showed gains of 0.19 cent to 0.50 cent.

headline: POLISH INTERNEES FIND EXIT BLOCKED
abstract: Marek Tabin, a 42-year-old sociologist who worked for an unauthorized publishing house, was interned for three months under martial law. Sometime during his spell in two separate detention centers he decided he wanted to live in the West.   He wanted, he said, to ''live in a country where a man can work honestly and does not need to live in constant fear.'' His decision was prompted by the Polish Government's declared readiness to let internees leave the country - an easy way of getting rid of those regarded by the authorities as agitators and troublemakers.

headline: Addendum
abstract: Money magazine increasing by 5.3 percent both its advertising rates and circulation base, from 950,000 to 1 million, effective with the July issue.

headline: Spending Plans Down
abstract: American consumers generally are pessimistic about the economy and are wary of going into debt or dipping into their savings to make major purchases, according to University of Michigan study released today. The quarterly survey of consumer attitudes said it found no evidence during the first quarter of the traditional signs of economic recovery - consumer interest in home, car and major consumer good purchases.

headline: HANOI TRIP: GAINS SEEN BY EX-G.I.'S
abstract: A group of American veterans of the Vietnam War has left this country after a six-day visit, taking with them what seemed a heightened awareness of the possibilities - and pitfalls - of unofficial diplomacy.   The veterans, who left today, were on their way back to the United States after their encounter with Vietnamese officials, high and low. They came to this country to talk about the fate of American soldiers missing in action, the chemical defoliant known as Agent Orange, the children of Vietnamese citizens and American servicemen, and the need, as they saw it, for more cultural exchanges between Vietnamese and Americans.   Several of the veterans remained unsure about what their mission had accomplished. Nor, despite Vietnam's release May 29 of information on several American war dead, did they know where such visits might lead or what Vietnam hoped to gain from such encounters.

headline: Discussions At Braniff Continue
abstract: Braniff International, which had hoped to consummate a deal by this weekend to lease its South American air routes for urgently needed additional cash, said yesterday that ''we will do our best to continue to fly'' while negotiations continue.   Meanwhile, Eastern Airlines officials said that carrier would make an offer for a major portion of the Braniff routes on Tuesday. Air Florida said it was studying figures that Braniff had put before its negotiators Wednesday.

headline: Family Weekly Head To Retire in June
abstract: Morton Frank, who sold the Family Weekly newspaper supplement to CBS Consumer Publications in 1980, will retire in June as chairman and publisher to be replaced by Patrick M. Linskey, former ad director who has been president and associate publisher since last year. Mr. Frank, 69 years old, will be chairman emeritus and a consultant to CBS.   Meanwhile, Russ Russomanno, who never really did retire after retiring as publisher of Family Circle, where he had worked for 30 years, next week is coming out as publisher of Great Recipes of the World, a newish publication from the Digest Publishing Company, Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

headline: Clevepak, UNC Forge a Link
abstract: The Clevepak Corporation, a manufacturer of paperboard, packaging and industrial products in White Plains, announced yesterday that it had elected to the board Keith A. Cunningham, president and chief executive officer of UNC Resources Inc., a diversified energy concern. The election expands Clevepak's board to eight members.

headline: HAIG SUGGESTS EXPANDED U.N. FORCE AND SMALLER SYRIAN ROLE
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that an expanded United Nations peacekeeping force and ''some lessening'' of Syria's 25,000-man military force in Lebanon should be part of a ''comprehensive solution'' in Lebanon after a ceasefire.   His comments and those of senior British officials indicated that, as an inducement for a cease-fire and an Israeli withdrawal, the United States and Britain were trying to devise arrangements for a more effectively policed buffer zone, free of Palestinian military forces, in a 25-mile belt in southern Lebanon.   This is apparently what Prime Minister Menachem Begin has been demanding in two days of talks with Philip C. Habib, the special envoy whom President Reagan sent to Israel Sunday to work for a halt in the fighting. U.S. Not Eager to Join Force   In other diplomatic contacts, Israeli officials have said they were more interested in a peacekeeping force that included American troops than in an expanded United Nations force. But high American officials said tonight that for the present at least the President and his advisers were not eager to get American forces involved in Lebanon.

headline: Market Place; Pac-Man And Beyond
abstract: Investor fears that the video game market could be approaching saturation have hurt Warner Communications shares. But fans are rallying around this maker of Pac-Man video games, the dominant factor in that marketplace.   Warner is a major success story - a company exciting enough to have attracted Dr. Peter Goldmark, the inventor of the long-playing record for CBS some years ago, who joined Warner because it was so receptive to new ideas. Dr. Goldmark was later killed in an auto crash.   Warner's movies include such major successes as ''Arthur'' and ''Superman II.'' Warner has the TV series ''Alice,'' too.

headline: MONDAY, MAY 3, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Exxon has withdrawn from the Colony shale oil project in Colorado.  The $5 billion project, the nation's most ambitious synthetic fuels venture, now appears doomed because Tosco, which held a 40 percent stake in the operation, said it could not continue the project alone. (Page A1.) Tosco will be forced to review its strategy. (D4)

headline: Wicor Purchase
abstract: Directors of Wicor Inc. and Sta-Rite Industries Inc. approved terms of a definitive agreement for Wicor to acquire Sta-Rite for $20.1 million. Wicor, a holding company for gas distribution and gas and oil exploration operations, will begin a cash tender offer on Friday for 1,150,000 shares at $17.50 a share. It reserved the right not to purchase any shares if fewer than 850,000 shares were tendered, and to purchase up to an additional 450,000 shares for the same price.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Air International Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell two million units, each consisting of one share of common stock and one common stock purchase warrant, through an underwriting group managed by First Affiliated Services.   * Amdeco Inc. said its board had authorized the purchase ot up to 200,000 shares of its stock outstanding.

headline: Hijackers in Honduras Said to Lower Demands
abstract: The 4 hijackers holding 28 hostages, including 8 Americans, aboard a parked airliner lowered their ransom demands today and were considering a Government offer to have them flown from the country in exchange for the release of their captives, officials reported.   The plane, a Canadian-built Dash-7 turboprop, was commandeered during a flight Wednesday morning from La Ceiba, 115 miles north of here.

headline: Fletcher/Mayo Given All Harvester Ads
abstract: The International Harvester Company, the Chicago-based heavy equipment manufacturer with major financial troubles, has consolidated the responsibility for all advertising for its equipment group, previously at three agencies, in one - Fletcher/Mayo Associates, a subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach.

headline: Federal Banking Laws Are Assailed
abstract: Federal laws restricting interstate banking represent a regulatory intrusion upon the free workings of the marketplace and have prevented consumers from taking advantage of technological innovations in the industry, Attorney General William French Smith said today.   ''The banking industry is in the midst of a revolution spurred by the technological innovation of the computer age'' but the momentum of change ''has been slowed by outmoded and largely unjustified regulatory barriers to competition in the banking industry,'' Mr.  Smith said in a speech to the Association of Reserve City Bankers in Phoenix.   The text of his remarks was released here.  Mr. Smith criticized the McFadden Act of 1927, which prohibits interstate branch banking, and an amendment to the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 that prohibits a bank holding company from acquiring a bank in another state unless the law of that state allows it.

headline: Soviet Reports Wide Damage In Georgian Republic Floods
abstract: Record rain and unseasonably warm temperatures have led to flooding in the southern Soviet republic of Georgia, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today. It said more than 300 buildings had been destroyed and some people had been killed and others injured.   In some areas, the report said, the rain was the heaviest in a century.

headline: BILL YIELDS OFF SHARPLY AT AUCTION
abstract: Underscoring last week's drop in short-term rates, the Treasury sold $9.8 billion of three-month and six-month bills yesterday at sharply lower yields than those prevailing at the previous Monday auction.   The average rates were 11.480 percent and 11.677 percent for threeand six-month bills, respectively. A week ago, the average auction rate was 12.189 percent for three-month bills and 12.187 percent for six-month bills.   Last week's rate decline followed moves by the Federal Reserve to make bank reserves more plentiful in the banking system - an action some analysts interpreted partly as a means of calming money markets in the wake of financial difficulties at Drysdale Government Securities.

headline: West German Bids Moscow Respond to Arms Proposals
abstract: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany called on the Soviet Union today to respond positively to Western proposals for disarmament negotiations.   He said in a radio interview that President Reagan's offer on strategic arms reduction talks and other Western proposals were unmatched since World War II.

headline: INDUSTRIAL COUNTRIES FAIL TO AGREE ON HOW TO MEET ECONOMIC CRISES
abstract: Government ministers from the 24 major industrial democracies completed a two-day review of the world economy this evening on a pessimistic note. They agreed that no early end to the recession is in sight and that six million more people are likely to become jobless this year, raising the total number of unemployed in their counries to more than 30 million.   The ministers, attending the annual meeting of the Organizaton for Economic Cooperation and Development, which monitors the economic performance of its member nations, promised to keep trying to reduce inflation, preserve free trade and modernize industry.   But their final communique shows they remain seriously divided over how to tackle the crises gripping their countries' economies. ''The message is not a very pleasant one,'' said Emile van Lennep, secretary general of the organization, in summing up the ministers' work at a final news conference.

headline: SALVADOR BLOCKS THE ENFORCEMENT OF LAND PROGRAM
abstract: In less than one month as a legislative body, El Salvador's Constituent Assembly has blocked most of the country's land redistribution effort from being carried out.   In its first session, the Assembly enacted legislation that effectively annulled the plan of the previous Government to make peasant cooperatives out of 1,700 of the country's large farms.   And last Thursday, the rightist-dominated Assembly suspended the ''land to the tiller law,'' which permitted peasants to buy the small plots they were working as tenant farmers or sharecroppers. The suspension was for one crop year, which for sugar cane, one of El Salvador's main crops, is four calendar years.

headline: Advertising; New Y.&R.  Unit's Key: Packaging
abstract: TRY this thesis out for size: The services that provide the nonrational inducements to purchase products will be those that grow the fastest, as constantly improving technology makes easily advertised, exclusive product benefits rare.   Jinglesmiths, art directors and set designers, writers of lyricthough-hazy copy and all of those who can generate an emotional, visceral sell will be much in demand.   J. Mac Cato agrees with the theory and says that his particular discipline deserves a place at the table. He has a design firm and 60 percent of its work is in package design.

headline: Oil Data Delayed
abstract: The American Petroleum Institute weekly oil data are not published today because of a delay in the gathering of statistics. The figures will appear tomorrow.

headline: C.A.B. TO STUDY LAYOFF AID
abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board plans to begin deliberations this week on which airlines qualify for the labor protection provisions of the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978.   Laid-off employees of the qualifying airlines - principally those that have cut back operations or shut down, as in the case of Braniff International -could receive monthly jobless payments and relocation assistance, and could be given hiring priority at other airlines.   Terms of the labor provision and the mechanisms for putting it into effect are far from clear, however, and there is doubt that employees will soon be able to receive aid.

headline: ARGENTINE DIPLOMAT ON A HIGH WIRE
abstract: For Nicanor Costa Mendez, Argentina's Foreign Minister, the Security Council meetings that he is attending in New York are the latest delicate step in a diplomatic high-wire act.   It began when Mr. Costa Mendez took office last December, asserting that it was ''time to produce concrete results'' to return the Falkland Islands, known here as the Malvinas, to Argentine hands.   The recent military intensification of Argentina's efforts to fulfill that quest has forced the 59-year-old longtime diplomat to inch along a narrow path between conflicting sets of values, not always with the desired outcome.   A member of a wealthy, patrician Argentine family, Mr. Costa Mendez said early on, for example, that the realities of Argentina's economy placed the country above the ranks of third-world nations. These types of remarks have not heightened the country's popularity with its Latin American neighbors.

headline: Apple Computer Is Suing Franklin
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. said it had filed suit against the Franklin Computer Corporation of Pennsauken, N.J., accusing it of patent and copyright infringement, unfair competition and misappropriation.   The suit, filed in the United States District Court for Eastern Pennsylvania, charged Franklin with copying Apple's computer programs in the form of diskettes and computer parts known as read-onlymemory.

headline: Chock Full o'Nuts Dissidents Gain
abstract: Jerry Finkelstein, the dissident shareholder of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, disclosed that two other shareholders had sided with him, effectively raising the group's stake to 10.4 percent from 6.1 percent.   The shareholders who agreed to ''act in concert'' with Mr.  Finkelstein were identified as Seymour Cohn, chairman of the Sylvan Lawrence Company, a real estate concern, and Norman Elowitz, chairman of Honey Fashions Ltd., in a filing mailed to the Securities and Exchange Commission and delivered to the New York Stock Exchange.   Richard Cheney, a spokesman for Chock Full o'Nuts, said that ''until we see'' the filing, ''I don't think we should comment.''

headline: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Authors of the Article Held High U.S. Posts
abstract: The article in Foreign Affairs that asked the United States and its European allies to consider renouncing the first use of nuclear weapons was written by four former high-level Administration officials.   McGeorge Bundy was national security adviser from 1961 to 1966 and president of the Ford Foundation from 1966 to mid-1979.

headline: Petro-Lewis Seeks Limited Partners
abstract: The Petro-Lewis Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange commission for a $1 billion offering of limited partnership interests in certain properties that it had previously acquired from the Hunt family and the Placid Oil Company.   Proceeds of the offering will be used to finance and operate the oil and gas properties, which it acquired on Jan. 20 for $408 million. The properties are in Prudhoe Bay, Alaska, and in Alabama, Texas and Arkansas.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Aluminum Company of America, Pittsburgh, has elected Robert F.  Qlagle treasurer.   * Atex Inc., Bedford, Mass., a Kodak subsidiary, has elected Robert W. Camp an executive vice president and chief operating officer.

headline: DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MEANS SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tiffany Near End Of Agency Search
abstract: The new management at Tiffany & Company, headed by Anthony D.  Ostron, president, is close to deciding on a new agency after months of searching.

headline: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OVERHEAD DOOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Peace March in Italy Draws Over 100,000
abstract: More than 100,000 people in this northern city marched to oppose nuclear weapons in a demonstration sponsored by the Italian Communist Party, the police said today.

headline: IMPASSE WORRIES BUSINESS LEADERS
abstract: Except for cautious optimism from the automobile industry, business executives yesterday painted a generally gloomy picture for the economy in view of the budget impasse between President Reagan and Democratic Congressional leaders.   The outlook - a rising budget deficit that would keep interest rates high -was viewed as particularly depressing for such areas of the economy as steel, housing, real estate, forest products, furniture and the suppliers that serve these and other industries. In credit markets, bond dealers and traders voiced dismay at the possibility of larger-than-expected deficits. (Page D1.)

headline: UNION TRUST BANCORPORATION (BALTIMORE, MD) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Quaker Oats To Sell Units
abstract: The Quaker Oats Company announced today that it had entered into a definitive agreement to sell its chain of 89 Magic Pan resturants to private investors. Though the terms and price were not disclosed, the resturant chain will continue to carry the Magic Pan name, and retain its San Francisco headquarters.

headline: CHILEANS FEARFUL OF THE ARGENTINES
abstract: Bernardo Mora, a construction worker savoring oysters in the Mercado Central here, said Argentina would have attacked Chile had it not seized the Falkland Islands instead.  ''It was either them or us,'' he said.   As a man with a guitar and a song of lost love strolled past, Luisa Parra, whose family has owned the oyster stand for seven decades, heartily concurred. ''The Argentines are never satisfied with what they have - they always want another bite, another bite, another bite,'' she said.

headline: Pan Am Seeking Braniff's Routes
abstract: Pan American World Airways yesterday filed requests with the Civil Aeronautics Board for some of Braniff International's Latin American routes, saying that the plan by Eastern Airlines to take over the routes would leave some serious gaps in United States flag service.   Pan Am, which lost out to Eastern when the C.A.B. approved an agreement between Braniff and Eastern to take over most of the routes, said that it was asking for authority to begin service to Colombia between New York-Bogota, New York-Cali and Los Angeles-Bogota by June 1.   Pan Am said that the Eastern plan would not replace Braniff's nonstop service to Colombia from New York and Los Angeles and would force all traffic to Colombia through Miami.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * American General Corp. and NLT Corp. have both been added to Standard & Poor's Corp.'s creditwatch list.   * Crystal Oil Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 937,500 common shares being sold by certain shareholders.

headline: Sohio Is High Bidder in Alaska
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) and its majority owner, the British Petroleum Company, jointly submitted the highest bid in a state and Federal sale of Alaskan oil leases.   They bid $15.36 million for a tract offered by the state directly south of the Exxon Corporation's Flaxen Island discovery, beating the Gulf Oil Corporation and a group composed of the Phillips Petroleum Company, the Mobil Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of California.
