In the oil lease sales, Alaska not only drew the highest bid but also fared better in total dollars received and relative response to acreage offered. Alaska received bids of nearly $32.6 million for its 13 tracts.

headline: Caterpillar Outlays
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company has further reduced its capital spending plans for 1982 to about $600 million from a recently projected $650 million, E.J. Schlegel, executive vice president, said yesterday in remarks prepared for security analysts. Caterpillar had originally projected spending of about $750 million. The company spent $836 million in 1981.

headline: Swiss Bank Gains
abstract: The Swiss Bank Corporation said today that its balance sheet total rose to $44.3 billion in the first quarter from $43.8 billion at the end of the year. Operating earnings were up from the first quarter of 1981, it said.

headline: Datapoint Has Loss of $23 Million
abstract: The Datapoint Corporation, suffering from a weak economy and irregular marketing practices, reported yesterday that it lost $23 million in its third fiscal quarter, ended April 30.   The loss was the first in nearly a decade for the computer and office equipment manufacturer and compared with a profit of $12.9 million, or 63 cents a share, in the similar period last year.  Revenues sank to $99.4 million from $116.9 million a year earlier.

headline: Republic Airline Chief Cites Reasonable Fares
abstract: Daniel F. May, Republic Airline's president and chief executive officer, does not think much of those who put the airline on the endangered list. ''They're all crazy,'' Mr. May said yesterday.

headline: Ladies' Home Journal Plans a Bus Campaign
abstract: In addition to a comparative advertising campaign in The New York Times and The Chicago Tribune, The Ladies' Home Journal will shoot for the ego of Madison Avenue with a three-month campaign using the posters on the sides of 100 buses that run on affluent avenues.   The ads will link agencies with certain favored clients: ''Hey, Backer & Spielvogel, want a good, nutritious media buy?'' The illustration is three red-and-white soup cans labeled ''Journal'' and ''New Improved''; then over the word ''Journal'' and made up of light bulbs is the headline ''Hey, BBDO, want a bright buy for G.E.?'' None of the ads talk about the magazine's future, whatever it is.

headline: S.E.C. Nomination
abstract: President Reagan announced today that he intended to nominate Bevis Longstreth to continue as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Longstreth, a Wall Street lawyer who earlier this month completed a one-year appointment as an S.E.C. commissioner, will complete the remaining two years of the term of Philip A. Loomis Jr., who recently retired.

headline: ABC's Profit Climbs by 89.1%
abstract: The American Broadcasting Companies, citing the strength of television operations, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit surged 89.1 percent, to $24.2 million, from a year earlier.   ABC said the earnings amounted to 84 cents a share, compared with profit of $12.8 million, or 45 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

headline: NUCLEAR MEDICAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. WORKED FOR CEASE-FIRE BETWEEN ISRAELIS AND P.L.O.
abstract: The United States worked intensively behind the scenes today to bring about a cease-fire between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization in Beirut, the State Department said.   Israel announced this afternoon that it would observe a cease-fire starting at 9 A.M. (3 P.M., New York time). The P.L.O. said later that it would also observe a cease-fire.   According to State Department officials, the United States worked to arrange for Israel and the P.L.O. to make separate statements that they would abide by cease-fires in Beirut. This followed the pattern set on Friday, when Israel and Syria also made separate cease-fire announcements.

headline: Market Place; Art of Picking Growth Stocks
abstract: ''EMERGING growth stocks,'' those venturesome vehicles of Wall Street, have taken their lumps lately, along with many largecapitalization issues. Several brokerage firms have tailored their current selections in small stocks to the changing market and economic environment.   In the first quarter of 1982, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 6 percent, according to the Interactive Data Corporation of Waltham, Mass. But two indexes more likely to reflect the smaller growth-type issues showed sharper declines. The American Stock Exchange's market value index dropped a steep 18.9 percent, and the Nasdaq composite index in the over-the-counter market declined 10.3 percent. The decline in the Amex index, in large measure, came from weakness in energy issues.

headline: Former Official in Iran May Face Firing Squad
abstract: Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, the former Foreign Minister of Iran, will face a firing squad if he is convicted of plotting to kill Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Iran's revolutionary leader, judicial authorities in Teheran said today.   The judicial officials said in a telephone interview that a revolutionary tribunal had started to interrogate Mr. Ghotbzadeh about his purported links to a monarchist group that has been accused of plotting to kill Ayatollah Khomeini.

headline: DSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IRISH PREMIER, AT THE WALDORF WARNS, VIOLENCE DELAYS UNITY
abstract: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey of Ireland told Irish-American leaders last night that violence would only delay the unity of all Ireland, which he called ''the first political priority of the Irish Government.''   Speaking to about 800 guests at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria's Starlight Roof, Mr. Haughey noted that there had been some uncertainty about the official stand on unifying Ireland.   ''Much of the confusion which has existed regarding the Irish Government's approach to the problem of Northern Ireland stems from a failure in communication,'' the 56-year-old Prime Minister said, ''and I am determined to remedy that.''

headline: Airport Seeks Braniff Eviction
abstract: The governing board of the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport voted to ask a Federal bankruptcy judge for permission to evict Braniff International from its airport facilities and headquarters building.   ''We need the right to generate revenue,'' the airport's executive director, Ernest Dean, said after a closed meeting of the airport board's committee.   Braniff the nation's eighth-largest airline, ceased operations on May 12, and filed for Chapter 11 reorganization in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Fort Worth early the next day.

headline: HIGH MORALE ASCRIBED TO ARGENTINE SOLDIERS
abstract: The commander of Argentine troops on the Falkland Islands said today that British attacks so far had caused only light damage and that morale was high as his men awaited an expected British invasion.   ''The Argentine people,'' Gen. Mario Benjamin Menendez said in a radio interview broadcast from the Falklands this morning, ''can be confident that the troops who had been destined to defend the islands will be up to the commitment they have assumed.''   It was one of the few public statements by the general since all independent reporters were expelled several weeks ago, leaving only a Government television reporter. The general spoke as military officers and Government officials here were gloomy about the prospects of a negotiated solution and said an invasion was possible any day.

headline: SECRETARY'S SPLIT WITH PRESIDENT LONG IN MAKING
abstract: A working lunch of the National Security Council had just adjourned in the Cabinet Room of the White House early Friday afternoon when President Reagan said to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., ''Al, may I see you for a moment?''   It was then, according to White House aides, that a stunned Secretary Haig learned that his offer to resign, made the day before, had been accepted, and that Mr. Reagan had selected George P. Shultz, a former Treasury Secretary, to replace him.   Later in the afternoon, it was Mr. Haig who in turn stunned Mr.  Reagan and his staff members by putting into his resignation letter a parting blast at the Administration. In recent months, Mr. Haig said, foreign policy had shifted from the ''careful course'' originally established by the President and himself.

headline: G.M. Unit Signs Japanese Accord
abstract: A General Motors Corporation subsidiary and a Japanese car importer signed an agreement that would allow the American auto maker to centralize the distribution of its vehicles in Japan, G.M. said.

headline: TEXT OF PRESIDENT REAGAN'S ADDRESS ON NUCLEAR POLICY AND EAST-WEST TIES
abstract: Following is the text of the commencement address prepared for delivery by President Reagan today at Eureka College:   EUREKA, Ill., May 9 (AP) - Following is the text of the commencement address prepared for delivery by President Reagan today at Eureka College:   It goes without saying that this is a very special day for you who are graduating. Would you forgive me if I say it is a special day for me also? Over the years since I sat where you of the graduating class of 1982 are now sitting, I've returned to the campus many times, always with great pleasure and warm nostalgia. It isn't true that I just came back to clean out my locker in the gym.   On one of those occasions, I addressed a graduating class here, ''neath the elms,'' and was awarded an honorary degree. I informed those assembled that while I was grateful for the honor, it added to a feeling of guilt I'd been nursing for 25 years. I always figured the first degree I was given was honorary.

headline: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japan Concerns Drop Print Ads
abstract: Two Japanese corporations implicated in a scheme to purchase computer secrets stolen from the International Business Machines Corporation said today that they had stopped print advertising because of their damaged reputations.   Spokesmen for the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation and Hitachi Ltd., two of Japan's largest electronic concerns, said they had withdrawn their newspaper advertising but would continue to advertise on television.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE   CROWN CORK & SEAL COMPANY-John Francis Connelly, chairman, made private sale of 25,000 shares leaving him directly with 208,900 shares.

headline: BUSH, IN SEOUL, HINTS OF TRIP TO PEKING
abstract: Vice President Bush said today that he might visit China during his tour of Asia and the Pacific.   ''There is a possibility that I would go to China,'' Mr. Bush said at a news conference here before leaving for Singapore. ''There will be an announcement on that soon.''

headline: Excerpts from speech, page A10.
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States would play ''a more active role'' in coming weeks in trying to end the Iraqi-Iranian war. He seemed to warn Iran that if it spread the conflict into neighboring nations Washington would protect its ''vital interests'' in the Persian Gulf.    In the Administration's first comprehensive Middle East policy statement, Mr. Haig discussed at length the Iraqi-Iranian war, the stalemated Egyptian-Israeli negotiations on Palestinian self-rule and the Lebanon crisis.   In connection with the Egyptian-I@sraeli talks, Mr. Haig said there should be a ''redoubling of efforts.'' Administration officials said that the United States had raised the possibility of a three-way meeting involving President Reagan, President Hosni Mubarak and Prime Minister Menachem Begin next month but that nothing had been set.

headline: RUSSIANS DEFEND VIETNAMESE LABOR
abstract: After months of rumors about planeloads of Vietnamese being transported to Soviet factories to work off Hanoi's debt to Moscow, the Soviet authorities have offered an account of the program designed to silence ''slanderers in the bourgeois press'' who made an issue of it.   Taken at face value, the account in the Government newspaper Izvestia was a rebuff to anyone imputing other than altruistic motives to the Soviet Union. It said 7,000 Vietnamese students, aged 17 to 35, had arrived for training in some 50 trades under a year-old agreement that provided for them to remain for a year, earning regular Soviet wages.   Far from being assigned to northern Siberia and other inhospitable areas, as some Western reports have suggested, Izvestia said that the Vietnamese, whose homeland is in the tropics, were working in ''regions with the most suitable climate for them.'' It named cities across the southern tier of the Soviet Union, from Astrakhan on the Caspian Sea to the Altai area of south Siberia.

headline: Advertising; Kensington Fragrances Gearing Up
abstract: IN the fall when the fragrance industry begins to come to a boil over impending Christmas sales, consumers will first start to hear about Pascalle for women and Cameron for men.   They are entries of the recently formed Kensington Inc., a subsidiary of the Kayser-Roth Corporation, and will be advertised together on television and later in magazines.   Kayser-Roth, a subsidiary in turn of Gulf and Western, also produces No-Nonsense pantyhose, one of the highly-advertised brands that in a few short years were responsible for making supermarkets the source of half of all pantyhouse sales.   And as supermarket managements, beset by increasingly smaller profit margins on food products and changes of consumption patterns brought on by fast-food chains, have loved the more substantial markups of pantyhose and of health and beauty aids. Richard J. Gyde, 39-year-old president of Kensington, is sure they will next love fragrances for the same reason.

headline: Motorola Buyout Of Toko Partner
abstract: Motorola Inc., the Chicago manufacturer of electronic equipment, announced that it would buy out its Japanese partner Toko K.K., with which it had, for two years, participated in a joint venture, Aizu-Toko K.K.   Aizu-Toko makes large scale, integrated, metal-oxide-silicon circuits.

headline: Boise Cascade Off 85.3%
abstract: The Boise Cascade Corporation, a leading forest-products company, reported today that first-quarter profit plunged 85.3 percent, to $5.5 million, or 21 cents a share, from $37.5 million, or $1.40 a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 9 percent, to $714 million, from $784 million.

headline: Bank Merger Complete
abstract: The previously announced merger of the Erie Savings Bank and the First Savings and Loan Association of Poughkeepsie has been completed, officials said today. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board gave its approval Monday. Erie Savings said it was now the nation's largest federally chartered savings institution.

headline: Caldwell Sees Profit for Ford
abstract: Philip Caldwell, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, told shareholders at today's annual meeting that he expected the No.2 United States auto maker to turn a profit, but he stopped short of saying when.   Ford lost $1.06 billion last year and $355.4 million in the first quarter of this year.

headline: Gulf Oil Spending
abstract: James E. Lee, chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, told the annual meeting that the company would lower its capital spending in 1982 to $4 billion from the previously planned $4.5 billion. He said that lower oil prices were resulting in less cash than the company had projected earlier.

headline: STOCKS HALT SLIDE WITH DOW UP 3.42
abstract: Stock prices edged up slightly yesterday in moderate trading that ended a seven-session, 33-point slide in the Dow Jones industrial average. The Dow rose 3.42 points, to 835.90.   Analysts said the rise was more likely a minor correction to the decline that began last week than a response to the Government report that the Consumer Price Index rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in April.

headline: Israeli Troops Rescue Aunt of U.S. Senator
abstract: Israeli troops have rescued the 88-year-old aunt of Senator James Abdnor from the combat zone in Lebanon and taken her to Israel, the senator's office said today.   Senator Abdnor, Republican of South Dakota, who is of Lebanese Christian descent, has been extremely worried about his aunt, Jurea Abnor, according to an aide to the Senator.

headline: WALBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Midway Airlines
abstract: Midway Airlines, a Chicago-based carrier, said it was canceling a $20 million conditional order placed in 1979 with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for two DC-9-80 aircraft.

headline: 2 EX-AIDES CONVICTED IN JAPAN IN '72 LOCKHEED BRIBERY CASE
abstract: Two former Government officials were convicted today, after a five-year trial, of having taken bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. The defendants, the first politicians to be found guilty in the scandal, were sentenced to suspended prison terms of two and a half years and two years, and both appealed.   Their cases were expected to have an impact on the trial and the political position of former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, generally considered the backstage leader of the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Mr. Tanaka, who faces charges of having taken the equivalent of $2.03 million in bribes while Prime Minister, has been able to delay judgment in his separate, long-runing trial until next year by prevailing on the court to call extra witnesses.

headline: LLOYD'S CANCELS SHIP COVERAGE OFF ARGENTINA
abstract: Underwriters at Lloyd's of London, the giant insurance market, have decided to cancel standard war risk coverage on ships sailing to Argentina and the South Atlantic waters as of midnight May 27.   This means that insurance rates may soar since shipowners will now have to renegotiate individually with underwriters the standard war risk charge of 0.025 percent of the insured value of the ship.   While some underwriters may feel the risk to merchant ships in the South Atlantic remains minimal, since the present fighting is focused on military rather than on civilian targets, others may interpret the present crisis in the Falkland Islands as a grave threat to any shipping in the area and consequently will set higher insurance rates.

headline: Salvador Army Builds Defenses Against Rebels
abstract: The army has stepped up its defenses north of the capital to fend off leftist guerrillas who have shifted activity from the northeastern corner of El Salvador, witnesses said today.   Journalists who returned to San Salvador from the Chalatenango Province town of La Palma, 51 miles north of the capital, said they saw scores of soldiers along one six-mile stretch of road near the Honduran border.

headline: WELLS FARGO MORTGAGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SALVADORAN COLONELS DIE IN CRASH
abstract: El Salvador's Deputy Minister of Defense and a senior combat commander were killed Thursday in a helicopter crash in a combat zone, according to an official military statement.   The victims, Col. Francisco Adolfo Castillo, 55 years old, the No.  2 man in the Defense Department, and Col. Salvador Beltran Luna, 55, commander of an elite infantry unit based in San Francisco Gotera, are the most senior military officers to have died in the war against leftist guerrillas.   A military spokesman, Col. Alfonso Eusebio Cotto, said today that the small civilian helicopter carrying the colonels crashed near San Fernando, in Morazan Province. San Fernando is about three miles west of Perquin, which guerrilla forces seized on June 5.

headline: ARGENTINE POLITICIANS HAIL NEW PRESIDENT AFTER TALKS
abstract: Civilian political leaders here said today that they were heartened by a promise made by the President-designate that he would immediately lift the military's ban on politics when he takes office next Thursday.   Maj. Gen. Reynaldo Bignone, a retired officer who was named last week by the army to succeed Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri as President, made the promise in a meeting with about 30 politicians representing 14 parties.   The five-hour meeting, which was hled in the ornate Senate chamber of the National Congress, began Thursday night and ended early this morning. It was the first time many of the politicians had returned to the building since the military took power in a coup more than six years ago.

headline: ANTIMISSILE GROUP IN BONN IS DIVIDED
abstract: A major rift concerning possible Communist influence developed today among groups opposing NATO's plan for deploying new nuclear missiles in Western Europe.   One of the leading component organizations charged that the West German Communist Party, which is aligned with Moscow, dominated and manipulated a meeting here Sunday in which representatives of 37 groups, describing themselves as elements of the antimissile movement, planned a major demonstration against President Reagan when he visits Bonn for a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization June 10.   The accusation was made by the group known as the Greens, an environmentalist party that has become increasingly active in leftwing politics in West Germany, winning seats in several state parliaments in the last two years. The Greens have acknowledged that members of their party cooperate with the Communists on certain local issues, but they described the meeting here as scandalous.

headline: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Webb Sells Hotel
abstract: The Del E. Webb Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 932-room Sahara Vegas hotel and casino for $50 million as part of a continuing sale of assets to reduce its debt. The property will be purchased by Paul W. Lowden, president and owner of the Hacienda Resort Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas and a former condominium developer in Hawaii. Mr. Lowden was also granted options to purchase a 22-acre parking lot and an 18-hole championship golf course.

headline: Fidelity Case Reversal
abstract: A Federal judge ruled today that the Federal Government illegally seized the financially troubled Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of Oakland and he ordered the thrift institution's forced receivership lifted.   United States District Judge Spencer Williams delayed for at least a day the effect of his order to remove the Federal receiver.

headline: ARGENTINA EXPECTS INVASION ON MONDAY IF THE TALKS FAIL
abstract: Argentine officials said today that the consensus within the Government is that the British will attempt an invasion of the Falkland Islands Monday if there is no diplomatic agreement before then.   They said that the British appeared to be holding off until European Common Market foreign ministers meet Sunday to discuss an extension of trade sanctions against Argentina.   Senior officials said that their assessment was based on the continued reinforcement of the British fleet lying off the Falklands and the daily shellings by warships of Argentine positions.   Meanwhile, it was learned that Vernon E. Walters, who serves as a roving envoy for the Reagan Administration, had made a secret visit here, arriving Monday night and leaving Wednesday night. The United States Embassy would not comment on the purpose of his visit, though he reportedly met with a number of military officials. Mr. Walters is a retired general and former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: 'DIRTY POWER' FELLS COMPUTERS
abstract: Shortly before 8 o'clock one night recently, the voltage in Con Edison's power lines serving the West Side of Manhattan dropped to 5 percent of normal levels for a fraction of a second. Most people in the area noticed only a flickering of lights, but for some the effects were more lasting.   A production of ''How I Got That Story'' at the Westside Arts Theater was delayed 15 minutes. Even though the house lights were working fine, the stage lights and a slide show would not work because they were controlled by computers, which had lost their memory.   Computers used for the production of The New York Times stopped working and could not be restarted for at least two hours, delaying production of the next day's newspaper.

headline: Wickes Sells Part Of Its Golf Unit
abstract: The Wickes Companies, which has been divesting subsidiaries to raise cash for working capital and to pay off a reported $600 million in loans, has sold a controlling interest in the MacGregor Golf Company to a private investment group headed by Jack Nicklaus, the professional golfer, for $17 million.   Sanford C. Sigoloff, who was named Wickes's chairman a week ago, announced the sale and said the company would retain 25 percent of MacGregor, which it purchased from the Brunswick Corporation in 1979.    A minority interest in the new company is owned by Clark Johnson, who resigned recently as a director and executive vice president of Wickes.

headline: U.S. EXPRESSES 'DEEP REGRET' OVER REPORTED LOSS OF LIVES
abstract: The Reagan Administration expressed ''deep regret'' tonight over the reported heavy loss of life in the sinking of the Argentine cruiser Belgrano.   The State Department added that the sinking, after a torpedo attack by a British submarine, ''pointed out the absolute necessity of reaching a peaceful settlement to this tragic conflict.''   Earlier today, when the Argentine Government said the ship was ''presumed sunk,'' the news had a chilling effect in the Administration here.   Later, the effect was magnified when the Argentine high command confirmed the sinking and reported that as of late tonight 123 men of the 1,042 men aboard had been rescued from the icy seas.

headline: Commodities; Futures Regulation In Dispute
abstract: LAWYERS rather than traders continue to generate much of the news in the commodity markets as the debate grows over which Federal regulatory agency should police the rapidly expanding industry, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission or the Securities and Exchange Commission.   Last week, the debate took another twist when the chairman of the C.F.T.C., Philip McBride Johnson, asked Congress in effect to overturn a Federal court ruling in his agency's favor, and to support a four-month-old informal jurisdictional pact with his counterpart at the S.E.C., John S.R. Shad.   What provoked this unusual display of amity between the two formerly contentious agencies was a ruling on March 25 by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago that said the Chicago Board Options Exchange had to obtain the approval of the C.F.T.C. to trade in options on Government National Mortgage Association certificates.   The Chicago options exchange had previously applied for and was granted such approval by the S.E.C. This infuriated the exchange's parent, the Chicago Board of Trade, because it wanted to trade Ginnie Mae options. Consequently, the big futures exchange filed suit to prevent its estranged offspring from using its S.E.C. approval to steal a march on it. The Chicago Board of Trade contended that only the Commodity Futures Trading Commission could approve the options, and this was upheld by the appeals court.

headline: Vietnam Announces Shift In Its Top Leadership
abstract: Vietnam announced a shuffle today of its Council of State, including the dismissal of Xuan Thuy from the posts of deputy chairman and general secretary.   The agency said that Le Thanh Nghi, another deputy chairman of the Council, now assumed the post of general secretary.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Aeronca Inc., Pineville, N.C., has named Clifton W. Phillips president of Aeronca Electronics Inc.   * American Stock Exchange has named William A. Fitzsimmons vice president for advanced planning and research.   * Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., Jacksonville, has elected to its board Frederick H. Schultz, former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

headline: VENEZUELA'S CLAIM TO MOST OF GUYANA IS ALIVE AGAIN AS MORATORIUM ENDS
abstract: A long-standing territorial dispute between two neighbors on the northern edge of South America, Venezuela and Guyana, entered a new and potentially volatile phase two days ago with the expiration of a 12-year moratorium on Venezuela's claim to a piece of land that makes up five-eighths of Guyana's national territory.   Although some influential Venezuelans have been pressing their Government for aggressive action against Guyana, including an invasion, the administration of President Luis Herrera Campins has said repeatedly that it will seek a peaceful solution to its claim to the land, which is slightly larger than New York State. It is widely believed here that the dispute, a highly nationalistic issue for Venezuelans as well as Guyanese, will not develop into war.   The land, called the Guyana Essequibo, covers 53,000 square miles between the Essequibo River in Guyana, formerly British Guiana, and the present border with eastern Venezuela. The disputed territory is potentially more valuable to Guyana, a poor nation with fewer than a million people, than to Venezuela, an oil-producing country with some 16 million people and petroleum exports last year worth more than $19 billion.

headline: SECRETARY OF STATE WILL SOUND OUT BOTH SIDES ON AVERTING HOSTILITIES
abstract: President Reagan decided today to send Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to London and Buenos Aires to sound out those two Governments on ways of avoiding a military clash over the Falkland Islands.   The decision was made early this morning before Mr. Reagan left for Jamaica and the start of his vacation in the Caribbean. Mr. Haig had been scheduled to accompany Mr. Reagan, but instead Deputy Secretary Walter J. Stoessel Jr. will represent the State Department.    The United States has avoided taking sides in the Falklands sovreignty dispute, hoping to create an atmosphere favorable to diplomatic efforts. France, West Germany, Belgium and Austria today banned all sales of arms and military equipment to Argentina in a show of political support for Britain. The Netherlands and Switzerland have already imposed similar sanctions. (Page A12.)

headline: LESSONS IN DEREGULATION
abstract: Reese H. Taylor, appointed chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission by President Reagan last year, sometimes finds that visual devices can be helpful in explaining issues of business regulation. Accordingly, in testifying before Congress and in meetings around the country, he has been known to brandish the accompanying illustration, drawn by a staff member to his specifications. The following is Mr. Taylor's narrative analogy, ''The Saga of Mac and Ray.''

headline: Plan for Industry
abstract: To the Business Editor: Frank A. Weil's ''Policy for Industry'' (March 28) is a first rate rational approach toward a solution for a serious national deficiency. The increasingly competitive world in which the United States does business and the difficult trade problems existing with its major trading partners have pointed up the need for national long-term industrial planning.

headline: Western Union
abstract: The Western Union Telegraph Company said that it would apply for licenses to operate cellular mobile radio telephone systems in a number of major markets in a series of joint ventures with the FMI Financial Corporation and several privately owned radio common carriers. The company said that it would submit applications to the Federal Communications Commission by June 7, the deadline set for applications for the nation's top 30 markets.

headline: Market Place; Buying Cheap, Holding Long
abstract: WITH few exceptions, most common stocks these days are trading at less than underlying values. But recession and a couple of wars have so affected the mood of the market that the low prices are drawing little enthusiasm from investors.   In the current investment climate, the ebullient attitude of Elliott Farr is thus exceptional. Mr. Farr, who is a managing director of Philadelphia's W.H. Newbold's Son & Company, will celebrate a half century in the market this summer. As befits someone with so many years in the market behind him, he has a long-term perspective.

headline: Advertising; Four-A's Praised At Meeting
abstract: The new activist American Association of Advertising Agencies won praise today from a representative of a longtime advisory organization, the Federal Trade Commission.   The praise was for a lobbying effort of the association's Washington representative, Charles F. Adams. But his work had already been rewarded Tuesday, when the Senate Commerce Committee voted, 13 to 2, to eliminate the Federal agency's jurisdiction over ''unfair'' advertising.   There will be little immediate effect as a result of the vote because the House has no similar action in the works.  But the praise, which came from Timothy J. Muris, director of the Bureau of Consumer Protection, who accompanied the F.T.C. chairman, James C. Miller 3d, and Bryce L. Harlow, the commission's director of legislative relations, down from Washington, was an indication that the course the association set for itself four years is being recognized where it matters. The F.T.C. officials were part of the first general session of the 64th annual meeting of the Four-A's, which will be holding forth at the Greenbrier Hotel here through Saturday.

headline: CHANGE IN TARGETS FOR MONEY URGED
abstract: The persistence of high interest rates that first pushed the economy into a recession and now threatens to stymie a recovery has led some economists to contend that the time is ripe for the Federal Reserve to bring rates down and help the economy by raising its money supply growth targets.   The issue of changing money supply growth targets is ticklish because the two most closely watched money supply measures - M-1 and M-2 - are already growing faster than planned. M-1 consists of currency, checking and check-like deposits, and M-2 includes M-1 plus small savings accounts, noninstitutional money market mutual funds and certain overnight bank borrowings.   Gradual reductions year after year in the growth of money supply are the cornerstone of the Fed's anti-inflation policy, but there is much room for disagreement in deciding just how much money supply growth can be allowed without igniting fears of more inflation in future years.

headline: Money Funds Show Decline
abstract: Assets of the nation's 196 money market funds declined by $182 million for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. It was the third weekly decline as investors continued to make withdrawals to pay income taxes, the Institute said.

headline: General Steel Link To Lukens Set
abstract: General Steel Industries said its shareholders had approved the company's merger with the Lukens Steel Company. Officials said 66 percent of G.S.I.'s common shares had been voted in favor of the merger at a meeting here.

headline: I.R.S. Adjunct
abstract: To the Business Editor: This is a proposal that would hold down Government spending, yield billions of dollars in extra tax revenue and would not cost the honest taxpayer one penny.   It stems from the furor over the elimination of thousands of Internal Revenue Service jobs - an ''economy'' which will sharply reduce the number of tax audits, as you reported in ''Lament of the Reagan I.R.S.'' (April 4).

headline: Holly Net Loss At $4.4 Million
abstract: The Holly Sugar Corporation yesterday reported a loss of $4.4 million in its fourth fiscal quarter, in contrast to a $5.1 million profit in the 1981 period.

headline: Classic's Store Deal
abstract: Classic Bookshop, the Canadian-owned bookstore chain, has signed a letter of intent to sell its two New York City stores to Waldenbooks, Brian Melzack, president of Classic, said yesterday.

headline: PYM UNINTERESTED IN ANY U.N. EFFORTS NOW
abstract: Francis Pym, Britain's Foreign Secretary, displayed a marked lack of enthusiasm today for any early efforts by the United Nations to resolve the Falkland Islands crisis.    Instead, he repeatedly told a news conference, Britain wants to ''maintain pressure on the Argentinians, diplomatic, military and political,'' to force withdrawal of Argentina's troops and compel negotiations over the islands' sovereignty.   Mr. Pym said, ''Of course, I don't exclude a U.N. role'' in the dispute. But he indicated that this was not the time and that Britain hoped to strengthen its bargaining position by inflicting more damage on Argentina.

headline: BRITAIN STRENGTHENS ITS NAVAL FORCE WITH MORE PLANES
abstract: Britain today strengthened the air component of the expeditionary force headed for the Falkland Islands. British military planners said the move would increase the prospect for successful landings in islands should fighting develop.   The Royal Navy announced that Atlantic Conveyor, an 18,146-ton container ship capable of 24 knots, would be chartered to carry additional Harrier jump jets to the South Atlantic. This will bring the number of Harriers available to over 40.

headline: ISRAEL SEES SOVIET GAIN AS U.S. SHUNS IRAN
abstract: Iran's recent successes in its war against Iraq have reinforced Israeli convictions that the United States is making a serious error by neglecting long-term Western interests in Iran.   Officials in Jerusalem, who say Soviet experts may have been giving military advice to the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, believe that Moscow's ability to influence a post-Khomeini regime in Iran is being enhanced by an absence of any American influence.   ''In spite of all Iran has done to the United States,'' a wellplaced Israeli official said, ''the United States cannot afford to permit Iran to be totally and unreservedly anti-American and leave the field open to Soviet penetration.''   Israel's small-scale sales of military equipment to Iran, which were confirmed by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon in a television interview Wednesday in Washington, have had no effect on the war or on Iran's policies, officials here say. Nor can Israel hope to have an influence on Teheran, they said, given the extreme anti-Zionism of the Islamic fundamentalist regime.

headline: The Economy
abstract: The recession seems to be ending, according to an increasing number of economists and bankers. Though segments of the economy are still slumping, the Commerce Department's next ''flash'' estimate of the gross national product, due next Monday, is expected to indicate the improvement. (Page D1.)

headline: PROVIDENT NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Limited Stores
abstract: Limited Stores Inc. said it had accepted for payment about 80 percent of the shares of Lane Bryant Inc. The company recently agreed to purchase all of Lane Bryant's shares at $29 each. The company also said that shareholders had approved changing the company's name to Limited Inc. and to change the state of incorporation to Delaware.

headline: FACTORY ORDERS DOWN 2.3%
abstract: Orders for new manufactured goods fell 2.3 percent in April from March, the Government reported today, in what private and Government analysts saw as a clear reflection of the continuing recession.   The Commerce Department, which announced the figures, also reported that the sales rate for new single-family houses dropped 15.3 percent in April, to the lowest level in the 19 years that the Government has been keeping such figures. (Page D15.)

headline: Ferguson Enterprises
abstract: Wolseley-Hughes said today that it planned to acquire Ferguson Enterprises of the United States for $30.7 million, subject to approval by the shareholders of both companies. The British company, a heating equipment distributor, said the acquisition of a similar business in the United States would enhance its long-term growth potential.

headline: Drop at Times Mirror
abstract: The Times Mirror Company said today that its first-quarter profit fell 23 percent, mainly because of a loss in wood-products operations, to $20.2 million, or 59 cents a share, from $26 million, or 76 cents, a year earlier.

headline: REACTION TO NEW ISSUES MIXED
abstract: A flurry of new issue activity in the corporate bond market met with mixed results yesterday, investment bankers said.  Among the new issues announced for sale today were $400 million of the World Bank's 14 3/4 percent, 10-year bonds that were increased from $250 million and priced at 100 by the First Boston Corporation and $225 million of the Alaska Housing Finance Corporation's 15 1/4 percent, 10-year bonds that were increased from $150 million and priced at 99 1/4 to yield 15.4 percent by Salomon Brothers.   Yesterday, Goldman, Sachs & Company offered $100 million of the Dayton-Hudson Corporation's 14 3/4 percent 30-year debentures that were not scheduled for sale but were registered under Securities and Exchange Commission rules that allow a quick offering when market conditions are favorable. 'Little Bit of a Window'   ''There was a little bit of a window, and investment bankers were quick to react by bringing new issues to market,'' said Howard L.  Blum Jr., executive vice president at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company.

headline: BRITONS STAGE NEW LANDING BUT THE COST IS CALLED HIGH
abstract: British troops have staged a major new landing in the Falkland Islands but have suffered heavily in the process, correspondents' reports and military sources said tonight.   A sizable force has been established at Fitzroy and at Bluff Cove, 12 miles southwest of Stanley, the Ministry of Defense reported. It said that at least 6 and possibly as many as 11 of the Argentine warplanes involved in trying to disrupt the landing were shot down.  They were reportedly intercepted and hit by Harrier jump-jets.

headline: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Group Fights Bell Breakup
abstract: The National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners told United States District Judge Harold H.  Greene today that the proposed breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company would lead to higher telephone rates and thwart the goal of providing telephone service for everyone.   The association's position was presented in testimony on the first of two days of public hearings before Judge Greene, who must decide whether to accept the Bell System breakup as proposed in a consent decree settling the Justice Department's six-year-old antitrust complaint against the telephone company.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The Royal Air Force reached back to the technology of the 1950's and an aircraft first deployed as a nuclear bomber in 1960 to mount the single most effective attack of Britain's Falkland Islands conflict.   Plucked out of impending retirement, a Vulcan made the 3,500-mile flight from Ascension Island and attacked the runway at the Stanley airfield. According to British reports, the attack effectively put the airfield out of operation by cratering the runway. The bomber was apparently refueled in flight by a Victor tanker.

headline: LENDERS ARE SKEPTICAL OF BRANIFF REVIVAL PLAN
abstract: Some of Braniff International Airways' major lenders yesterday expressed doubt about supporting the company's plan to restart operations as a smaller, low-cost carrier. But they said they would listen to management proposals with an open mind.   ''I don't see how they can reorganize and fly again,'' said Harold K. Herzog, senior vice president for investments for the New York Life Insurance Company, one of the 39 institutions to which Braniff owes $733.2 million. ''But you always have to listen and see what their plan is.'' New York Life holds $25 million of the carrier's outstanding debt.

headline: Buffalo Coke Plant
abstract: Citing sharply lower steel demand, the National Steel Corporation said that the Bonner-Hanna coke plant at Buffalo would suspend its operations indefinitely, beginning Monday. The plant is jointly owned by National and the Republic Steel Corporation.

headline: Fed Weighs Shift on Data
abstract: Next Monday the Federal Reserve Board will consider several possible changes in its publication of money supply data, according to an agenda for the meeting released yesterday.   Last year the Fed asked for public comment about publication of M-1, a closely followed money supply measure defined as all currency in circulation plus checking accounts at banks and thrift institutions.

headline: Dow Up 5.42 as Trading Rises
abstract: The stock market registered a moderate advance yesterday in accelerated trading with some of the technology and energy-related issues making the best gains.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, ended with a rise of 5.42 points, to 854.45.  In the last three trading days the blue-chip barometer has risen almost 10 points.

headline: Turkey's Prime Minister Starts Visit to Cyprus
abstract: The Turkish Prime Minister, Bulent Ulusu, flew to northern Cyprus today with pledges of political and economic support for the Turkish Cypriots.   The visit, the first by a Turkish Prime Minister to the divided island, has been denounced by Greece and the internationally recognized Greek Cypriot Government of Cyprus as ''a provocation.''

headline: OFTEN, IT PAYS TO GO BANKRUPT
abstract: As the news reports bombard us with the recurring theme of rising and spreading business failures, the word ''bankruptcy'' relentlessly creeps into the vocabulary. And just last week, a proud old name in American business - Addressograph-Multigraph, now called AM International - did what many corporate executives dread. It filed for protection under the nation's bankruptcy law.  To some chief executives, bankruptcy in business means abject failure no less than personal bankruptcy does, with all the associated stigmas.

headline: RETAIL SALES IN NEW YORK OFF IN APRIL
abstract: Sales of New York City's big retailers last month slid below the 1981 level for the second month this year, with volume down an average three-tenths of 1 percent from April of last year, according to a monthly spot-check.   In January, local sales also declined from the 1981 level.  Some retail executives attributed the latest decline to the heavy snowfall that began in the first week of April, but they added that business was lagging even before that. Merchants had been hoping that the Easter season would bolster the April performance.

headline: WALL STREET IS WORRIED ON OUTLOOK
abstract: Wall Street's money managers are filled with some sobering thoughts on the domestic economy after a week of disappointments that included the collapse of the talks in Washington to reach a compromise on the Federal budget.   ''The outlook for the economy over the next couple months is bleak,'' said Seth M. Glickenhaus, chairman of the investment firm bearing his name.   A further worry for some market professionals is that a business recovery - whenever it starts - may lack staying power. ''Prospects are for a fairly anemic recovery that will depend primarily upon consumer spending,'' stated Victor J. Melone, chief investment officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. ''And the consumer,'' he added, ''is still subject to shock.''

headline: FALKLANDS CASUALTIES BRING DISMAY IN EUROPE
abstract: Britain's allies reacted with shock and dismay today to the sinking of the Argentine cruiser General Belgrano, with the presumed loss of many lives.   News of Argentina's retaliatory attack against the British destroyer Sheffield reached Europe too late at night for reaction.  But even before the news of the British loss, European governments were calling for an end to the fighting, in the interests of both sides.   In Washington, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. abruptly canceled a trip to New York for a speech and rushed back from the airport to the State Department, where he met for three and a half hours with Sir Nicholas Henderson, the British Ambassador. (Page A16.)

headline: Ontario Hydro Bond
abstract: Ontario Hydro is raising $150 million in United States currency through a seven-year Eurobond, the lead manager, Deutsche Bank's London branch, said here today.

headline: Advertising; Mobilizing A 'Western Air Force'
abstract: THOSE newsreel cameramen of yesteryear surely knew how to make the patriotic juices flow with those shots of flights of American bombers and fighter planes roaring overhead in formation. It took the breath away, inspired, made prideful.   With the help of its new agency, McCann-Erickson, Los Angeles, Western Airlines will seek to stir a few emotions, including parsimony, by going all the way in equating the current fare wars with all-out war.   So it is creating a ''Western Air Force,'' mobilizing new routes, elevating its pilots to aces and going ''to war on the side of beleaguered airline travelers.''

headline: BEIRUT IS QUIET AFTER A DAY OF HEAVY FIGHTING
abstract: This city and its suburbs were subjected today to a relentless series of bombings and artillery and gunfire exchanges as Israelis and Palestinian guerrillas continued to do battle.   But tonight, after Israel announced that its forces would cease fire as of 9 P.M., the Palestine Liberation Organization said it had sent a note to the United Nations saying that it would agree to a cease-fire based on Security Council Resolutions 508 and 509 calling for a cessation of hostilities and prompt Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon.   And shortly after the 9 P.M. deadline, the sounds of battle subsided.  Still, an air of uncertainty pervaded the city.  Residents had stayed indoors as Israeli attacks continued through all of the night and all of today.

headline: EPSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOUTHWEST FOREST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SAL CABLE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: People
abstract: * William K. Hoag has been named a senior vice president and media director of Creamer Inc/New York.   * William S. David has been named a vice president of Straight Arrow Publishers Inc., publishers of Rolling Stone magazine.   * Frank R. Zilla has been appointed advertising director of McCall's magazine.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * CBS Inc.'s $150 million issue of notes due in 1992 was priced today at 99 3/8 with 14 1/2 percent coupons to yield 14.62 percent by underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co.

headline: Earnings Decline 20% At Ogilvy & Mather
abstract: Like the JWT Group, which announced its first-quarter results last week, Ogilvy & Mather International suffered from the Mexican peso devaluation.   Yesterday, it reported that net income fell 20 percent, to $2 million, or 48 cents a share, from $2.5 million, or 59 cents a share, despite an 11.5 percent increase in revenues, to $73.9 million, from $66.3 million the same period last year.

headline: NU-WEST SALE
abstract: Nu-West Inc. said it intended to sell all its Arizona residential land and a 2,000-acre parcel in San Clemente, Calif., to Western Savings and Loan Association. Nu-West said the proposed purchase price included a combination of notes secured by a portfolio of mortgages and preferred shares of Western savings with a combined face value ranging from $86 million to $116 million. The company said that it would continued to manage and act as sales representative for the residential land assets for a transition period after completion of the deal.

headline: HIGH COURT ALLOWS SUITS BY COMMODITY INVESTORS
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that investors in commodity futures are entitled to sue their brokers and the commodity exchanges for damages resulting from fraud or market manipulation.   In a 5-to-4 decision, the Court concluded that Congress did not intend to do away with the right of investors to bring private lawsuits when, in 1974, it set up the Commodity Futures Trading Commission as the principal regulator of the burgeoning commodity futures market.   Neither in the 1974 legislation nor in the versions of the Commodity Exchange Act that preceded it did Congress specifically address the question of a private right to sue.   The closeness of the vote reflected a longstanding debate on the Court over the circumstances under which Congressional silence should be taken to mean approval for private access to the Federal courts when there is a Federal agency charged with enforcing a particular statute.

headline: 6 Journalists Reported Safe After a Battle in El Salvador
abstract: A military spokesman said six journalists were found ''safe and sound'' today, a day after they disappeared near the scene of a clash north of the capital between guerrillas and troops.

headline: Inventor Sues On Machines
abstract: Jerome Lemelson, a Metuchen, N.J., inventor, has filed an antitrust suit against the Bendix Corporation and the Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company. He charges that the two companies conspired to boycott his patents relating to automatic measuring machines used in inspecting parts.

headline: P.& G. Gains 15.1%; Rockwell Up 2.4%
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that net income in its third fiscal quarter of 1982, ended March 31, rose 15.1 percent, while sales increased 4.7 percent.   P.& G., producer of a wide range of household products, most notably soaps and detergents, said that net income in the latest three months increased to $198 million, or $2.39 a share, from $172 million, or $2.09 a share, in the corresponding fiscal quarter a year ago. Sales advanced to $3.09 billion from $2.95 billion.

headline: NEW BID EXPECTED FOR LANE BRYANT
abstract: A new bidder is preparing to outbid a private investor group headed by Wertheim & Company for control of Lane Bryant Inc., the nation's largest retailer of extra-size apparel, Wall street sources said yesterday.   The new contender, said to be a company rather than a group, has indicated to Lane Bryant that it plans to offer a minimum of $27 a share in cash, or about $97.2 million, for the 3.6 million common shares outstanding, the sources said.

headline: Pyro Coal Stake
abstract: The Pyro Energy Corporation said it would acquire rights to additional coal interests from Alcoa Fuels Inc., a subsidiary of the Aluminium Company of America. About 40 percent of the reserves will be bought for $19.5 million cash, the rest leased.

headline: HEALTH CHAIN ACCUSED
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused Quality Care Inc., a health care service company in Rockville Centre. L.I., of selling fradulent franchise agreements to investors to finance its rapidly expanding private nursing home business.   The S.E.C. charged that in 1978 and 1979 Quality Care devised a scheme to sell contracts styled as ''investor-owned franchises.'' These so-called franchises, which raised about $5.7 million for the company, were actually a variety of securities and should have been registered with the S.E.C., it said.

headline: Chock Full o'Nuts Seeks Acquisitions
abstract: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation said it would consider being acquired by another company or seek its own acquisitions in an effort to thwart the advances of Jerry Finkelstein, a New York publisher who recently acquired 6.1 percent of the company's stock.

headline: PROGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: Three major oil companies yesterday announced discoveries of natural gas and oil reserves.  Mobil Oil Canada said that it had tested gas in four more zones near Sable Island, bringing to 10 the number of zones yielding natural gas in the Venture B-43 well off the coast of Nova Scotia.

headline: IN IVORY COAST, PALACE ON 8-LANE ROAD TO NOWHERE
abstract: They say there are more streetlights in this ''village'' of 15,000 than there are in the Ivory Coast's capital of Abidjan with its population of 1.5 million.   The streetlights - spindly sentries on highways wide enough to take eight automobiles - shine through the night on roads that lead nowhere, illuminating, among other things, an 18-hole golf course hewn from the bush, hundreds of villas that no one lives in and a luxury hotel whose design seems to share common features with the set of the television show ''Star Trek.''   A few years back, Yamoussoukro was just another village in the bush, but it had the distinction of being the birth place of Felix Houphouet-Boigny, who has ruled the Ivory Coast since its independence from France in 1960 and who is the doyen of West African leaders -so much so that his example of transforming his home village, at huge cost, has become something of a vogue.   President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, for instance, has built a retreat at Gbadolite, in northern Zaire. And President Ahmadou Ahidjo of Cameroon has a spread in Garoua, his hometown. The former Emperor of the Central African Republic, Jean-Bedel Bokassa, turned his home village of Berengo into a virtual seat of government, and the Presidents of Gabon and Togo have done the same.

headline: FORMER CHIEF OF AMAX RETIRING AS A DIRECTOR
abstract: Ian MacGregor, the former chief executive officer of Amax Inc., a diversified mining and energy development company based in Greenwich, Conn., will retire as a director in October at the age of 70, according to the proxy statement for the May 6 annual meeting.   When he retires at the ''normal retirement age'' for directors, however, Mr. MacGregor, who is currently chairman of the British Steel Corporation, will not cut all of his links to Amax, with which he has been associated for 25 years. The proxy states that he has a $25,000-a-year consulting agreement with the company until 1987, as long as he does not engage in competitive activities.

headline: POLISH DEBT NEGOTIATOR RELIEVED OF HIS POSITION
abstract: Poland's top debt negotiator, Marian Minkiewicz, was relieved tonight of his position as the chairman of Bank Handlowy, the Polish foreign trade bank.   Mr. Minkiewicz was recalled at his own request, according to an official announcement. His place is being taken by Stanislaw Kobak, formerly chairman of a large state-owned insurance company. No further explanation was provided.

headline: MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOUTH GEORGIA: FORBIDDING BATTLEFIELD
abstract: The island of South Georgia, where the Argentine takeover of the Falklands began, has become the focus of speculation as the place where the British effort to recapture the islands may also begin.   That is not likely to be a very pleasant prospect. South Georgia, a dependency of the Falkland Islands, is a forbidding outcropping of rock some 800 miles east of the Falklands. It is so climatically cruel that it is a permanent home for only seals and birds.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Anacomp Inc. said its wholly owned subsidiary, Anacomp Micrographics Inc., had extended to June 10 its tender offer for all outstanding shares of common stock of D.S.I. Corp. at $6.25 a share net in cash.   * Bearings Inc. and Barnes Engineering Co. announced an agreement for acquisition by Bearings of substantially all the assets of Advance Bearing and Supply Co., a subsidiary of Barnes.

headline: Market Place; Taking a Look At Culbro
abstract: THE CULBRO CORPORATION, the tobacco company, could be a stock for most seasons. Investors still worry about inflation, but the company's commercial acreage, formerly tobacco land, offers a major hedge against it.   Investors also worry about taxes. But Culbro has a large tax-loss carry forward. The company can earn substantial sums before it has to send a check to the Federal Treasury. Its cigar business, including such labels as White Owl, Robert Burns, William Penn and the recently acquired Garcia y Vega, is becoming more profitable.

headline: American Natural
abstract: American Natural Resources said it had withdrawn from the Alaskan Northwest Natural Gas Transportation Company, which would result in a $17 million charge against its second-quarter earnings. In 1981 American Natural had second-quarter earnings of $23.8 million.

headline: SYRIANS REFUSE LEBANON'S PLEA ON WITHDRAWAL
abstract: A Syrian official said today that President Elias Sarkis of Lebanon had asked for the withdrawal of Syrian forces from Beirut, but that the request had been turned down.    The Syrian official, Ahmed Iskander Ahmed, the Information Minister, said the request had been rejected because it appeared to have been made under duress, with Israeli guns trained on the Lebanese presidential palace.   (The disclosure came as an emergency council representing Lebanon's major factions met in Beirut to discuss ways of ending the Israeli siege of the city. The council meeting, its first, made no progress.  Page A10.)

headline: FOR MEXICO'S NUCLEAR POWER PLANS, THE WORD IS MANANA
abstract: MEXICO CITY THE polished pitchmen from the United States, Canada, France, Germany and Sweden have become familiar figures along the treelined streets and elegant corridors of this capital city. They have been engaged in an increasingly determined effort to sell the Mexicans an unusual piece of merchandise - a nuclear power plant that they hope will open the door to many others.   Their job isn't getting any easier. Last Tuesday the Mexican Government announced that any decision on Mexico's nuclear energy program would be shelved until at least December, when the next administration takes over. And with Mexico now pinched by declining oil revenues and a huge foreign debt, there are doubts that a decision on the program will be taken much before 1984.   For the world's nuclear power industry, which has pinned its hopes on Mexico's plans to buy as many as 20 nuclear reactors, the announcement could set back efforts to throw off a severe slump in sales. Vendors sold just 10 reactors last year, mainly in heavily oil-importing countries, and they have been viewing Mexico's proclaimed eagerness to become a major generator of nuclear power as perhaps the best opportunity to sell reactors for the next decade.  Orders are drying up in advanced industrialized nations, and even such eager customers as South Korea are slowing their atomic programs, largely because of slower growth in electricity demand.

headline: PRODUCTION BY OPEC INCHES UP
abstract: Increased crude oil output by Iran and Nigeria has increased total production by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to 17 million barrels a day, compared to the low of 16 million last month, a Middle East weekly oil publication reported here today.   ''This is still a very low level output by any standards,'' added the Middle East Economic Survey.

headline: MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THE ZIP IN ZERO-COUPON BONDS
abstract: THE liberalization of Individual Retirement Accounts has sent c reative minds scurrying for ways to tap that huge pool of potential i nvestment money, and one of the newest gimmicks is the zero-coupon b ond.   A zero-coupon bond is one that is issued at a huge discount - often at one-third to one-quarter of its face value - and then redeemed at full face value when it matures eight or 10 years later. In the interim, investors clip no coupons and receive no periodic interest - hence, the name zero coupon.   But at maturity, they receive a lump sum payment representing the principal they have lent the issuer, usually a large corporation, plus the interest that has accrued on the bond. Several brokerage firms are promoting zero-coupon bonds as ''money-multiplier notes,'' which can be bought for as little as $250 and redeemed in 10 years for $1,000. Eight-year bonds can be bought for about $333 and fiveyear bonds for $500. Yields are currently hovering around 13 1/2 percent.

headline: OLYMPIA ACCEPTS PABST OFFER
abstract: The Olympia Brewing Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by the Pabst Brewing Company for $69.9 million in cash and securities. The combination, if it is approved by the Justice Department and Olympia's shareholders, would create the nation's fourth-largest brewing company.   Robley W. Sundmacher, vice president of public affairs at Olympia, said, ''We want the Midwest market, which they have, and they want the Northwest,'' where Olympia's sales are concentrated. He said that while Pabst's offer last week had caught company officials by surprise, after discussions between the two boards, Olympia's directors had accepted it, under more favorable terms than originally proposed.

headline: Bus Plunge Kills 22 in Peru
abstract: A bus plunged into a deep canyon today, killing 22 people and injuring 15, the police reported. The accident occurred 45 miles east of Lima on the Central Highway, which connects the Pacific coast with the Peruvian highlands.

headline: MONEY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Iran Says Army Advances on Port
abstract: Iranian forces are advancing in a multipronged attack on the strategic oil port of Khurramshahr, the only major Iranian city still in Iraqi hands after 19 months of the Persian Gulf conflict, the Iranian press agency reported today.   Iraq said the Iranians were repulsed with heavy losses.  The military command in Teheran said the Iranian troops, advancing on at least three fronts, scored their first success shortly after midnight with the capture of the important Iraqi supply town of Shalemcheh.

headline: U.N. Warning on Food
abstract: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, warned a conference here today that the world food situation was at its most critical point since the early 1970's.   Mr. Perez de Cuellar was not present at yesterday's start of the conference, sponsored by the 36-member United Nations World Food Council.

headline: TESORO IS OBJECT OF DECISION
abstract: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation was the mystery defendant in a Federal appeals court decision requiring it to turn over internal documents to a grand jury investigating questionable overseas payments.   The appeals court in Washington ruled April 23 that ''a multinational Fortune 500 corporation whose activities have come under investigation'' had to give the grand jury some material developed in an in-house inquiry into illegal payments. A Government source confirmed yesterday that the company in question was Tesoro.

headline: PATENTS; New Process Developed To Treat Nuclear Waste
abstract: A method of treating high-level nuclear wastes such as those created in the United States military programs was patented this week by an Australian geochemist, Alfred Ringwood, who assigned Patent 4,329,248 to the Australian National University at Acton.  The process is directed at immobilizing radioactive wastes containing major amounts of aluminum and iron.

headline: STANDARD OIL (OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Real Estate; The Shift In Taxation For Transit
abstract: THERE will be more money for mass transit in New York City as a result of a change in real estate taxation, according to authoritative accounts.   The new system, recently approved by the State Legislature and signed by Governor Carey on April 5, will raise an estimated $42 million in the next fiscal year, according to figures developed by the New York City Finance Commission and the Real Estate Board of New York.   The controversial and recently repealed 10 percent tax on profits from major New York City real estate transactions, also intended to support mass transit, raised about $9 million since last October, when it took effect.   Figures used by the Finance Commission and the Real Estate Board provide this breakdown for the estimated revenues under the new tax system:   - Doubling the real property transfer tax, to 2 percent, on sales of $500,000 or more would raise $12 million.

headline: Kaiser Steel Pact
abstract: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said that it had signed an agreement for Kawasaki Steel of Japan to provide Kaiser with technical assistance to develop a system to move and control steel slabs to the Fontana plant. The study, scheduled for completion in September, will cover a system to transport up to 64 shiploads of purchased steel slabs a year, Kaiser said. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Around the World; Mauritians Go to Polls To Decide Leadership
abstract: Mauritians braved rain today to vote on whether to continue the 22-year rule of Prime Minister Seewoosagur Ramgoolam or replace his pro-West minority Labor Party Government with a left-leaning coalition.   When balloting on the Indian Ocean archipelago was suspended for an hour, about 60 percent of the 500,000 eligible voters had cast ballots.

headline: Chrysler Rebates
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation is offering factory-paid cash rebates through June 6 of $300 to $2,000 on selected models of Dodge trucks built in the United States, the company announced. Rebates include $300 on 1982 Ram Miser pickups and Rampage trucks, $500 on 1981 and 1982 Ram pickups, $750 on 1981-82 Royal S.E. pickups, $1,000 on 1981-82 Royal S.E. Ram wagons and $2,000 for 1981-82 Ramchargers, the No.3 United States auto maker said.

headline: General Foods Sees Profit Dip
abstract: The General Foods Corporation said that earnings for the fiscal year ended April 3 would be reduced by $1.20 a share as a result of selling its Burger Chef fast-food business and plans to close or sell other restaurants.   The total value of the reduction will be $59.31 million.

headline: Lehman Sued Over Nucorp
abstract: Two California investors have filed suit against Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., accusing the investment concern of fraudulently promoting the purchase of securities issued by Nucorp Energy Inc.   Lehman Brothers ''vigorously recommended'' the purchases last fall despite its access to information that the San Diego-based company was ''certainly not a wise investment,'' said David Cooper, a lawyer with Irvine & Cooper of Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Boston International Finance Corp., a subisidary of First National Boston Corp., will make a public offering of $100 million of 14 1/4 percent Eurodollar notes due June 1, 1989, at 99 1/2 percent, to be guaranteed by First National Boston Corp.   * I.T.T. Financial Corp. is offering $250 million principal amount of serial zero coupon senior debentures due in 1983-1992, to be sold through a Lehman Brothers group.

headline: BRITISH SAY NEW ARMS FOR ARGENTINA WOULD MEAN LONG, HIT-AND-RUN WAR
abstract: British views on the duration and nature of the conflict with Argentina will change drastically if it proves true, as reported here, that Buenos Aires is receiving Gabriel missiles and additional Mirage and Dagger fighter-bombers and Exocet air-tosurface missiles.   In that event, British analysts said, the expected elimination of Argentine military power on the Falkland Islands would not end the conflict but would usher in a period of hit-and-run warfare by air and sea in which the islands' British garrison and supply lines would be under constant attack.   Although British officials do not believe that additional weapons can prevent an eventual British victory in the war, they fear that their delivery to Argentina would insure continuation of the conflict. Strikes by Argentine aircraft armed with Gabriel or Exocet missiles from bases on the mainland, one official said, might force London to reconsider the question of British air attacks on bases in Argentina. Such attacks are now forbidden.

headline: Wickes Auditor
abstract: The Wickes Companies, now operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, named Arthur Andersen & Company as its independent auditor for the fiscal year 1983, succeeding Coopers & Lybrand. Wickes said the change had been made so it could ''take a fresh look at the company and its problems.''

headline: Western Features Sells Sponsored Comic Strips
abstract: The latest advertising incursion into previous ad-free areas of print is the sponsored comic strip, according to Editor & Publisher.

headline: Taiwan Acts to Widen Its Nuclear Technology
abstract: Taiwan has announced plans to reduce its almost complete reliance on the United States for nuclear expertise by seeking French technology to reprocess its weapons-grade nuclear wastes.   Officials said the move, announced yesterday by the head of the Taiwan Power Company, showed that the Nationalist Government intended to insure continued operation of its nuclear power stations at a time when its relations with the United States were uncertain.

headline: Knight-Ridder In Affiliated Tie
abstract: Affiliated Publications and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. have signed an agreement that could lead to marketing a home information system, called Viewtron, in Boston, both companies announced.

headline: U.S. SAID TO FAVOR INFORMAL REAGAN-BREZHNEV TALK
abstract: The Reagan Administration is considering a full-fledged summit meeting in October between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev, but prefers an informal get-together of the two leaders, Administration officials reported today.   Senior officials said that internal Government memos were circulating on the pros and cons of a Reagan-Brezhnev meeting in either Austria or Ireland, but that the President himself had made ''no decision'' so far.   While they could not exclude the possibility that he might agree, these officials said that, contrary to a report in The Washington Post, the issue had not been discussed lately with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union or had even gone to President Reagan for a decision.

headline: Article 051285 -- No Title
abstract: Gov. John Spellman, turning aside national security arguments, today rejected a proposal for a port and pipeline to carry Alaskan crude oil to refineries in the Northwest and upper Middle West.   Governor Spellman said the need to protect the environment of Puget Sound, under which the pipeline would pass, outweighed the benefits of the $2.7 billion plan.   ''I have rejected the application because the proposed project constituted a very real threat to Puget Sound, which is a national treasure,'' the Governor said. ''I cannot allow the Sound, its delicate ecology or the economy and life style it supports to become endangered.''

headline: BUSINESS ECONOMISTS PESSIMISTIC
abstract: The nation's leading business economists released a grim forecast today that shows only a weak recovery in the last half of 1982, with high unemployment and high interest rates continuing to the end of the year.   A poll of 400 members of the National Association of Business Economists found, however, that they believed that inflation would remain in check, with price rises averaging less than 6 percent this year and next year.   The relative pessimism of the economists who advise companies, banks, agencies of the Government and other institutions offered little election-year comfort to the Reagan Administration, now locked in battle with Congress over tax and spending policies.

headline: P.L.O.'S ALLY SAYS GUERRILLA GROUP APPEARS 'FINISHED'
abstract: The principal Lebanese ally of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Beirut said today, ''The P.L.O.  as it used to be in Lebanon is finished.''   With the Palestinians trapped in western Beirut and Israeli jets continuing to attack their encampments, that assessment was made by Walid Jumblat, who heads the National Movement, a coalition of Moslem militias and leftist groups.   As the main leftist Moslem spokesman, Mr. Jumblat has represented one of the two major contending Lebanese forces. The other is made up of the Christian militias.

headline: SALES OF STEREOS ARE LESS SOUND AS AUDIO INDUSTRY'S MARKETS SLIP
abstract: AS surely as the needle tracks the groove, the stereo component i ndustry followed a path of ever-rising sales and profits during the 1 970's boom decade. But a three-year-long sales slump has worsened t his year, as a critical surplus of stereo components threatens the i ndustry's profitability as prices plummet.   Many factors have contributed to the industry-wide recession: intense competition from different electronic entertainment products, most notably video; shrinkage of the key 18- to-24-year-old age group, which buys most audio equipment; tightening of consumer credit in the late 1970's, and the general recessionary economy that has reduced consumer interest in many luxury goods.   There is no formal industry-wide technical definition of hi-fi equipment. But the industry describes itself as manufacturers of high-quality stereo component gear - as opposed to all-in-one compact stereos or low-grade, low-cost audio components with questionable sound reproduction ability. The makers of such brands as Pioneer, Technics, Fisher, Sony and JVC rode the demographic wave of steadily increasing numbers of males between the ages of 18 and 24, which make up most of its purchasers.

headline: Economic Scene; Pragmatism And Dowries
abstract: WITH so much excitement around the world - Israelis battling Syrians in Lebanon, the British rounding up Argentines in the Falklands, the biggest crowd in the history of the nation calling for a nuclear freeze -the economic story has been driven off page 1.  President Reagan doubtless hopes it will stay off.   The recession has slowed to a walk. The industrial production index fell only two-tenths of 1 percent last month, and some economists thought that would be the last decline before the economy starts to crawl upward.

headline: GLEASON WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Chessie Port Plans
abstract: The Chessie System plans to spend more than $58 million and create 145 new jobs to modernize and add to its rail and coal loading facilities here, a Chessie spokesman said. The railroad has asked the Peninsula Ports Authority of Virginia for permission to sell tax-free industrial revenue bonds to finance the project.

headline: ISRAELI ARRAIGNED IN MOSQUE RAID
abstract: Shouting ''Justice! Justice!'' an Americanborn Israeli soldier was taken into a court here today for arraignment for his rifle attack Sunday at the Dome of the Rock Mosque. The soldier, Alan Harry Goodman, was ordered held for 15 days pending trial on charges of murdering two Arabs and wounding 30 others.   After his initial outburst, the soldier sat quietly to listen to Judge Chanan Shellah ask him if he had anything to say in his defense.

headline: A TOUGH-MINDED WEST POINTER
abstract: Nearly 20 years ago, Edward Leon Rowny poured after-dinner cognac for some guests in his cramped rooms in a Saigon bachelor officers' quarters, put a recording of his own harmonica music on a tape deck and settled back to ask several reporters their impressions of how the Vietnam War was going in the Mekong Delta.  Startled by the reporters' pessimistic views, a newly arrived colonel who was also present objected that they must be mistaken. Mr. Rowny, then a major general, interrupted in a gruff voice, ''Shut up dummy, you might learn something.''
