In the next 16 years General Rowny was given only one more general's star, but he retained a reputation as a skeptical intellect, suspicious of official policy lines, willing to listen to diverse points of view and with a strong dislike for polishing apples. New Treaty Is Aim   Today in Geneva, General Rowny, who retired from the army in 1979 to be free to oppose the strategic arms limitation treaty signed that year, began the task of attempting to negotiate with the Soviet Union a new treaty on reductions in long-range nuclear weapons.

headline: GETTING A BIG BOARD LISTING
abstract: Minutes before 10 A.M. yesterday, officials from National Utilities and Industries entered the crowded trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange, where N.U.I. was getting ready to be listed on the Big Board for the first time in the company's 127-year history.   John Kean, N.U.I.'s lithe, mustachioed president, found the going tricky. It is barely possible to breathe on the floor, an untidy labyrinth where the stocks of America's major corporations are traded. New ones join and old ones leave on about a weekly basis.  N.U.I. was the 32d listing this year and was neither more nor less momentous than the others.

headline: U.S. SAYS HAIG EFFORT SEEMS TO FAIL AND FALKLANDS FIGHTING IS LIKELY
abstract: Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s diplomatic efforts had apparently failed to produce a solution in the Falklands crisis. They said heavy fighting between Argentina and Britain was likely to begin in the next day or so unless there was an unexpected development.   Mr. Haig, in a closed-door briefing for the House Foreign Affairs Committee today, said that he had not completely given up hope for a diplomatic solution but that there was little chance that fighting over the Falkland Islands could be averted.   According to several participants in the meeting, Mr. Haig added that once it became apparent there was no longer a plausible prospect for a negotiated settlement, the Administration would publicly make it clear that it stood with Britain in the crisis. He left open the possibility that, even if fighting began, there might still be an opportunity for a diplomatic solution.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 30, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Subcommittee on Petitions - 10:30 A.M.   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M.

headline: BRITAIN DECLARES RETAKING STANLEY IS NEXT OBJECTIVE
abstract: British troops are poised for a drive across East Falkland Island toward the Argentine garrison at Stanley despite the ''grievous'' loss of a destroyer and a merchant ship in air raids on Tuesday, Defense Secretary John Nott declared today.   Mr. Nott told a sad and solemn House of Commons that the 3,500-ton destroyer Coventry had capsized after being bombed and strafed at the northern entrance to Falkland Sound and that the 15,000-ton container ship Atlantic Conveyor, requisitioned from Cunard for use as a makeshift aircraft carrier, had been crippled by two Exocet missiles.   A total of 24 men were killed on the two ships, bringing known British losses to 100, he said, and about 25 others were wounded. Bleak Day for Britain   British officials freely acknowledged that Tuesday, National Day in Argentina, had been the bleakest of the war for this country. But they said they had continued to chip away at Argentine air strength, shooting down four Skyhawks and a fifth, unspecified plane.

headline: Brown's President Adds Chief's Post
abstract: Brown Group Inc., one of the nation's largest shoe manufacturers, announced yesterday that B.A. Bridgewater Jr., president and chief operating officer, had been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer.   The company, based in St. Louis, said that the 48-year-old Mr.  Bridgewater was replacing W.L. Hadley Griffin, 64, who remains as chairman and chairman of the executive committee. ''This was part of an orderly transition that we have been carrying out for several years,'' Mr. Bridgewater said.

headline: SEX BIAS OR CLASH OF CULTURES
abstract: For Lisa Avagliano, whose case the United States Supreme Court will hear April 26, it seems like a simple matter of justice.  Miss Avagliano went straight from college to Sumitomo Shoji America Inc., an American subsidiary of one of Japan's largest trading companies. Starting in 1976, Miss Avagliano earned $170 a week for reading and sorting telexes, sending out estimates and invoices, and doing general secretarial work. It wasn't long before she felt stuck in her job.   ''You just knew you weren't going to get anywhere,'' she said. ''I was doing the same job as most of the Japanese men, but I knew it was useless to think I could have the same opportunities, even though I had as much education. All the women were in clerical jobs. I think they really honestly thought women were inferior.''   So together with 11 other women employees, Miss Avagliano filed an employment discrimination complaint against Sumitomo. Miss Avagliano, whose name has been spelled Avigliano on all the court papers, has since left Sumitamo, as have all but one of the other plaintiffs.

headline: GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Continental's Bid To Be Resisted
abstract: Management Assistance Inc. will ''vigorously oppose'' any attempt by the Continental Telephone Corporation to gain control of the computer company, Raymond P. Kur@shan, chairman and president of Managemeft Assistance, said.   Management Assistance, a data-processing and computer company, reported that it had learned through a required filing by Continental with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the Atlanta company had increased its shares in Management Assistance to 14.5 percent of the outstanding common and may seek more in order to attain the 20 percent necessary to claim a pro rata share of the computer company's earnings.   Mr. Kurshan said that Continental, the nation's third-largest telephone company, had been ''pursuing a surreptitious plan'' to acquire Management Assistance.

headline: ORDERS FOR TOOLS RISE 11.6%
abstract: Orders for new machine tools rose 11.6 percent in April, to $153.8 million, from $137.8 million in March, according to the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.   Industry shipments, however, fell during April, to $303.2 million.  The industry group, in a report prepared for release today, said that shipments dropped 26 percent from $411 million in March and were off 32 percent from April 1981.

headline: U.N. Security Council Decides Not to Discuss Iraq-Iran War
abstract: Security Council members decided today not to open a public debate on the Iraqi-Iranian war as Jordan had requested.   Jordan, the only Middle Eastern country on the 15-nation Council, has supported Iraq and called on the Council on Sunday to consider a public session to discuss the present situation.   But members said after a private meeting that Jordan had agreed not to press the request once Iran and Iraq had made it known that neither was interested in having a public debate at this time.

headline: G.M.-Toyota Pact Denied
abstract: The General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Company ended their second round of talks on joint production of small-model autos in the United States without reaching any concrete agreement, a Toyota spokesman said.

headline: IN UNLIKELY BOTSWANA, SINISTER SPY PLOTS UNFOLD
abstract: When the British decided to turn what was known as Bechuanaland into an independent state called Botswana, they looked around and discovered there was nothing resembling a capital in which to hold an independence ceremony.   So they hastily summoned a team of town planners who then dreamed up the Gaborone that has since risen, if not exactly blossomed, in this arid setting.   Although it is undeniably symmetrical, Gaborone still has an accidental look when viewed from the air, for it is not instantly apparent what it is doing there in a seemingly illimitable expanse of scrubby bush.   On the ground, it has the feeling more of a campus than a city. No lore or mystique attaches to its name. No one could possibly take it for a center of international intrigue, the kind of place that might tickle the muse of a Le Carre. Yet Gaborone has its share of mysteries.

headline: MARSHALL & ILSLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tadzhikistan Leader Named
abstract: The Communist Party of Soviet Tadzhikistan has named Rakhman Nabiyev as its First Secretary, replacing Dzhabar Rasulov, who died earlier this month, the official Tass press agency reported today. Mr. Nabiyev was premier of Tadzhikistan, a predominately Moslem Central Asian republic bordering Afghanistan and Pakistan, Tass reported.

headline: GRAHAM PREACHES AT CHURCH IN MOSCOW
abstract: The Rev. Billy Graham preached his message of disarmament and Christian rebirth at a tightly guarded Baptist church here today while outside 250 Christians sang hymns from behind police barriers.   The 1,000 ticket-holders who squeezed into the Moscow Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists, including a sizable number of foreigners, reporters and security officers, heard Mr. Graham inveigh against atomic weapons, which he said had put man ''at the gate of hell,'' and give a spirited appeal for a recommitment to Christ.   But as he has since his arrival here Friday, Mr. Graham stayed clear of any references to religious freedom in this officially atheist nation or other topics potentially offensive to Soviet authorities. At one point in his sermon he said Jesus gave man ''the power to be a better worker, a loyal citizen.''

headline: NICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Stake in Bathurst
abstract: Consolidated-Bathurst Inc., a diversified forest products concern, said that the Associated Newspapers Group had increased its holding in the company's stock to about 15 percent of the total outstanding. As of Feb. 26, Associated Newspapers beneficially owned 3.3 million Consolidated-Bathurst shares, the company said in its proxy statement for the annual meeting. The company did not disclose the value of the holdings.

headline: CONDOMINIUM RISES ALONG HUDSON IN EDGEWATER, N.J.
abstract: For years this small municipality (population: 4,600; size: three and a half miles by a quarter mile) seemed destined to be bypassed by the slow but steady march of high-rise office and residential development along the west bank of the Hudson River from West New York to Fort Lee. The main reason was that its riverfront, which lies directly across from Lincoln Center and Upper West Side neighborhoods, was largely occupied by industrial plants and warehouses.   Now, as they have closed, development has come with a rush to Edgewater,, causing the town's planning board to delay approval of new projects while studying the impact of large-scale development on the town.   The activity has brought controversy, too; three residential projects appproved for the riverfront by town officials are being challenged in court by citizens' groups.

headline: FILMWAYS NARROWS 4TH-QUARTER LOSS
abstract: Filmways Inc., a diversified entertainment company, said yesterday that it narrowed its loss to $40 million in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1982 from $46 million in the three months a year earlier.   Filmways, which underwent a major reorganization on Feb. 28, said that in the latest three months it had a loss from discontinued operations of $7.5 million, while in the corresponding quarter a year earlier, it had a loss from discontinued operations of $8.6 million.   Filmways said that revenues in the latest quarter dropped 26 percent, to $20.2 million, from $27.3 million. The Los Angeles-based concern produces and distributes motion pictures, publishes books and magazines, and manufactures broadcast equipment and photoslide mounts.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 14, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on Non-Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: VOLUME HEAVY
abstract: The stock market declined slightly yesterday in heavy trading that featured General Motors as the stellar attraction for investors.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range through most of the session, closed off 0.10 point, to 865.77.  Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored stocks that advanced in price by a 780-to-681 margin.

headline: Trucking Costs
abstract: The average cost of owning and operating a heavy truck rose nearly 14 percent in 1981 and a hauler will spend more than $520,000 to run a tractor-trailer over the next five years, a study released today showed. In its annual study, the Hertz Corporation said that the cost of running a truck had tripled since the Arab oil embargo of 1973. It said that the average per-mile cost to operate a five-axle diesel tractor-trailer was 82.3 cents a mile in 1981, compared with 72.45 cents the year before and 27.4 cents in 1971.

headline: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 2 Geneva Banks Are Bombed
abstract: Bombs exploded at two downtown Geneva banks, causing considerable damage but no injuries, the police said today.

headline: 26 Reported Slain in Mexico
abstract: Cattlemen and hired gunmen killed 26 peasants outside an east Mexican town in a dispute over land, the official Notimex press agency said today. It quoted the mayor of Mecapalapa, 180 miles east of here, as saying the cattlemen had ordered the killings to end a five-day occupation by the peasants of grazing land near the village.

headline: 2 SYRIANS OUSTED
abstract: A powerful car bomb tore through a crowded street in central Paris at rush hour this morning, killing a young woman and injuring 46 people.  The French Government, in a statement four hours later, expelled two Syrian diplomats and recalled its ambassador from Damascus for consultation.   Interior Minister Gaston Defferre, announcing the expulsions during a television statement on the bomb explosion, said that the perpetrators of such attacks were using French territory for ''settlements of accounts which have nothing to do with France,'' an apparent reference to the longstanding underground war between Syrian and Iraqi secret services.   After saying that the Government would not rest until it had found the attackers, Mr. Defferre added, ''Here and now the Government has decided to declare the military attache and the cultural attache of the Syrian Embassy non grata because of their activities'' in France. He stopped just short of explicitly making Syria responsible for the explosion.

headline: EAST GERMAN PASTORS PROTEST BAN ON PACIFIST BADGES
abstract: A letter read by Protestant ministers at Easter Sunday services in East Berlin and in neighboring areas of East Germany today accused the Communist authorities of alienating young people by refusing to allow them to wear badges and armbands advocating disarmament.   The ban on the badges, worn by a small number of youths who have called for arms reduction and protested against militarism in East Germany, was re-emphasized during the week by Klaus Gysi, the Government's State Secretary for Church Affairs.   According to West German news agency reports that quoted from the letter, Mr. Gysi told representatives of the Protestant Church Conference that the symbols - a sword beaten into a plowshare - were being misused and were undermining military service in East Germany.The symbol itself was produced by church groups for a peace forum last year.

headline: ORANGE & ROCKLAND UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Alfa Romeo Cites Gain
abstract: Alfa Romeo S.p.A. has achieved a 28.2 percent increase in productivity in the last few weeks, helped by a 13.7 percent cut in its work force, Ettore Massacesi, chairman, said today.

headline: CAPITAL OF CHAD REPORTED TO FALL
abstract: The capital of Chad fell today to rebel forces commanded by Hissen Habre, a former Defense Minister, the French Embassy there reported.   The seizure of the city, Ndjamena, would mark the culmination of two years of fighting between Mr. Habre's Armed Forces of the North and troops loyal to President Goukouni Oueddei.   French officials here, quoting reports from the embassy in Ndjamena, said the rebels met little resistance.  The officials said they were unable to confirm diplomatic reports that President Goukouni had been killed crossing the River Chari, which forms the frontier with Cameroon.

headline: Air Products Merger Accord
abstract: Air Products and Chemicals Inc., a major industrial gas and chemical producer, said its board had approved a definitive merger agreement to acquire the Stearns-Roger Corporation, an engineering and construction concern, for $210 million in cash. The companies also agreed to a $20 million reduction from the previously announced price of $230 million.

headline: Fiat's Profit Up
abstract: Fiat S.p.A. said today that its net income last year rose to 97 billion lire, or $76 million, from 51 billion lire a year earlier. The auto maker also raised its dividend to 140 lire from 125.

headline: METROMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CUBA ASSAILS U.S. ROLE IN CRISIS OVER FALKLANDS
abstract: Cuba denounced the United States today for supporting Britain over the Falkland Islands. It offered to join other Latin American countries in providing ''all necessary help'' to Argentina in the conflict.   The attack, which came at the opening of a meeting of foreign ministers of the third-world nations professing nonalignment, prompted an official United States observer to walk out in protest.

headline: Cattle on Feed Rise
abstract: The number of cattle fattened in feedlots prior to slaughter April 1 rose 2 percent from a year earlier for the first year-to-year rise in four years, the Agriculture Department said today. Cattle and calves on feed in 13 states totaled 8.82 million head. The figure was 2 percent less than two years ago.

headline: ROWAN COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VOTE IN U.N. HEALTH AGENCY
abstract: Hard-line Arab countries lost their bid today to have the World Health Organization transfer its Eastern Mediterranean regional office from Alexandria to Amman. However, in a secret vote in committee, the United Nations Agency's annual assembly of member states decided by 57 to 37, with 21 abstentions, to shelve the issue until next year.

headline: Amax Reduces Colorado Mining
abstract: Amax Inc., the mining and metals producer, said it would begin in early May an additional 20 percent reduction in manpower and production at its molybdenum operations in Colorado. Some 380 employees at the Climax mine and about 230 employees at the Henderson mine will be affected.

headline: Israeli in Larceny Case Resigns From Cabinet
abstract: An Israeli Cabinet official who received a suspended prison sentence last week for larceny and breach of trust resigned from the Cabinet today, effective this weekend.   The official, Aharon Abuhazira, Minister of Labor, Welfare and Immigrants Absorption, submitted his letter of resignation to the Prime Minister's office after the Central Committee of his party, Tami, authorized it Thursday night.

headline: Savings Yields Rising Today
abstract: Increasing interest rates on Treasury securities auctioned yesterday raised the yields that banks and savings institutions may pay on various kinds of savings certificates.   Based on results of yesterday's 91-day Treasury bill auction, savings institutions may pay a top rate of 12.074 percent on new 91-day certificates beginning today while banks may pay a top rate of 11.824 percent.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 29, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Special Session of the General As- sembly Devoted to Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT CUT IN QUARTER
abstract: The deficit in the United States merchandise trade balance with foreign nations narrowed to $5.9 billion in the first quarter of this year as imports of oil and other products fell, the Commerce Department reported today.   But Commerce Department officials said they expected the deficit for all of 1982 to surpass last year's $27.9 billion, although the first-quarter deficit was well below the $9.1 billion registered in the fourth quarter of 1981.   Shortly after the report was issued, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted that the broadest measure of United States foreign trade -the ''current account,'' which encompasses services as well as goods -would likely show a surplus in 1982 for the fourth consecutive year.

headline: SOLIDARITY RADIO URGES POLES TO STAGE PROTESTS THURSDAY
abstract: A clandestine Radio Solidarity broadcast called tonight for a 15-minute strike in the capital and other acts of symbolic protest on Thursday to mark five months of martial law.   The transmission, which lasted less than a minute, was drowned out by a strong emission of rock music on a nearby frequency. The interference was apparently caused by the authorities to block the pirate broadcast.

headline: Buckley and Burt Appointed To New Posts at State Dept.
abstract: President Reagan named Richard Burt today to be Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs and James L.  Buckley to be State Department counselor.

headline: Costa Ricans in Jerusalem
abstract: Costa Rica today became the first nation to move its embassy in Israel back to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv.

headline: 30 INJURED IN WEST BANK-GAZA VIOLENCE
abstract: Violent protests erupted in the Israelioccupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today over the rifle attack by an Israeli soldier on Moslems in the Dome of the Rock Mosque.   Sixteen Arabs were reported shot by soldiers breaking up the demonstrations, and an Israeli television cameraman working for the European television service Viznews was struck in the shoulder by a bullet that had apparently ricocheted. Fourteen Israelis and tourists were reportedly struck by stones hurled by protesters angered over the shooting in the mosque on Sunday.   Scores of Arabs were detained by the police as a result of the violence, and 30 were still in jail at nightfall.  The two Moslems who were slain by rifle fire in the mosque were buried as dusk fell in an Islamic cemetery near the Lions Gate of the Old City. A large Israeli force was in attendance.

headline: East/West Network Takes Over Clipper
abstract: East/West Network, which already publishes magazines for travelers on nine airlines as well as on Amtrak, will take over the publishing of Clipper, the in-flight magazine of Pan American World Airways with its July issue.   East/West will be taking over from Ziff-Davis, which has been publisher for the last two years, having itself been in charge of advertising sales since January.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Acton Corp. said it had entered into a $36 million long-term revolving credit agreement with a group of banks led by the American Security Bank of Washington.   * Arkla Inc. announced the setting up of two-year credit arrangements with several banks for a total amount of $255 million, increasing its bank lines to about $330 million.

headline: Money Fund Assets Rise
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market funds grew by $515 million, to a record $202.9 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   The 122 general purpose funds, including four new funds, gained $327 million, to give them total assets of $65.76 billion.

headline: NORPAC EXPLORATION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Shuffle at McDonald's
abstract: Edward H. Schmitt, 56, has been elected to the newly created position of vice chairman of the McDonald's Corporation, the leading fast-food concern. The company's board elected Michael R. Quinlan, 37, president of the corporation, succeeding Mr. Schmitt, who will continue as chief administrative officer.

headline: VICTORIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. ENVOY AFFIRMS SALVADOR POLICY
abstract: The United States Ambassador, Deane R.  Hinton, said today that the election of a right-wing coalition to lead the new Constituent Assembly would not affect the Reagan Administration's policy toward the country.   Mr. Hinton said the Administration's support of the Government here ''will continue in any case.'' He said he ''would certainly hope'' that Congress would not suspend military and economic aid to El Salvador as a result of the Assembly vote.   Roberto d'Aubuisson, head of the far right-wing Nationalist Republian Alliance, was named president of the Assembly Thursday night, and members of his party and two other right-wing parties were chosen for all eight other positions in the Assembly leadership. The centrist Christian Democrats received no key legislative posts.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The British are a pragmatic people, and their postwar history has been a process of accommodation to the reality of reduced power and to the need to act in concert with allies.   But now, in the wake of the triumph over Argentina, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher seems prepared to lead a nationalist revival. In the euphoria of victory, she has sounded increasingly like Charles de Gaulle, increasingly determined to tell the world that Britain is quite able to work out its own solutions to its own problems.   Thus in her statement to the House Commons on Tuesday, Mrs.  Thatcher emphasized several times the ''will to succeed'' that this country had shown in the Falklands. And she angrily told Michael Foot, the opposition leader, that British servicemen had not died in the Falklands so she could turn the islands over to international control.

headline: AMERICAN MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; April 7, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on Nonuse of Force in International Relations - 3 P.M.   Conference on the Law of the Sea - 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Ad Hoc Intergovernmental Working Group of Experts on International Standards of Accounting and Report- ing - 10 A.M.

headline: UNILEVER PROFITS UP 5%
abstract: H.F. Ahmanson & Company, parent company of the nation's largest savings and loan association, reported a first-quarter loss today of $42.4 million. Ahmanson reported earnings of $2 million, or 9 cents a share, in the 1981 first quarter.   Ahmanson blamed continued high interest rates for the reverse, noting that its interest expenses for the first quarter were 38 percent higher than in 1981, while first-quarter revenues were only 27 percent higher.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Anschutz Corp., a privately held Denver concern, said it had purchased a Missouri copper scrap refining facility, formerly owned by a Penn Central Corp. unit, for undisclosed terms.   * Artek Systems Corp. of Farmingdale, L.I., said its board had adopted a plan of reorganization and a revised agreement to merge with a Dynatech Corp. subsidiary.   * BRT Realty Trust said lending banks had waived any default under its credit agreement through July 30 arising from the its failure to repay $2,835,000 in debt.

headline: 2 Educators Freed in Poland
abstract: A Warsaw University dean and another educator were released from internment after a written protest from faculty members, university sources said today. The educators, who were released Monday after three days' internment, were among 43 persons officially reported interned after last week's demonstrations against martial law.

headline: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Heileman Bid for Pabst Held Likely to Succeed
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company is likely to accept a $196.8 million cash offer that the G. Heileman Brewing Company made for it on Friday, industry analysts said yesterday.   Pabst has refused repeated offers from C. Schmidt & Sons, a small Philadelphia brewer whose most recent offer was $25.50 a share, which included $5 in subordinated debentures. The Heileman bid was for $24 a share in cash.

headline: 6 Oil States in Pact
abstract: Finance and economy ministers from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates have agreed to abolish customs tariffs on national products and apply new and freer transit and travel regulations from Dec. 1, the official Saudi press agency said today.

headline: BURGER KING CORP. REPLACES CHAIRMAN
abstract: Louis P. Neeb will step down as chairman and chief executive of the Burger King Corporation on June 1, the fast-food chain's parent, the Pillsbury Company, said yesterday.   Mr. Neeb, 43 years old, said he will ''explore a variety of business opportunities,'' including the possibility of becoming a Burger King franchisee. He will be replaced by Norman E. Brinker, 50, president of Pillsbury's restaurant group.

headline: Braniff Holds Debt Talks
abstract: The Braniff International Corporation presented a plan yesterday to restructure its $733.2 million of debt to 39 of its creditors at a meeting in its headquarters at Dallas-Forth Worth Airport.   Sam Coats, a vice president and spokesman for Braniff, said in a telephone interview that the meeting lasted most of the day and that the lenders would now evaluate the plan.

headline: China-Canada Grain Accord
abstract: China has agreed to buy $1.8 billion (Canadian) worth of wheat from Canada over the next three years, the Government announced today.   The agreement is the sixth between the two nations since 1961 and calls for annual shipments of between 3.5 million and 4.2 million metric tons starting on Aug. 1, an increase of 700,000 tons over an agreement expiring this year.

headline: 6 ARGENTINE JETS REPORTED DOWNED IN FALKLAND RAID
abstract: Six Argentine aircraft were shot down and three others were probably downed in fighting between British and Argentine forces over the Falkland Islands, the British Defense Ministry announced Sunday night.   Early this morning, the ministry acknowledged that one British frigate, which was earlier reported to have ''sustained some damage,'' was on fire in Falkland Sound.   There were unconfirmed reports, meanwhile, that British forces , meanwhile, were unofficially reported to be were advancing on the airstrip at Goose Green after intensive bombing there early this morning by British planes. The airstrip is near the settlement of Darwin and is about 17 miles south of the British beachhead at San Carlos Bay, where about 5,000 troops reportedly reinforced and consolidated their ground positions Sunday.

headline: LEWELLYN PLEADS NOT GUILTY
abstract: Gary Lewellyn, the stockbroker who is accused of embezzling $13.5 million from his father's bank in the tiny town of Humboldt, pleaded not guilty today to eight charges of embezzlement and making false statements to bank officers. Mr.  Lewellyn, who has already pleaded guilty to a criminal contempt charge in New York, did not volunteer any grounds for his latest plea.   Conviction could carry a maximum penalty of 34 years in prison.  Trial was scheduled for July 19 in United States District Court here. He remained free on an unsecured $500,000 bond.

headline: TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POPE MAY CANCEL VISIT TO BRITAIN
abstract: Basil Cardinal Hume said tonight that Pope John Paul II would cancel his visit to Britain, scheduled to begin on May 28, if hostilities between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands had not ceased by the middle of next week.   Speaking to reporters at Heathrow Airport after returning from talks with the Pope in Rome, Cardinal Hume, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster, said that British church authorities hoped to postpone a decision for as long as possible.

headline: Penn Central Corp.  Will Keep Arvida
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday that it had decided not to sell the Arvida Corporation, a real estate developer with extensive land in southern Florida.   ''We didn't receive an offer we thought was competitive,'' said Charles E. Cobb Jr., whose promotion from chairman and chief executive officer of Arvida to senior executive vice president and chief operating officer of Penn Central was effected yesterday.

headline: STAR SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LATE SELLING REVERSES PRECIOUS METAL GAINS
abstract: A late burst of selling erased modest early gains in silver and gold futures yesterday. Brokers described the trading in precious metals and most other commodity markets as trendless, attributing the early advances of 10 cents an ounce in silver and $10 an ounce in gold to the heightening of the Falkland Islands conflict.   The final bell on New York's Commodity Exchange, the leading metals futures market, found gold bullion virtually unchanged on the eve of the expiration of the spot April contracts. While April gold closed unchanged at $352, the active near June delivery eased 20 cents an ounce to finish at $356.50. Spot silver, meanwhile, closed down 14.5 cents an ounce at $7.102, with the active May contract of 15 cents at $7.11.

headline: EAST EUROPE'S BURDEN OF DEBT
abstract: While Poland and Rumania have borne the brunt of the problem thus far, Eastern Europe's huge $60 billion debt to the West is putting strains on almost every member of the Communist bloc.    Weak demand for their exports has cut into the revenue that was to pay off the debt. The lenders, facing their own political pressures, are holding back on new credits while trying to decide how to help their debtors. High interest rates in the open market have added to the problem.   Given the pinch, there is widespread conjecture that Hungary and East Germany, once the Eastern bloc's economic showcases, may follow Poland and Rumania in asking to delay debt payments.

headline: Bush Visits Army Units Stationed in South Korea
abstract: Vice President Bush watched American soldiers at this forward base today prepare to patrol the Demilitarized Zone between South Korea and North Korea.   ''Most impressive,'' Mr. Bush said after talking with troops and looking at their weapons, ''and very, very important.'' Mr. Bush first toured the headquarters of the combined field army for a briefing, then went to a South Korean hill post overlooking North Korea, and finally to Warrior Base, headquarters of the First Battalion, 23d Infantry, of the American Second Division, about two miles south of the zone.

headline: Business Conditions; A ROBUST BOOK REVIVAL
abstract: In the face of findings that 20 million to 30 million Americans are functional illiterates and that home computers and cable television are absorbing leisure time, book sales are showing surprisingly robust growth. Last year sales were 9 percent above 1980's levels, and books did even better in this year's first quarter.

headline: THAYER TO GIVE UP CHIEF'S TITLE AT LTV
abstract: Paul Thayer, the 62-year-old chief executive of the LTV Corporation, will relinquish his title on Dec.1 to Raymond A. Hay, president and chief operating officer, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Thayer, who took over leadership of the Dallas-based company in 1970, is credited with rescuing the then-foundering conglomerate from bankruptcy.   Mr. Thayer will remain as chairman until his retirement in 1984, in accordance with a planned management transition, LTV said. Mr.Hay, 53, has been president and chief operating officer since 1975, when he came to LTV from the Xerox Corporation.   ''Many chief executives retain the chief executive officer title right up until the day they retire,'' Mr. Thayer said in remarks prepared for LTV's annual meeting in Dallas yesterday. ''I don't think that this is the best practice for most companies, including LTV. I have recommended to the board of directors, and they have agreed, that we will make the transition differently.''

headline: Trading Stays Heavy In Treasury Futures
abstract: Trading in the new 10-year Treasury note futures continued at a hectic pace yesterday. Although prices closed slightly higher, this was considered less important than the huge open interest - the number of contracts outstanding - that has developed in just three days of trading.   Indeed, the open interest at Monday's close, 19,478 contracts with a face value of $100,000 each, was by far the largest ever recorded for the opening day of a new futures market in the history of the commodity industry.

headline: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RECOVERY PROSPECTS FOR CHIPS
abstract: The semiconductor industry is showing signs of emerging from its protracted slump. Industry executives and analysts say that new orders are at the highest level in nearly two years, excess prouction capacity is diminishing and soft prices have firmed a bit.   No one, however, seems willing to proclaim that a recovery is at hand. They fear that the recent upturn might be only temporary, especially if the overall economy does not improve.

headline: TELEDYNE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Francana Buy-Out
abstract: Sceptre Resources Ltd., a Canadian oil and gas exploration company based in Calgary, Alberta, said it had completed its earlier announced acquisition of the Canadian assets of Francana Oil and Gas Ltd., also based in Calgary, for about $160 million (Canadian).  Francana's non-Canadian assets, which consisted of a 28 percent interest in the Adobe Oil and Gas Corporation, based in Midland, Tex., and a 57 percent interest in Trend International Ltd. of Bermuda were acquired earlier by two subsidiaries of the Anglo-American Corporation of South Africa Ltd. for about $68 million in assumed debt. Francana Oil will henceforth cease to exist.

headline: FLAGSHIP BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Kenyan Parliament Approves Measure for One-Party State
abstract: Kenya officially became a oneparty state today under the ruling Kenya African National Union after Parliament unanimously approved a bill to amend the Constitution to this end.   The bill, stating that ''there shall be in Kenya only one political party, the Kenya African National Union,'' was rushed through three readings and committee stages unopposed by the 158 elected members, all of them representing the ruling party. Kenya has been a de facto one-party state since 1969, when a short-lived opposition party was dissolved.

headline: WOOLWORTH APPOINTS HEAD FOR BRITISH UNIT
abstract: The F.W. Woolworth Company said yesterday that it had sent one of its most senior executives to head its ailing British subsidiary, F.W. Woolworth P.L.C.   John L. Sullivan, Woolworth's senior executive vice president, was elected deputy chairman of the subsidiary, in which Woolworth holds a 52.6 percent interest. The company said he would likely succeed Geoffrey Rodgers, the subsidiary's chairman and chief executive, on his retirement at the end of the year.   At the same time, Woolworth said, Arnold S. Anderson, senior vice president and general counsel of the parent company, was named to the board of the subsidiary.

headline: IMPERIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ARCO Solar Plant
abstract: ARCO Solar Inc., a subsidiary of the Atlantic Richfield Company, said it plans to build a solar-powered electricity generating station capable of serving 300 to 400 residential customers of the Southern California Edison Company. The photovoltaic system will have a peak output of one megawatt, a tiny fraction of what a typical generating station produces, but it would be three times larger than any existing photovoltaic system. The plant, expected to be operational by year-end, will be built about 100 miles northeast of Los Angeles.

headline: POPE BACKS PALISTINIAN RIGHTS
abstract: Pope John Paul II, describing reports from Lebanon as ''terrifying,'' reiterated a call today for the recognition of Palestinian rights and said he would dedicate a mass to prayers for peace in ''tormented'' Lebanon.   ''Let us pray for the salvation of Lebanon and for all its communities that they might live in concord and collaboration,'' the Pope told 35,000 pilgrims in St. Peter's Square.

headline: Briton Wounded in Ulster
abstract: Irish nationalist guerrillas wounded a British soldier today by setting off a mine by remote control as his armored patrol vehicle passed over it near here, the police said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECHES BY POPE AND ARCHBISHOP
abstract: Following are excerpts from speeches by the Archbishop of Canterbury and Pope John Paul II at a service today at Canterbury Cathedral, and the text of their joint statement after the service, as provided by the Vatican Press Office: Archbishop of Canterbury   In the year 597, in the words of the English historian, the Venerable Bede, Your Holiness's great predecessor ''Gregory, prompted by divine inspiration, sent a servant of God named Augustine and several more God-fearing monks with him to preach the word of God to the English race.'' Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury and I rejoice that the successors of Gregory and Augustine stand here today in the church which is built on their partnership in the Gospel.   We shall trace and celebrate our beginnings in this service by reaffirming our baptismal vows made at the font at the beginning of Christian life and by saying together the creed, an expression of the heart of our common Christian faith, composed in the era before our unhappy division. The emphasis, then, will be on the riches of what we share and upon the existing unity of the Christian church, which transcends all the political divisions and frontiers imposed upon the human family. One of the gifts Christians have to make to the peace of the world is to live out the unity that has already been given them in their common love of Christ.

headline: REAGAN IN CARIBBEAN, LINKS GRENADA TO MOSCOW
abstract: President Reagan, opening a four-day stay in Barbados by conferring with five eastern Caribbean leaders, charged today that Grenada had joined with the Soviet Union, Nicaragua and Cuba in attempting to ''spread the virus'' of Marxism in the region.   For the second time since he began his visit to the Caribbean Wednesday, Mr. Reagan assailed Cuba for what he said was its support of terrorism in Central America. Nicaragua, Cuba and the Soviet Union, he said, were ''attempting to shut the door on democracy'' in El Salvador and elsewhere. Last night in Kingston, Jamaica, Mr.  Reagan said Cuba was trying to ''undermine democracy throughout the Americas financed by its master across the sea.''

headline: NEW RAIL GIANT SET TO ROLL
abstract: Robert B. Claytor, the recently elected chairman and chief executive of the newly merged Norfolk & Western Railway and the Southern Railway, emerged from a meeting with senior executives of both railroads the last week of May and said: ''The one thing we don't want to do is mess it up.''   Moving too fast on a merger had cost him business before, he recalled, leaning back in a chair in one of the downtown Washington offices that served as headquarters of what used to be the Southern Railway. This time around, ''We would rather go too slow than go in helter-skelter and have problems,'' he said.   There is wide agreement among analysts, competitors and company executives that the merger, which was consummated last week to form the Norfolk Southern Corporation, should be a success.

headline: Market Place; Chase Stock: Brokers' View
abstract: ON Monday, May 17, shares of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the holding company that owns the Chase Manhattan Bank, closed at 52, down 3/4, in routine trading. But the next day Chase tumbled 3 1/2 points in response to news that jarred not only its shares but also the stock market in general.   Yesterday Chase's stock touched a 52-week low at 39 5/8, before finishing the session at 39 3/4, down 1/4. That meant that, in a span of slightly more than three weeks, the market value of the holding company's 33.4 million shares fell by approximately $400 million.

headline: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Stock-Index Futures Suit
abstract: The Commodity Exchange in New York said yesterday that, despite a lawsuit by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, it would begin trading Comex 500 stock-index futures as soon as it receives approval from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

headline: U.N. COUNCIL DEFERS VOTE ON CEASE-FIRE RESOLUTION
abstract: The Security Council postponed a vote today on a compromise resolution on a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands.   With new amendments introduced at the last minute, Council members agreed they needed more time and set another meeting for Friday.  The compromise text calls directly for an immediate halt to the fighting and indirectly urges Argentina to withdraw its troops.  Delegates said Britain opposed the document because the demand for an immediate cease-fire could leave Argentine troops in Stanley. That was the reason that the resolution, drawn up by Panama, was acceptable to Argentina.

headline: Addendum
abstract: Shaw Elliott Inc. has changed its name to Hirsch Elliott Inc.  ADVERTISING

headline: Talks Seeking Alsands Deal
abstract: William Daniel, the president of Shell Canada Ltd., said today that he did not rule out the possibility of extending the April 30 deadline for an agreement on the Alsands project.   Speaking to reporters following the company's annual meeting, Mr.  Daniel said that although the consortium did not want Government discussions to go beyond the deadline, there was no way to know how long the talks would continue.   ''The history of Alsands is that we pass one deadline after another,'' Mr. Daniel said.

headline: SENATOR JACKSON SEES PRESSING NEED FOR EXPANDED U.S. SOVIET HOT LINE
abstract: Senator Henry M. Jackson urged the United States and the Soviet Union today to establish a jointly manned communications center to ease what he called a growing concern that a nuclear war might be touched off by accident.   ''It's the missing institution when we talk about nuclear arms control,'' said Mr. Jackson, Democrat of Washington. ''I think it goes to the heart of the nuclear fear in the world, the fear that a war might be started accidentally.''

headline: G. HEILEMAN OFFERS $24 A SHARE FOR ALL OF PABST
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company got a second suitor late yesterday when the G. Heileman Brewing Company announced a $24-a-share cash offer for all of Pabst's 8.2 million shares outstanding, a total of $196.8 million.   Pabst is also being sought by a smaller brewer, C. Schmidt & Sons, of Philadelphia. Earlier this month, Schmidt upgraded its offer to $25.50 a share, $5 of it in subordinated debentures. While indicating that the improved offer was not acceptable, Pabst said it would consider an all-cash bid of the same amount if made promptly.

headline: A FINE HARBOR WON STANLEY ITS PLACE AS ISLANDS' CAPITAL
abstract: Stanley, the remote South Atlantic settlement that has become the final prize in the battle for the Falkland Islands, seems an unlikely site for a colonial capital.   Little more than a village, the settlement, which has a peacetime population of just over 1,000 and is the only real town in the Falklands, is on a narrow strip of land on the east coast of East Falkland Island surrounded by some of the wettest and roughest terrain in the entire colony.   But it has one key feature that made it an ideal site for a colonial port - a deep, almost landlocked harbor connected by a narrows to an even deeper semiprotected outer harbor known as Port William.

headline: Talking Business with Reddy of Charles River Associates
abstract: SIgnificance Of Sea Treaty   At the beginning of May, the United Nations adopted a wide-ranging treaty governing use of the seas. Although the United States was one of four countries to vote against the treaty, most anlysts believe that America would have to abide by it once it is ratified and signed in December in Caracas, Venezuela.   Commercial ocean mining is one of the major areas covered by the accord. The Law of the Sea treats the nodules of copper, nickel, cobalt and magnesium on the floor of the Pacific Ocean as the ''common heritage of mankind.'' A global mining authority established by the treaty will issue licenses to mine the sea and will retain a mine site equal in size or value to the site mined by a private or government-controlled company.

headline: NARDA MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IN TOKYO, THE ADS ARE OCCIDENTAL
abstract: Tokyo - It qualifies as one of the minor ironies of business in Japan. The market here may still be off limits for any number of Western products. But for Westerners themselves, or to be more precise, their images, it is wide open. From subway posters to fashion magazine covers to television ads, the Western faces hawk Japanese products to Japanese consumers.   Many are famous faces. Woody Allen touts the Seibu department store. Kirk Douglas sips Maxim coffee. Scott Carpenter plugs JVC video equipment. The Bee Gees sing about TDK tape.   But equally evident are scores of nameless Western models, usually blue-eyed blondes, who pour whisky, puff cigarettes and parade about in designer jeans. Even department store mannequins modeling bathing suits and kimonos ape foreigners with Western faces and light-colored hair.

headline: CONIFER GROUP INC (WORCESTER, MASS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IMPORT TAX ON STEEL EXPECTED
abstract: The Commerce Department has decided to impose duties on a wide range of European steel imports because of a finding that they are being sold in this country at unfairly low prices, a Commerce Department official said late tonight.   The official, who asked not to be identified, said that the findings would be announced at noon Friday and published then in the Federal Register, unless last-minute efforts to negotiate an agreement on a quota for steel imports from Europe is concluded successfully. The chances of this happening in the few hours remaining were characterized as poor by American and European officials.   The department's action would result in the most severe and widest application ever of duties on steel imports.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The British ground, sea and air forces around Stanley, the last Argentine stronghold on East Falkland, have subjected the garrison to prolonged bombardment by field artillery, naval guns and bombers.   This kind of attack, military analysts said, is one of the most terrifying and the one most likely to sap the defenders' will to resist. Three factors worsen the Argentines' plight. The first is that the ground troops have meager means to respond. Fire against the destroyers and frigates of the British fleet is likely to be ineffective. These ships reach their positions after nightfall and move constantly. Without air observation, the Argentine gunners are at a serious disadvantage.

headline: ITT World Appoints Manager
abstract: The Western Union Telegraph Company held a monopoly position in domestic telex and data-communications systems for almost 40 years.  But that changed last year when the Federal Communications Commission decided to allow the major international carriers to offer similar services in the United States.   At this point in the message business, ITT World Communications Inc. is changing leaders. Richard W. Pryor, 49, has been named president and general manager of the company, which is a unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

headline: JOB DISABILITY: LAWSUITS RISE
abstract: Edward Blankenship had been working at the Cincinnati Milacron Chemicals plant, mixing dimethyl tin-dichloride, for about six months when he and his wife began to notice that his personality was changing.   ''It took a while to realize what was happening,'' he said. ''My wife and I didn't know what the problem was, but I found myself arguing a lot, getting depressed and not being able to remember things. The doctors ran some tests on me and sent me to the hospital.''

headline: ARGENTINA TELLS OF RAID ON SHIPS
abstract: Argentina said today that it had sent waves of warplanes against British ships and repulsed an air attack by British Harriers on Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands. The military command said the planes seriously damaged one British warship.   Two other ships, both frigates, were less seriously damaged and a medium-sized transport ship was probably damaged in the raids, a military communique said. It said that one Argentine plane was shot down.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: SOCIAL ACTIVISM SPROUTS AS INDIA'S POLITICS DECAY
abstract: In all but a handful of the 350 administrative districts of India, there are groups of volunteers administering social programs and rural development plans intended to better the lives and raise the hopes of the downtrodden.   Some of the activists are Marxists and some are religiously inspired, but many are apolitical young people who have left middleclass comforts to go to the countryside, much like some of the civil rights volunteers in the United States who went to the South in the 1960's.   The efforts of these groups range in scale and effectiveness from a huge dairy cooperative with 400,000 prospering members to a rural medical clinic run by a husband and wife and young doctors who have spurned private practice.   There are at least several thousand such groups, though attempts to count them have been incomplete. It is a decentralized movement in a basically decentralized society, but according to some of India's most respected political scientists and commentators, the aggregate effect of their work is becoming a significant factor. The social activism, the commentators say, is moving into the vacuum left by the decay of older political institutions.

headline: MUBARAK URGES NURTURING OF DEMOCRACY
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak called on Egyptians today to safeguard the country's nascent democracy ''against those who exploit it,'' an allusion to Moslem fundamentalists who advocate the abolition of Egypt's present Government.   Mr. Mubarak, in a speech to Parliament marking the 11th anniversary of the thwarting of a Soviet-oriented political faction that tried to oust President Anwar el-Sadat, also reaffirmed his commitment to economic changes.   Diplomats, officials and others here felt that the speech was more significant for its omissions than its inclusions. These officials and reports in the non-Egyptian Arab press, such as Jordan's, have been saying for several days that Mr. Mubarak would use the anniversary of what is called the corrective revolution to announce major changes in his Cabinet.

headline: Eddie Albert And Ecotrin
abstract: As an actor, Eddie Albert has played a bad guy as often as he has a good guy. So you'll have to decide for yourself which role he's playing in the new 30-second commercial for Ecotrin, a safety-coated aspirin that is being advertised to arthritis suffers on television for the first time starting today.

headline: ARGENTINE PLANE IS REPORTED TO CIRCLE BRITISH FLEET
abstract: An Argentine Air Force reconnaissance plane circled Britain's powerful naval task force in the South Atlantic today, apparently pinpointing the size, speed and position of the flotilla, according to reports received from the fleet.   In Buenos Aires, an Argentine military spokesman denied tonight that any Argentine plane, civilian or air force, had flown over the fleet.   British correspondents aboard the British flagship, H.M.S. Hermes, said tonight that the plane was a Boeing 707, seemingly unarmed, marked with the light-blue-and-white roundels of Argentine military aircraft. The correspondents reported that it had flown directly toward the task force and speculated that Soviet spy ships had provided the coordinates of the fleet.

headline: BOEING DOWN 57.6% AS BUYERS CUT BACK
abstract: The Boeing Company reported yesterday that a sharp cutback in commercial airline deliveries, among other factors, caused net income in the first quarter of 1982 to plunge 57.6 percent on a 13.7 percent decline in sales.   Boeing, the country's largest builder of commercial jets and also a major producer of military aircraft and missiles, said that net income in the latest three months dropped to $61 million, or 63 cents a share, from $144 million, or $1.49 a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Sales fell to $2.09 billion from $2.42 billion.

headline: SINGAPORE PLANS TO REVIVE STUDY OF CONFUCIANISM
abstract: The Government of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, disturbed by what it sees as a falling away from certain ancient moral values that are thought to be capable of protecting this modern city-state, has decided to revive the study of Confucianism.   Mr. Lee himself is believed to have inspired the plan. Once started in the schools, about two years from now, it would reassert values of filial piety, scholarly discipline, fraternity, decorum, integrity, a proper sense of shame and, perhaps, a moral obligation to enter government service so long as Confucianism prevailed in the state.   Confucianism was the official and mostly very conservative state philosophy of China for nearly 2,000 years. Its influence on ethics and social behavior has survived to the present in some sectors of ethnic Chinese society, and some scholars believe that even in China the reaction over the last few years against the Cultural Revolution may be viewed as a reassertion of Confucian values.

headline: A MAN OF MANY WORLDS
abstract: George Pratt Shultz, President Reagan's choice to succeed Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State, is a labor economist whose service in government during the Nixon Administration led him into the international business world, including significant involvement in the Middle East.   While there are some questions about how this experience will help shape policies on the Middle East, East-West relations and other matters, there seems no doubt that Mr. Shultz will operate well in the Administration. And there is also no doubt about his experience in government.   ''I am very high on George Shultz,'' said Walter Heller, a liberal economist who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.

headline: Around the World; Mexican Volcano Erupts Again
abstract: El Chinchonal Volcano hurled rocks, lava and debris for miles tonight in the biggest eruption since the peak in southeastern Mexico turned active in the last week.

headline: AM's BRIGHTEST YEARS NOW DIM MEMORIES
abstract: In 1893, an inventor named Joseph Duncan breezed into Chicago to find his fortune with an automatic addressing machine. He sold a dozen of them in a year's time and was heartened enough to form the Addressograph Company in 1896. Meanwhile, Henry Gammeter had concocted a machine that could duplicate a complete line or a complete page of characters at a single stroke. In December 1902, he formed the American Multigraph Company in Chicago.   For several decades, the two companies went their separate ways, though their products often churned away side by side in many American offices. It was a logical marriage, then, when the two joined forces as the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation in 1930.

headline: Amoco in Indonesia
abstract: The Amoco (Indonesia) Lombok Petroleum Company said today that it had signed a production-sharing contract with Pertamina, Indonesia's state oil company, for a 25,500-squarekilometer block off Lombok Island. Amoco paid a signature bonus of $1.2 million and committed itself to a $68.8 million work program over six years.

headline: Ad Club Reschedules Annual Awards Dinner
abstract: Because of a conflicting advertising industry event, the Advertising Club of New York has rescheduled its annual Andy Awards dinner to June 21 from June 3.   The location remains the same, the Imperial Room of the Sheraton Centre Hotel.  Awards will be bestowed in 32 print, 25 television and five radio categories.

headline: Hotel Companies' Net
abstract: The Hilton Hotels Corporation, citing severe winter weather and the recession, reported yesterday that its first-quarter profit tumbled 18.5 percent, to $21.9 million, or 82 cents a share, from $27 million, or $1.02 a share, in the same 1981 period.

headline: Reliance Unit Lifts Holdings in Tiger
abstract: The Reliance Financial Services Corporation, a unit of Reliance Group Inc., announced that it had increased its holdings in Tiger International Inc., the air cargo concern, to 22.51 percent, and planned to increase that stake further to more than 25 percent.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Reliance Financial Services said that it holds 3,826,400 of Tiger International's common shares - including 100,000 shares purchased between Feb.10 and March 3 - or a total investment of $76.8 million.

headline: MARKET COUNTRIES POSTPONE A STAND
abstract: Members of the Common Market refrained tonight from any definitive comment on the landing of British troops in the Falkland Islands pending a meeting in Brussels Monday to decide on whether to continue economic sanctions against Argentina.   A West German Government source said it appeared to be an open question what action Britain's Common Market partners might take when the foreign ministers meet. With the exception of Ireland and Italy, the group decided on Monday to extend its economic sanctions, announced last month, for seven more days. Italy is continuing its embargo on delivery of military supplies to Argentina.

headline: THE ISLANDERS TAKE LANDING WITH SERENITY
abstract: It was a few minutes after four o'clock on Friday morning at the sheep station of Port San Carlos in the Falkland Islands. Dawn was still an hour away, but Isabel Shore and her husband had been awakened by their 12-year-old son, who said he had heard noises on the beach at the far end of the family garden.   Suddenly, there was a knock at the door of the two-story wooden farmhouse. Mr. Shore answered it, and saw a Royal Marine officer standing there, face blackened, armed, in full battle dress.

headline: Auto Output Is Seen Falling
abstract: Production of cars in the United States in the 1982 model year will be the lowest in almost 25 years, Ward's Automotive Reports, an auto industry trade journal, said today.   Industry projections indicate that only 5.15 million 1982 cars will be built, the lowest total since 4.3 million were produced in 1958, Ward's said.

headline: U.S. FLEET REACHES EAST MEDITERRANEAN FOR NAVAL EXERCISES
abstract: The United States Navy has assembled a task force of 50 warships led by four aircraft carriers in the eastern Mediterranean for NATO maneuvers, but has ordered them to be ready for possible rescue operations in Lebanon, Pentagon officials said today.   At the same time, the State Department said a Navy transport would arrive in Junieh, Lebanon, on Thursday to pick up 700 Americans who have said they want to be evacuated.

headline: HERE COMES LOW-POWER TV
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Federal Communications Commission, when it approved final rules last month to initiate low-power television stations, created what many experts feel may become a gold rush. For the first time in 20 years, a significant increase in television outlets is possible.   The commission is even now burrowing its way from under 6,500 applications, and thousands more are expected to be filed before the process is completed, according to F.C.C. officials. When the dust settles, it is expected that some 4,000 stations will have been created by the new policy. One major question is whether they will be, as originally planned, stations to serve neighborhoods and ethnic groups - or whether the profit potential will turn them into big business run by big business.   Low-power stations will differ from conventional television in several significant ways. Their power output will be limited to 10 watts for VHF stations and 1,000 watts for UHF stations, which means that under most circumstances their reach will be limited to a radius of 10 to 20 miles. They will be subject to fewer regulations than conventional stations, but where their signals interfere with existing ''full-service'' stations, the low-power station must give way.

headline: PATENTS; Bacteria Transformed To Produce Proteins
abstract: Methods of inserting genes into bacteria so they will produce desired proteins or other materials were patented this week for Harvard University. Richard N. Goldstein obtained patent 4,332,901 for a cloning vector, which is explained as a plasmid used in biological research and engineering to insert a selected fraction of a gene.

headline: WACKENHUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dow Gains 4.95; Oils Strong
abstract: Energy-related issues led the stock market to a modest advance yesterday in accelerated trading. Analysts attributed the new strength in the oil group, which has been depressed, to the growing belief that oil prices have reached bottom and may be heading higher.    Reflecting the market's stronger trend, the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 4.95 points, to 865.87. On Monday the Dow tumbled 8.28 points as a result of profit taking and investors' fears that interest rates would rise. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange expanded to 54.7 million shares from 46.3 million the day before.

headline: MOST INHABITANTS OF STANLEY HAVE FLED TO THE COUNTRYSIDE
abstract: Most of the 1,000 civilian residents of Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, have fled to remote parts of the countryside, according to people here who have knowledge of the islands.   ''Our information is that there are no more than 100 or 200 people left in Stanley,'' said Alastair Cameron, a native of the Falklands who is helping to staff an information office here for friends and relatives of the islanders.   British Government sources, although unable to offer solid confirmation, shared the general impression that most of the islanders had scattered widely in the four weeks since the Argentines invaded. Their dispersal, across a land the size of Connecticut, is one reason that there seem to be no firm plans for Britain to try to evacuate civilians.

headline: RCA SOURCE CONFIRMS FIRESTONE TALKS ON HERTZ
abstract: A Wall Street source close to the RCA Corporation confirmed yesterday that the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company was a leading candidate to buy the Hertz Corporation from RCA.   The source, who insisted on anonymity, said that while RCA was still ''open to better offers,'' it appeared that the nation's No.1 auto rental company would be purchased by Firestone for between $700 million and $900 million in cash.   Richard W. Miller, executive vice president and chief financial officer of RCA, declined to either confirm or deny reports that Firestone was the leading contender, nor would he discuss how much his company would demand for Hertz. Firestone confirmed on Friday that it was discussing the possibility of acquiring Hertz.

headline: Faberge Talks Off
abstract: Faberge Inc. said it had broken off talks with an undisclosed suitor after Faberge's board had ''unanimously decided'' to end acquisition discussions that began last week.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Cities Service Co. said that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to issue up to 2,750,000 shares of its common stock to the First Boston Corp. in exchange for its 6 1/8 percent debentures due 1997, 6 5/8 percent debentures due 1999 and 7.65 percent debentures due 2001.   * Fleet Financial Group said that it had filed a ''shelf'' registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the proposed offering of up to $100 million of notes from time to time on terms to be determined at the time of the offerings.

type: Financial Desk Marks reported pretax profit
headline: SALES OF NEW HOMES FELL TO RECORD LOW IN MARCH
abstract: The rate of sales for new homes dropped by 9.5 percent in March from February's level, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 335,000, the Commerce Department said today.  It was the lowest level since the Government began keeping records in 1963.

headline: Business and the Law; Photocopying Vs. Copyrights
abstract: THE Sony Betamax case awaiting Supreme Court action may be getting a lot of attention, but an obscure case in a Manhattan Federal court is likely to decide another copyright question that could be just as important.   Unlike the Betamax case, which deals with home video cassette recording of television programs, the case pending before Federal District Judge Lee P. Gagliardi involves the more prosaic issue of photocopying.   The Association of American Publishers is suing the Squibb Corporation for failure to pay copyright fees on the articles in scientific and technical journals that its employees photocopy in the corporate reference library.   The Squibb case is the second of its kind. Last December the publishers' group filed a similar suit against the American Cyanamid Company for copyright infringement. That case was settled in April, with American Cyanamid agreeing to report all copying to the Copyright Clearance Center, a nonprofit organization established in 1978 to collect royalties for publishers whose material is photocopied.

headline: INDUSTRY COOL TO CANADA ENERGY PLAN
abstract: Canada's oil and gas industry reacted with skepticism today to a $2 billion federal tax relief package designed to revive lagging investment and exploration activity.   Energy Minister Marc Lalonde, who announced the tax concessions on Monday, told a news conference today that the package represented ''a significant push for industry'' when combined with $5.4 billion in royalty cuts announced by Alberta last month.   Mr. Lalonde, who was forced to defend his national energy program in the House of Commons Monday amid calls from opposition Members that it was a ''disaster,'' said the new measures were designed to help smaller companies that needed it most.

headline: Canadian Sales
abstract: Sales by wholesale merchants declined 2.5 percent in January from a year earlier, Statistics Canada said Friday. The agency said wholesale inventories rose 11.5 percent in January from 1981.

headline: 8 MARKET NATIONS AGAIN EXTEND BAN AGAINST ARGENTINA
abstract: In a new sign of support for Britain, a majority of the Common Market countries agreed Monday to extend indefinitely the economic sanctions imposed against Argentina in retaliation for its invasion of the Falkland Islands.   Italy and Ireland, which dissociated themselves from the ban on Argentine imports that was voted a week ago in Luxembourg, again refused to go along with the eight other countries in continuing the trade measures, which would have expired at midnight.   At the same time, Britain, which had vigorously sought further support from the European Economic Community in the Falkland dispute, retreated a considerable distance on two demands in the internal affairs of the community: for a smaller budget contribution from the British and for a commitment that the veto prerogative of members would be respected in the future. Accord on Budget Rebate   The British retreat allowed the group to achieve an accord just before 3 A.M. today on a problem that had nearly paralyzed it for weeks: how much of a budget rebate Britain should be given this year.

headline: SOUTH AMERICANS INTENSIFY CALLS FOR MEDIATION BY U.N.
abstract: The British landing in the Falkland Islands intensified calls throughout South America today for reviving the lapsed United Nations mediation and, in several cases, for increasing Latin solidarity moves in support of Argentina.   None of the countries of the continent altered their previous positions in the dispute. The assault had been forecast for some time in all Latin capitals and consequently did not provoke the vigorous notes of official protest or spontaneous street demonstrations that an unexpected escalation of the conflict might have.   The most dramatic reactions came from Venezuela and Peru, the two countries that have been most vocally behind Argentina since the conflict arose more than seven weeks ago. Colombia and Brazil continued to be the most reserved in their comments.

headline: STAUFFER CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Boston Bank Sets 16% Prime
abstract: The First National Bank of Boston lowered its prime interest rate yesterday to 16 percent from 16 1/2 percent, the second major bank to do so in the last 10 days.   Officers of First National, the country's 17th-largest bank, said they hoped the move would encourage other banks to drop their prime from the 16 1/2 percent level, which has prevailed at most major banks since Feb. 23.

headline: Suit Settled At Firestone
abstract: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that it had reached a tentative agreement of more than $2.2 million in a shareholder suit filed against the company, several former officers, members of the Firestone family and Coopers & Lybrand, the company's independent auditors.   Terms of the settlement call for Firestone to receive $1.3 million from the company that insures officers and directors of Firestone against wrongdoing and $125,000 from Coopers & Lybrand, Firestone said in material mailed to shareholders last week.

headline: PIPELINE SANCTIONS UPSET BONN
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt expressed concern today about the repercussions of the Reagan Administration's attempts to hinder development of the Soviet-West European pipeline deal in a speech before Parliament.   The speech contained no direct attacks on the Reagan Administration and was generally cautious in tone. But it conveyed a sense of concern about the impact on East-West relations of Washington's attempts to slow construction of the pipeline, which would bring Siberian gas to Western Europe by the end of 1984.

headline: DEMOGRAPHICS; THE BOOM NEXT TIME
abstract: THESE are hardly times that encourage optimistic economic e xpectations. But as we look beyond our immediate troubles, the f uture does seem promising, for we are experiencing major structural c hanges in the age composition of the population which could make fore xtraordinary differences in our economic affairs.  The demographic timetable that accounted at least in part for our malaise in the past decade or so will be working in our favor in the coming years. A review of our recent past gives some insights into the potential of our future.

headline: Bloc to Meet in Budapest
abstract: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov of the Soviet Union flew to Budapest today for a meeting of the Soviet-led Council for Mutual Economic Cooperation, the press agency Tass said.

headline: Around the World; Americans in Hanoi Urge Defoliant Study
abstract: A group of American veterans proposed today that United States scientists come to Vietnam to investigate the effects of Agent Orange, a highly toxic defoliant used by American forces during the war.   Vietnamese officials said they would have to discuss the detailed, seven-page proposal from the Vietnam Veterans of America before agreeing to the study. Dr. Ton Buc Lang, a Vietnamese researcher, acknowledged that there was still lack of scientific proof of the agent's harmful effects.

headline: OUTCAST VIETNAM CHILDREN STILL HOPE
abstract: Scores of children and adolescents of mixed American and Vietnamese parentage were camped outside the Cuu Long Hotel today to sell peanuts to a party of visiting Vietnam War veterans from the United States and some American reporters.   They also begged, posed for photographs, laughed if the visitors smiled, stared somberly, and occasionally scattered when a khaki-clad policeman or some other government agent stabbed his finger down the boulevard and told them to go away.   There are uncounted thousands of the offspring of American fathers and Vietnamese mothers in Vietnam. Most live in Ho Chi Minh City.  About 70 such children have been declared by the State Department to be United States citizens, able to pick up their passports at any consulate. Yet none of the 70, none of about 500 others whose American paternity has been established, and none who have appealed over the past two years to Vietnamese and American authorities, have actually left Vietnam.

headline: HARVESTER CLEARED FOR PHONE SERVICE
abstract: The International Harvester Company, the financially beleaguered producer of farm equipment and other heavy machinery, received Federal authorization today to enter the interstate long-distance telephone business.   The Federal Communications Commission, in a two-page order issued by its telecommunications committee, authorized the Chicago-based company to operate as a so-called resale common carrier throughout the continental United States.   The designation gives the giant manufacturing concern clearance to lease facilities from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and A.T.& T. competitors and then resell the interstate communications services to its own customers at a discount.

headline: Around the World; Biafran Secessionist Returns to Nigeria
abstract: Odumegwu Ojukwu, the former Biafran secessionist leader, returned to Nigeria today, ending more than 12 years in exile after his defeat in the 1967-70 civil war.   More than 5,000 people, most of them from Mr. Ojukwu's Ibo ethnic group, braved torrential rain and half-flooded roads to reach the airport, and hundreds of them stormed through customs barriers to welcome him.
